reviews.review: worth the visit. The Mosteiro dos Jerónimos is absolutely worth the visit. But be aware of the massive tourist crowds.

Magnificent Monument. If you are a lover of heritage monuments and ancient architecture, you will totally love this place. This place has this vibes of purity and divinity. You feel this beautiful feeling of calmness and serenity that will stay with you forever

Worth to visit. If you like to visit Monasteries and Churches, you came to the right spot. Historic building related with the trades made with Asia back to XVI century . Beautiful church (free) and you can also visit the clausters ( paid ) .
Patricia Keenan. This monastery was absolutely breathtaking. We expected it to be lovely but not to this extent.Well worth the visit it was amazing.
Very informative. Get there early from 09:30 - 10:00 the queues build up quite quickly, the square is very peaceful and almost serene like you are in a painting setting
Amasing Monument. One of our best simbols of the XVI century portuguese discoveries. The sea way to India. Then, totaly anknown

Worth exploring inside and out. Tip: do get a combo ticket if you plan, like we did, to tour the Tower of Belem (or any related, nearby museum).  Monastery was beautiful and contains a full history exhibit. Wasn't too expensive - but if you're on the cheap, the chapel portion was free (as are most, of not all churches) and contains the tomb of Vasco da Gama

Outstanding architecture. The ones who love admiring the architecture of old buildings will surely love this place. I was speechless when walking inside it. There is also a historical timeline available to help you understand where in history it is situated.

An unforgettable sight. This Monastery is absolutely marvelous and unforgettable! It is located in a calmer district of Lisbon. As soon as you arrive there you get fascinated by it! It is so beautiful and outstanding, you can spend quite a while walking in and around it! If you visit it at night its illumination will catch your eye for its beauty!
Beautiful and breathtaking. I visited the monastery last time I was in Lisbon 13 years ago, and it was on my shortlist of things to see again. I am still amazed by this extraordinary masterpiece.
Very interesting. This was one of many historical places we visited. It was easy to get around, reasonably priced and very interesting with many descriptions in English.

Beautiful cloisters and church. Actually went here twice during our stay in Lisbon. First time visited the church (line on the right--no charge). Vasco de Gama is buried here. Went back to visit the cloisters on the first Sunday when the admission is free. There was a HUGE line but it moved very quickly. Also visited the Maritime Museum at the far end of the building--separate admission but free the first Sunday of the month. Wonderful ship models. Combined the visit with the Coach Museum and Belem Tour. All within walking distance.

Visit and reflect. The monastery is perhaps the second most significant portugueses monument, all made of limestone and decorated with motives linked to the maritime discoveries of the portuguese. As usual in monasteries a church and a cloister attract the most attention and display delicate stone work dating from the 16th century. Not longer with its steps on the river Tejo due to landfill, it is connected to a construction dated of much later (XIX century) where the Etnographic and the Navy Museums are installed and has the Tower of Belem and other monumnents as its neighbors (see photo). In the church of Jeronimos two tombs can be seen that epitomize the splendor of times past : 1)that of the epic poet Luís de Camões, deceased at the verge of the loss of the indepence of Portugal, at the end of the 16th century, and 2) that of Vasco da Gama who led the navigators around the Good Hope Cape into India for the first time in 1492. A visit that leads to a double reflection: A) How could such a small kingdom assert itself in various domains across the globe, for so long?, and B)Why did Portugal lose so fast not only its geopolitical power, as dive into poverty and illiteracy of all types that led it to some of the worst indicators in the western world? Thoughts for a nice touristic and cultural visit.

A must visit landmark in Lisbon. The Jeronimos Monastery, along with the Tower of Belém, is one of the well known landmarks of Lisbon. We can appreciate the architectural style named Manuelino, which was developed to comemorate the discoveries of the New World. The stonemasons sculped the stone in a way to reveal the ropes and the sails of the ships used in those discoveries, along with representations of the "new" animals never seen before in medieval Europe. It is a part of the history of Portugal and Europe, represented in stone. For those that love to read Dan Brown, they can indulge to try to find out in those stones, plenty of "secrets" waiting to be decifred...

history. Portugal History. Great unique monument. Unique architecture. Surrounded by beautiful gardens and other museums.Great location to spend half a day visiting Jeronimos and all the surrounding area

An impressive piece of history!. The Jeronimos monestary is one of the most outstanding buildings of its type in Portugal. Be aware that if you plan on going on Sunday when it is free admittance to expect very long lines.
Great site in Belem!. Outstanding historic building full of history and intrigue. Quick to get into the monastery [no queue] and works with the Lisboa card.
Beautiful and well preserved . The monastery and church (don't miss the church!!!) make you think of what the life and work of these monks was like.A really stunning site and a must see in Lisbon!
Worth the Trip. Worth the trip down, take the trolley down #15 and then a Tuk Tuk back....we also went to the maritime museum. Go to the art of the line to assure your place to sit

Uniquely Portuguese (w/ tips!). The Gothic Manueline architecture and decor is a must see in this unique Monastery. Tip #1 - I had first gone to the side of the building where there is an entrance for the Cathedral. Just inside the entrance a person is there to collect a small fee to enter the church. Luckily I decided not to enter at that time, walked around to the main entrance where there was another door to the Cathedral with a sign "Free Entrance". Tip #2 - If you have the Lisboa Card you can skip the long line. If you don't have the Lisboa card, you can head next door to the Museu Nacional de Arqueologia and buy your ticket for the Monestary as well. Funnily enough, there are signs telling visitors this, but everyone insists on standing in the one line for upwards of 30+ minutes to enter even though the line next door is considerably shorter. Once you enter, you're immediately brought out to the cloisters, which is the centerpiece of this building. The warm color of the limestone that has been carved into gorgeously ornate shapes is a sight to behold. It's truly lovely and unique. The easy layout allows for random wandering through the cloisters and yet also guides you easily through several rooms with insights on the day-to-day of the monks who once lived there. There is gorgeous tile work in a few of the rooms, as well. As I mentioned above, there is a lovely gothic cathedral to tour either before or after your visit to the Monastery. If you enter the Monestary, there's the opportunity to go onto the balcony that has an amazing overlook view of the Cathedral.
Worth the trip. Try to visit early in the morning to beat the crowds. . . This building is very cool and worth the trip to Belem to see it.

Breathtaking. Belem in the sunshine ...what a joy and walking towards the monastery was sheer bliss. We were lucky to get in just before a wave of tourists arrived and were able to walk around this magnificent building and savor its beauty. An absolute must visit.

A giant monastery with impressive ornaments. The definition of beauty. An important place for history of Europe. I visited it in July 2015. It is more than enough to visit the church part of it, because there is just an abundance of ornaments. This should be considered a wonder of the World.
Top experience . Definitely one of our favorite sites in Lisbon, beautiful architecture, very peaceful. If we had more time I would go back with a book and coffee

Way too busy,. We visited on a day when there were so many tour groups the crowd had to be marshalled. Once inside there were so many people that one was retuned to a series of shuffled manoeuvres through the throng! But the building was magnificent and worth the time. Just be sure to get there early and before the tour busses!
great place to see. Great place you must to see. Beautiful building, not too big . Takes about an hour to see everything . Every first Sunday of the month admission is free

Great combination of Beauty/History/Architecture. Don't miss!. This is a beautiful old monastery, very large. It is located in Belem parish across from the Tagus River. It was absolutely jam packed with people, but i suspect this is always the case.It is in the unique MANUELINE gothic style so interesting architecture to see.also known as Heironymite's monastery, as those monks lived there on order of Manuel I to provide spiritual assistance to the mariners. Vasco De Gama stayed there in 1497. Lots of history and beauty. Inspired the famous Pastel de Belem tarts ( sold nearby if you can handle the line.)

So Historical and a must see. This was so easy to be overwhelmed by the size of this structure built so long ago. The history and beauty of this building is amazing. You must stop here and see this building, so beautiful.

Beautiful. Very beautiful attraction; impressive architecture, although other sections of the monastery are used for two other museums; would suggest combining ticket with that for the Belem Tower which is a short walk away.

A Highlight of Our Tour. This Monastery includes the tomb of Vasco da Gama and many other historical figures such as poet Luis de Camões, author of the epic The Lusiads in which he glorifies the triumphs of Da Gama and his compatriots. Other great figures in Portuguese history are also entombed here, like King Manuel and King Sebastião, and poets Fernando Pessoa and Alexandre Herculano.

Phenomenal and simply stunning interior architecture!. A very busy and crowded tourist site. Houses the tomb of Vasco Da Gama besides other monarchs who ruled and were responsible for the many discoveries of lands around the world. The interior architecture is superb, the gold laden room is stunning. Just to be in a church that withstood the 1755 earthquake that destroyed most of Lisbon is something special. A simply fantastical historic site to visit in Lisbon.
Worth a visit. Get the 15 tram from the city centre it takes you right there. You can buy ticket for the monastery Belem tower and archaeology too.

Massive Tribute to the King and Church. My wife and I visited in October. It is a short train ride from Lisbon's Cais do Sodre train station, then a 4-5 block walk.The church and monastery are very impressive due to the size and the amount of carved stone. It continues to amaze me that the architects and builders were able to build these substantial structures and have them survive so well. We visited on a Saturday afternoon and were treated to see a wedding take place in the cathedral. Using our Lisboa cards and we were granted free admission. Further, the train ride's cost was covered by Lisboa card. My only caution to visiting here is that the lines for admission get quite, quite long. Visit here early if you can. Otherwise, great attraction.

Gorgeous architecture!. The church & monastery are absolutely beautiful! You walk into the church first (it's free) and pictures do not do it justice. You must see it in person! You have to pay to visit the monastery, but it's not much & I don't mind giving my money to preserve such beautiful places! We didn't have time to visit the archeological museum.
Wonderful architecture!. Apart from the amazing architecture, the Jeronimos monastery houses the tomb of Vasco Da Gama. It's right next to the maritime museum. Worth visiting.
Beautiful. Wonderful and majestic and so worth it! Take the bus to get there and then get paseis de nata beforehand...worth waiting in line for.

stained glass windows to die for. try not to be there when a cruise ship is in port as you may need to queue - but it is free to get in and its HUGE inside and so very ornate. Vasco de Gama's tomb is in here which is a good reason to visit.

Gorgeous. The exterior and facade are pretty impressive. The intricate details on the church doorways and the sides are perfection!Tourists come by the bus loads (unfortunately!) Theres a line for entry into the church and this is free. Theres a shorter line for entry into the monastery and this you have to pay for. Unless you are really watching what you spend, do go in and see the cloister. Its really impressive. The details on the pillars and the walls are amazing.

Grand Former Historical Monastery. The initial view of this imposing structure will stop you in your tracks. Could be very crowded. Once inside, the architecture is amazing. This structure withstood the 1755 earthquake, fire, and tsunami which killed more than a third of the population and destroyed the town. The church houses royal tombs and the tomb of Vasco da Gama. A portion of the structure now houses the maritime museum. The church is worth a visit.
nothing inside.. the entrance ticket is costly. there is nothing much to see inside. Just take a picture from outside and save time and money.
Gorgeous Architecture. This incredible monastery and church, really more like a cathedral is monumental. Felt humbled being inside but didn't have time to visit museum which friends raved about.
Monastery. Beautiful place full of history. I paid 12 euros to see the monastery and the torre de Belem . There is a nice garden inside.
beautiful with history to match. Very large and beautiful Monastery in the Belem District of Lisbon. Line to get in was not long. Cloisters were remarkable.Site of Tomb of Vasco De Gama

Beautiful cloisters were my highlight. Try to go early or late to avoid the crowds! There is a bargain ticket available after mid-afternoon which includes the Belem tower. If you're not planning to scrutinise every frieze and moulding, it's a good buy.
A must to see. A must to see in Lisbon. most interesting visit in Lisbon for us. learnt so much about the history of Portugal from this.

a place really to find out even if you're in line, it goes fast for what awaits you. a place of beauty in the image of the monasteries.
everything is beauty in architecture and invites to reflection on what has been this place

Stunning Monastery and Church. A trip to Lisbon is not complete without a visit to Belem, with the Jeronimos Monastery being the main drawcard. Apparently this monastery is the most visited place in Lisbon.I caught the tram 15 from outside the Cais do Sodre station at what appeared to be rush hour in the morning and it was absolutely packed. You can catch any of the trams 15 that state Alges as the final destination as they stop right at the Monastery. The queue for tickets was very long and bus loads of people arrive so it is a busy place. We were told to go to the Museum entrance to get tickets as the queue wasn't as long, but it still seemed rather slow. It is definitely worth getting a ticket that combines the Monastery and the Belem Tower otherwise you will stand in a long queue again at the tower. The price for the museum, tower and monastery for an adult was 16 Euros which seemed very reasonable. However, if you only want to visit the church at the Monastery then it is free entrance, you just have to make sure you are in the correct queue.Although it was very busy, once inside the cloisters it actually seemed very peaceful and not crowded at all. The carving on the stonework is truly spectacular, the columns and arches look as if they are made of lace, so beautiful and individual. You can go upstairs to the upper level for a better view and an opportunity to go into the church and see it from the gallery. This church is truly wonderful, the pillars seem to grow from the floor and branch out across the vaulted ceiling, I have seem many beautiful cathedrals but I was blown away by this one.You can access the church again when leaving the monastery.The museum at the monastery is small and I couldn't really see its relevance to the rest of the site. I would recommend a trip to the monastery and church. For a good view of the site climb to the top of the Discoveries Monument across the park.
Excellent example of unique architecure. It ´s an excellent place to study architecture but it´s a pity the behaviour of most of the people who don´t respect the silence of the church.
Fantastic vaulted ceiling. Well worth a visit. If you go at lunch time, when the bus tours are eating, there isn't as much of a queue.
Incredibly detail. The temple is nice, but when you go to the monastery you are awed by the impressive detailed work this is a must see in Lisbon

Eat custard tart, visit monastery and then eat custard tart again.. This monastery is only a stone's throw away from the famous Pasteis de Belem. The monastery is definitely worth a visit. Impressive architecture and rich with history. The queue gets really long though, and the chapel gets pretty warm during the warmer months. But if you are visiting the Pasteis de Belem for custard tart - you shouldn't miss this site.
Don't miss it. This is a must see attraction in Lisbon. Go there early before the bus tours and avoid long lines. You can walk to Belem Tower from here so set aside at least half a day in this area.
Is that all? . For €10 you get to see a court and some rooms around it. I have no idea why it's rated so highly on tripadvisor.
Spectactular attraction. This monastery is stunning. Every aspect is beautiful. One of the highlights of our holiday. It is very popular, but spacious so well worth a visit even at popular times.
beautiful. lovely monastery with some great history and some lovely art and architecture. Pretty crowded to get in but nice inside.

A must see attraction. Beautiful, the line was okay, and there was okay amount off text on the walls so you know what you are looking at. But remember a bottle off water to the line, there are no shadows to stand in.

One of the best attractions. Took about 20 mins by tram which can be very crowded, but well worth the trouble, the church was free but get a ticket to visit the cloisters and refectory are very beautiful, you also get a view from the gallery into the church.
Outstanding architecture. Impressive architecture and surroundings. Grandeur and depth. Part of a complex of museums, all worth seeing.

This is the number 2 attraction...?!. I really don't know what the fuss is about. The architecture is quite pretty, but that's it. It's not worth €10 just to get into the monastery, or the combined ticket to the Belem Tower for €12. The queues are monumental and the information is absolutely mad - had to work out where to go etc. all on our own. Save your money and go to the tile museum (only €5 and as pretty, if not prettier) or take a day trip to Sintra and go to Pena Palace. If you MUST go here, just go to the church (free entry) to the right of the monastery as it's really pretty, and free.
Must see in Belem!. Located in Belem, this is an amazing monastery and church. Would highly recommend that any visitor to Lisbon see these places! Easy to reach via Tram 15E.

Nice place. It was very crowded and we had to wait in line even though we had Lisbon Card, where it is clearly stated that you avoid queues but it is ok. When you enter inside you forget that. The monastery is huge and really beautiful.

Packed. Good experience, such a busy place when we were there though. Amazing the work they were able to do back then, craftsmanship was amazing. Gardens outside looked very nice but didn't get a chance to stroll through at all. If you need a selfie stick, scarf or cheap sunglasses, plenty of people to help you with that!

Insider tip . It took us about 1/2 hour in line for tickets and then we noticed that we could also buy our ticket to enter the Tower of Belem at the same time and for a savings of 4 Euro. This easily saved us over 1/2 hour in another line up later that day. The monastery itself was incredible to view. We spent about 45 minutes inside. The church is free to enter but access is limited and the lineup was long while a service was occurring. We returned after lunch to no line up and more access so keep that in mind.

Amazing building . After our visit to the heavenly Pastry we visited this beautiful Mosteiro, such a beautiful building and grandeur and historic value. We walked around and enjoyed the view and the architecture and the sun which made it extra nice to enjoy our time at this beautiful spot at the seaside and the marina.

breathtaking!. wonderful, awesome, everyone should have the oportunity of watching it live! It's not just architecture or ancient buildings...it's atmosphere, it's feelings... I didn't expect so much!
Meh..... While in Lisbon, I spent a morning in Belem. I rode out to Tram 15. The Monastery was massive, but I wasn't blown away.

Beatiful building inside and out. Well worth a visit as long as you don't go by hop-on-hop-off bus (Grayline) The monastery in beautiful inside with inspring alcoves and stained glass windows. This was spoiled by our method of getting there. Don't use the Grayline bus red route. We waited in the scorching heat for over an hour to get the bus back - would hardly call it 'hop-on-hop-off!!
Simply amazing. Worth leaving Lisbon for. The size alone is amazing and located close to other highlights such as Belem tower.

If you have plenty of time, then probably nice to do. We only passed by this building as we were not keen on staying inside with the beautiful 30°C October weather.But it is a beautiful building and it must be great to see if you have plenty of time.

Worth it once you get in. The Monastery was well worth a visit. But we had to queue for a long time in baking heat to get in. There were lots of people but we waited so long because the whole organisation of the queues and the ticketing was shambolic. Once we got inside it was cooler and we spent a long time seeing most of the monastery and it's chapel.We saw the beautiful cloisters on two levels, the high chapel (the chapel balcony), the main chapel, a very well presented history of the monastery aligned with the history of what was going on outside the monastery at the same time and a very interesting presentation about Alexandre Herculano in the room that houses his tomb.All well worth seeing but by the time we had queued and seen the monastery we'd had enough. With better organisation, we may still have had time and been more inclined to see more of Belem.
Well Worth a Visit!. Excellently preserved and the monastery surrounds a fantastic cloister. We really enjoyed our visit in Belem.

Pretty, but doesn't compare to other monasteries in Portugal. If you're only going to stay be in Lisbon then this is a very nice monastery to visit, otherwise you are better off visiting the monasteries in Tomar, Batalha and Alcobaça. The building is very pretty but mostly empty and there's not a lot to see in it. There were no guided tours or even an audio guide (even though there are audio guide markers).I did like the fact that unlike other monasteries, this one included the tombs of writers and explorers such as Fernando Pessoa and Vasco da Gama.
Must do attraction . Jerónimo s monastery certainly is a must do when in Lisbon! Charming architecture and a very nice place to visit!

Impressive!. This is a really impressive monastery that must be visited when you are in Lisbon. I recommend for you to get the Lisboa card, because with it the entrance to the monastery and the way to get there are free. This is an example of architecture that can’t be missed!

Not great organisation on entering.. We queued for half an hour and saw that only one person was selling tickets excruciatingly slowly, as we entered the ticket office a whole group of people who were behind us were waived forward to another ticket selling area, we eventually bought our tickets but we were now behind the twenty or so people who were waived forward, so now people with tickets were being blocked entrance to the monastery by people who hadn't yet paid. This after half an hour of queuing was infuriating. So much so in the end we took it upon ourselves to make our way in via the exit where we found a man checking tickets and we were let in. So the experience of getting in was terrible, but once inside it was fantastic.

First Sundays Free. We visited on the first Sunday of the month when many Lisbon museums and historical sites are free. Because of that, there was a ridiculously long line. Portugal is the best place to travel with a baby, because they're so thoughtful and considerate. We were told to go up to the front, and didn't have to wait in line at all. I've had this experience at the grocery store, airport, train station, everywhere. People here are just so nice. The monastery is beautiful and full of so much history.
Beautiful setting. This is free on the first Sunday of the month, so we got a break. It was crowded but still worth the visit. Beautiful architecture and a stunning church. Not to be missed.
Beautiful place . Nice monastery, both inside and outside. If you want to skip the long queue, try going there in the late afternoon. Was there at 4pm on Saturday and no queue to go inside at all.

Great architecture. If you're in the Belem area, then you should definitely plan to visit the monastery. Please note the entry in the chapel/church is free of charge, but for the monastery there's a fee-> but it's still worth visiting. Probably the nicest part is the interior garden.There isn't too much to do inside, so you can schedule just one hour for visiting (fingers crossed there'll be no queue when getting the tickets). Across the street is the monument of discoveries and also nearby, the Maritime museum which is worth a visit too. Don't miss the original Pasteis de Nata which are sold close to the Belem tower, less than 10 minutes away from the monastery.
Impressive. Impressive building. Loved the history. But the annoying street sellers ruined any hope we had of managing to take pictures or truely admire the outside of the building

Loved the atmosphere . Enjoyed our visit here
Beautiful white building, so peaceful. Architecture interesting. Loved the chapel.

Amazing building (but spoiled by long queues inside the church). If you're in Lisbon this must be one of the 'attractions' that you must visit. When you arrive the long frontage is amazing with incredible carved decoration and this is carried through into the cloisters and church. The cloisters are on two levels, rather than the normal single level, and the carved limestone was sublime. Inside the church the intricate rib vaulted roof is supported by soaring thin columns which you would not believe could take the weight. This is probably the most impressive and best preserved ecclesiastical buildings I have visited.Unfortunately the big downside was the long queue to get in and the very slow procession of tourists shuffling around the church on a one way system so it was difficult to take in the overall beauty of the building.As an aside, if you are hoping to catch the 15E tram to Belem from Lisbon please be aware that it was not running the whole distance when we were there (due to road improvements) and the replacement bus service was abysmal so we ended up catching a taxi. I believe it should be back in service in November/December 2016.
Meh. Not worth to pay just to see the cloister. But if you're there, why not... they take credit card so save your cash for public transit.
Not to be missed in Belem. Belem. A stunning building and not to be missed.Queues can be hideous, book in advance if you can. (€12 admission which includes the Torre Belem)

Stunning building, FREE church is where Vasgo da Gama Is buried . Stunning location! We talk a walk around the outside of the monastery as advised due to cost no to go in. There are many picture moments. The church whilst very busy is worth the free entry and truly wonderful.

Well worth visiting. Free entry first Sunday of the month! Get there at opening time to avoid queues. Two separate lines for church & cloisters, both well worth visiting. Interesting timeline of events upstairs in cloisters. Great to visit Pasties de Belem for authentic Portuguese tarts, just up the road from monastery
Must see!. Gorgeous building and surrounding area.The views inside are lovely and worth the visit and the architecture in the cathedral is amazing .

Gorgeous courtyard. Behind the church, needs a ticket (10 euros), very worth it. Very beautiful Manueline architecture, lovely play of light and shadows in a beautiful courtyard, quite magical. You can also enter the second level of the church on this tour, and get a birds eye view of the scene below.

Must see if into architecture . This monastery was constructed at the height of Portugal'a power and the stone work and church are amazingToday it also is home to several other museums as wellBut if you have time it is a must see
Breathtaking. The stone carvings from the Jeronimos monastery are simply breathtaking. I enjoyed it more as a work of art than as a place of worship, but in my opinion it's well worth the trip.

Great place!. Really enjoyed our visit here, it's such an impressive place. We turned up around 10.30/11am and the queue was very small and we pretty much went straight in, but when we caught a glimpse of the queue around 11.30am it was crazily long! Definitely pays to go soon after opening, at around 10.

Definitely Worth a Visit!. We stopped here as part of a city tour. The church is gorgeous and has the tombs of Vasco de Gama and a poet whose name is escaping me as I write this. The architectural details are amazing-note the references to sailing in the gothic arches- rope, artichokes, etc. The Manueline style of decoration is very evident here from the entry way to the side alters. We didn't have time to go into the actual monastery though. Lovely grounds too.

It was nice, if you have not already had enough of admiring gorgeous architecture. We went there by ourselves in a local bus. That was the funnest part of the entire trip to Belem. The monastery is of course gorgeous. We just liked the ambiance of the place, walking around than monastery itself. We ate at one of those cafes there. Pretty good food. Can't remember the name. Overall a good trip.

Fabulous. For us this was the star visit when in Lisbon. The outside is impressive but the inside is breathtaking. Well worth the entrance fee. The attached church is free of charge and is also otstanding. We recommend to get to the monastry early before the groups arrive.

best gothic in lisbon. Apart from the hoards of tour groups, even in the autumn months, the double story columned courtyard, the tiled refractory and the main church are outstanding examples of the weird mix that is Portuguese architecture even to this day. The art works aren't overly exciting but if Catholic, the copious madonnas will be a bonus.

Jeronimos Monastery. a must see attraction while in Lisbon as the monastery is simply awesome considering this was built 500 years ago and the cathedral is stunning. The architecture with ornate designs later known as manueline includes maritime elements and naval objects.
Beautiful architecture and place of history. Get your tickets in advance to avoid the crowds, the monastery is beautiful and shows its ancient charm with quiet spaces and cool corridors.

Beautiful Inside and Out!. The Monastery is closed on Mondays. Visit any other day :) It was 10 euros to go inside the Monastery itself but the church was free. It is so beautiful inside and you can see the whole thing in an hour. There is a museum section too but the ticket for that section is separate. We did not visit that section.
must visit while in Lisbon next to Torre de Belem. you will be in Awe when inside. architecture and history one of the most beautiful places in Lisbon spend about 2 hours there.

Beautiful inside and out. My husband and I visited Jeronimos Monastery while in Lisbon. We would highly recommend anyone travelling in Lisbon to visit this special place. The entrance to the church of Santa Maria is free and the church is magnificent with it's slender octagonal pillars. I would say it's worth the money to visit inside the monastery. It would have been nice if the place provided the audio recording that talks about different rooms as does the Batalha and Alcabaca Monastery.
Worth the wait.. We had to stand in line for 15 minutes to enter because it was a Sunday, but it was well worth it. Beautiful place with intricate archetectural details,

Some advice. Go buy your triple pass at the archeological museum (west end of monastery). Then head to Torre Do Belém, 1st part of pass (5-10 min walk) and go upstairs to the line up to go up the tower. We made the mistake of going downstairs first and the line up was too long, so we skipped climbing to the top.Next go have lunch at the Museum of Contemporary Art. They have a cafeteria (4th floor) and a small bar (ground floor). If you are an art lover, go see the museum - it's amazing. If not, head over to a small bar-cafeteria at the Naval Museum just west of the Monastery. It's very nice there too. Head over to the Archeologic Museum (2nd part of pass). This is a great museum that offers a great historical view of ancient Portugal. Housed in a long, elegant wing makes the visit very enjoyable.Finally around 3-4 pm, go see the monastery (3rd part of pass). Why then? The crowds are smaller but more importantly, the late afternoon light makes the building glow with a red light and the building is more sublime.Remember with a pass there is separate entrance for ticket holders to all sights. To go up and see the cathedral from above is free too and if you are tight on time, go see this because it is truly amazing.The monastery is truly a must see but the crowds are enormous. We arrived late around noon due to missing the #15 tram but the #564 ? bus also goes there, but takes longer. Check the timetable at Cais do Sodré stop for the exact bus route.All of these buildings are all in one area focused around a large garden / fountain so it doesn't take much time to walk to the next place (the tower is the furthest). Our trip to Belém was a must see but getting there almost ruined the trip.I hope this advice helps?

A must!. For the most beautiful views of the city! Try to catch one of the guided tour of the ancient part, they are every half hour or so. Dedicate a good part of your morning, we found out that the earlier, the better, as we were leaving for lunch there were huge queues.

Top 1 highlight of Lisbon. Being an amateur of arts, architecture and monuments, i can honestly say that this one of the major attractions one could visit in Europe. Impressive Gothic Cathedral with unparalleled fine architectural details. The monastery also is nice to visit. Try not to miss it.If you wish to visit before 3 pm you can get a discount on your ticket for up to 25% which is a good deal.

A Must-See. Classified as World Heritage with the Tomb of Vasco da Gama... Ifever you visit Belem, don't only go for the "Pasteis de Belem" (worth the trip...) but ABSOLUTELY add the cultural visit of Jeronimos Monastery.

Not enough time. This place packed with tourist go early is my suggestion doesn't mean you won't encounter crowds. By the time I got back in the afternoon it was about to close. The structure from the outside- definitely a must see if you have time. The courtyard maybe highlight to some people who truly appreciate it. It is also nearby different kind of museum.have a comfortable or great walking shoes or sandals
Wonderful Place to Visit. I visited this place from outside only because they are closed on Mondays, however, I loved the outside design and structure.

A pretty monastery but those who worked there were horrible. The monastery is what you'd expect. It's cool-looking, with a unique design. The church is quite beautiful as well and the tomb of Vasco da Gama is right at the entrance.The staff however... were HORRIBLE. You buy the tickets to the monastery from two useless old women that practically know no English (why would you have people like that work at a tourist attraction?). We asked questions and they only used hand gestures. Also, when we stood in line to get inside the monastery, another rude old woman came up to us (and several other people behind us) to move us to a different line. She didn't even give us an explanation and basically just screamed at us to move to another place. I think she might have thought that we had not yet bought our tickets or something, because when she later noticed that we were holding our tickets - she just left us alone (and didn't even apologize for the misunderstanding).This almost completely ruined our experience there and is why I'm going to rate is low. There's nothing worse than bad service and rude people.Also, you should go when there are less people there. I think you'd have a much better experience when it's less crowded.
Breathtaking!. Visited with tour group. Saw the tomb of Vasco de Gama and learned some interesting history on the discovery of the Americas.
Amazing!!!. Must see if you are visting Lisbon.Absolutely amazing structure. One of a kind in the world. Magnificent building with incredible church. Inside you can see grave of Vasco De Gama.

Very good . Jeronimos Monastery is a very good architectural tourist attraction. Inside, there is a big gallery about the monastery's evolution throughout the years.
Maybe it would be more interesting to have a guided tour.
Bare in mind that I do not usually go to tourist attractions like churches or monasteries...

Beautiful building, *cool* interior. If you make it out to Belem, odds are you will see this monastery, which I thought was quite beautiful. It is also interesting to consider its place in the history of Lisbon, based on when it was built. We admired the exterior for a while and started waiting in the ticket line on the left but realized soon thereafter that you could actually go into the cathedral for free on the right, so we did that instead. For free you can see the sarcophagus of Vasco de Gamma, appreciate the gorgeous architecture, and cool down a bit in the peaceful interior if it is a hot day like it was for us! Take a look into the ambulatory for the sarcophagi balanced on top of elephants - a great reminder of Portugal's global reach through the ages!
best monastery ever. amazing historic place. good located. I always love to take pictures of the outside view. amazing ..
Well worth a visit !. The Hop on / off bus stops there, which is a big plus. It is a great place to take beautiful pictures, and it's full of history.
A MUST VISIT MONASTERY. You have to spend some time to visit this monastery.It internal and external impressive.When we went there there was a lot of people and we had to wait in queue.

Interesting and beautiful. We visited this monastery with a tour group. The spacious cloisters of the interior has many columns and archways. It is a UNESCORTED World Heritage Site. Definitely worth a visit
Historic and cultural value. Amazing architecture and representation of local history. Definitely worth a visit! Stone and wood carvings are photo-worthy.

Stunning. We visited the Monastery last week on their National Cultural day, which meant we got in for free. We arrived around 9.30 which meant we were at the front of the queue. This allowed me to take some fantastic pictures with nobody else around. The building is stunning, a bit like lace carved. 4Do arrive early as the queue can got all around the block very quickly!
Mitchell. I would skip buying admission and go into the church which is free. Very crowded. Liked the church. If you go pick a time to avoid tour groups if at all possible
Stunning church...... This a must see if you're travelling to Lisbon. Be prepared for crowds in high season if you're planning to see the museum.
Architectural Novice Detective Delight. Our Smithsonian Sponsored trip prepared us well by having our expert Architectural , Gail Cornell, lecture us the evening before this magnificent visit.
WOW !!!!!. A "must do" if in Lisbon..Must add to your list of gotta see !!! The size alone of the Monastery amazed us. Could have spent more time looking but crowded..

Great manuelin art. Great experience. The monastery is a Lisbon must. We went there around 10:15 and the queue for buying tickets was quite small. We waited for the 12:00 English language volunteer tour. It was ok, having in mind the woman had to do it simultaneously in French and English and it was totally free. It was quite crowded at noon, but around 14:00 it was almost empty. I would suggest visiting it in the afternoon.
JUST OK. liked the exterior but there are always large queues to get in and not much worth seeing inside. Theres a museum besides the Monastery which could be interesting for history lovers

Exceptionally nice. I was quite surprised by the grander of this beautiful church and monastery. Absolutely a must to see in Lisbon. Very unique and beautiful interior decoration with heavy stone carvings. None of the average baroque guild.The best is the tomb of Vasco da Gama.

Pretty Average. We visited the basilica and the courtyard. The church was pretty but I have certainly seen many that are much more elaborate or much quainter. Although pretty average on the decorative side (for a really old church) it certainly has interesting stories. Worth a visit if you have a guide because if you don't, there isn't much to get on your own.

Long Lines shrink after 4 pm. Just a 15minute tram ride from Bairo Alto, the riverfront at Belem harbors a grand esplanade of museums, churches, monuments and parks. We first visited the maritime museum situated in a wing of the huge monastery complex. Wonderful. Then we crossed the main road to see the modern museum and civic center. Beautiful architecture and water gardens. We passed by the immense concrete Explorations monument, and returned to find a shorter line waiting for the monastery. The adjacent church visit was free of charge and had no line-up, so we went in. Majestic! Then we got into the shortened line to see the monastery. Magnificent!
Bellissimo !!. one of the best Monastery I've ever been. Great architecture inside ( Manuelina) , don't miss it if you'll visit Lisbon. Awesome !!!

very interresting place with great architecture. The place offers a striking mix between gothic and arab architecture, summarizing the history of the area. Only lowlight might be the crowd, so go there on weekdays if you can.

Not what I expected. I just wasn’t impressed by the Monastery. We did not do an audio tour and we did not stand in the long line to get into the church. There were a few rooms you can enter but nothing stood out to me.
A must visit.. The monestory is an awesome fete of architecture inside and out. A much photographed attraction. 10 euros entrance fee.

Impressive!. We took tram 15E just outside the Cais do Sodre station to get to Belem. It's covered by the Via Viagem card. The ride was interesting, going through various neighborhoods and under a few highly elevated freeways. We reached Belem in about 20 minutes, and the stop is within easy walking distance to the monastery.We walked past a very long line of people 4 or 5 deep waiting to get into the church and queued up in a much shorter line for the cloister, which was 12 euros each and included admission to the Tower of Belem (hint: a huge bonus).The cloister was interesting: basically 4 wings on 2 stories around a lawn. In one corner there's a wash basin outside a very large tiled room which was the dining hall for the monks. There were also very small rooms which must have been confessionals, Plus on the 2nd floor there are more rooms and an entry to a veranda overlooking the adjoining church (there is no entry point to the church on the veranda).We left the cloister and walked around to the main entrance to the church. The line was minimal at this point. The inside of the church is beautiful, but I'd say the biggest drawing point for me was the tomb of the great Portuguese explorer Vasco de Gama at the rear of the church.We left the church and walked across the street, through the Jardin da Praca do Imperio with its gardens, fountains and little old ladies selling cork jewelry, and proceeded to the Tower of Belem in about 15 minutes. There were 250-300 people in line to buy tower tickets, but since we bought the combo ticket at the cloister, we just walked to the front of the line and walked in!After seeing the tower we took a cab back to the town for late lunch. As we passed the monastery, I noticed the lines for both the church and the cloister were non-existent, so I figured the best time to go is mid to late afternoon (hint)Anyway, I glad we went. The monastery, church and tower are all must-see items in Lisbon, and are important historical and cultural sites
A nice trip. If I had paid for it and not used the Lisbon card, I would have said it was expensive. Said that, just the cloister is worth the admission!
A must see if you visit Lisbon. The queue is always very long, but don't let that scare you. The Monastery absolutely worth waiting. It's beautiful. You can sense the spirits of the past inside.

the crown jewel. This unique monastery is the most important building of manuelino architectural style. Here you could find the Luís de Camões tomb, the greatast portuguese poet of 16th century. Enjoy!!!

An amazing building and interesting history. Please remember, closed on Monday's..so we really didn't get to explore the monastery but walked around the outside. The architecture is just amazing and I am glad that we got to see the outside.

Beautiful Jeronimos monastery in Belem. Beautiful weather beautiful monastery. The only must see in Lisbon. I take tram 15E from Rossio metro (walk towards the fountain & statute opposite train station). Approximately 40mins by tram. Be careful on pickpockets.
Its hot so bring a hat. Take a tram or yellow bus boat to Belem. Bring a hat as queues can be long and it was very hot. Cool off by the fountains in the garden in front of Jeronimos.

Beatiful stone carvings everywhere!. It is hard to imagine that the monastery was built with money from imported pepper. It must have been huge amounts and worth quite a lot. Do not miss, and be overwhelmed!

Fantastic Cloisters. When we arrived here at the monastery it was slightly confusing, there was a long queue going into the church, so we joined the queue, but soon realised these people only wanted to go into the main church and this was free entry. we found the ticket office and were able to just go through into the monastery and the grounds. what is so striking about this place is the colour of the stone and all the carvings around the cloisters, there are also large halls to go in, containing different displays and exhibitions. it is a major tourist attraction and well worth visiting.

A Unesco World Heritage - an example of the Portugese Late Gothic Manueline style. This gorgeous monastery is situated on the banks of Tagus River. Constructed on January 6 , 1501 , not completed till 100 years later. It is one of the Portugese Late Gothic Manueline style architecture with maritime elements carved in limestone.The entrance and wings house the Maritime Museum and the National Archaeology Museum.The details of the church and cloisters are the best admirable of this site.You could take the Tram and visit all attractions on one single journey since they are closed to each other.Once needs a relaxing moment, then sit on the grass of the Tagus River , have a really good breeze, take a fresh mint tea leaves or have a snack then continue to the next attractions. Bring hats , scarves since there are not many tree shades.

Must see the Monastery in Belem. This is one of the main attractions to see if you visit Lisbon. However you get to Belem, whether train, bus or as we did a 40 minute tram ride about 10.00 am on tram number 15 from Plaça de Figueira- it will be very busy and hot on the tram.On arrival there were many coach tours and numerous tourists as you would expect for a major attraction. The queue to get into the Monastery was too long to wait in the baking sun so a tip would be to look around other parts of Belem and then go back as we did later in the afternoon when there was virtually no queue!You have a choice, you can go into the cloisters on the right for free or pay €10 per person to have access into the inner courtyard and upper cloister as well as then going back down to see the main cloister with everyone else. It is a spectacular building from inside and outside but upon reflection I think just to see the main cloister for free would be sufficient.

Historic Beauty. If you are spending time in Lisbon take the time to visit this beautiful piece of the country's history. The church, monastery and grounds are exceptional. Admission to the site is free and easy to reach from any part of town. Don't be shocked by the lines they move quickly.

Amazing must see. I am not usually a fun of churches but this place is special. The church is linked to the monastery and they beutifuly interlink so you can go in between them if you choose. The church offers a bit of heat relive too so always welcome on a hot day. Go upstairs to enjoy the columnar view and the stained glass up close. The monastery is beutifuly designed with the arches and other ceiling works. It is so pieceful and gives you a feeling of calm and serenity. Wonderful. It can get busy , we did not book the tickets upfront and had to queue but luckily it was moving relatively fast and we were in within 30 minutes. Definitely worth it even if have to queue for longer. I would do again when in Lisbon. Dont recommend buying the combined ticket to Tore de Belem for reasons i described under a seperate section.

Beautiful monastery!. Enjoyed our visit here in the beautiful September sunshine. The building is very intricate and beautiful! There was a large queue outside when we arrived about 11am. When we returned at 1530 it was much shorter!Tip: visit the Belem torre first where you can buy a combined ticket for there and the monastery and skip the queue on your return. We found queueing for the torre far more pleasant by the water where there was a breeze. The church in the monastery is free to visit! A definite must see in Belem!
beautiful. An unbelievable experience looking at the workmanship. The detail on the columns was amazing. An absolute must for every tourist.
Very Good. It is probably the best church in Portugal and it contains the graves of Fernando Pessoa, Vasco da Gama and other portuguese heroes.

Beatiful. Make sure that this is on your list. It is slightly outside the Lisbon but you can easily get tram or bus there. The assess to the church is Free and if you want to visit Monastery you can combine your ticket with Torre de Belem £12. Plus you will avoid waiting on the Tower where waiting time to ticket office is quite long.
Beautiful Architecture. A beautiful and serene place to visit. Rather long queues, so be prepared, but the architecture was stunning and it has beautiful outside space.
A landmark of Lisbon- must see. I was impressed by the Jeronimos Monastery, the architecture is exquisite, clearly showing the rich culture of the Portuguese land. I recommend it.
Beautiful. Not to be missed. One of the great examples of Manuelino Arquitechture. Belém is wonderful. If you are in Lisbon you must check this

Beautiful – but get in early. This is a magnificent building and its frontage is a pleasure in itself. Admission can be part of a combo ticket (about 16 euro) but queues build up early and traffic in the area can be very busy. I suggest that if you plan to spend a day in Belem do this first then head off through the Gardens, through the underpass to the Mon of Discovery and then onto the Tower. That way you are on the right side of the road to get a taxi back to Lisbon.

Must to see in Lisbon. Definitely worth a visit!!! Unbreathing,beautiful amazing church. After such kind of place I understood why people were so greedy to explore the word. This place give a great willing to act, to live and travel. But if you try to get this spot by public transport be careful about schedule and bus station.

Vow!. Stunning architecture. Stunning historical significanceWell maintained.The best tourist experience to remember in Lisbon.The courtyards are fabulous.The enormity of what was done centuries ago is simply amazing.
Don't miss!. Stunning architecture; well worth the lines to get in. Hint: buy the ticket online or in the shop to the left of the entrance.

Amazing old building. One of the stops on our day tour. This building was amazing and the fact it is still in use is fantastic.Spent a lot of time walking around looking at great works of art, well worth a visit.

The church was nice. The church attached to the monastery was nice, but there is no need to wait on line and go to the monastery. The church is free and worth a visit. The design of the monastery is impressive but you see it all outside without a ticket.

Beautiful ancient Monastry in Belem near Lisbom. When you are in Lisbon go to the Terreiro di Paco and take tramline 14 (new tram) to Belem. After one half hour you can step out nearly in front of the Monastry. A magnificient building. One part is now a museum and one part is a church. When I was there there were long cues for the seperate entrances. Opposite is a small park with a nice fountain

Amazing place!. Definitely worth a visit, just amazing and very informative. The church was stunning and the exhibition was really interesting comparing world and Portuguese events along side each other.

Beautiful cloisters - See the cathedral from the second level. Beautiful church and Monastery. If I had it to do over again, I would have skipped the main floor (free) church entrance with the long line. If you buy a ticket to the cloisters, it includes an entry point to the cathedral on the second floor. The day we were there, a wedding was going on and we couldn't advance beyond the back of the cathedral anyway.
Dont pay the entrance fee. The Monastery is very interesting from the outside but the entrance fee is very steep and not worth it.

A unique monastery. This ancient and well preserved monastery is certainly worth a detour when making a city trip to Lisbon. Only about 7 km from the city centre, it is a living proof of the once immense wealth of Portugal during the colonisation era.Entrance fee is acceptable as the magnificent restored monastery is a delight to visit with the family. Also the adjacent cathedral is spectacular and contains tombs of some of Portugal's best known historical figures. You'll have to accept the long lines of visitors during the high season.
Fantastic. Well worth a visit. The architecture is magnificent and inspiring.We spent several hours wandering round the monastery and the church and learnt about the history of Lisbon.

Wow what an Awesome Experience in Lisbon. Visited this amazing building that brings you back in time to experience of long ago .The church and the cloisters are awesome as is the high celling chapel with its upper choir area that gives a lofty view of the church. The courtyards are very impressive and the outside appearance massive.Well worth a visit.
Walked by en route to pasteis de Belem. Didn't go in so can't comment.Wandered by from torre de Belem en route to pasteis de Belem.Impressive from the outside.

Incredible. This was very amazing to see. After you stand in a very long line you find out that the church part is free which is a different line. We paid to go through the museum part which was neat to see and not very expensive. Once you get your ticket don't keep standing in line you can go straight in. It's a bit disorganized getting in. If this is your first stop before going to Belem tower buy your ticket here to avoid the line there.
Crowded!. Entering the monastery costs 10€. It's not worth it. Too many people. Visit the church instead, since its free.

Silghtly dissaponted. Having visited Belem for many years I finally paid a visit to the monastry. I have been in the church before . Entrance costs 10 euro but I feel there should be more rooms to view other than walking round the magnificent couryard.
Expensive but pretty. The entry fee for adults is 10€ and there really isn't all that much to see inside. Granted it is pretty, but I would not recommend.

Early Birds. My suggestion is to get there as early as possible to avoid massive queues. The outside is awesome but there's little to see inside. It has a cal.ing atmosphere and the church is stunning.
History of luxury. The Monastery looks gorgeous from the front view. When you get inside - it appears to be as beautiful. Lots of sculptures and art...

Not loads to see. The cloisters and church are certainly very impressive. The monastery should certainly be on your list if you are in Belem. It was a bit smaller than expected though. From the frontage it looks to be an enormous place but most of that is a separate museum. The monastery itself is just the one courtyard and the church. Both are predictably full of guided tours Nonetheless they are very pretty and worth seeing. One tip, when we arrived there was a very long queue on the right that turned out just to be to get into the church. If you go to the left there is a ticket office for the monastery, which gives you access to the cloisters and also to the choir section of the church, which affords a lovely view of the space.

Not to be missed. Get the combo ticket from the Belem Tower and see them both, without the long ticket lines at the Jeronimos monastery. The outside looks very somber and imposant, but the interior cloister (needs paid ticket), is stunning. Some good restaurants nearby, to the left as you exit.

Nice... be aware of what the ticket gets you. It's a great attraction and on most 'top 10' Lisbon things to do and for good reason. It is well preserved, the church (free) is stunning and the Vasco de Gama tombstone is surely an attraction in its own right. Having said that, be aware that the 10 Euro ticket to the monastery is only getting you the entry to the cloister. Whilst well preserved and beautiful, it takes less than 10 minutes to visit. It's true that usually they also have an exhibition on, but not to be disappointed make sure it's an interesting one before you purchase the ticket.

Impressive. The most impressive thing is just the immense size of this facility. It is not the most beautiful monastery I've seen but is interesting. The monastery itself is free but there is a fee for the attached museum & cloisters.
it's ok. well it looks nice but there is not really much to see inside, I expected something more. The architecture is interesting though
Superb. A wonderful visit, it is truly beautiful, a must see in Lisbon. Don't miss the church and Vasco de Gama's grave.

Stunning monastery. Jeronimos monastery was absolutely stunning. It was easy to get to on the tram from old town Lisbon and it appeared out of nowhere on our journey.It is a beautiful and ancient building and definitely worth seeing. We didn't actually pay to see the exhibition because the monastery itself was free and was lovely to walk around. It is definitely the highlight of Belem. Just opposite the monastery is a lovely botanical garden and also a museum with a Portuguese contemporary art exhibition. So Belem is definitely worth a day trip!

An architectural gem. The beauty of the monastery building is unbeliveable. The balance between the numerous ornaments and elegant proportions of the whole structure is striking. We did not see the insides, but the facade itself is a must-see.

Looks great, easy to find. Jeronimos Monastery looks beautiful and it's a shame to miss it. I didn't spend much time there but for me it was enough to see it to appreciate it. We saw Vasco da Gama's tomb (i think that was there) and it looks really good. Monastery is easy to find, especially with their great public transportation.

Excellent architecture!. We visited this beautiful monastery to see the lovely building. Some rooms inside are nicely tiled, and some have a great display on politics and cultural change during the 1800's. The church is beautiful too.

Beautifully Preserved . This monastery is beautiful and well preserved. All of the limestone in the cloister looks original belaying it's age. The adjacent church was elegantly decorated with lots of gold leaf and stone carvings. Don't miss the elephants under the columns in the transept. It's also one of the two UNESCO World Heritage sites in lisbon so it's world class.
Fantastic history . Well worth the €10 per person. Especially the exhibition on the dates though history. Even when there was lots of people there it was quite

Worth the wait. Beautiful monastery and cathedral. I'd recommend adding the torre de Belem (about a 15 minute walk along the river). Be careful about when you arrive - I came around 11am on a Tuesday and there was a 30ish minute line; when I walked out around 1:30/2pm, there was hardly any line. Make sure you check out the exhibits inside the monastery as well (particularly the World/Portugal/Monastery history one!)

For those ho love history. Jeronimos Monastery is a place that you have to visit if you love history! There is a church inside where Luis de Camões e Vasco da Gama are buried. Two very important portuguese figures! And there is also the museum with a lot more history inside!

Beautiful architecture. We didn't go into the monastery itself as queues were extremely long but it's a very impressive building to see & photograph. We were lucky enough that it was a Sunday when we visited and they open the church for free so we got to go inside without the queue it's beautiful inside and I would recommend visiting it even just to see it from the outside
Interesting. The Jorenimos Monastery is no far away to Belem Tower. Is nice and big, so for sure you should go ti visit. If you buy ticket for monastery and Belem Tower, you save few euro.
Amazing visit. Brief trip to Belem, visit to the Monastery was very worth it. Amazing place, the building is spectacular both inside and out. A must see.
Well worth any queue. Exactly as the guide books say, impressive and a must do. Belem area very busy at weekend we were there, easy access from city by train or tram.
Nice views. Overall good ambience - its a huge structure which makes an impressive impact. There was a huge queue to get inside. It is better to plan visit early in the morning.
Beautiful cloistures!. Loved this monastery for photography! The church is nice but touring the monastery is a must. Architecture is lovely.

Wonderful Example Gothic Architecture!!. Unfortunately, when visiting Belem to taste the famous Pastel de Nata, I didn't realise just how close we would be to the Jeronimos Monastery, so I hadn't arranged a tour or pre book tickets. As the queue was long, and temperature in excess of 30 degrees, I opted to just go inside and wander around myself. This monastery is very impressive and a great example of European Gothic Architecture, and Unesco has classified it as a World Heritage Monument. Just inside the door to the left was the tomb of Vasco da Gama. It was here that both he and the crew spent their last night in Portugal before leaving for India. There are also tombs of other Portuguese historical figures as you walk around. However, I will have to read up on these before my next visit. Had I queued for tickets I could have visited the garden, laid out in 1940's, which has hedges cut in the shapes of various municipal Portuguese coats of arms. I will definitely be returning to this monastery on my next visit to Lisbon - but will be more prepared!!!

Large and intricate. We visited on first Sunday of the month - the advantage is that it is free, the disadvantage is that it is busy.It is quite away from the city centre. We had a lucky problem getting there - the tram stopped halfway there and we decided to walk - the bus that eventually passed us was packed. We then found out why - at 11am they do a changing of the guard ceremony at the nearby national guard museum. Entertaining and an unexpected bonus.The monestry is two things to visit- the cathedral building (queue to the right). At the time we visited it was packed but an interesting building with unique architectural features. Queue to the middle to get to the main monestry. This is a large intricately decorated building over 2 floors. For the British visitor there is limited information but we simply enjoyed looking around. I guess there might be a written guidebook for info but we enjoyed our visit without the urge for being educated! It was generally unfurnished. Queue no. 3 on the left was for the attached museum. We didn't visit. There was a small market nearby (not our thing) and the Torre is across the park in front. A busy but jolly ride got us home.Travel tip - Lisbon does a 24 hour travel card for a reasonable price. Pick one up at the metro station though there is a 50c charge for the rechargeable card.Don't forget to appreciate the exterior in your determination to visit the inside!

A real treat. One of the must-see's in Lisbon. The line to get tickets can be very long. Either get the ticket online in advance. Or walk into the museum adjacent to it. Recommend to get the combo ticket of tower of Belem and the monastery.

Breathtaking . On our day trip to Belem we had made the plans to see the Monastery and the Tower. Wow what an awesome building. The sheer architecture alone is enough to blow you away. A must see for anyone visiting.

Nice cloisters. A huge queue for tickets when I got there at 10.15. Many many big buses and large tour groups. But it's still quite easy to get nice pics of the cloisters. I got plenty with no people in them at all - you just have to be patient.At the top there's a historical display (Portugese and English) which details the development of the monastery in terms of the calendar of world historical events. I found that quite interesting.Here's my best tip. There are two ticket offices. Most people queue up at the ticket office on the right hand side as you are looking at the monastery. The ticket office on the left is the entrance to the archeological museum. You can buy your ticket there (get a discount if you combine it with the tower of Belem) and then walk back and straight into the monastery.

Just lovely. Another place where you may need to be prepared to queue but it didn't take too long. You can see why it is a UNESCO heritage site. Very peaceful and beautiful architecture. Well worth a visit.
Beautiful. Beautifully carved stone on the outside, a lot to see inside, very interesting historically. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful. A beautiful church and home to the tomb of Vasco da Gama. The only downside to the visit, and it's not a reflection of the church itself, was the waves of tourists but what else can you expect when you are one!

Brilliant. There is so much to offer in this monastry. It is breathtaking and busy and all at the same time, peaceful and calming. We were luck enough to catch a little show of the horses outside before entering, and it made the experience all the more superb. I would say that if you see a long queue, just do something else for a while and then go back later. We went to the tower first as the queue for the monastry was far too long, and when we came back, there was no queue at all. There is also a lot to do around this area - spend the day and explore as much as possible!
What a special place. This is such a beautiful building, definitely worth a visit. Lovely place to catch your breath and relax and enjoy the beauty

Beautiful. Great place to take photos Wish I had done a tour to learn more. Spent a good hour there. Buy your ticket ahead if you can to save time in line and make sure you get your ticket to the tower at the same time. Not too crowded.

Skip the cloister and stand in the FAST line on the right to the chapel :). Save yourself the line around the block that is actually the line for the paid cloister and go on the fast-track line on the far right to enter the chapel. OR, pre-purchase your tickets to the cloister and you'll be let right in. Otherwise you'll literally wait in line for over an hour :) I had the magical experience of attending during a chapel service which was one of the most beautiful experiences I've ever witnessed - the choir, the music with the background of the echoing church was incredible.

Must see. We took a tour bus trip to see this monastery as the Lonely Planet guide recommended it as the number one sightseeing spot - they were right.The queues to get in very quite long but fast moving. We happened to go there on the first Sunday of the month and realised that on this day - there was no charge to get in so we were quite pleased to save 10 euros each.The structure of the monastery is huge and the interior decor, arches, tile work was exceptional that had a lot of moorish influence. It was quite a peaceful place to sit and admire the stunning architecture. I really enjoyed the day trip to this monastery.
So much detail, Fantastic!. Everyone should go here to visit this monument in Belem. We are glad someone suggested to us to go here. Also to Tower Belem. We walked to great pastry shop nearby.
Gorgeous a must in Lisbon to visit. Just lovely, positioned in a perfect location, a must to visit in Lisbon. Great history, easy access,stand back & take a photo from the park across the road.
Church only. Very impressive and interesting but like others have said very busy and cramped so you need to be very strong to get round

If you like monasteries, this is a good one to go. There is a reason why there is always a line in front of the Jeronimos: it is a beautiful place for those who like historical buildings. Entrance is free every first Sunday of the month.
Closed on Monday. Looks great from outside two metro trains and a very busy tram ride to get there only to find it closed Monday's . Area around very good and well worth a visit.

Magnificent but packed. The monastery is huge and surely has a lot to offer. The inner yard for starters is something to see. The main problem is the hordes (really) of tourists and particularly big tour groups all allowed inside at the same time, that tend to take the magic of the place away.Try to get there as early as possible to really enjoy the magnificent architecture and charm of the place! Oh, and be smart and take the duo ticket with Belém Tower included if you don't want to wait in second long line later.

Family visit to Portugal. So get there early...lines are super long in summer - not a surprise but just a reminder. There is a park across the street if you have multiple people one stand in line other hang out with the kids or chill in the shade. The monastery is spectacular.
Delightful old architecture. . Well worth seeing. Get the combined ticket with the tower to minimise queues. Don't miss the timeline exhibit. It's in English and very interesting and easy to follow.

Wonderful and beautiful. Well worth the admission to go into the monastery (the adjacent church is free of charge).
Not only is there this beautifully preserved building, they also have a room with a visual story of the past 500 years - the Monastery and the world

Very impressive Monastery. Went to Belem today, about 20 minutes from downtown Lisbon. Very impressive Monastery but not sure worth spending half a day unless you will be in Lisbon for at least 2 days.

Nice architecture. Going into the church is free (right line), and going into the monastery cost a bit more (maybe 7-9 euros). If you haven't seen enough church architecture, then it is worth going inside. But if you've seen previous monasteries, or even universities with the nice arches, then you might want to spend time elsewhere if you have limited on time.
A HUGE MONASTERY. The Jeronimos Monastery is a must see site in Lizbon.After your visit you can go to Belem Pastry.Outside and inside is fantastic.

one of the best I have visited.. Awesome place.we visited just the church.Church provided with calmness and solace.due to time limitations couldn't see from inside.very close to the other momument and museums.the huge Jardin in front is also beautiful.

Beautiful on inside and outside. A beautiful monastery in a moorish style very elaborate architecture. Well worth the 10€ for the ticket and you can finish in about one hour as there are very few exhibitions.

Worth going to see. Try to get there on a day when one of the gigantic cruise ships is not in town. The lines aren't as bad. The monastery and the church are both beautiful structures that shouldn't be missed.

Nice architecture. Beautiful place, missing audio ( or any other type of guide). If you are by your own, you will enjoy the beauty only, but there is no note,signs or guilds to tell you about the history/ back ground

Worth a quick tour. The monastery is imposing as is it's history, and you can say hi to the grave of Vasco da Gama. Free entrance and I assume the most "must see" in Lisboa (also is a UNESCO heritage sight). A quick visit will do, and I recommend to spend more time in the small squares and streets , such as the Bairro Alto area.
Impressive old monastery. Impressive church, amazing architecture, enormous cloister, plenty of history. Tombs of Vasco de Gama and Camoes are in the church.

Beware the crowds!. This is deservedly one of the main, even "must see" sights in Lisbon. However, its success makes it a very uncomfortable experience. The crowds are most off-putting and I would not have waited for a ticket if I had been on my own. Luckily, I was with a group and our leader organised tickets for us. The cloister is delightful, the baroque decoration over the top and the whole thing incredible. But do go early if in peak season and try to avoid afternoons.
Beautiful place . Beautiful place to visit. Would be good to combine with near historical sites such as padrao dos descobrimentos and Belem.

The crowds!. The monastery is gorgeous and worth seeing, but be prepared for lines and hordes of tour groups. The attraction itself is five stars, but the experience is rough due to its popularity. We got there before it opened and there were already about a dozen tour buses lined up.
A Beautiful Place : Mosteiro dos Jerónimos. Mosteiro dos Jerónimos an impressive Monastery ! If you went to Lisboa , a must be place to visit! We went a second time after 10 years . Still beautiful !
Fascinating History. This is well worth the visit. I recommend shelling out for the guided tour. The guides have fascinating stories that bring the place alive.

A must see in the heart of Lisbon!. This is a beautiful Monastery and in conjunction with the "Palacio da Pena" in Sintra, it's an absolute must see. During sunny days it is super relaxing to go for a walk in the gardens. It's also very close to the river line and the harbor.
Very touristic. Too much promotion for this monument, I'm afraid not justifiable. I sometimes think that these huge buildings are more interesting from outside than inside!

Check it out from outside not inside. This is beautiful building, amazing architecture. We decided to listen to our friends who came and visited inside. There is no need to wait, not much to see inside and the queue is sooo long.
Cloistered peace. I was fortunate enough to be second in the queue for this site . It was a lovely peace of architecture and cool and peaceful . Worth a look.

Timing is everything!. We got this one right by arriving shortly before it opened to purchase a ticket. Unlike Belem Tower (horrible!), there are two ticket offices and the line does move at a decent pace. If you decide to visit Belem Tower (not recommended-see review) do buy a duel ticket and save yourself time in a long line at the Tower to purchase tickets where there is only one person selling tickets. At Jeronimos Monastery the large tour groups go directly into the church (free) while those buying individual tickets enter into the cloisters and have an opportunity to first see the church from the upper floor, flooded with tour groups. Enjoy the cloisters, the one museum like information room gives plenty of bilingual details on the history and building of the monastery and small rooms on the upper floors, while the church empties out of tour groups, then go downstairs; absolutely worth visiting slowly and at your own pace, without the tour groups. As other reviews have mentioned it's a UNESCO World Heritage site. Do spend time looking at the outside details. Clean bathroom near the ticket office. If you are a senior (over 65) they offer 1/2 off the admission ticket.

Serenity radiating from exquisite architecture. I walked a great distance through Lisbon to find Jeronimos, so already felt grounded and mentally ready for the austerity I expected. Yes and no. Each time completely appropriate. The stonemasonry is extraordinary and can be seen clearly because a light yellow material was used in the monastery. The balcony is especially beautiful. The cathedral was more austere and sombre, but equally befitting the reason it was built and exists in the first place. Great visit.
Well worth a visit.. Another wonderful place to visit in Belem. Queues to get into the monastery. You pay to get in here although the church is free. Well worth a visit.
Peaceful and Pretty. The monastery is beautifully preserved, I found it to be a calming place as Belem is really busy.This was a little oasis of calm

A little disappointing . Like with everything else in Lisbon you have to wait in a very long queue to get inside. What you actually find inside is a little disappointing. Not much to see. The church is definitely more interesting in my opinion than cloisters. Would not visit again. Also make sure you have change if you plan on buying a ticket as the lady who sells them does not want to accept bigger notes. Do not take tram 15 to get to Belem, take a train. It is much faster and far less crowded.

Mosteiro dos Jerónimos in Belém is worth visit, but allow time to visit the many other attractions around.. Mosteiro dos Jerónimos in Belém (Lisbon neighbourhood to the west) is a short train trip and as well as seeing the monastery, there's a few palaces and gardens, so it's a full day out in Belém, so its better for an early start to get everything in.  Monastery is 15th/16th work of art, and we spent some time there looking at artefacts, and well thought out displays. Yes its worth going to see, and the museum next to it is also worth a visit.
Stunning architecture, quite a lot of people. Must see in Lisbon. Visit early in the morning if you want to avoid queues and plenty of tourist buses

World class unique jewel of the early 16th century. Its unique architecture and cultural significance make it an unmissable visit to both tourists and the native. It is a masterpiece and a well deserved UN World Heritage site.
