Amazing outside and in. We walked from Belem Tower to here which was quite a hike but the outside was amazing and the inside was interesting too.
Beautiful building. We did not go inside, but talking to some other visitors it is well worth it - the exterior is fantastic.
Impressive Monastery. Impressive architecture, A witness of the past glory and wealth of Lisbon!Do not queue stupidly in line, but figure out first, what you want to visit and what line to go to ;-)

Just beautiful . What a gorgeous place and the church was simply incredible. We tried on day 2 but the lineup was so long we decided to skip it. Luckily our meeting ended a few hours early so we had a second chance and worth it

Loved the Manueline Architecture. The church and cloisters are beautiful. We were there in a heavy rain that quickly turned to sunshine. The church is free and has the grave of Vasco deGamba and a major poet. Other poets and statesmen are buried near the cloisters.
Magnificent visit. The exterior is magnificent, and the interior is mesmerizing. Definitely worth a visit. We bought a dual ticket at Torre de Belem, which made our entrance speedier.
Spectacular . We didn't visit inside the monetary as it was closed on Mondays. However the outside of this building in stunning. The effort that it must have taken is awesome.
Go on the first sunday of the month!. This monastery is beautiful, but it is not worth paying to get into the cloister. Thankfully, it's free the first sunday of every month!

Nice architecture. The Jeronimo Monastery has very nice architecture, but there is very limited exhibitions within. However, the courtyard is very beautiful. The church connected to the monastery has free enstrance. The line for the monastery may be long - go to the other end and buy your ticket in the Archeological museum and skip the line. Buy combo-ticket with Belem Tower here, if you want to skip line there as well.

Well worth a visit. A beautiful place to visit a good morning out without the museums or a half morning with a good sardine lunch and walk around. One thing to note they advise getting a no 15 tram from outside the ferry port we waited over 30 minutes, passing dramas and buses said they didn't go to Belim the que's were mammoth - then we saw a no 18 opposite this attraction - plus several other buses go there or near by.so research where and what buses you can get as the trams get packed. Plenty of nice lunch time restaurants across the road, a nice park next door for 2 euros entry and lots of tsk tsk tours from outside if wanted around 45 euros for an hour around all Belim has to offer.

Masterpiece. Go goIt s fantasticTrue you have to wait a bit under the sunBut it s with it at 200%One advice When you buy your ticket ask for the one included the Belem towerYou ll avoid a long wait overthere

Nice, but........ This mosteiro (monastery) is nice but the surroundings are very touristy. For good pictures take them from the side. In front a huge car park and taxi stands. Easy to get in and worth the 10 euro's . Combine this attraction with the "Tower of Belem" which is in walking distance. Taxi's very cheap, they bring you back to the city center for a couple of euro's.

confusing queues!. there were 3 queue's going into the building. One seemed to be group tours which already had tickets, one was going to a ticket counter and another into the church. There was no explanation or anyone to ask about which queue we should join. All the guide books said it was free on sunday's between 10-2pm. It is only free on the 1st sunday of the month. When we arrived at the front of the queue we pad 12 euros to enter the monastery and the belem castle. As churches and monasteries go it was pretty, and worth visiting, but go later in the afternoon when the queues have gone.
Unmissable. This monastery has an important meaning to Portugal as it is today. Very old and beautifull. We can go down in history inside it.

Fabulous.. Belem can be got to by bus or tram. The porch to the old church is quite fabulous, as is the church itself which is free. We did not go into the main Mosteiro as there were too many large parties queuing. Afterwards take a walk into Belem itself. There a a custard tart shop which is like a maze inside. Further on through the beautiful gardens is the wonderful Museu dos Coches (Coaches). Even the one used by our own Queen when she visited Lisbon in the 1950s.

Great History. But as far as monasteries go they are all very similar. This was the first monastery I visited. I went very willing to pay the 10 euro entrance. Once inside, I found the price very expensive for what is there to see.

Imposing Mosteiro. If you would visit the convent, I would advice to go a bit later in the morning. Early morning (between 9am and 10am) there are long queues, but later on there are no queues at all. Also the church is beautiful and free to visit.
Jeronimo Lisbon. Beautiful architecture. Wonderful sculptures. Easy to read history plaques. Amazing Hercules. Wonderful day

Awesome and Inspiring . The Jeronimos is a must visit if you love architecture and landmark. The design and carvings on the structure is just jaw dropping and awesome. The inside of the church is even more beautiful than I thought it was. No regrets at all and a must visit in Belem, whether before or after you try the Portuguese tart within 200 meters away!

Beautiful detail, lacking in information. My friend and I recently visited here on a Saturday, we were expecting huge queues based on the overcrowded #15 tram to get there but we only waited for 15 minutes despite the fact there were only 2 guys selling tickets (which actually went down to 1 guy just before we reached the counter) The staff member seemed disinterested and didn't offer a map of the area which meant you just wandered around without an idea of what there was to see. The Cloisters were stunning and a great place to spend studying all the details or just relaxing in the sun. The view of the Church from the Upper Level was beautiful but we didn't bother visiting the Lower Level as the line was massive. It would have been good to provide more information at the entrance as to what the ticket options were and some kind of map / guide would have been helpful. That being said it is a beautiful building and well worth a visit.

Burial site of Vasco da Gama. Stunning, but a tourist trap.. Beautiful, impressive architecture, with a fascinating history. A must see when visiting Lisbon. Unfortunately, everybody else must see it too, so it's packed with tourist groups, tourist coaches, guided tour parties and buses.... Make sure you get there early to appreciate the calm & tranquility of the place. It's well worth it.
Must go. THis is a must go venue, offering a very nice walk and views as well as history. Easily accesible by car, just next to Belem Tower.

Beautiful monastery but crowded and overly touristy. My friend and I visited the monastery in April so not right during high tourist season; it was nonetheless very busy and the whole set-up was very touristy. There are large car parks for buses right in front of the monastery and street vendors trying to sell selfie sticks and other useless things. The queue seemed long but moved quite quickly and the inside is big enough to not feel overly crowded. The monastery is beautiful and one can spend hours looking at all the different stone figures. The church right next to the monastery (free entrance) is beautiful as well. I wouldn't say it is a waste of time but the crowded touristy atmosphere does dampen the experience.

Oh wow. This is very beautiful. If you are in Lisbon, definitely make your way here. Not only is the structure itself stunning, one of the upstairs room has a time line display of history's important points in several languages. You can buy a small printed copy of it which is a good keep sake. The paid access allows you to see the church (free access to ground floor only) from the balcony.

Huge line, tons of tour buses.... Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is the place that every tour bus in Portugal is headed. Seriously, we counted seventeen tour buses parked outside the monastery on the Tuesday that we visited. Wall-to-wall tourists. The line wrapped all the way around the front of the building and did not move. We asked a couple of people mid-line and were told they'd been standing there over an hour. While it's quick and easy to get into the church, if you want to see the monastery and the beautiful cloister, you must contend with the line. Belem was already so crowded and touristy that the thought of waiting an hour or two in line for this one site was incredibly unappealing. We went and saw everything else there was to see in town, had a long lunch, waited in the line for pasteis de nata (much better than others we'd had and actually worth the 20 minutes in line) and took a walk along the waterfront to kill time. We headed back to Mosteiro dos Jeronimos at 3:00pm and the line was down to about a 15-minute wait. That was well worth it to enjoy this beautiful site. The cloister really is stunning.We heard after the fact that you can go to the museum directly next door and buy a dual ticket that allows you to bypass the line. I can't vouch for this, since we didn't try it, but it's another option.Belem tips: (1) Prepare to enter the inner circle of tourist hell (2) Be willing to either wait an hour+ in line or come back at the end of the day when the line is shorter.

World Heritage Site. Sadly, all I can tell you about this Monastery is that it is the most visited site in the city of Lisbon and contains the tomb of explorer Vasco da Gama. It is a World Heritage Site since 1983. The outside is a blend of Moorish and Gothic styles. We arrived here on a Monday and found it to be closed since Monday is considered a day of rest after the busy Sunday mass schedule. There is plenty of parking, most of which is taken up by tour buses. As at most sites in Lisbon, you must run the gauntlet of souvenir hawkers on the streets outside the Monastery. There is much to see inside according to the information plaque on the front of the monastery, so plan to visit here on any days but Sunday and Monday. The Maritime Museum is also located in the Monastery and is closed on Monday as well. So arriving in Lisbon on a Monday was doubly unfortunate for us as both these places were on our tour.We did return to Lisbon another day the following week and the Monastery was open, but the line for tickets stretched for several blocks. I would suggest a check of the online site to see if tickets can be purchased in advance to avoid the crowds and the long waits. The Church however, was open. Just inside on the left as people file out of the church is the tomb of Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama. There is another tomb on the right as you enter but we weren’t familiar with the name on the plaque. Apparently Vasco da Gama died elsewhere and his bones were moved to several places before being permanently interred in the Jeronimos Church. There are several other tombs of notable and historical personages inside the church as well. The church was beautiful with soaring ceilings and mighty pillars to hold it up, though not as ornate as some churches we have visited in Europe.The line of people visiting the church moved quickly and quietly, or you can step out of the line and move about at your own pace. So if you find yourself in Lisbon on a Monday and find the Monastery closed, you can at least pay a visit to the church.

Overrated, extreme wait times.. Despite travel guides and reviews found it average.First, you can go see the cathedral, free and worth the visit.Next, there is a huge line to buy tickets and see the cloister. Well, there is not much to see there, honestly. Exhibits in side rooms are not dull, or the rooms are plain empty. Nothing there is worth waiting 1 hr in line. To summarize - see the cathedral, skip the cloister.

Not to Miss if Visiting Belem. Well maintained monastery and worth a visit if spending a few hours in Belem. The area is not as overrun with tourists like the center of Lisbon, so one can stroll the ancient corridors, admire the intricate carvings and arches at a leisurely pace.
Magnificente. Manuelin style one of the most beautiful monasteryes in the world. There is no art peace similar in all tje continents

Beautiful, must visit. this is an absolute must do when you visit Belem. There is the old monastery and a church that offer lots to see. it also offers some cool shade on a hot day. Allow at least 2 hrs order to see everything.

Skipped the mosterio, saw the church. The line to get in to the Mosterio dos Jeronimos was at least 200 yards long and didn't seem to move...so my friend and I skipped the line and went into the church (free) and sacristy (1 euro) instead. The church is GORGEOUS. There are many members of the Portuguese royal family interred there, as well as Vasco da Gama and Louis de Camoes. Really cool...and free!
Belem for culture and pasteis. Belem is a train ride or lengthy walk along the coast from central Lisbon. You can sample traditional custard tart and enjoy the beautiful old monastery.

An architectural style unique to Portugal. The Monastery of Jerónimos is one of the top Portuguese monuments. At first sight one would say it was built in the gothic style but although based on gothic elements such as the ogival arches the decoration is unique. Seaweed, palm trees, ropes sculpted in stone adorn the arches and they take you back to the times when the Portuguese were the first to brave the unknown seas to discover new lands and the maritime way to India.
Worth a visit. If you are visiting Lisbon then a visit is a must. Stunning. The area is worth spending some time. There is a lot to see.

Amazing structure. You must see the kitchen. Beautifully maintained cloisters, monks cells. Duck into the archeology museum to the left of main entrance to buy tickets...time saver if you have not prebooked,

Mandatory. It is impossible to visit Lisboa and not visit Mosteiro dos Jerónimos.
The Portuguese history, discoveries, globalization are here.
Near, you have Pasteis de Belém, Centro Cultural de Belém, Torre de Belém... Take a full day (at least) to visit this district!
Perfect and a must. A place of extreme beauty, you cam see a history, the beauty of art and arquitecture. The is a place that you have to go in Lisbon

Museum of Archeology is also within the complex. The monastery itself attracts the most visitor, including myself, but on this particular occasion I was able to visit an interesting exhibition about the influences of the Roman Empire in Portugal in the museum located within the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos.
Amazing. Absolutely amazing experience to visit this site. Skip the no inexpensive tour and just do the free self guided church tour and make a donation instead.
Wonderful. Stunning monestry, queues but well worth the wait, stunning from the outside and even more inside, well worth a visit.

Visit the tomb of Vasco da Gama. The church is beautiful in a fairly restrained way. The big surprise for us was to discover that it contained the tomb of Vasco da Gama. The cloisters are in excellent condition and are an outstanding example of stonemasonry. Access to the cloisters was free for holders of the Lisbon card, only requiring the printing of a ticket on presentation of the card.

Fabulous and impressive. It is not difficult to see why this is one of the most visited sights in Lisbon. It is a truly impressive building. We bought a combined ticket for the Mosteiro and the Torre de Belem which makes the price very reasonable. It's a good idea to time your visit as the Mosteiro gets busy - I imagine that tour buses arrive early morning (stopping in Belem on their way to Sintra) or late afternoon (on their way back from a morning in Sintra). We arrived shortly after midday on an April weekday and it was relatively quiet - when we left Belem some five hours later there seemed to be huge crowds of people around the Mosteiro. There are two parts to the Mosteiro. The 'church' is free to enter - entry being from the incredibly impressive south portal. The church with its fan vaulted ceiling is a masterpeice and in case you wonder why people gather round a tomb at the ntrance to take photos it's because its the tomb of Vasco da Gama. Even more impressive than the church are the Cloisters which you pay to enter. We were there for well over an hour marvelling at the carvings and the sheer majesty of the place. It's a photographers paradise - a truly beautiful building.
Big. The sculptures on the walls of the outer building are many and varied. The monastery is a huge building.

Impressive . Here's a tip: Probably the most popular tourist attraction in the historic town of Belem, or even Lisbon. The line to get in is super long, ridiculously long wait line. I have my Lisbon card, so I went to the museum first. Mind you, the museum if also a must see and you cant miss it. The ticket is good for entry to the Monastery and when your done with the museum, just show them your ticket and you'll skip the line. The cloisters are magnificent, each column differently carved with coils of rope, sea monters, coral and other sea motif.
Wonderful Architecture . A lovely place to explore as part of a visit to belem. Reminiscent of a Game of Thrones set. Worthwhile visit

Must-see!!!. We went there the morning of the first Sunday of the month when the entrance is free. There was a short queue but the wait was worth it.Its construction was started at the beginning of the sixteenth century by Diego de Boytac and continued by Jeronimo de Ruão, to pay tribute to the discovery of the route to India through the work of Vasco de Gama, it is a celebration of territorial expansion of Portugal and the expression of his national style; it was once inhabited by the monks of the Order of St. Jerome, whose spiritual task for four centuries was to comfort the sailors and pray for the soul of the king; when the order was dissolved in 1833, the monastery was used as a school and orphanage until about 1940. Manueline cloister is a triumph of natural details with its meticulously carved arches, ribbed turrets and spiral columns that have engravings of leaves, vines and nodes; there are the symbols of the era such as the armillary sphere and the Military Order of Saint George, and the gargoyles and fantasy creatures at the top level.

Interesting. The church is free to enter and it costs 10 euros if you want to visit the cloisters, which we thought was worth the money. There is some impressive stonework around the cloisters but the whole thing could be improved if the central courtyard was given a little more care and attention. The monastery is worth a visit if you are in the area, but perhaps not worth a special trip on its own.

magestatic monasteer. Build during the XVII century is particular architecture is unique. Called "Manuelina" in honor to king Manuel - who demand something different and almost bankrupt the country with is excesses thou leaving interesting monuments. A visit to the chapel is worthwhile but the inside gardens ara fabulous. Just side but side the "Museu de Marinha" /Naval Museum and watch the stars at the simulator

Impressive. When you prepare your list of "must see" places in Lisbon, you'd be short changing yourself if you didn't include this. The architecture of the Cloister is quite amazing & the story behind it is just as unique. The church is equally as impressive and is free to enter. My only suggestion is to be there at least 15 minutes before they open so that you can enjoy site without the crowds. It opens at 10:00 am (at least in April).
A must visit when in Lisboa. The Archeological museum may be sjkipped bt the the inside of the Jeronimos Monaster. It is abslutely fantastic architecture and a must in a Lisbon Visit.

Glad we didn't queue!. A lovely building, and the cloisters are a great piece of decorative architecture but when we went in the morning the queues were ridiculous. We found that buy going into the museum next door you can buy a joint ticket and skip the queues for the monastery. But DON'T SKIP THE MUSEUM, IT'S GREAT!!! Fantastically displayed Roman artefacts, and permanent exhibitions on Ancient Egypt and ancient jewellery. The building inside is great architecturally as well. The Monastery was lovely too but I would definitely recommend the two together.

Amazing. I have been there few year ago and it is amazing, Tourist are flocking to go there, the tourist buses stop right accross the road, but if you like to do your own thing then, you can catch a train and get of at Belem train station 5 minutes walk and train from Lisbon central wil take you 10 minutes and you can do a lot of sightseeting there and it is near Pasteis de Belem. The ride will cost you 2.50euro from Lisbon. You can do this as a family great Portuguese Architecture. You can buy the train passes from any newsagents.I would definitely recomment Mosterio dos Jeronimos. So peacful and trainqual.The park accross the road is beautiful and also you can walk to Torre de Belem.

Beautiful monastery. This was an incredible, humbling, and impressive religious monument. Our favorite area was the cloisters. It was interesting to walk around and see how short the doors were and how ornate the arches were. The entrance archways were incredibly detailed. I would say that visiting the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is a must when visiting Portugal.

Absolutely Beautiful and a Must See if in Lisbon!!!. Would suggest at least a half an hour or more in the gothic church. Entry is free there. If you want to visit the cloisters it's €7 extra. The entire complex is amazing and filled with tons of ornate things and lots of Portuguese history! MUST-SEE while in Lisbon!! You won't be disappointed!!!

Amazing architecture, design, and art. This was a highlight of my trip. The monastery is massive, with a lot of information, beautiful art and spaces to see and spend time in. Absolutely beautiful. A must!
Memorable. Well worth a visit. Beautiful both inside and out. Unfortunately, the tourist crowds can be enormous. Nevertheless, it is memorable.

Beautiful building but only worth the wait in the queue if history or architecture are your things. There are so many amazing places to see in Lisbon that if you are short on time or funds it is better to use them for a different activity in my opinion. Here you can enter the church area for free and the whole place is free on a certain Sunday every month..I think the first Sunday but check the website. Even though it was free for us to visit we have been much more impressed by other places around and in Lisbon. I think after visiting Sintra though it is hard to compare these other sites. Great location for a walk on the river afterwards and many other art, cultural and historical attractions around.

The masterpiece of a unique style. The powerful Portuguese empire of the XVI century has a masterpiece: Mosteiro dos Jerónimos. The greatest and richest example of the portuguese gothic known as Manuelino Style. Lavish of intrincate stone decoration the cloister is wonderful and seems like a sandcastle. The main chapel and its high ceiling is breathtaking.
Beautiful . Enormous and beautiful! Amazing how ornate this is. Be sure to get a custard tart down the street when you're done :)

Beautiful church - well worth a visit . Travel to the monastery by bus or tram, and spend half an hour or so in the gothic church (free entry). If you want to visit the cloisters it's €7 extra. The area also has the impressive Berardo art collection - modern art from 60s on, just across the road.
UNESCO site well worth visiting. We entered the cloisters and were stunned by the magnificence of the stone work. Such detailed stone carving is amazing and is well worth the entrance fee.

Going Back in Time.. I have lost count how many times I have visited the Mosteiro in Belem. I feel I'm visiting the place where it all started with Vasco de Gama. He was one of the 1st Explorers that opened the door to the New World and without him, the world would still be flat. The famous Portuguese poet Luis de Camoes is also there. The church is beautiful and functioning and there are lots of exhibitions in the area. Don't forget to visit the Nautical museum and the Planetarium. It's a great outing for the whole family. There is a wonderful/famous pastry shop next to Starbuck's which has the best custard pastries in the world. Pasteis de Belem. A must see everytime you come to Lisbon!
Nice architecture. The arhitecture is nice. But can be boring for people not interested in museums. Queye sometimes gets very long.
Looks great from the outside. Lovely building but gets busy from mid morning if there's a queue go somewhere else. it's not worth the wait to see inside.

great and very beautiful place. celebration for architecture lovers. this Unesco world heritage site is such amazing, impressive building. you can see outside that it's incredible, but when you enter, you see all details and the columns are like flowers and with many details. you don't see how the did it

Beautiful Monument. Located in one of the historic section of Portugal, Belem, from where many of the discoveries trips were launched, The Monastery of Jeronimos is one of the best examples of the late gothic architecture, under the known Manueline Style.It has been recognized by UNESCO as one of World Heritage Site. It took over 100 years to build and it is located in an area with many other interesting places to visit: Torre de Belem, Discovery Monument, Belem Cultural Center, the Maritime Museum. The Monastery of Jeronimos withstood the earthquake of 1755 with only partial damage, when most of the city of Lisbon was damaged or destroyed. The tombs of Vasco da Gama who led the first expedition to India and Portuguese poet Luis Vaz de Camoes are located there. The Treat of Lisbon that created the European Union was signed in the Monastery in 2007. A monument with over 500 years, a beautiful testament to the architecture and will of the Portuguese that all of those who make it to Lisbon must visit and they do, As the area of Belem has become one of the most visited section of Lisbon. Truly magnificient !

Beautiful site!. Easy to get there on public transit (Metro to Bus 728). Excellent historical museum inside, well preserved. Lovely church as part of the property as well. You must pay to get into the Monastery, but entry to the church is free.

Hard to believe your own eyes!. An astonishing piece of architecture. Fantastic inside and out. Who knew monks had such surroundings? Impossible to describe. Must see for yourself. Note to Asian tourists: selfies in religious museums are simply selfish. Knock it off.

We were lucky!. We had planned to visit this place on a Monday and were disappointed to realize that it is closed on Mondays. After seeing the inside view and reading about it's history, we were really disappointed that we were going to miss this! However, luck was in our stride and it was open on the Monday we visited as a part of 500th year completion of the Monastery and was completely free entry! Talk about having luck!Beautiful interiors and great architectures with Chapel and a huge courtyard, not to be missed if in Belem or Lisbon!
Beautiful buildings. Being able to view the monastery and the cloisters was a wonderful experience. Lovely architecture and stained glass windows. A must see when visiting Lisbon.
Beautiful . Enjoyed our visit to this beautiful monastery. Plan on spending at least one hour to have time to see it all.

Stunning. Visited twice, once under our steam, bus journey longer than we expected, good 3/4 hour, but worth it. Second with private firm Premium Tours - learnt so much ore the second time and got to see so much more of Lisbon. Both were great fun to do.

Too bad one wasn't a monk some hundred years ago. The Monestary of Jeronimo is a most impressive architectural testimony to the willingness of people to invest a significant portion of GDP into buildings of worshipping. The place is a tranquil, rock solid oasis for contemplation with a huge interior yard, a dark, mysterious church and a museum with an impressive collection of national treasures. The whole place has a soothing effect especially when there is choral music echoing through the large hallways. One can easily visualize monks doing their prayers and singing of psalms ( the rule was 7 hours per day). Lots of marble and stone statues of saints, noble men and other "high society" personalities decorate the outside. Mosteiros dos Jeronimos can be reached from the city centre either by taxi (about 15 minutes, around $14) or tram # 15 (about $3). Entrance fee excluding museum is €10, the museum is an additional €6. Admission to the church is free. It is worth it.

Nice visit.. The Monastery is a cultural reference point that has attracted artists, chroniclers and travellers in the course of its five centuries of existence. It received, and became a burial place, for kings, and later poets.Today it is admired by everyone, not only as a remarkable piece of architecture but also as integral part of Portuguese culture and identity.The Monastery was declared a National Monument in 1907 and in 1983 UNESCO classified it as a "World Heritage Site".You will need time to see all the rooms and sites within. Probably the best historical site in all of Lisbon.

Impressive!. This beautiful monument,a representative of Manueline architecture is in Belem area about 10 min taxi ride from city centre and can be visited along with discovery monument,berardo museum and Belem tower .The grey towers are asymmetric with beautiful carving on main doors..Take tram 15 from praca commercio at get down at the stop jerenimo which is after the Belem stop.

Interesting cultural site/beautiful architecture. This was a stop on my Lisbon day tour, unfortunately we didn't get to look around for long. There was quite a large queue for one section of the monastery and a shorter one for another section so for time I only visited one section of the monastery. I can say, however, I was not disappointed. It was quite beautiful; it has an 'aura' about it that made it feel like you were almost experiencing it another time completely. It was quite busy so I let my group on occasion which meant I couldn't really focus on it all; I was too worried I might be left behind! So that spoilt it for me, but I can say that with a decent time frame to spend here I would have enjoyed it more. Due to this I would definitely recommend at least an hour or 2 (I could only spend about 30 mins here). I loved the architecture, the art and the cultural significance. It was definitely worth going to see and I would highly recommend it to anyone going to Lisbon.
Overpriced. The entrance fee to this monastery is overpriced for what lies within which is pretty much more of what can be seen from the outside.

Beautiful. This was really a beautiful cathedral. We have been to most of the large cathedrals in the world and this is a bit different. It is more accessible to a religious person. Our guide pointed out a lot of interesting items in the church. The cloister is really beautiful and has a moorish edge but not necessarily a moorish design. I was glad we visited here.

Worth a visit. Perhaps the highlight of our visit to Lisbon. The structural magnificence coupled by its historical relevance helps you both embrace the significance of the Monument, and the tenacious spirit of the Rulers and Navigators of Portugal.

Magnificent monastery . The architecture of this building both inside and outside is impressive.Inside there is little to do other than appreciate the architecture. There is a little exhibition about its history on the second floor. We got there just as last entry and 30 mins was sufficient for us to see everything.Free entry with the Lisbon card.

ornate gem. The monastery proved relatively peaceful on a mid-week in April, allowing for close and leisurely inspection of its ornately sculptured cloister - something I had longed to visit for a very long time. It did not disappoint. It would be well worth a visit even if crowded on a rainy day.
Breathtaking. Buy you tickets for the Monastery from one of the museums in the same building beforehand to avoid the long wait.

A Must to see in Lisbon!. The Monastery of San Jeronimos is a awesome place where Vasco de Gamma, the Portugese Viceroy of India is buried. The columns inside this monastery are grand with beautiful engravings depicting the history of that country. The sheer size and architecture of the building are impressive and inspiring. Definitely a 'must see' while visiting Lisbon!

Fine building but crowded out. This is no longer a Monastery, but a church. The archictecture is fine and there some interesting tombs...including that of Vasco de Gama. But so many tourists leaves one with a feeling of wanting to hurry out. No sense of awe or deep religion. I suppose it is a victim of its own popularity

Worth the money. We are very happy that we visited the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. Many people visit the church next to it, the church is busy because it is free. Many of these visitors don't spend the money to go to the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. It is beautiful and we are pleased that we spent the money.
Amazing. Don't miss seing the mosterio. Really worth the time to wait in line. The details are beautiful and their is a room to read about the construction of the mosteiro.
A nice area with beautiful and gothic architecture!. This should be a must on your "to do list" when in Lisbon! The area itself is really nice and busy with lots of tourists. Be prepared to queue :)
Beautiful. It is beautiful from both outside and inside. I prefered cloisters over church a bit. We used a Lisbon pass and didn't wait much.

Just beautiful!. Belem is beautiful in general, everithing is near and this is one of the most beautiful places. I have to admit, I was a bit more impressed with the cloisters than the church (although it relly is a nice church). You can look around the arhitecture or just sit in the sun and relax while enjoying the view. It is a great picture-taking opportunity as well. We took a Lisbon pass and didn't wait to enter.

Stunning Portuguese architecture. The monastery is a brilliant example of the Manuelino architectural design, beautiful place. I visited it 4 times already, but I have never paid for the actual visit inside the monastery. I have only enjoyed the exterior and the old chapel where the tombs of Vasco da Gama and Luis de Camões are.A must see if you are in Lisbon.
Worth a visit.. Probably the most impressive place in the city that we visited. Resting place of Vasco da Gama. Lovely park opposite too.

Magnificent architecture. Much bigger and a lot to see inside. Architecture in side the cloisters was fantastic. Signs for the ancient library but then disappeared. There is no ancient library just where it used to be which is now an exhibit.
Must see - absolutely beautiful. Unesco cultural heritage and must see! Stunning cloister and church. The church is free and the cloister costs 10 euro. Take a tuk tuk or tram 15 to Belem.
Amazing!. A fantastic exhibit of architecture of the 16th century. Simply stunning! Also quite amazing that it survived the earthquake.

Wonderful gothic architecture . This is a fantastic, gothic building with some interesting historical exhibitions to boot. The attached church is spectacular and contains the tombs of João III and Sebastião, as well as Luiz de Camões and Vasco da Gama. Also mostly it is wheelchair friendly, the only inaccessible bit being the upper floor of the monastery, which is excellent. A must see if you're visiting Lisbon.

Amazing, both inside and out. Fantastic place to visit but so busy. Ensure you queue to the left when approaching the main entrance, as there were 3 ways to go: right (free entry to just the church) middle (exit from Monastery & cross-entrance to Church) left (ticket office and entrance to Monastery)Price was very reasonable - we chose to pay for Monastery & Belem Tower (10 minute walk away) together, but this isn't clearly marked on the ticket and had to be asked for specifically.Superb photo opportunities abound and there were no limits on the photos we could take (except others in the way)Monastery is very close to other superb attractions (Belem Tower, Pastries de Belem, No 15E new style Tram & Statue to celebrate Portuguese explorers.Would recommend setting aside most of a day to see everythingNote: avoid Tik-Tuks - overpriced @15Euros, as a taxi back to the City is only about 10Euros!

Good but busy. When I arrived the ticket queue was the lenght of a football pitch and then some. 10-11am seemed to be prime time for school and tour buses to arrive. I decided to go to the Torr Belem first where I purchased a combined ticket and was then able to enter straight away and avoid the still lenghty queue. It is a remarkable building and not as crowded as expected once inside. Just felt like hard work to get there and it wasn't even high season.
Beautiful. Beautiful. make sure not to miss the inside. If you go early in the morning you can miss the queues if you're lucky, or if the timing is right at lunchtime.

Excellent piece of history.. One of the most "must be seen" in Lisbon. Excellent piece of renaissance world heritage. The monastery is evidently kept in very good shape. The 1st Sunday in month is free of charge hence a queue is necessary to expect,but the organisation in front of the building is perfect so no long time to wait.

History. Queues were a bit confusing. The monastery is beautiful and impressive. It contains the tomb of Vasco da Gama. There is a fantastic chart showing the history of Portugal with simultaneous world events - the way to teach history..
Very big monastery. This is a very large building, the church is nice, did not visit inside the monastery due to cost (11 euros)

Lovely scenery. Me and my fiancee visited Monastery few days ago on warm and sunny spring day. The location was full of tourists, relaxing by the fountain and soaking the sun. We've really enjoyed it.
Amazing belem. Summing up Belem MonumentsCulture HistoryFriendly localsDiscoveries Truly atmosphere Soberb pastries of nata and sun and sailing

Amazing stone carving. I attended as part of an architectural tour. Outside and in the building was amazing. Thank God this beautiful building survived the earthquake of 1755. Definitely worth the price of admission to see the cloister area.

Beautiful building. We enjoyed a late afternoon visit to this beautiful monastry when it wasn't too busy and we were able to appreciate the calm and peaceful atmosphere as well as the wonderful stone carving

Main attraction ....with Vasco de Gama. We took hop on hop off from central Lisbon to Belem, where the monastery seemed to be the main tourist attraction. The church is free to visit, to see the wonderful architecture and tomb of Vasca de Gama....one of Portugal famous early adventurer . It's worth getting tickets to the beautiful cloister but we did not went in.

Glorious. E10 for entry to the cloisters. Everywhere you look, the stone carvings are utterly magnificent. You could spend hours there really. There is also a bilingual exhibition explaining its development, mapped against world developments and those in Portugal. Dry but informative.

So impressive!. The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is huge!! It is a combination of museum(s), monastery and church. Located in the Belem district, you should not miss this important historical site when visiting Lisbon. Easily coupled with a visit to the Torre de Belem and/or other museums in the area.

Oustanding Piece of Lisbon History. You may be distracted by the Torre de Belem and the lure of custard tarts nearby, but it's really worth going to the monastery if you intend to go to Belem.
Lovely architecture and stone carvings and the church is the most impressive in Lisbon - more so than the Se.

Beautiful but busy! . We visited yesterday - good idea to go to Belem tower and buy a combined ticket as we missed a massive queue when we arrived - the cloister is beautiful, the exhibition is interesting and the upstairs view of the church is stunning. You can also visit the church free of charge and see Royal burials and vasco de garma - well worth a trip.

Pretty place. It's very pretty and beautiful piece of architecture there but it's €10 to go in was quiet too much but we had Lisbon card so we went in free.U can travel with Lisbon are on busses, trains and trams for free too if u got it for 24 or more hours
Beautiful . I loved to be there! When I was visiting the place I had a very nice and peaceful feeling. I really want to visit this place once again.

Beautiful place. We didnt actually go inside the building but walked around the oustide and spent a while in the gardens to the front of it by the fountain. My kids loved running around the grass areas playing and gave lots of great photo opportunities

No words to describe. The church is amazing, one of the best in Lisbon, I have no words to describe the walls, figures,etc. The Mosteiro's architecture is another amazing heritage from Lisbon, nice to walk, take pictures and relax with yourself or more people.
Not worth €10. While the monastery is a very good example of Manueline architecture, it seems over priced. The whole visit took us less than an hour.

Beautiful but overpriced and a bi disappointing. Well... Advertised as the best attraction of Lisbon - Monastery is nice, but for 10 euro I expected more - you only see some terraces, one empty hall, one hall with boring exhibition and a choir. That's it, 30 minutes is enough. I spent more tome waiting in the queue for tickets. The best part, beautiful church with Vasco da Gama tomb, is for free anyway.

Beautiful 1500's church. Although much of the complex was destroyed during the earthquake of 1755, the church itself was left in tact. There is a lot of very interesting Portuguese history here and parts of the church are beautiful. The cloister of the old monetary is also worth discovering. We had a guide who explained many of the finer things in detail which made it very interesting. This is a must see in Portugal.

Beautiful for strolling. It's beautiful but read about it beforehand or get a guide. Not a whole lot of signage or info and it's actually a very interesting place. Skip the Belem tower ticket combo. Too long a line to get to the top.

Stunning church and cloister. You can get the tram, train or bus from central Lisbon to Belem, where the monastery is the main tourist attraction. The church is free to visit, to see the wonderful architecture and tomb of Vasca de Gama. It's worth getting tickets to the beautiful cloister as well, though, and you can get combined tickets to visit other Belem attractions more cheaply. It can be very busy here if you are unlucky enough to coincide with the bus tour groups!
Not to be missed. This place is a must see while in Lisbon. It is truly spectacular and unlike anything I've seen before, particularly in size.

You need to visit it.. Lisbon, Portugal !!Confirming my preference among the European countries, PORTUGAL, is a country that is different, in my opinion, the other the European Community; after all, our brothers discoverers receive us with open arms, always cheerful, doing and telling jokes, courteous, extremely pleasant; extensive food and "cheap" when compared to costs in other European countries including, mainly in food, with the prices we pay in our Brazil (Historical, monuments everywhere, museums, spectacular highways, stunning cities and reiterating unique cuisine, the Portuguese still today show everyone your culture, capability and intelligence as one of the most developed peoples of the world the epoch, after all, its discoverers braved unknown lands and non-existent, and are, as conquerors, present in various parts of the globe.Jeronimo monastery is a Place among another in Lisbon you need to visit, it amazing.I'm leaving, already with plans soon return, because I think we all should do and look for what we cherish the most; I particularly love to travel, and return to places known and loved today, it is still not a priority, but it is essential !!!!
Lovely architecture. Lovely building but exhibitions less interesting. Expensive for what there was to see. Closed Easter Sunday and Mondays.
Amazing . A beautiful place; great for prayer and meditation in a middle of a crazy holiday! Great place to take pictures as well. I really liked it!
Great cloisters. Pay extra to see the cloisters - beautiful carving and the colour of the stone is stunning. Worth seeing

Cloisters Extraordinaire. The late Gothic Manueline style of this monastery is almost too much for the eye and mind to absorb and truly needs to be seen to be believed. If you only visit one monastery in your entire life THIS is the one you should see.

Beautiful. It was not destroyed by the 1755 earthquake or tsunami like a lot of Lisbon was which makes it really cool. The inside is beautiful and if you at the alter you might be able to see R2D2 (I'm not lying). The staff inside was rude though which was surprising. Definitely worth a look.

Amazing architecture. This is probably one of the most architecturally detailed places I have ever been to. The detailed homage to the age of discovery, there is a room that traces the 500 year history that was very fascinating. Tip: it's free the first Sunday of every month!
Great. This is one of the best monastery I have seen in my life. If you go to Lisbon, you have to visit this monastery.
Beautiful Structure. Touring this monastery one feels as if you're walking back in time. The stone work archways are magnificent.

Magical place, you can feel the history. Definitely a must-see when you're in Lisbon. We had a Lisboa card so we didn't have to wait in a queue to buy tickets. Beautiful church and the surrounding area, you really feel the history. Recommend! The only "issue" is to get there - take a tram from the Lisbon center and expect approx. 30min ride with a hundreds of tourist :)

Gorgeous, but needs the sun. Gorgeous place to visit, but only worth the money it if it is sunny as it is just an open area. There are two other rooms to see, one which has a history of Portugal and the monastery and the other that gives you access to the upstairs of the church that is next to the monastery (which you can see for free)

Beautiful architecture. Be sure to keep an eye out for the nautical themes in the monetary. The entire structure is wonderful. It is a shame that similar buildings are not constructed today.It is cool to see the grave of Vasco de Gama, after reading about him so many decades ago!As reviews may have mentioned, the lines can become quite long, so try to get here early.

Old Older Oldest. We were here for the blessing of Portugal's newest president, but the beauty of the Mosteiro over staged the event. WOW the best was a display showing what was happening in the world from the first building to the place Amazing.
Monastery. One of the best monasteries I have visited in the world. We took a tour and the guide gave us very important information.

Don't miss it!. Located in Belem distrct where you'll find lots of reasons to come back! You can visit the unique gothic-Manueline church (free entrance, lots of visitors), the cloisters, the archaeological museum. Admire the sculptures, the colomns, the space looking like an oriental grotto. Choose early hours.

Beautiful. We went on busy Sunday morning, and only toured the cathedral (time crunch). It's a good place to begin the sightseeing for this area, as there are other good places to see in the vicinity.

See Vasco Da Gama. The monastery displays some really nice architectural work, but the prettiest section is in the church, which is free. You can pay to see the monastery portion for 10 euro but you can do package deals with the Belem Tower and museum to get better discounts. We did the Tower and the monastery for 12 euros. Vasco da Gama tomb (the explorer) is located in the church. The monastery has 2 floors that overlook a courtyard, and other rooms to see. The prettiest displays are the chapels in the church and the stained glass windows. The best place to take a picture of the entire building is across the street, near the big fountain, where you can get some of the ornately cut shrubs in the picture. You can get to the monastery using tram 15.

Beautiful . Worth visiting for the historical and architectural value.You should also visit the garden and take the steps to the second floor where there was an exhibition on the history of the monastery and you could also enter the upper floor of the cathedral.I have to go back.

A very beautiful cloister and church. Not as big at it seems from outside. It is worthwhile to see the cloister´s stone work and the church. There are two other museums around and a new arts space with shops and parking space.

Beautiful location and full of history. We visited the monastery on a rainy day so we could not appreciate the beautiful building from the outside. Unfotunately the whole monastery is empty, no furniture or portraits anywhere, a but dull as the only things you can see are massive rooms. The highlight of the visit was the monastery Cathedral which still in use. Also on the second floor there is the old library room which has an amazing history timeline panel of Portugal.

Amazing building to see. We went to the Monastery of Jeronimos last week when we were in Belem. In the morning there was a long line but I think you can avoid this line by either buying a ticket in advance on line , a Lisbon Pass or a combined ticket at the Tower of Belem. We bought the a combined ticket at the Tower but the line was smaller in the afternoon any way. The Monastery is an amazing and unusual feat of architecture. There is an archeology museum there too but we ran out of time to get to see this.

Worth the wait. We came a bit after 10, but the queue was horrible, so we decided to only visit the church and then walk around in the area. Then when we passed the monastry just after lunch, there was hardly any queue at all so we got to visit it. The atmosphere and architechture is amazing! We loved it!
Enjoyed my visit. You can visit the church for free but need to queue to get into the Mosteiro itself - free with a Lisbon Card. Beautiful architecture.
Well worth a visit. The outside and the cloisters are well worth visiting. Also within walking distance of the Torre de Belem and Padrao dos Descobrimentos
Fabulous. Magnificient architecture with its lacelike dekorations. Worre waiting half an hour for in the line.It is UNESCO World heritage. The Church is NOT quite so impressive.
Completely OTT but lovely. A fantastic space - madly ornate carving. Really interesting timeline exhibition on the history of the monastery compared with the history of Portugal and the wider world.

Remarkable architecture. This is completely worth the visit. It is at the end of the tram line in Belem but is worth travelling to. The cloisters and church and external architecture is awe-inspiring.

Large but not much to see. This is a gorgeous and huge building that is seen as a "must do" in Belem. It was 10 euro for a ticket, but this gets you into a limited part of the grounds which are not that impressive. It's not really worth the money. The church part is free.
Impressive Cathedral. A huge cathedral with many inner attractions. Worth a 2-3 hours visit. Beautiful masonry, extensive use of marble and sandstone to create artful decorations all around

Unbelievable, an absolute must do!!. This beautiful Manuelin style church and monastery is breathtaking. This style dating from Manuel I ca 1500 is distinctly different from style in Europe at that time. Look especially at the cloister square inside. Naturally also to the entrance portal.

Spectacular cloister. Luckily, we had visited the Torre de Belem first, and purchase a joint ticket there. The queue at the Monastery was long, but we went straight in. Tip - visit the Tower first, early, and get your ticket there.The main thing to see is the amazing, dual-level cloister. Not seen many like this. There are small rooms around, and an interesting panoramic history of the place, with a timeline of world and Portuguese history.The large church has free entry, but is gloomy. It contains the tomb of the explorer Vasco da Game.

Fascinating mix of wealth and religion. Confession: We went to Belem to eat pasteis de nata and wondered: what is that pompous building next to the pastry shop? It turned out to be the very famous "mosterio" built from taxes on the spice trade. We only enjoyed the look of the enormous and elaborate piece of fancy architecture from the outside; our mission of eating the best cakes in Lisbon could not be postponed. The sight was a wonderful bonus for the cake lovers and our pet "galo".

Beauty on the outside. Stunning architecture outside and beautiful interior cloisters but not much else to see inside, took less than half hour at most to explore. The chapel which is free, is the best. Unfortunately absolute chaos with school parties and senior citizen coach trips. Worth combining with a recovery visit to pasteis de Belem cafe nearby although unfortunately also madly crowded.

Exceptional experience. This building is worth visiting, not just for the gorgeous church and monastery courtyard/architecture, but for an exhibit that was so compelling. The history of the world, alongside the history of Portugal and the history of the monastery itself. It took me 90 minutes to walk through that exhibit and I learned you could buy the sheets documenting the timeline at the gift shop. Absolutely incredible.

Amazing!. I went there to visit on a Sunday. Palm Sunday that is. I was able to participate in the Palm Sunday mass and procession. What an amazing experience! The place itself is beautiful. It is quite busy mid day and there is a line to get in, so I would recommend going early. On a sunny day it is right near the water as well, so you can walk down there afterwards.

THE highlight of our 2 day visit. Worth a 10 minute queue and the Euro 10 ( 12 if you do the double ticket with Torre tower) admission fee. Amazing architecture and history. We liked the exhibition showing the history of the monastery in comparison to Portugal history and the history of the world. A special moment for me when I saw the final resting place of Vasco da Gama, having seen his first grave in Cochin, India. His body was moved in 1880 to the Church in the monastery. The church is free entry.

An amazing place to pray, to visit, to stay. The mosnatery is a place full of surprises an hidden treasures. If you are a believer, no matter in what, try to assist a mass on a sunday at 12h. The corus is divine. Next door you can visit the calustros, where you can see how the monks lived. also in the same building more to the left, you have 2 museums, the archeological museum and the maritim museum. Both are really interesting. The forst sunday of each month...you don't have to pay entrance.
Queue!!. Don't wait in line but visit the spectacular church (free) and the adjacent empty Archeological Museum. It's better doing something than queuing for an hour or more. Barry

Interesting visit to the Jeronimo museum. Close to the Torre de Belem, this is an interesting place to visit when you are in Lisbon. The architecture is really good and can spend 30 min. All museums have free entrance on first sundays of each month. So do take advantage of that!
Beautiful. I felt as if I was inside of a confection made of stone. A delicate beauty of outstanding proportion, do not miss this place.

Very Beautiful. This was pretty much the first touristic place I have visited in Lisbon. I really liked my visit a lot as there were not many people at all (might be due to the fact that I was there in January). The architecture is fascinating - can definitely recommend going. Needed time: maybe 1.5hrs or even less
WOW!. After visiting numerous Cathedrals, Castles and Palaces in both Spain and Portugal, I was surprised that this Mosteiro was still able to take my breath away!
Beautiful!. A must in Lisbon. Beautiful architecture, especially the monastrey is breathtaking. Easy to reach by tram or the train from Cais do Sodre.
Ornate architecture. This is an amazing architectural gem, not to be missed. Arrive before 11am to beat the crowds. The Belem area by the river is worth a whole day visit.

It seems fabulous from the outside. This monastery is a historical building of great importance in the area close to the mouth of the Tagus. Unfortunately, it is closed on Mondays so please keep this in mind.

Magnificent !!. Built in the 16th century is one of the most important monuments to visit in Lisbon. It takes you back some centuries to the "Portuguese Golden Era" of the discoveries. It's a "national monument" since 1907 and declared "World Cultural Heritage" by UNESCO in 1983. Impossible not visit it !!

one of our favorite parts of our visit. This monastery is incredibly beautiful, although it got uncomfortably crowded during our visit. We visited the church first - I recommend going directly to the monastery and go early to avoid long ticket lines. The church is free; the monastery is not. This is a "not to be missed" part of any visit to Lisbon. Our only complaint was the crowds of poorly-behaved teenagers on what appeared to be local field trips. Oh, and the gypsies hawking cheap sunglasses and scarves at the entrance. They were very aggressive and even made fun of us when we firmly declined their wares.

Well Preserved site Incredible Architecture. I rode the tram down from main square to Belem. This area is fantastic I originally was only going to visit the monastery but ended up staying all day as there is so much to see. The ocean is wonderful. I was surprised at how much there was to see in the monastery and how well it is maintained. The only down fall is all the women selling things in the area can be a bit tiresome and some are very persistent.

Beautiful and impressive!!. A very, very ancient building, amazing "facade", brilliant architecture outside and inside. Large rooms to visit and know about the history of the monastery. So cool!! You'll get impressed as well with the Chapel inside it and the room of the Tomb of Alexandre Herculano. Everything in there is interesting, it's not a boring attraction, and it has a good location: close to Tejo River, and lots of shops and restaurants around!!
Morning Visit. This is a fantastic monastery. try to keep away from the peak times as it is best seen when "quiet". It is stunning and a not to miss site. Keep away from monday as it was closed.

Must see. This cloister is very impressive indeed. The amount of detail put into every part of the building is very high, and it is worthwhile to explore for 2-3 hours. Entrance fee to the cloister is low (10 euro), with every first sunday free entrance. The church can be entered for free in all cases.

Two storey cloisters . Manueline style double cloister with access to church upper choir gallery from first floor. Also interesting timeline of Monastery, Portugal and the world since it was built. Cost 10 euros to get in this bit but church downstairs is free to see tomb of Vasco da Gama and some great mitres.

Nice but busy. Architecture here is lovely but because of the number of tours it lacked the atmosphere of a monastery. The timeline boards give a very good insight into the position of the monastery relating to world history

Horrible weather, lovely location. We made the fatal error of deciding to walk to Belém from Santos (a perfectly achievable walk) in the rain....and we were drenched, soggy feet and all, by the time we arrived. However it was worth it. The service at the gate was efficient and they spoke English which was helpful! The monastery itself is spectacular. Intricate carvings and perfect symmetry. There were a few rowdy school groups there while we were there (on a Friday), but it was a large enough attraction you never felt hemmed in. The view over the church was worth the entry! You can enter the church for free, but from the monastery you get to see it from above, and it took your breath away. Beautiful. Incredibly clean and immaculate place...especially considering how many people walk through.

Wow. Hop the tram off to Belem, get some home made lemonade and then head in to the Monestry to have your spiritual cup filled. The carving in the main building is well worth the visit. Make sure you have your camera

Stunning Architecture . The architecture was amazing. Emanuel design I think. The cloisters are a must see, the chapel we peeked at only as mass was taking place. Went on the first Sunday of the month do it was free for both the chapel and cloisters.

Amazing ...!!!. Have been there now after a long time ago , and its still impressiv ! I didnt saw any way , if you need a wheelchair f.ex. to access the upper levels , so please check this out if you use a wheelchair . Otherwise , if you are " fit " its not a big issue . So , the Single Addult Ticket was 10,Euros just for the Monastery . The Church , as far as i saw is still for free ( and open as long they are no services bcz the church is still in use ) . Otherwise , if there is a service , it could happen that you just get a look to the inside from the upper choir . The Monastery itself its what too see with his rich artwork in stone so please dont expect lots of exhibitionspieces in the inside . And there is not a lot more to say ... Personally , i agree with the most ...its worth it to visit without a doubt and just delight your eyes and feed " your soul " .

Worth making time to visit. Well worth taking a tram to visit this riverside attraction. In the church you will find the tomb of Vasco da Gama and the builder of this monument to the voyager. Fine stonework on their tombs and elsewhere inside.

A GEM. The monastery is one of the most prominent examples of the Portuguese Late Gothic (Manueline style, typical Portuguese, mainly motives with nautical elements), a a UNESCO World Heritage. King Manuel originally funded the project with moneys obtained from trading spices from Asia. An extraordinary architecture. Pay attentions to the details of the portals. Do not miss a visit to the two-storey cloisters. Watch the tombs of illustrious people of the Portuguese history, particularly the tombs of king Manuel I and his wife Maria of Aragon,King João III and his wife Queen Catherine of Austria, navigator Vasco da Gama, poets Luís de Camões and Fernando Pessoa, and so on.As much as possible, avoid weekends!

Worth the wait to see this piece of history in Belem. Gothic architecture at its best, I think. Located in the beautiful town of Belem. It was a rainy day and there were long lines but it was certainly worth the wait. Such a serene environment. I believe the entrance fee is 10Euros for adults and free the 1st Sunday of each month. I think there is a certain time for the free admission though. Here are direction to go to the Monastery by Tram.We were on a cruise ship that docked in Lisbon at Santa Apolonia terminal. This is over an hour's tram/bus ride to Belem. However, it is very easy to get there by bus/tram or train. So, exit the Port, go left and walk along the waters edge until you get to Praca de Comercio Square, one of Lisbon's main square. The square is on your right. Praca de Comercio is also called Terreiro do Paco. It is about an 8-10 min walk. It is a stopping point for buses and trams etc. Look for the stop for Tram #15E, should be ahead to the left. We paid 2.85Euros each way per person. You can buy the ticket on the Tram from the machine, which takes coins and notes. The machine gives change. Or you can buy it at a Metro station before you get on the Tram. The 15E to Belem would say "ALGES" because that is the last stop, but Belem is before this, about the 13th stop. The tram stops right in front of the Monastery, so you will know when you are in Belem. You can also take Bus #728, which I think is about 2 streets over in front of Apolonia cruise terminal. \ Look for the 728 going in the same direction you would have to walk to get to the square. If you take the bus you just sit on it until it arrives in Belem. It would also pick up passengers on its way at Praca de Comercio Square.  On the way back we took Bus # 728, across the street from the Monastery. The cost was less than the Tram...1.80Euros each. You can buy on the bus. We got off at Praca de Comercio and walked around to see Lisbon's city centre. It takes a different route, passing the the Alcantara Mar & Cais Sodre Train station. We saw different things on the way back. If you walk up the Main street by the Square you can get to Rossio Train Station where you can get Trains to Sintra to see the Beautiful Palace. I hope this is helpful.

Weekend to Lisboa. Well preserved building. Plenty of photo opportunities. Witnessed the changing of the guard!! This is very interestins as it happens every 2 hours. The soldiers stand guard like statues.

A must see in Lisbon. Apart from usual stuff, I was enthralled with a live performance by the college students on the first floor corridor. The church in the ground floor is free to enter. Nice decorations. You need ticket to enter the first floor and the other parts. Wort spending some time. Some museums are there in other sides. Didn't explore them.
really touristy. lots of tourists but fantastic place and lots of small restaurants to chill they were pretty quiet as most tourists were on buses

It's kind of a secret spot . We were so suprised by the harmonic and silent athmosphere in it! Because all the other monuments are so crowded and busy...at Mosteiro dos Jéronimus you don't have to wait in line for getting in. And check out the towers at the end. You'll get the best view over the city.

Beautiful. Really worth queuing for quite a while! Disturbing that hordes of cruise boat tours appeared by the thousands, although they are herded through so quickly with their guides, that they had no time to look in any detail! Mass tourism at its worst!!!
History. Worth visiting for the historical and architectural value. Within walking distance and Close to other museums worth viewing - Marine Museum.

Great Monument and surroundings. You may and must visit the church where you will find the tomb of Vasco da Gama and Luis Vaz de Camões. It's the star of manuelino art and architecture style.If you have time you may visit the cloister and some room of the monastery, but you must pay the admission.They have no furniture, since the building his base for two other museums: Archeological museum (where you may found some roman status and egytian art); navy museum (where you will have replicas of all boats since all times and objects reated about the discoveries)

Beautiful and worth the trip!. It is a little further outside of the main attractions in Lisbon, but it is easy to get to via public transport or a tour bus and it is definitely worth it. The monastery is breathtaking and situated in a great area!

Follow St Jerome. We had a lovely visit to this church and cloisters. This is quite a big place so unless you have all day you should probably only visit two places within. We chose the church and the cloisters. The church is free and is well worth a tour. The cloisters are amazing. Wonderful architecture, beautiful light, loads of information.

Great architecture. I loved Portugal and Lisbon and this monastery is a great reminder of how powerful their empire was - stuff like this is build only in prosperous and rich places & times. It may not have the sophistication of the Italian churches but it's really impressive.
Beautiful. Beautiful and amazing 15th century church and monastery. Wonderful carvings on the outer walls and in the cloisters. Vasco De Gama's tomb is in the church.

Most beautiful monastery in Lisbon. The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos made a huge impression on me when I was visiting it. It's definetely mandatory visit when you're in Lisbon. When I was there a part of it was under reconstruction however I could visit the tomb of Vasco da Gama. I was also impressed by the amazing structures and paintings inside the monastery.When visiting, you should also visit the garden and take the steps to the second floor where there was an exhibition on the history of the monastery and you could also enter the upper floor of the cathedral.
Beutiful monastery, truly breathtaking. We went on a Sunday and the 15 tram to Belem was a long wait and packed to capacity, however well worth the visit
Wonderful historical place. If you are in Lisbon you can't miss a visit to Mosteiro dos Jerónimos. Such a imponente church with historical meaning.
Amazing . Amazing cloisters, very calm and peaceful, well signposted in both Portuguese and English, beautiful and inspiring place, set in wonderful grounds.

Unique Architectural Style in the World. The architectural style called "Manuelino" (a kind of portuguese gothic) is a unique style larged used by King Manuel I (though created before is kingdom, and used long after is death) whose particularities are the use of very specific themes, all around the big theme "The Discoveries", where we can see all the the elements related to the sea ande the boats, However, it pretends to bring a larger message, since we can find also elementos related to de popular tradition, the christian tradition, alchimic elements, anda other icons related to the messianic aspirations of the King Manuel. Is main symbol is the "Esfera Armilar" who pretends to be the "Spera Mundi".In Mosteiro dos Jerónimos one can find and admire all these things descrived above, and read the History of Portugal carved in the beautifull stones. The Big Chappel is absolutly amazing and it deserves to get lost inside for a while and search for the details. Also in the huge cloisters one can find many different tracery in each column, in each corner. One og the biggest philosophers im Portugal (António Telmo) says that the Horoscope of Portugal is written in these Walls.It really is one of the Big 5 Monuments you must visit in Lisbon.

A piece of history. Lisboa is fantastic. I think the Portugal is fantastic, but I don't know whole country. The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is one of the miracle of this city. I have seen together such styles, what nowhere else. I have to go back.
Amazing interior!. Well worth paying the admission to see the full building, it is a fabulous interior, make sure you make the time to visit it.
You should visit it mandatory if you are in Lisbon. The monastery is remarkably both outside and inside. An excellent example of Manueline style. The tombs of Vasco da Gama is here too.

Jeronimos Monastery.. Before you go to the water from to see Belem. Go here. Worth the visit. Very gothic. Stain glass windows amazing with sun coming in. The pillars are carved out indavidually different not one the same. This is were you will find. Vasco da Gama tomb. It's a few hours but work the view. Enjoy.
Beautiful monastery. The church on the side of the entrance is gorgeous and the monastery is very spacious so you don't feel crowded at all.

A must see in Lisbon. This UNESCO World Heritage site is a must for all Lisbon tourists. A real travel into the past, into the history of this beautiful country.The Monastery itself is roughly an hour to hour and a half program, however to experience the activities around it you will need a full day.I suggest you book online to avoid the lengthy queue.

Magnificent. Visited this historic attraction by using the yellow bus. It us a magnificent building inside and out and well preserved. A very busy attraction and as such would recommend getting there for opening at 10 am

A Grand, Gothic structure, with great history attached. Within walking distance from the monument to the maritime explorers and located next to National Archaeology Museum, you will find, the World Heritage Listed Gothic Monastery, Mosteiro dos Jeronimos.Built it in 1502, this monastery was populated by the order of monks, known as Saint Jerome and hence, its name.At first glance upon approaching the monastery, you will notice the most impressive and elaborate sculptural details and maritime motifs.The Architectural splendour continues within the church itself with ahuge and spacious interior, with vaulted ceilings, decorated reliefs, gargoyles and delicately scalloped arches.The well-known navigator, Vasco da Gama's is entombed here, near the entrance, as is one of the greatest Portuguese poets, Luis Vaz de Camoes, among others.You can read about some of the history, on the plaques that adorn the tombs themselves.The entry fee is only 7 Euro however,the ticketed, admission price for the Monastery, the National Archaeology Museum and the Torre de Belem, located only a few minutes away, is at a discounted price of 16 Euro for all three.
Nothing interesting. Dont waste the time and money for this attraction. Entrance to the church is free of charge. You may look outside. Nice garden and fountain a front of monastery.
Stunning. Travelled out to Belem on 15E tram on a sunny March morning and the Monastery looked stunning in the sunshine. Fantastic architecture.
A wonderfully ornate church.. This church was breathtakingly elaborate with so much historical content.Didnt do the museum due to time limitations

Touch the History. Magnificent Monastery build in Manuelino Style named after the Portuguese King Manuel I which under his regency the Portugues Empire expanded to the 5 continents.
The Poet Camoes and the Navigator Vasco da Gama have their Tombs in two chappels of this stunning building.
Great. It is well worth a visit. There are many explanatory tiles in English and one gets a sense of Portuguese history
great building in and out. lovely building, stunning and worth a visit. a quick train trip from Lisbon and you reach the place. Also visit the inside of the church (free entry)
Beautiful building. Worth a visit although quite expensive. We bought a ticket to access monastery and the Belem tower, which saved some time queuing at the tower

Manostero dos Jerónimos. Nice place to see, even if is not possible to get in.
It's really huge and has a park just in front.
It deserve to pass by if you visit Belem.
Great night and athmosphere. A Saturday night out with a fantastic choice of food and athmosphere spending time going around each food emporium and the choice is huge.

Beautiful. Amazing architecture and such a peaceful atmosphere. The entrance fee is worth it. Not all of the rooms are open to the public, but there is plenty to see. There is also a nice exposition showing the history of Portugal and the Mosteiro.

Historic Grand Monastery. It's a Grand, historical cathedral and monastery with the tombs of Vasco de Gama. It has been built with detailed & architectural stone work. Free to enter, when mass is not in session. Located near the shore of the parish of Belém, at the entrance of Lisbon Harbour. It was classified a UNESCO World Heritage Site, along with the nearby Tower of Belém, in 1983.

beautiful. A really wonderful visit that probably should be the highlight of anyone's trip to Lisbon.I felt the cost was quite high given the only advantage to not paying was to see the cloisters when the church is free.

1st Sunday of the month!. In Lisbon many museums are open for free on the first sunday of the month! I didnt know this, we just got lucky.. if you are there jump on bus 15 out to Belem where it drops you next to the Mosteiro.. well worth it.. beautiful old building, interesting exibhits.. and a pasteleria very near that had queues half way down the street.. must be good

Beautiful monstatery. Worth the 10 euros to go in as peaceful, ornate and beautiful inside with some informative displays on the history of Lisbon and Portugal on a timeline with the rest of the world. Great photo opportunities and although busy you can find a quite nook to enjoy the scenery.

Perfect attraction. You can use Lisboa card for free visit to this beatiful place.Even to reach it by train also for free with Lisboa card.We were impressed with monumental,stone architecture and perfect acoustic.Choose good weather to walk around.
Mosterio dos Jeronimos impressive. Although closed as it was a Monday a was very impressive from the outside Would go back in order to visit the whole building
Magnificent monastery. You have to visit this magnificent monastery. Use your Lisboa Card if you have one. I was really impressed with the details on the building structure.

One to take a look at if you can!. You can get to Mosteiro dos Jeronimos via the number 15 tram, and it is a nice little ride, and free with the Lisbon Card. I didn't get the chance to take the museum tour, but inside the main Monastery is quite a sight, and one I am very glad I got to see!
Must see. Buy your ticket at the other entrance..no queu. Impressing architecture. Unesco classified. Good quality for the money you pay.
Beauty. Didn't go inside since we were busy eating pasteis. You can't take one shot of the whole monastery at once. Very nice

One of the most important Portuguese landmarks. Grand, historical cathedral and monastery with the tombs of Vasco de Gama and much of the royal family. One of the largest cathedrals I've ever seen, with detailed stone work and precious metals everywhere. Looks as if it was created using the riches brought back from Africa, Brazil, India. It's free to enter, but you have to visit while mass is not in session. The monastery is simple, yet beautifully carved. Amazing piece of local design. There is an entrance fee for this part.A trip to Lisbon isn't complete without coming here.

Beautiful monastery but I expected it to be bigger on the inside. The cloister of the monastery is truly amazing. Beautifully and in small detail decorated stone walls and pilars were absolutely beautiful. Also the chapel was quite nice. Judging from outside, i expected to see much more on the inside. It is quite small site after all and not much more than the cloister and the church. For that 10 euros admission was quite a lot. (Luckily I got -50% with student card though).

Superb. One of the highlights of our trip. Well worth a visit and discounted student entry was a bonus! Very impressive and a must see for anyone visiting Lisbon. Catch the 15 tram from central Lisbon. It is worth buying tram tickets at a 'paypoint' available in shops before travel as it is much cheaper than buying the tickets on the tram.

Very pretty building. I was too late to go in the monastery, as it was already 17.00 o'clock. But I did go in the church, which was very nice. The building is really nice and has a serene appearance. Definitely worth the visit, although the Belem-area is a bit overrated...

Best of Belem and Portugal - must to visit here and around!. From Rossio square or Lisbon square, we took a (crowded) tram to reach Belem in around 30 minutes. Jeronimos monastery is beautiful - outside is white and magnificient, inside had square shapped corridor - glittered in gold color structures. Our key expectation of this trip was to visit Vasco Da Gamma, after all he came so far to reach our India. He was resting in peace here at this monastery church . Cathedral was very beautiful inside and outside. We walked all the way upto Discovery monument (not very far) which looked like a boat in one side and a big sword at the front.
