From this place, all of Belem tower, Discovery monument, San Franciso replica Bridge and Brazil replica Jesus were visible and presents a beautiful look. Dont miss to try a Portugal sweet dish from Pasteis de Belem and it was really tasty. Fountain in front of Jeronimos Monastery is huge and very beautiful. On return we took a taxi and it came around 9 Euros as we waited for tram for long and it did not turn up. This place should not be missed if you are coming to Lisbon.
Monestary. Beautiful church (which was free to enter) and great monestary. Was a neat visit and the tart place was close by to refuel.
Jaw-droppingly beautiful. Number 15 tram from Praça de Figueres takes you right there. Ignore what your old guidebook says about it being free to enter on Sundays.
amazing carved stones. Breath taking views. And stones. Man, stones they carved like it was wood. Just take a wall, follow the corridors, look at everything.

Really interesting. Well worth paying to see the whole building and archeological section. The tower is also worth paying for. There is a military museum, not mentioned in my guide book that was worth a visit as we were in the area

Beautiful place. Interesting place with nicely prepared educational components. Quite far from town and near the costline.There is no metro station nearby but there is overground train station.We had to buy additional ticket as 24h ticket didn't cover overground. Beautiful piece of architecture worth every penny.

A Lisbon "Kodak crack" therefore yes a must to see. Although we went on a wet,cold Febuary day the numbers of visitors were still slightly too many for an un ticked venue to hold .A single venue that encapsulates the great history the world owes to Portugal with the marine exploration history,the European tumults of history ,religion,art and architecture all present on a trip to Belem .Maybe an early or late time would make the visit more memorable?
Over priced. We paid 12 euro each to go in definitely over priced you can go into the church for free which is recommended.

Spectacular to visit.. Worth the trip down the Belem area just for this...we were lucky enough that the South Portal was open when we visited.... stunning entrance. And well worth to pay the extra few euros for entrance out to the Cloisters.

Remarkable place. Some stunning architecture, and a very interesting timeline display which puts the monastery in context of Lisbon and European history. One must wonder what a religious order were doing building such an opulent establishment- but it's not unusual in Catholic countries.

Amazing - must see!. This place is amazing! The detail on everything, I can't imagine the hours put into all the work to make it so beautiful. Kids might find it boring, but anyone who appreciates architecture should see this place. A short taxi or tuk-tuk ride from the Belem Tower (which is a short train ride from Lisbon), easy to combine in a visit. Highly recommend as it is really breath-taking to see the detail put into everything.

Incontournable. A must see in Lisboa.You can visit the church fort free.In the neighborhood other exhibitions.Walk in the cloister and enter the rooms to discover exhibitions.A very interesting place.
Worth the entrance fee.. A very beautiful and interesting building with English and Spanish information available. It's also very close to Pastéis de Belem. (The oldest pastela shop)
Definitely worth a visit. We visited this monastary on a cold and very wet day. It was an excellent way to spend an hour or so.

A MUST see!. This was an incredibly important stop on our travels. It really added to our understanding of the architectural aspects of Portuguese history, and the tomb of Vasco da Gama is a must. Do not miss it!

The origins of the famous pasteis. The Mosteiro has to be visited when in Lisbon. It is a large and interesting building. The highlight of our visit was the temporary exhibition with a very detailed timeline of the monastery / Lisbon / and the rest of the world.

Amazing event for today . I recommend a good foto camera to visit this monument.
Its amazing to see how Portugal was só advanced in that era!
A proud to be Portuguese.

Situated in a nice area.. Great monument, with a nice surrounding. I would suggest to walk there by the coast, especially in a sunny day. If not in the mood, there is a train from LISBON center that will take 5/10 minutes to Belem station. Be aware that you'll have to buy a different ticket from the metro ticket.

One of the Most Beautiful Buildings in Portugal. Distinctly magnificant Portuguese Architecture with plenty of world history. This is probably the most picturesque buildings in all of Portugal. A visit should be on all tourist itineraries. This place is hard to describe and capture with pictures. You just have to visit to experience its magnificence. To the left there are several museums and to the right is a very beautiful church.
Great place. Visited this monastery on a sunny day together with torre de belem. The architecture is impressive and the church (free to visit) is also amazing

Amazing architecture in a unique neighborhood. If you are visiting Lisbon, you must see this old monastery. It is simple as that. They simply don't build things this beautiful anymore. The design and architecture of the building, the church and the cloister are breathtaking. This is a simple stop that can be accomplished in under an hour for the schedule-oriented traveler. It also lies in the unique neighborhood of Belem (Bethlehem) which is inundated with shops, bars, and restaurants.

Portugal’s history and pride. This is one of Lisbon’s must do and in fact after being here, you will understand the country’s glorious past. Vasco da Gama and Camões are buried here and that pretty much says it all, aside from bing a beautiful monastery.

Beautiful inside: makes you (almost) want to join a church. You can see now how the church recruited people. You walk into the space and your jaw drops. I was a bit reluctant to spend €10 to get in but it was stunning. Not huge, but we still managed to spend a few hours between the rooms.

Beautiful. Well worth the trip to see this astonishing building. Just breathtaking, and strangly peaceful, even with crowds of people visiting. The Tower of Balem is also worth looking at when you are there.

Essential place to visit in Belim. This is one of the main sights in Lisbon and a must see - currently part of the building is undergoing renovation but it is still a great place to see - Perhaps get there early as it clearly gets very busy. But it is also located in the Belim area where you can walk along the port area and visit other sights such as the Torre de Belim- can easily spend a half day or more in the area

Take me to church!. Stunning!...an absolute must if you're in Lisbon, a journey full of rich Portuguese history.The architecture is truly breathtaking, with a beautiful court garden in the centre of the building. A real feast for the eyes & it's free to enter.

Magnificent Example of Portugese Architecture. The exterior shows no clue of what waits within this imperessive monastery.Take your time to examine the fine points on each of the columns in the courtyard. The entire surrroundings easily conveys a sense of another era. Not to be missed.

Stunning place. Worth the trip down to Belem for this and Torre de Belem. 10 euros for entry and for that you get to look round the monastery and the church. Both are stunning and the level of detail in both really is something else. Definitely worth the trip.

Beautiful church. Very nice church. One of the nicest churches I have seen and without entree fee. Lot of things to see. You can go to a special part for 3 euro. Can't say that was worth it. But rest of the church is worth a visit.
Lovely. Just amazing! Beautiful church and surroundings . There's alot to see in here a must ! Another great piece of history

Beautiful. I can not reccoment enough the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. When we went in we just took a sit and froze for some priod of time. So beautiful. Would definitely back again if get the chance. Buy a comby ticket with Belem and skip one queue.
Amazing place!!. Great architecture, great city, i love Lisbon. Don't forget the pasteles de belem, are really good :)
It's beautiful. The architecture is very beautiful, the day we went we couldn't see inside, but my husband went some years ago and said it worth it.

Well worth the visit. We used our Lisbon card to travel out to Belem and had free entrance here using the card also. What a beautiful building! It was bust there but at the same time peaceful. Loved it!
transcending beauty. spectacular from both the outside and inside. definitely worth more than one visit. just sitting in the courtyard of the monastery gives u a wonderful sense of serenity
Vasco da gama resting place. Didn't have time to do the whole tour. Had nice selfie with wife in front of the monastery. Within walking distance of the discoveries monument.

Is all true. Amazing architecture that looks like the perfect scenario for a movie. You should not only visit the church (that is free) but the Mosteiro also (they have student discount). There are many activities you can do near here in the same day and one of the closest is to eat the Pastel de Belem, is delicious. :D

Great Spiritual, faith and religious significance!. One of things we want to visited when we arrive in Portugal.The Monastery was built in the Manueline style (after king Manuel of Portugal). In 1983 was included in the World Heritage list by Unesco. We visited the Monastery as part of an European tour we did in 2015, we had a tour guide who was extremely important to get all the details and history behind the monastery.

A must see in Lisbon. This is a jaw-droppingly beautiful place, fully deserving its World Heritage status. The intricate cloisters are dazzling works of sculptural decoration and the church is both magnificently ornate and structurally austere. Wonderful.

Cloisters reveal a riot of stunning carving. Tram 15 deposited us right outside the huge facade of this amazing monastery. The Lisboa card allows free entry into the complex and covered the travel to it.An English audio guide is available at no extra cost (you just need to deposit a document with the desk to secure the handset's return) and I would recommend it as it has a lot of information to impart apart from the basic trail (so you can either skim round on the basic tour or go into more depth as your taste/time constraints determine).There is a lot of detailed carving in the cloisters - nautical emblems, flora and fauna abound in a giddy and lively parade.Two exhibitions were very informative. The first, about Alexandro Herculano, an aptly named towering figure of learning, was a fascinating insight into Portugal's 19th Century history. The second was an exhibition on the Monastery's, and Portugal's development and history which entwined with the world's time line. Cleverly presented and informative
Nice architecture, but not worth the price tag. Interesting monastery, but overall there wasn’t much to see and the price tag was not worth it (10 euro to enter).

The architecture!. The architecture of this building is just magical. There were also few exhibitions inside, but there's nothing interesting comparing to the building itself. See the inside balconys and chapel.

Beautiful. We took the tram from downtown Lisbon which took about 20 minutes or so to Belem and got off right outside the monestary. It's about 10 euros to get inside and i'd say thats a bit steep however i'm glad i went inside. The archetecture is really something and i found it really peaceful to wander round just taking it all in. The church part (which is free to enter) was also really impressive.
What a beautiful building. Well worth the tram ride to Belem. If you head out early in the day you will avoid the cues. A well preserved historic building.
Very impressive outside. Only went to see the church (free admission). It looked very impressive from outside and I think it's best to be watched from distance.

Reason to visit Belem. This was one of my top 3 things to visit in Lisbon and I was not disappointed. There was virtually no Q and were in within 5 mins. Admission is €10.00 per adult which is ok. Note- admission to the church only is free (entry is on right hand side of the entrance Q)

Not worth the money you spend. I kept a half day reserve for Jeronimos and the Belem and got down across the monastery, while travelling by public bus. Nothing much could impress me as some portion of the monastery was not open for the tourists. It was'nt a value for money compared to the entrance fee. On the contrary the church outside the monastery which has free entrance is worth visiting.
UNESCO World heritage site- wonderful. It is a must visit when in Lisbon. It is also near the Belem tower and downtown Belem where they serve pastel de nata... Yummy!!!!

Well worth a visit. Took the tram which was hideously overcrowded but the monastery was well worth the visit. Even my museum/church/culture hating children enjoyed wandering around - helped that we had a beautiful sunny day!
Sight seeing. Impressive building and adjoining gardens. Nearby the famous custard tarts - delicious. Easy to get to by train or bus from centre.
Worth the walk. We walked from the central of Lisbon and it was a challenge, but worth it. Lots to see in the close vicinity, too.

Experience tour of building. We took the option to enter the building which cost 10e each - it was very expensive for an entry rate as you can get into the church for free which comprises much of what you can see for 10e. The only addition is that you can walk around a small courtyard.

Spectacular. This is one one of the most beautiful buildings we've ever visited. It's busy but you don't notice. Photography is allowed and there's lots to capture. The adjoining church is also worth a visit.
Really nice outside, rather poor in inside. If you have time and money go inside, it's nice. If don't - you won't miss anything special. It's definitely too expensive

Mosteiro dos Jeronimos: history in itself. A must visit to anyone in Lisbon, it is a monument to the Age of Discoveries and a place where you find the tombs of famous Portuguese such as Dom Manuel I, Dom Joao III, Cardinal D.Henrique, Luis de Camoes and Vasco da Gama. Beautiful gardens, church and fantastic architecture, since 1983, it is one of Unesco's World Patrimonies.
Magnificent building. Beautiful location and steeped in history of St Jerome' s travels from Bethlehem. Within walking distance of several other places of interest.
Great experience. This is another must visit for any tourist. The gardens are beautiful and the church and the museum has ornate architecture which is mesmerising to the eye.

Lovely church . This is definitely worth the trip to Belem to see. It's a classic gothic church with high vaulted ceilings. You can just visit the church for free; the entrance was on the right of the long queue of people lining up to pay to go into the cloisters. The cloisters are worth paying to see and considering the queue it felt quiet inside and we had the time and space to enjoy the beautiful architecture. You also gain access to the balcony of the church.

Not just a great architecture. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, Lisbon (near Torre de Belem) is a great architectural piece and full of history. It´s also a place to get married (I´ve seen it on my last visit). Being a symbol of Portugal, not just Lisbon, it was fairly linked to the "Age of Discoveries" when the brave Portuguese explorers left from the port nearby to "conquer" new lands.

Atmospheric . This monastery and church took 100 years to build and when you see the intricacy of the carvings you can understand why. The church itself is free to enter and with its high arched ceilings, tombs and many naves it is quite atmospheric. The monastery next door costs €10 or €12 if you buy the ticket for Tower of Belem. There is a central courtyard and two storey cloisters. There again you can imagine the monks walking along the stone corridors. Upstairs in one of the rooms there is an exhibition on the time line of Portugal alongside the rest of the world. Quite interesting to read.A visit is highly recommended.

Definitely worth visiting!. Interested in history and architecture? Go for it. Not a religious person? Who cares?! The place deserves a visit and you should take your time to admire the beauty of the architectural style of the monastery. Besides, there's a very interesting exhibition about Alexandre Herculano, who played a very important role in Portuguese history. To top everything, devote some time to visit Portuguese poet Fernando Pessoa's tomb: his words have the ability to make your heart shake with the vibe, passion and musicality of Portuguese language.

Impressive architecture. Stopped off here after visiting Estoril on a day trip from Lisbon. The monastery is a 10 minute walk from the railway station across the park. Entrance to the impressive church is free though there is a charge for the museum.

Amazing. Although I had only two days for Lisbon, and half a day for this Monestary, this is the place I like the most. I could actually stay there all day. It felt so calm and peacefull. The people who work there were so kind to explain everything to us, even though we didnt pay for the guide. That was a really good gesture. This is the place which I would go back for sure.

An Interesting Place to Visit. It is a very attractive building so just going to look at the outside of the building is very worth while. The tour inside does not take very long, the Museu Calouste Gulbenkian takes at least three times as long, but it is interesting and worthwhile.

Walking among history . This building has seen many stories through out it's lifetime. It's architecture is beautiful. Especially the cathedral next to it which has the tomb of the famous Vasco de Gamma.

Beautiful architecture.. Lovely Manueline building - all the columns and arches have different carvings and you can play spot the gargoyle/animal with so many different creatures hidden in the carvings. A great little history display too that puts world, Portuguese and the monastery history on three separate timelines. You can visit the church and cloister and close surrounding rooms - the actual building itself is much larger though didn't investigate if that's ever open to the public. I visited with a Lisbon card as there are several other museums in the Belem area.

Astonishing beautiful!. We were luckily to visit the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos free, because on the first Sunday of Feb. The architecture is simply gorgeous and you may feel the time of the building when you walked around. Simply astonishing!
Very interesting place to visit. Be careful if you go on the first Sunday of a month, this, and many other, sites are free, and the queues can be long. ?But despite the wait it was worth a visit.

Incredible.......beautiful...... It has to be a sight not to miss when visiting Lisboa. Truly breathtaking, the outside alone enchanting just wait until you go inside......stunning just stunning........

Beautiful!. It is a beautiful church from both inside and outside. If you love architecture and history this must be on your list! The entire area is nice, Belem is nearby and should be visited as well, plan to spend at least half a day in the area.

Monumental work of architecture . An impressive architectural work and a landmark of Lisbon. A must visit for tourists. Lots of historical data. Make sure you ask for the e-guide at the entrance it's worth it and no extra-charge for it.

Super. the great place to see and to reast a little.
Fantastic history of this place. And the pastel de belem?? great!
Historical church. The architecture is unique, this place is huge and beautiful, if you love history, this is a place you must visit,beautiful and very meaningful ⛪️
Amazing, jaw droppingly awesome!. Just an amazing, jaw droppingly awesome building AND because it was the first Sunday of the month entry was free. What else to say but very hIghly recommended?

Amazing!. Gorgeous! A must see for anyone visiting Lisbon. We visited while a festival was ongoing (some sort of Fatima statue), so we didn't see as much of it as we would have liked, but what we did see was fantastic

Dodged in out the Wet, and it was wet!. Queued for a good 15 minutes to buy a ticket, TIP, buy online prior to visit and skip the queue.The visit is to the cloisters that are on two floors that are somewhat unusual.Two good expositionsVery dark church, decadent adornment, but that is not unusual for churches of that age.Is it worth the entrance fee, grudgingly "Yes"
Amaizing. If you are in Lisbon don't miss this place. The architecture is absolutely breathtaking and it s really easy to reach!!!

Beautiful Building but not much on the inside. The building is gorgeous but had it not been free on the Lisbon card I may have felt a little cheated. There is an interesting display comparing the history across three locations and how that fitted in with the monastery but very little else that we saw. If you do go though don't go into the church first...the best view that is quite breathtaking can be had from up on an inside balcony...but if you just want to see the church you can do that for free downstairs

An architectural wonder at the heart of Portuguese culture. An absolute must to see. Even through the original structure dates from before, the actual construction of the monastery was completed in 1601. The monastery is one of the most prominent examples of the Portuguese Late Gothic Manueline style of architecture in Lisbon. It was classified a UNESCO World Heritage Site, along with the nearby Tower of Belém, in 1983.The monastery is walking distance to a number of interesting places including the Cultural Center of Belem, The Monument to the Discoverers, close to the famous Pasteis de Belen bakery and to two great wine restaurants: Descobre and Enoteca de Belem.

Church of Santa Maria. My wife and I visited the Church of Santa Maria, which is part of the Jeronimos (St Jerome) Monastery in Belem, Portugal.We were impressed by the ornate side entrance with its Manueline style architecture and symbols. The interior of the church is beautiful, peaceful and prayerful. It was interesting to find the tomb of Vasco da Gama, the Navigator, in the church.
Fabulous monoment. A trip to Portuguese history, with the possibility to see also the maritime museum and therefore understand the Portuguese discoveries started on Modern Age
Very interesting Place. Impressed by size of dining room. Very well arranged for visit. Stone carvings are amazing. Not very crowded even on weekends
Pretty if you're in the area. The area is pretty with lovely gardens and the Monastery has gorgeous stonework. Apart from that though there's not a huge amount to see or do

"Magnificent Monastery". This magnificent Monastery is not only a remarkable piece of architecture but also as integral part of Portuguese culture and identity.Exquisite stonework ,vaulted ceilings and quadrangular layout will definitely charm your vision.In case you are not using a Lisboa Card, it is best to buy a combined ticket for the monastery with either the Belem tower or museum or both, definitely a better deal.

Interesting place, expensive entry price. And interesting place to visit. Was quite busy on a Sunday, even for low season (late November). We found the entry price (I don't have the receipt so can't quote exactly) a bit much for what was in there, but it was still worth a visit. The cathedral is also nice.
Amazing. If you are in Belem you need to see this incredible historical site! It is beautiful and if you want to pay for a ticket to go inside you can see even more of it.
magic place. Really beautiful place, the cloister is probably one of the best in the world. The place is also well mantained, magic atmosphere.
Beautiful. It was a beautiful visit. The people were very friendly. The building was in a good condition, everything was very clean.

MOSTEIRO DOS JERONIMOS NEXT TO SANTA MARIA DE BELEM CHURCH. MOSTEIRO DOS JERONIMOS (10euro lisboa card free) next to SANTA MARIA DE BELEM CHURCH (FREE ENTRANCE )is a must see monument.It was even more beautiful than the pictures I admired earlier, for me together with SANTA MARIA DE BELEM next door and TORRE DE BELEM and the new MUSEU NATIONAL DOS COCHES the highlights of Belem.Interesting expo on circular wall on history of the MOSTEIRO DOS JERONIMOS,PORTUGAL,GLOBAL HISTORY,PORTUGESE ROYAL FAMILY.Nice gardens on Rua dos Jeronimos.

Amazing display of architecture. When in Lisbon with some time at hand, the monastery is a must see, not least because of its spectacular architecture. Somewhat expensive with 10 EUR per person for the one hour it takes to explore the property (incl church which, as a stand-alone unit, can be visited free of charge. Go early in the day before the groups arrive which can be quite noisy. A special treat for school classes is the Portuguese language act explaining the history of the place. The monastery can be reached with public transport, stop BELEM. While there, you may also visit the Torre de Belem. All in all, a half day experience.
Visited just the church. Magnificent exterior designs on the church, spent some time looking inside.paid the E1.50 to visit sacristy worth seeing the chalices, wooden vestment cupboards and art work.

Beautiful, unspoilt monastery. The cloisters here are remarkable, the stonework is beautiful and very ornate and you can walk round them at an upper level too. The views inside, again, worth going up,to the gallery are impressive. It seems higher then many cathedrals with more glorious stonemasonry on the columns. The maritime museum which is housed in a wing of the monastery is separately reviewed.
Amazing architecture. This was actually quite unique. I've never seen a monastery with such interesting architecture before. Worth a visit. Note that you can see the church itself for free.

Great building but not used to its best. This is a building that just oozes local history and significance but if you didn't know that then you wouldn't know that from this visit. The information provided is poor and the staff seemed completely bored and just there for a job. If it has a curator I'd sack them

Ornate and attractive . Take the No 15 tram from the centre of Lisbon to get you here. The church is free to see but you need to pay to see any more. We enjoyed it and bought a ticket that included Belem Tower.A good value day out

A World Heritage site. This Monastery from the 15th Century and was built in the Manueline style (after king Manuel of Portugal), which is a late rendition of the Gothic. In 1983 was included in the World Heritage list by Unesco.

Wonderful monastery. First off the beautiful two storey cloister is really amazing (the first of its kind in Portugal), built in the Manueline style, they columns and arches have some superb decorations regarding nautical themes (typical of the Manueline).On the upper part are the tombs of portuguese novelist and historian Alexandre Herculano, and famous writer Fernando Pessoa.The visit then continues in the free part of the complex: the church. Among the many important tombs located here of several kings of Portugal, right at the entrance are the more modern tombs (late 1800s) of the famous explorer Vasco da Gama and famous poet Luis de Camoes, which are thought to contain their bones.

Beautiful and interesting monastery. We enjoyed walking around the monastery.The site is very impressive and has a number of highlights including grand rooms and tombs of prestigious people including Vasco de Gama.

Beautiful architeture. This is an amazing building full of history and great stories. They have a really interesting room where you can learn a lot about royal families all over Europe and how they entwined between them with marriages that achieved them territories and power.A must see place in Lisbon!

Lovely. This is a busy spot but worth it. You can get a modern tram down to this part of town form the commercial centre. Lovely views and you are right next door to the Belém Pastry shop for coffee and tarts - on week days you will get a spot!

History incarnate. Lovely big church and the monastery / museum area is well worth a visit too. Esp. liked the time-line history of the building placed against world events. Hated seeing people taking selfies in front of Vasco de Gama's tomb.

Very grand interior, worth a look if you're in Belem. The outside of the monastery is beautiful but as you enter the building you're greeted by intricate stone work and a huge church. Definitely go inside, it's worth it!

It's big! Free if you're not visiting the museum area.. Very popular attraction and even for a complete atheist worth a visit! The church appears unnecessarily large but the masses need to be impressed I guess. Tombs of major Portuguese figures including Vasco da Gama and Luís de Camões. Belum has several attractions so you don't need to go to only see this edifice. Worth a walk through while you're in town.

Great monastry to visit. Beautiful form the outside and very much worthwhile to visit the inside. It is a pity that not much is seen from the real life in the old days at this place. But it is still great to walk around.

One of the most decorative churches in Portugal!. This is a little out of the way, but definitely worth making an effort to see. Go early to avoid lines to see the cloisters. The church has a massive vaulted ceiling, highly carved alter, and an exterior highly carved with images of saints and pinnacles. Jerónimos was once populated by monks of the Order of St Jerome, whose spiritual job for four centuries was to comfort sailors and pray for the king’s soul. When the order was dissolved in 1833, the monastery was used as a school and orphanage until about 1940.

Fabulous building and excellent displays. This was definitely the highlight of our visit to Lisbon. The architecture is wonderful and the exhibition displays were very informative. You can easily spend an hour or two here.
Amazing. Can be overwhelming, so best to consider doing some/part of the mosteiro, rather than the whole thing, if you have kids. However, a great place to stroll and take on history!

A must visit in Lisbon- Belem. Located in Belem, the monestary is easily accessible by bus. It is a gorgeous building with intricate manuelin architecture and beautiful white stone. The cloister is absolutely gorgeous. If you like taking pictures, there are many opportunities for beautiful shots. Spend the time to meander and stop to appreciate the craftmanship and beauty.It is best to buy a combined ticket for visiting the Mosteiro and the Belem Tower.
Beautiful and Interesting. Fantastic architecture, the inner courtyard is really nice and it's an interesting place to spend and hour or so wandering around, learning about its history.

Cool Architecture but Needs More Content. The monastery has very little information on what the day to day life of monks in this monastery looked like. So, it's easy to admire the actual building, but it was harder to come away with more than that.

Got to go! Preferably on a sunny day. Just an amazing experience to be there. Get a great feel of Manueline architecture. The Church part is free but the Cloister not to be missed. Once you go upstairs from the Cloister, then you can also view the Church from there to see a different perspective. The ticket sales is also done at the Archeological Museum next door, which is opposite side of the church entrance.
Ok. It is beautiful but the wait was long and compared to other church like buildings it was not the best.

beautiful place. easy to access from Baxia by bus 714 ,OW 180 €entrance fee for students 5 €wonderful place of history with the chapel next to it - still operating normal,the day we been there was a funeral in the chapel

Don't miss a visit to Jeronimos Monastery - Some Tips for you. Don't miss a visit to Jeronimos Monastery for any reason - the masterpiece of the Manueline Architecture, the most important monastery in Portugal.Some tips:- Avoid the long lines - arrive early- The church is free admission (only need to pay to see the cloisters)- Church is closed when mass service is happening. You can attend mass if you wish- There's big part of the monastery serving as museums (side entrances), like the Museu da Marinha (Navy Museum) for example.You cannot miss a visit to Jeronimos while in Lisbon. A place that took 100 years to be built, and represents an important part of our history, when Portugal sailed the world and had it's huge empire.

interesting, but don't go out of your way. The monastery was nice, especially the inner courtyard, which had some ornate architecture. but it doesn't compare to similar sites in Italy, for example, like Florence's Convent of San Marco and it's frescoes by Fra Angelico.

Every day is a perfect day to visit!. A huge monument that took almost 100 years to be finished. A phenomenal construction in the middle of Belém, in front of the Belém Garden and facing the Tejo River. An amazing monument that incorporates de Marine Museum and the Archaeological Museum, and it is home for one of the most impressive churches of Portugal! To visit it is good to come at any time, but if come earlier you can see and live more the history and the stories that surround this huge monument. All the information is provided there. This is part of the Portuguese History.

Great architecture. Visited the monastery as part of a tour group and found the architectural detail absolutely beautiful. I would have liked to stay longer to admire the grandeur of the building. The only disappointment was Vasco da Gama's tomb which was so crowded that I could only remain there a brief moment. I visited in the off-season so I hate to think how crowded the place would be in high season. It is certainly an attraction that should not be missed but be prepared to share the beauty with many others.
Beautiful. The architecture is very massive and beautiful. You will get a combined ticket with Torre de Belem, it's better to queau for the ticket here, as it's much longer in Torre de Belem.
Stupendous architecture. Stupendous architecture, very huge buit and you can take nice photos. It was closed to visitors when i went but it should be a great place inside.

Great monastery, bring sunscreen. i've never in my life seen anything like this, and don't expect to see anything like it ever again. That being said, either make sure you get your tickets in advance, be aware that you can get a combination ticket for the exhibit right next to it with small lines or bring a bucket of sunscreen, because i spent 40 minutes out in the sun waiting in line.

Astonishing architecture. Just beautiful stonework, brilliant building full of amazing details..... Spent quite some time finding great images in the carved images, grasshopper gargoyle, mythical beasts and botanical detail.
Monastery is beautiful!. It is a must to visit it from the inside. It is beautiful! Do not miss to visit nearby bakery which is making Pastel de Belem - very tasty!
Beautiful, Crowded & Worth a Visit. This was a really beautiful site. A bit crowded and the live tours provided to school groups were a noisy. But the architecture made up for it!

Must see. World heritage place, 500 y old building with nice history and story. Portugal wants to show with Vasco Da Gama hero and so their power. Beautiful architecture and a church inside. Also museums.
Interesting history, exhibitions and beauty. The museum contains the best world time line I've ever seen. It ties Portugal's history together with the world. Fascinating and well done.
GO, GO, MUST GO. History, the manuelin style, the discoveries, the beauty and balance. That´s why it´s World Heritage
Lisbon Vacation. Beautiful architecture. Easy to get to by Trolley. Lots of other sights in the vicinity. Even on a rainy day. Learned more Portugese history.
Beautiful Lisboa. Very interesting place to visit, outside and inside also. I like the architecture and the atmosphere.

Stunning. The monastery is one of the few old buildings to survive the earthquake that destroyed Lisbon in the 18th century. There are a number of attractions in the complex, including a marine and archaeological museum. The cloisters are stunning and a must visit for anyone with an interest in architecture. They also house a timeline exhibition paralleling world history, Portuguese history and the story of the monastery. The church was peaceful and free to enter.
Absolutely Huge. The architecture in this building is unreal. Full of ancient artefacts and beautiful stained glass windows.
Amazing monument. I just had a great time by visiting this monument. Just an astonishing visit for the best city in the whole world
Amazing National Monument. Really beautiful church and gardens. All the surroundings convey the sense of an epic Portuguese era. Generally busy and fresh in the summer.

Majestic and beautiful. Monastery is beautiful, but you cannot see the monks mode of life, only courtyard is available, however it was nice.Church is great, there is a tomb of great discoverer Vasco da Gama

Marvelous building with great transport links.. This building has amazing architecture and is simply beautiful to visit. Before you even worry about getting here, there are amazing transport links either by tram or bus. You can even come and visit at December because there shall still be some sun and sunshine. (can rain sometimes, not a lot though) Lastly the admission is for free, which if you are on a budget is perfect for some sight seeing.

As nice as in my child memories. First place I wanted to go and see again after so many years without visiting Lisbon. Manuelin architectural style is unique and only in some places in Portugal, a must see. The cloister is magnificent, could spend the day scrutinizing details and feel the stone changing tonalities according to the light and moment of the day. For those interested in culture or in photography. Discovery monument, the Belem Tower and the pathway along the Tagus river are all at an easy reach, a great day altogether provided you wear comfy shoes!
You need to go here. Lovely building with many interesting facets to it, Vasco de Gamas tomb, lovely interior just well worth a visit
Beautiful . Quite impressive , the free admission itself is worth visiting and going further inside (we took the €10 tour) was fascinating. All in all, a beautiful place to visit
Best in Lisbon. If you only have time to visit 1 attraction in Lisbon, I will recommend the grand Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. Quite spectacular.

Stunning Architecture. This was such a treat! We went during low season so there were very few other tourists and we could enjoy the beautiful architecture essentially to ourselves. The gargoyles are stunning and the shadows were beautiful! What a lovely morning!

A marble jewel. Look at it from far, look at it from close, get inside and taste the solemn atmosphere of the rich architecture of this monastery. When you get out you have the feeling of having contemplated an lived a historical moment.

Amazing architecture. If you are into historical churches and similarly related buildings then this monastery is well worth a visit if only for the spectacular architecture. The available pictures say much more than any words can do it justice.

Must visit place. The monastery is breathtaking and l think it is worth visiting. Also, they have a good collection of stone monuments in archaeological department. If you don't have money for entrance, go to the church - it is free and magnificent.

it's huge, and incredible inside. one of the most amazing churches I've been in. it's in excellent condition, has very intricate carvings in the stone, and a lovely carved wood alter that is gilded in gold. Definitely worth visiting, you will be right next door anyways for an egg tart!
Amazing, one of the best church architecture ever. Visit the church and the rest of monastery, which is truly worth visiting: beautiful ceiling, superb craftwork, cannot be be missed!!!!

A Masterpiece!. This place is amazing! A true masterpiece and a never-ending source of picture opportunities! I went there on a rainy day and nevertheless I was able to enjoy the place to the fullest. I have never been an art expert but I could really appreciate both the interior and exterior parts of the monastery. Make sure you have a Lisbon Card on the day of the visit, so you will be able to skip the very long queue that builds up during the day. Enjoy your visit!

Must see!. This is the place which needs to be visited once you're in Lisbon! Besides reach history, it's full of hidden beauty. Definitely worth those 20-ish minutes spent in the queue for tickets :)
Breathtaking site!. This monastery is magnificent beyond our imagination. We only had an hour and we wish we set aside more time to appreciate everything...
Beautiful. Well worth the trip to Belem as so much to see there. The monastery was lovely and the church exquisite. A huge site with many attractions to suit everyone.

A Breathtaking Church. I have spent many years in Europe and the Mosteiro was incredible! The interior as well as the exterior of this beautiful church have mind blowing ornamentation. Take time to take it all in.
Great heritage. Very large historical place. Little bit far from the center of the city but you can use tram. Near here there are famous cafe of Pastis de Belem and also Padrao dos Descobrimentos.

Great. The church itself is pretty amazing. I definitely recommend this place to visit. Look very close for the little things. An example is the mini bottles with wine in it. They were hidden and behind the elephants right paw. Definitely take your time to see everything. I don't recommend going to the cloister. It's really not worth it. I had 50% discount, but it still wasnt worth it.

Beautiful . This place is definitely worth a visit. Jump on the number 15 team from town until you get there. The cloisters are absolutely stunning for a 10 euros entrance you get access to these and the church. Well worth a visit.
Crowds can be intimidating but visit for sure!. The architecture alone is worth the visit, but there are so many other historical things to see ! Plan on spending a few hours to indulge yourself.
Nice architecture . Free entry in the museum and church if you can provide at the security access your Lisbon Card! Polite stuff and the museum it's very organised.

Mandatory. If you are in this area, it is mandatory to visit the Monastery. It is a beautiful building, with lots of heritage and history. Sometimes a bit crowded, weddings at the door, but always majestic. Visit it.

The Monastery was the best!. The Church was very interesting, with tombs of Vasco da Gama and Luis de Camoes at the beginning of the nave. One particular cloister had an incredible amount of gold. The south portal was very ornate. One can imagine how returning sailors felt when they saw this on their return from long voyages. The Monastery was the best with gorgeous Manueline architecture. A perfect spot for photographers. Usually one has to pay to get into the Monastery except for the 1st Sunday of the month.

Bellísimo. The best of Lisbon Manueline cloister impressive. In January there were many people and we could enjoy this wonderful Portuguese architecture.We bought the ticket to visit the cloister and Tower of Belem 12 euros in total. The visit to the cathedral is free. Architectural and sculptural jewel of great beauty declared world heritage by Unesco.

Mesmerizing!. Belem is full of attractions, but Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is the most astonishing of them all. It's Gothic architecture is incredible and it is immense. You cannot even imagine that there was a monastery. You shall not miss this place, you won't regret it!

The place not to miis in Lisbom by all means. Overwhelming history, overwhelming building.
In the side visit and taste the Pasteis de Nata (there is usualy a wating line)

Arrive late in the day. We arrived just 30mins before closing and just visited the church part inside [ free admission].
We were able to walk about without with only a few people and this gave the place the serenity it needed .
Amazing Place. The place is fantastic, the architecture is amazing a must see place.You should see this place and visit the inside of the monastery it takes us back in time.

Worth a look but not worth the price !. Beware guidebooks - they tell you that this is free on Sundays, so we dutifully left it until Sunday to visit. Not true. What you are not told is it is only the first Sunday in each month that is free entrance. Having trekked across the city to see it, we decided to spend the ten euros for entrance. It is a stunning place but not really worth that much. The potted history of the world, the monastery and Portugal were interesting, but would I say it is a must - I think not.

Breathtakingly beautiful - a must see in Lisbon.. Absolutely worth the steeper than usual entrance fee (€10) as this permits you to go up to the second level of the majestic church and admire it anew from higher up (you can visit the church for free downstairs) as well as the awe inspiring cloisters again on 2 levels and a fascinating room which puts the Monastery into a historical and global context.

The best monastery to visit in Lisbon. Fantastic architecture worth a visit. The cloister is the jewel of this monastery, so please don't miss. Better to visit early hours as the queue on holiday is really long. It's a pity that there is no internet booking.

Beautiful, But not a Must See. Very beautiful, but if you've seen a lot of churches then it's nothing too spectacular. The church is free but you pay for the monastery. We went on a free day which is the first Sunday of each month. If you haven't seen a lot of Baroque European churches then check it out, if you have, don't feel bad about missing it.
Mosteiro dos Jerónimos. The Jeronimos Monastery is a monument to those who truly want to know Lisbon has to necessarily visit. I recommend

Steeped in history. One of the must see places in Lisbon. Busy day with long queues, but we started at Torre Belem where the queues were shorter and you can buy a double entry ticket. Cloisters were stunning and the chapel absolutely breath taking.
Awe inspiring. The architecture of this place alone is worth the visit. The history and the beauty inside are the icing on the cake.
Nice architecture. If you like old churches, this one had it all, very impressive. It was built in the 16th century and had extraordinary carvings.

Beautiful. Nice walk.. Even though it wasn't open on the day that we visited, it was such a pleasant place to talk around the outside of the building and enjoy the view of the fantastic architecture. It took us half and hour or so to walk to here from the Torre de Belem, but it's probably best to wait for the tram.

Beautiful. It was some what busy the day I visited. That said, I was able to walk around the monastery and view all of the beautiful architecture.
I also got to see the tombs of Vasco Da Gama and Luis Vaz de Camoes. Pretty cool.

Good.. Needs some restoration or at least good cleaning outside.Interior interesting including resting place of Vasco da Gama,etc.Good place for a little break (especially during January rain) before continuing to see other attractions.
Breathtaking. A definite must see on your trip to Lisboa. And, make sure to swing next door to Café Pasteis Beleme for the pastries!

Never seen anything like this before; great to see. The Cloisters are the main attraction, and well worth taking the time to visit. They are square and double storied. The carving is exquisite and very well restored/preserved. The overall scale is breathtaking.We particularly enjoyed the extensive timeline of the monastery's history over five centuries that is connected to parallel timelines for Portugal and the world. For foreigners with only a limited knowledge of Portugal's history this was very helpful in understanding the place. This exhibit is in a room on the upper level.
Wow. Just Wow. I didnt know Vasco da Gama's tomb was inside. I was very happy to see that. It's beautiful inside.

Amazing! One of the most important sites in Portugal.. This is one of the most beautiful monasteries in the world! A definitely must see especially if you're a history buff as this location played a big role in the Age of discovery.Make sure to pay and see the cloister! Known to be the most beautiful in Europe according to Rick Steves & I believe him.. It's amazing.
A must visit, but on pricey side. It is bit expensive, but get the ticket to all attractions and will work out OKish. Tomb of Great Portuguese explorer Vasco D Gama rests here too.

Amazing Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. incredible in visiting the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is the most representative of the Manueline style. Listed by UNESCO as a world heritage site despite the unfinished aspect of the monastery boasts the strength and monumentality expected to portray the naval power of the 16th century Portugal Erected by order of King Manuel I in 1501, has developed colonnade and arches of the cloister and guard the graves of national heroes like Vasco da Gama, Luis Vaz de Camões and Fernando Pessoa. Abroad and in the beautiful facade are mysterious details and mentions the Age of Discovery. It Definitvamente of the programs required in Lisbon.

Beautiful Cloister and Church. Of the attractions in the Lisbon area this one is on a grander scale. The architecture is beautiful on the outside while the cloister and church are the two most beautiful interior features. If you already have a ticket you may bypass the queue. Tickets for multiple attractions may be purchased at a reduced price.

Lines were too long and didnt get in. Would have loved to see the Monastery but after waiting for 30 minutes in line, we decided to just walk around and visit another attraction.The outside of the monastery is very impressive and the gardens across the street are a nice place to take a break and regroup.Even though we were not able to see this attraction we were not disappointed. Lisbon is a beautiful historical city and since we were able to spend 2 weeks we saw many other wonderful places.My personal opinion is that when people are on a limited time schedule they all tend to hit the most popular places. Thus, this being one of them.
Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. One of the most beautiful places I've visited. We arrived about an hour before closing and it wasn't crowed at all. Highly recommended.

It is a must in Lisbon. I don't like monasteries or churches but this monastery it is beautiful. I love it. On the first day of every month the entrance is free... but you need to go early in the morning to stay in the trail. You need to visit, you will like it for sure.
Magnificent cloisters and church. The archaeological collection is limited but the architecture of the cloisters and church should not be missed.
Not sure the inside is worth the trouble !. Nothing to set the world on fire inside ! Nice on the outside . It is okay if you have nothing else to do on a rainy day !
Beautiful . This place is for me the most beautiful monument in Lisbon, both outside and inside. It costs €10 to get in (church is free), but it's worth from every point of view. Must go in Lisbon!

A must do for any history or architecture lover. We took the trolley from the center of Lisbon and it dropped us off right Monastary. It is a must do while visiting Lisbon. Also we ate the pastries at the bakery next door, they were delicious. The Tower of Belem is something that can be skipped since there is not much to see from the inside.

Amazing . Such a beautiful place! Lose yourself in the glamour and drama and sheer peaceful tranquility of this stunning place.
Spend an hour or two just immersing yourself in the fantastic spectacle of this place.

Worth visiting. Free admission with a Lisboa card, but the lines are huge, so it's better to come early in the morning or late afternoon. Here you can see a tomb of Vasco da Gama and admire the architecture of the monastery.
stunning monastry. Beautiful building with superb stained glass windows and masonry work. If you are on a budget just visit the church part of the monastry, it's free!!!
Amazing building. A very beautiful and magnificent building with an extremely interesting place in Portuguese history. A must see in Lissabon.
Memorable. The architecture was amazing and some of the exhibits were amazing but I felt like there wasn't a lot to do so that's the only reason it didn't get 5/5.

Amazing! A "Must-Do" in Lisbon. The monastery in Belem, near Lisbon is an amazing piece of Manueline architecture -- unlike anything you have likely seen before. Of all the sights in Belem this is the one not to miss.

Wonderful place, but tricky journey to reach it. This place is absolutely lovely and it's definitely a must see while in Lisbon.However,reaching it was a bit of a hassle.The metro doesn't reach the Belem area, so we took the metro as far as we could, and then we took tram 15 from Praca do Comercio.10 minutes wait for it,then 25 minutes in the tram until the final destination.Us and all the other thousand tourists that wanted to visit the monastery had to stay like sardines inside the tiny tram until the monastery.On our way back,the tram ride was 40 minutes like sardines again,due to traffic.At the monastery, we had to queue for about 20-30 minutes to buy the tickets - so,if you can get them online or from Torre de Belem, please do so.
Talking stones. The best religious builging I've ever seen. A work on stone that let me petrified. I can't imagine how they could work so perfectly.

Was that it?. Belem was a great area to visit, and we were excited to see the hyped Mosteiro. The massive building was easy to find once we hopped off of the trolley. We checked out the church first and then bought our tickets for the monastery. The detail and the architecture of the cloister are stunning, but that was it. We literally walked around for about 30 minutes, and then asked, is that all? The building is so huge, but apparently the Mosteiro part is just a small part of it. Maybe the rest is a museum. Plus: The stonework in the cloister is as good as advertised. The exhibit (December 2015) on the history of the monastery in the context of Portuguese and world history was also interesting. Con: Really not much else to look at here.

Magical. Beautiful and unique architecture especially in the cloisters. Get there early in the day (they open at 10) to beat the crowds and get some nice photos in the mostly empty cloisters before they fill up with tourists. Great opportunity to walk around and admire the excellent craftsmanship in the stonework. The tomb of Vasco de Gama is busy but pretty neat. One if the best places to visit in the city.

great building, not so great exhibitions. Makes sense to have a Lisbon Pass as the tickets are quite expensive. Great building, but very bare interior. If you are not somehow a fan of Portugise history, it's hard to understand the exhibitions.

have to see this, to complete the Lisbon experience. go there in the morning. Not too crowded yet and the sun hits the arches on the middle square. After visiting it, only than take the time to make pictures outside. The sun will be at the front by than.

Worth the money. 10$ entrance fee. Can be comined with Belem Tower but only before 3.30pm. Really interesting architecture. Vasco de Gama tomb is in the church, which is the only part with free entrance.

it was nice to see but long lines. Worth seeing but would not put it on my top of the sites to see. We waiting too long in line to get in so a bit tired in walking through. It is one of the top sites but we felt it was a lot of walking for less to see.

Amazing monastery, if you're in Belem don't miss it!. It's a lot better than the tower of Belem, and the manueline architecture inside is wonderful! Its cloister is the most beautiful I've visited and the church that is also part of the monastery is great as well! Again, don't miss it!

Extremely boring church with a 10$ rip-off. This one was very boring. It's a giant cathedral but that's nothing if you've ever been to any major Italian cities. There are two floors of the Cathedral; ground floor is also open to worship and the top floor has an admission of 10$. There is absolutely NOTHING TO see up there. Just a few mediocre paintings and even these are stored behind some safety area. Certainly nothing special, so why would you restrict access to these? At least let the people examine a few awful paintings for 10$. Don't visit there if you don't have a week or something like that.

If you want to get combined tickets, get there before 3 p.m.. The monastery is quite impressive. If you have a Lisboa Card, and want to combined tickets for Belem Tower as well, get there before 3 p.m. They refused to sell them to us at 3:02 p.m. and without even asking gave us tickets to the Museum instead and sent us straight there. Monastery was nice, staff not so much,

A magnificent monestary. Upon entering the church I had a strong desire to just sit and be still. Unfortunately we were short on time and attempted to visit another day, but the church was closed. It is difficult to appreciate all it has to offer if you don't have the time. I was a bit annoyed with the gypsies outside trying to sell their "handmade" scarfs and trinkets. There are other places to sell goods.

Wowza! . This might be an extraordinary place to visit, but when we arrived, the line to enter went around the block! The outside was beautiful, although the main tower was in scaffolding for cleaning. Perhaps there is a way to avoid the line with previously purchased tickets. I did not have that.

Important monument to visit. We got here with our guide and he explained a few things in and outside. What I've noticed was a lot of people waiting to get inside or to buy ticket and it was really crouded. Nevertheless it's one of the most important things to see when you visit Lisabona.

Nice location, but Tomar is better.. The monastery is conveniently located near the monument of the discoveries and the tower of Belem, so at least you can see three major attractions in close proximity. The monastery is nice but I prefer the convent of Christ in Tomar. It's older and has a very unique oratory that you will not find anywhere else in Portugal. This monastery's claim to fame is the burial tomb of Vasco Da Gama.

Interesting and arrive early! . I arrived early and had to queue up a bit. This was one of the most confusing lines ever. There was a line to buy tickets but it also seemed like it was for people who already had tickets. If you want to go to the Church (free admission), you'll have to go into the entrance near where people are trying to enter the Monastery. The Monastery is pretty. You also get to learn some items in Lisbon's history. Worth a visit. I didn't add on anything to my general ticket, which was €10.

Spendor. This old monastery in the occidental side of Lisbon was built to celebrate Vasco da Gama's trip to India. It is spendid both inside and outside. It's worth searching for a guided toor. The building is full of small statues of kings, queens, sailor men and saints. The cloister has plenty of symbolism from the Portuguese "Golden Era" (15-16th century). The church was clearly built in two stages. I draw your attention to the pillars which - upon careful observation - are just like palm trees inside the church - as you expect in the tropical countries. A must!

Historic and Beautiful. You'll probably be in Belem so do stop in this beautiful monastery - church. Much history here to marvel at and read some captions. Visiting the church is free. Great photo ops from the exterior.
Interesting. It's an impressive place, a big building with really nice work on walls.Be careful to arrive a bit earlier before closing to get a chance to get in.

Access to the church is free. Entry to the church is free, though this is not immediately obvious. If you are facing the building, access to the church is on the right hand side. There is a separate queue for to access the church. To enter the monastery you need to pay the entry fee. This enables access to the cloisters, a small museum and also access to the upper gallery of the church. The building also contains the archeological and the maritime museum. If you have a few hours to spare, I would recommend a visit. There is a separate entry fee for both of these museums. The archeological museum does not have a cafe but the maritime museum does if you are feeling hungry.

Enjoyable walk. It was fun to roam the cloistered. We did find 1(& I believe the only) book in English in the gift shop. The small exhibit explaining the Royal Houses of Europe was interesting. We had a hard time finding the tombs of the kings of Portugal, as signs were confusing. The tombstones we were lead to were famous poets of modern Times, which although important were not what we wanted to visit. We still enjoyed this site, and found it pleased our teen photographers.

Largest monastery in Portugal . This monastery is well worth the visit. You can visit the church first and see the tomb of Vasco da Gama. You then go inside to the cloister and you can walk around and see the refectory the cloister itself and then go upstairs and see a museum on the history of Portugal and on the restoration of the monastery. The water used to come up very close to the monastery and this is the spot from which the Explorers used to say farewell to Lisbon, pray at the church front and then leave for the New World.

Beautiful. Beautiful monastery. I like the internal structures . The external of the building I also great to look at especially there is a be open space in the front of the monsters . Definitely worth a visit when in Lisbon .
Stunning. You have to go there at least once in your life..... The cloister is breathtaking as well as the interior.

Impressive. Although I never went inside, the monastery is quite impressive from the outside. I believe there is a charge to enter the monastery but the church is free. On sundays I think the church is free, but the queue can be insanely long since everyone wants to visit while it's free.
A must. It has a beautiful sense of space in an amazing style. We just wanted to stay here and spend time walking around and reading.

Stunning outside, nice inside. Magnificient monastary from the XVI century with a great exhibition of old articles from ancient periods inside as well as the tombs of the Portuguese navigator Vasco da Gama, one of the greatest and iconic writers Luís Vaz de Camões as well as the tombs of some of our most remarkable kings: Cardinal-King D. Henrique or D. Sebastião. Entrance in the church is free. However, you have to pay 10€ to visit inside and, honestly, I don't think the cloister is worth this price.
Interesting place to visit. Interesting place to visit to see a bit of the Portuguese culture. Architecture is fantastic. Would definitely recommend.

Must see in Lisbon. This is a top attraction in Lisbon you must visit. It is close to the Belem Tower and Monument of Discoveries. We took Tram 15 from Rossio to get there. Thanks to Lisboa card, the tram was included and so was the entry to this museum. Close by is the famour Pasties de Belem where you can savor on the pastels.I dont remember what the entry fee was since we used our Lisboa Card. Plan to spend around 1-2 hours touring the place.

Architectural Marvel. The size of this building looked to be about four city blocks long. We went on to learn that half is a monastery and not open to the public. We visited on a very sunny day. The interior of the church was massive and extremely dark which showed off the beautiful, colorful stained glass windows. We did not stay long as the crowds were overwhelming. We decided to spend the time walking along the waterfront with spectacular views of the 25 of April Bridge and Torre de Belem.
Must visit. This is a must see stop when you are in Lisboa. The monastery is huge and the interior cloister is very beautiful.

Beautiful interior. This is a must-see on the city tour and is a stone's throw away from the original Pasteis de Belem. The monastery is huge and the interior cloistwr is very beautiful. the ticket is not expensive and right outside is the Discovery Monument across the road.

You can't visit Lisbon an not see this! the architect is amazing an inside also beautiful. Also if you buy the city bus pass(I bought for 2 day's as it works out cheaper an you can jump on an off at different tourist points) an you also get a free 'Tak Tak' ride(like a small open taxi) I got it to the Belam Tower!

a must-see. The church, with the tombs of Vasco da Gama and the royal family, combined with the uniquely strange version of gothic, is itself a place unlike anywhere else in the world. Nothing prepares you for the initial view of the inner courtyard of the monastery. It is again as unique as the Gaudi cathedral in Barcelona. A sunny day is a plus, as the sun and shade add attraction to the architectural splendor.Be sure to check out the portals outside the building (including the one to the church), as they are simply masterful in their details and just the magnitude of decorations. I was surprised to see a tomb of Pessoa within monastery walls. He was one of the leading Portuguese writers of the early 20th century.
Just for the carvings.. The building is now used to house two museums, but the sheer size - combined with the intricacy of the stone carvings on the entrance portal are just breath-taking.

Amazing manueline style. The most characteristic expression of Portuguese typical art is concentrated in this beautiful monastery, concentrating the best expression of this true Portuguese style. Plants, animals, tiles and like lace decorations all blended together to create a spectacular final effect. Both the monastery and the church are beautifully kept and they are included in the Lisboa card, something you would buy as soon as landed, if you want to take the most of your stay in the city. A must see.

Can't miss it. In my younger years I visited Jerónimos very often with my parents and a few times in school visits. I've been there last friday and I think, after so many visits, still worths to go there. It is a place that is worth for the architecture and the historical heritage.You can visit it in family, with friends or in solo.And if you go there, please don't miss "Pasteis de Belém" and "Pasteis de Cerveja". These are very special cakes, which are sold nearby. "Pasteis de Belém" should be eaten hot and the "Pasteis de Cerveja"can be eaten hot or cold. Are specialties not to be missed.

Magnificent ... a must go to destination im Belem. Spent a day touring this magnificent building and its surroundings. There is so much to take in. Magnificent Architecture ... great history. A must go to destination while visiting Lisbon.

Nice!. Nice place to visit in Lisbon. It's possible to save a bit of money if you buy your ticket to the Monastery together with that for the Tower of Belem. The tomb of Vasco da Gama is inside the church, on the left after entering through the main entrance. As far as I could figure, access to the church itself is free. The Monastery is an easy walk away from the Tower of Belem, but this area is a little far from the city center.

Great architecture. Historical treasure.. Some of the most beautiful Portuguese architecture is found in the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. It is well worth a visit along with the many other excellent attractions around Alges, such as the Monument to the Discovers, Torre de Belem, and Ajuda Palace.

A Must.. Based in Belem, this would be my top place to visit in the Lisbon area. Built around 1500 to celebrate a voyage of Vasco de Garma it does that in a big way. Intricate stonework, a wonderful atmosphere and enough history to fill over two hours at least, this is a must. Can be linked up with a ticket to Belem Tower (highly recommended) and the archeological museum (not so impressed.)

Far from the city center!. We reached it only by the bus tours, quite far from all the other activities. During the winter it closes at 17.00, if you get there late, nu chance to visit it. Beautiful architecture, nothing else to do around.

Obliged visit of a masterpiece. This wonderfull monument composed by church and cloister divided in 2 levels, is an obliged Lisbon icon; built in a true portuguese style (manueline), is a really a masterpiece of art where richness of the age of discoveries is well showed.Important figures are buried there: kings, Vasco da Gama the discover of the trail to India, the best portuguese poet (Luís de Camões)...Besides is considered world heritage.

Shhh, the free line is on the right!. Long lines were forming when we arrived and the longest was on the left. I could see a sign saying that admission would be charged and that this it was a UNESCO World Heritage site. Since we have been unimpressed with the way other World Heritage sites are run (Pont du Gard, Newgrange), we were unimpressed and started looking for a reason to leave. Suddenly a man came out of the office and closed our line and moved many of us to the end of a much longer line that had already formed. While waiting now in the much longer line, we took a close look at a shorter line to the right. It said Free Entrance to the church. Since this is all we really wanted to do we bailed out of the paying line and went through the free entrance, thus avoiding the whole UNESCO fiasco. On entering the church there were Silence signs everywhere which was funny because there was construction going on within with ear-splitting jackhammers working. We admired the interior of the church, paid our respects to Vasco de Gama and then headed out to see the Marine Museum.

Beautiful building. Definitely worth a stop and viewing. This attraction is near the ocean and with four other attractions to visit at the same time. there is an underground passage to get to the other attractions. Worth the time.
impressive. this building is very impressive, only went to the church as was short of time but even for photos from outside its well worth a visit when in the Lisbon area

Such an interesting timeline inside the building. The best part was this timeline they have, comparing what was happening in the world, at Portugal and at the Monastery. You can spend a whole hour just seeing it.

Best place to visit in Lisbon. The fabulous church has the most exotic carvings all over the walls, carved in deep relief. Among the most impressive I have ever seen. It also houses the tomb of Vasco da Gama who discovered the route to India by sailing around what is now South Africa. Well worth a visit.

Amazing cloisters. We visited the museum attached with interesting artefacts found in Portugal. The monastery was beautiful, the cloisters exceptional with beautiful carvings. Inside the church was beautiful.. Well worth a visit. Cloisters and museum have a fee, the church is free
Great monument. Fantastic peace of art and history with cathedral and museum was amazing and stanning visit lost in the past of portugal with history of kingdoms and nvigation
Impressive . Absolute must-see in Lisbon. Both, the monastery and the church part are very impressive. The church part was free of charge while the monastery part cost 10 euros - totally worth it.

Tourist. One of the places we visited on and organised tour. / thank goodness in was organised as the queues are off putting. . We still had a short wait but it was worth it we did the church and the stone work is unbelievable.watch out for the beggars very intimidating.

Stunning architecture. While I did not go into this location due to time constraints I did tour the outside. It is truly stunning. The sheer size of it is impressive but the small details are all the more stunning.It is worth noting that directly across from this monastery is a celebration park with a lovely fountain. In the background you can see the monument for the new discoveries by the sea shore.

Extraordinary. A must see in Lisbon. Built T the height of Portugal's power by a king who wanted to be remembered. It houses the maritime museum the archeological museum and part of the former church, cloisters and refectory. Decoration is beyond comparison contains the tomb of Vasco de Gama. A true work of art.

Impressive Stonework . This was a very pleasant place to visit. The sculptures on the stonework is astounding both in the church and the monastery itself. If you're down Belem way it's well worth a visit.

Well Conserved with Great Symmetry. Prior to enetering dos Jeronimos we visited the church on the right hand side, this is a spectacular, large Church which also contains the sarcophagus of the esteemed explorer Vasco Da Gamma; what a nice surprise. It cost €10 per person to enter the Mosterio are and whilst it gas stunning carvings and stonework spread over two floors it was much smaller than we expected.
Place to visit!. Free every Sunday morning until 01:00pm, but hurry up, the queue can be very long. A beautiful monastery with a fantastic interior garden.

AMAZING MONASTERY!!! Impressionante em todos os aspectos.. Fantastic in every sense. For sure one of the most amazing sights from Lisbon in the beautiful Belem, where you need minimum 2 hours to visit the Monastery and the Belem Tower. The architecture of the Monastery is someting unique and you must visit inside for make fantastic pictures. A must see spot that I will be pleased to visit again.

Mosteiro dos Jerónimos. A fabulous masterpiece. Its location is perfect, between the famous pasteis de belém and belém cultural center.This is a world heritage monument and a significant part of portugal history
Don't miss it!. Worth the excursion to Belem. Fabulous decoration from Lisbon's hey-days. Beautiful cloisters. A Lisbon must see.

Beatutiful. Beautiful and great place to go. Very easy to get to, I stopped during my open top bus sightseeing tour and saw Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, Torre de Belém and Padrao dos Descobrimentos together.
amazing even with repairs being done. to think this building made it through the earthquake and flood just a miracle - make sure you see all the details there are some hidden gems in this place
A must see. A beautiful 16th century building. Pay the 5 euros to go inside the monastery -- it's the highlight of the visit.
Beautiful!!!. I've been with my friends here & the building itself is beautiful...i love how it is made.The location itself speaks of its beauty.A place not too miss when you visit Lisbon.

What an amazing place!!! Don't miss it. The Mosteiro is gorgeous! Definitely a must do!! You can buy a ticket that merges both the Mosteiro and the Torre de Belém, what makes it cheaper!
Don't restrict your visit to the church! Go inside the Mosteiro! You will not regret!

Beautiful monestery.. Take the tram to Belen to see this beautiful monestery and another part of Lisbon. The monastery has been restored and is very ornate with gothic-like arches but much more decorated. There is a good short history of Portugal. We chose to visit the cloisters, - which is not free. Entrance to the main church is free.
Impressive building. We didn't enter the monastery. The church which is attached on the right hand side is free and very impressive.

Historically interesting church. Very distinct interior, with astoundingly high vaulting ceilings of stone, some Gothic arches and some Romanesque, extensive intricate stone decorations in parts and massively tall plain stone walls on the sides, and its ceiling's embellishments in the Manueline style copied throughout Europe in royal courts. How it survived the great earthquake of 1755 is hard to imagine given its massive stonework, but it did.Don't miss Vasco de Gama's tomb just on the left of the entrance in a sarcophagus that looks like a king's tomb (and could be easily confused for the king's tomb from the late 19th-century on the right of the entrance).

Nice architecture. The architecture was most impressive. The church is free, but the monestary, which is beautiful, has a charge. I had the Lisboa Pass, so it was included. Hint, if you have the pass, don't wait on the long line. Go into the small kiosk just to the left of the archway and no waiting.
Beautiful Building. This was a beautiful building. It is right across the street from the river and many little restaurants and tourist shops.
Beautiful. WE went in quite late so didn't have as long as we would have liked to but it is a stunningly beautiful building and is definitely one to put on your visitors list

One of my favorite sights of our trip. I love this beautiful monastery -- especially the Cloisters! We were a bit confused about where to go and what our tickets included -- once we finally figured out exactly where the ticket line was -- but the guides were helpful once we found them. This is where Vasco de Gama is entombed which was interesting.
Really impressive. Inside the cloister veerything is so sophisticated and clean. It is a real pleasure to walk around inside this building
OK BUT EXPECT TO PAY. This is a very expensive place to visit for not much the church is free to see so really you are only getting the cloisters if your on a budget i would give this a miss

Great afternoon. Old monastery with a beautiful cloister with intricate stone carvings.
I found the displays in the upstairs room very interesting and informative.

Must visit despite the tourist hordes. It's hard to avoid the long lines to this amazing structure. The ground floor of the church can be visited for free and with no line. It houses the tombs of Vasco da Gama and Luís de Camões. For the rest of the monastery, one must stand patiently in line, and it's worth it.

My Visit to Mosteiro & Belem. If you like churches this is a must the cloisters are wonderful with all the carvings on the stone work go outside to visit the church where you can see Vasco da Gama tomb you can buy your ticket for Belem tower here joint ticket is better value excellent value for your euro
Excellent sightseeing. Plenty to see and do in Lisbon.Museums, the Castle, Belem, ( Means Bethlehem ) Where the lovely Custard Tarts are made Pastiserie Belem Lovely Restaurants and plenty to do.

This place is breathtaking... and I've seen quite a few places.. Knowing what I know today, I would consider visiting Lisbon without seeing the sanctuary at Mosterio dos Jeronimos, as a tragic lost opportunity. I've been to most of the great monuments of the Western world, and this place, especially in its historic context, is breathtaking. Do not miss it. The naval museum next door is worth the walk, too. It seems boring at first, but then you get to the huge exhibit hall with its royal yachts, and it becomes another place you'll be glad you didn't miss.

Impressive even for the most jaded teenager.. In one hour we went from, "what the heck is there to see at a stupid monastery," to ,"that's the coolest thing we've seen in Portugal." Even American teens will be impressed by a building which was commenced in 1501. The balustrade overlooking the church is awe-inspiring.

Visit the monastery at Belem - Sao Jeronimo. When you visit Belem, we would recommend you to go inside the monastery there, as well as the church.
