It looks stunning from the outside, but it is well worth paying the modest price of a ticket to go inside and see the cloisters and the refectory. The overall effect of the beautiful cloisters is great, and if you look at the hand carvings on the pillars you will be amazed at the intricacy. There are themes from the sea, ropes and fish, in the local cream and rose coloured limestone, and excellent tiled pictures in the refectory around the walls.There is also a second level, which allows a different perspective. The whole place is unique and very photogenic.

“Impressive architecture”. This is an awesome church, with amazing architecture. I highly recommend a visit Belem quarter. You can visit White Tower and Discoveries Monument if you come to visit this monastery, they are on opposite side and only problem is how to cross the street. You must walk a lot for a gangway.
Good Museum. This is very interesting and can be part of the other attractions in the area. You can get tram 15 here or the train and walk up not too far.
Closed on Mondays. You would think in this day and age of austerity and unemployment they would want to maximise income. But no, they close on a Monday. Duh!The outside looked nice.

The heart of Lisbon. For the History savvy person. This is a must place. Most of The history of the New World can be found there. Unique construction, then walk to the right to have some Portuguese Custard Tarts (Pasteis de Belem)

Fascinating but a visit of two halves. there is a free bit and a fee paying bit. On a weekend it always seemed to be very crowded though once you get out there from Town you need to do both sections. if the Q is too long just go to the new Museum just 100m further on (but that is modern art)
Impressive monastery. Great monastery with an impressive church. Very tall pillars and lots of derails at the maìn portal. Surely worthwile visit.

Interesting Tour. We had a little trouble finding the entrance to this attraction due to some renovation work on the facade, but once inside, we certainly enjoyed it. Crowds were reasonable and you could save some money by getting a combo ticket with Belem Tower.
Extraordinary architecture. Monastery and church are both worth a visit out to Belem to see this stunning architectural gem - quite unlike anything we have ever seen before.
Impressive. This is an awesome place with such wonderful history and architecture. I highly recommend a visit here if you're in Portugal.
Stunning. Awe inspiring well worth a visit the architecture and grand scale of this building is something to behold

Nice .. . The entire area is very nice . Fountains and lots of park architecture.
The monastery itself is very impressive and we enjoyed the visit very much

Beautiful cloister, fine architecture and some history too. The Mosteiro holds a significant place in Portugal's history. It should be on your itinerary, and it is worth seeing the amazing and intricate carving in the cloisters.

Lovely. Beautiful in side, with loads of history and about Portugal.
You can go on a tour with speakers, but we did our own thing.

Very nice! Busy and touristy though!. Be prepared to queue to get in! You can get a ticket for both the monastery and Belem Tower (that means you only queue once - you get priority for the second one you visit). Great place! Quite busy - hard to get pictures with no tourists in! :)
Amazing Carved Cloisters. Definitely worth the trip out of Lisbon. The cloisters were amazing. Not a huge site to visit so combined tickets with other attractions worth while.

See the church and discover Gaudi's inspiration and an impressive stone work. All the Monastery is really impressive but its church is one of the most beautiful I have ever seen. Take your time and look at the columns, the ceiling, the influence from Orient in the decorations and details. If you remembers it dates from the XVI century, and the majority of the Europeans had never travelled so far, you will understand how amazing some decorations were, and still are. Buy a complete ticket and use 2 or 3 hours to see everything in detail. And after that indulge yourself with a nice meal in Descobre restaurant, nearby (go to the side of Centro Cultural de Belém, continue in the trams street and it will be on your left side).

Add to your must see list in Lisbon. Love history , then this place is well worth the visit. Not only is the external architecture amazing, but the internal view is absolutely breathtaking, so much to see and experience . Easy travel option is to take the hop-on-hop off bus to get there and make sure you visit the maritime museum next door. Get there early to avoid large tour groups.

What architecture!. This place is not only huge but full of art, history and has crypts of ancient historical figures from mideaval times. It's massive the art is extraordinary and the gardens, fountains and views are amazing. You have to go visit this place in Lisbon. It's surrounded by other historical monuments, lots of cafes, restaurants, gardens etc. Etc.
History. Do you want know about Portugal, you should visit Jeronimos, our history it's inside the building. And a little of the history of the world.

Nice but not great. I very much enjoyed the chapel but I don't think the courtyard cloister is worth the admission fee. The church is free to enter and you get a view of Vasco da Gamo's tomb.Worth a visit but not the price of admission.
Not to be missed. As well the church as the monastery / cloister are amazing, and I do not use this word for anything like Americans do!

Amazing architecture & area in Lisbon. Love the architecture, the surrounding, the history, the atmosphere. It's dark inside the cathedral and if it's not too busy with tourists it feels like going back in time. Seeing the tomb of Camões made moving impression on me as one of his poems is one of my favorite of all time. This place is a must see in Lisbon!
A lot to see. A great venue for tourists with lots to see. Close to where the famous pastries are sold, so a good location
Beautiful and must-see when you're in Lisbon. This is a fascinating historic location and worth making the trip out of the centre. Stunning architecture with a story to tell

Impressive Stonework. Jeronimos Monastery was our favorite tourist attraction in Lisbon. We were especially impressed with the architecture and detailed, gorgeous stonework. We also like the nautical theme throughout in stonework as well as stained glass. It was quite crowded when we arrived and though there was a service being held we were permitted to be in the back near the tombs. It is free to enter the main part of the monastery; however, there is an admission fee if you want to see the cloister area.

An architecture masterpiece. If you like both architecture and sculpture, this is a place to see. Though it is far from the old town, 15 minutes in taxi, it is worth the ride. While there go to Das Pasteles, the oldest patisserie at Belem. Founded in 1837.

Beautiful, but overpriced. Was it nice? Yes. The hand carved stone work is pretty amazing and you can see the tomb of Vasco da Gama. On a more personal note, none of us really fell in love with it, but then again it depends on your perception of beauty. The ticket costs 10 Euros which for us, based on our taste in attractions was a bit too much. You can visit the church free of charge. The guard let us in with a smile, but after three minutes he started yelling why we haven't already left since it was their closing time. Based on the fact that he had just let us in we had no idea it was closing time.
Worth the trip. Worth the trip. Spent about 90 minutes touring. Would recommend having a Lisboa card to get you into multiple museums and use on transit otherwise could be spendy

Amazingly beautiful must visit . This 14th century is a must visit for anyone. Considered the finest example of this architectural type. The church itself is a free entry but you have to pay 10 € for the cloisters and it's well worth it. Built in the mid 1500's it retains all the the charm and carving.

Escape from the Rain. We first entered the Monastery to escape the rain outside but once we entered we knew we picked a great place to escape to. It wasn't busy on our particular day probably because of the weather. There is a lot to do in walking distance of this attraction.
Impressive architecture. Its a very impressive monastery to look at. Very picturespue with the gardens in front of it. Beat the crowds and go early.

Excelent. Jerónimos Monastery is one of Lisbon’s greatest historic landmarks and declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1984. The Monastery houseinitias the tombs of Kings D. Manuel I, D. João III, D. Sebastião and D. Henrique, as well as those of seafarer Vasco da Gama and writers Luís Vaz de Camões, Alexandre Herculano and Fernando Pessoa, three of the most important names of Portuguese literature.Curious story: as part of a rite of passage, before departing on the first voyage, the future seafarer had to find the column with the "hand of God" inside the Church and touch it.

Too crowded for the soul. This was originally a monastery, and now the church is open to the public. Unfortunately it is on the main day-trippers route, and when we were there was packed with tour groups. The architecture is simple and superb, with some wonderful stone carvings. And yes, Vasco da Gama's tomb is here.

Good landmark to visit . The architecture is impressive and everything is seemingly hand carved inside. A beautiful piece of history, it should be on everyone's to do list, especially due to its location.

Good but uncontrolled. Strange one this. The church itself was beautiful and amazing. However the people and control of them ruined the experience, children playing in the aisles, a lot of flash photography, just general chaviness (if you don't know what this means; Aussie = bogan, US/Canada = trailer trash, not sure on the rest of world). The rating is for the building not the experience so please go and support the place!
Nice. We visited the monastery in a hot summer day, but being only June, it was not that crowded. It was a nice visit
Belem attraction. Easy tram ride on #15E. Although this is a UNESCO attraction, the entrance fee of 10 Euro is steep without much to offer.

A unique historical place: definitely a must-see in Lisboà. Together with friends, we spent 2 hours visiting the monastery and church located in Belém area (Western part of Lisboà, after the 25th of April bridge).We reached the place using E25 tramway.The church itself is amazing (see the tomb of Vasco de Gama) and the cloister is definitely worth seeing. The two-storey cloister gives access to the second floor of the church as well as to the monks' refectory.We purchased a ticket combining both Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and Belém tower.

Not that much. This place in Lisbon is famous, but it is not that much really interesting, in my humbled opinion. On the other hand, the area surrounded Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is a nice place, where you can find the famous original "pastel de nata" and nearby you can visit the Belem Tower.
Amazing view in belem. It made me feel like im in granada, spain but bit different from it. Exhibition was great and i could get a student discount
Be Sure to See the Cloister. An interesting complex. But my favourite was the cloister. By far the biggest and most ornate I have ever seen

A monastery made possible by the money obtained with the profits of the sea route to India. The Portuguese King D. Manuel was very fortunate. In his life time he saw Vasco da Gama discover the sea route to India, eliminating the Arab and Venetian trade of spices.Suddenly Portugal become a super power, a very ric one.It was possible, then to D. Manuel to order to build this magnificent Monastery.It took 100 years to be built...and it was worth while.It's huge in length, but surprisingly elegant, with a wonderful church, and magnificent cloisters.When you enter Jerónimos you travel in time and the experience you'll have will transform you for ever.

Long queue to enter. We visited the Monastero on Sunday morning and there was a long queue to enter (except for families with kids), but the inside is really beautiful. A must see if you are visiting Lisboa.

Major conservation works are taking place. It was a good job there were other sites to visit at this location. Be advised that not only is the main tower covered with scaffolding at the moment, the area in front is also being used as a building site and parking place for construction vehicles.

History and spiritual. Went to evening mass here and the atmosphere and the priests' voice made me feel as if I were a few hundred years back in time. That my phone has so many pictures from monastery of Jeronimos says it all.

Top sight for the city tour. There is a long term renovation project (to end 2018) which leaves the main tower shrouded, but focus your photos instead on the magnifcent entrance. If you don't want to pay to go into the monastery itself visit the church and make a donation there instead. The pillars and church are inspiring. Let your eyes get used to the dark interior , after the white exterior and I'm sure the camera will get some good shots. The fountains in the park opposite are spectacular.
Spectacular!. Both the church (free of admission) and the museums are very interesting. Portugal has a very rich naval history and the museum is very well displayed. Great staff.
UNESCO. UNESCO World Herritage site, monastery in gotic style. The tomb of Vasco da Gama and Luis de Camoes inside
WOW!. This cannot be missed. One of the most beautiful buildings in Lisbon. The details outside and inside are breathtaking. Don't forget to stop for a cream tart!!!

Not worth the price. The building is lovely on the outside but vacant except for the church. You can visit the church proper at no charge. The interior is very beautiful. But to pay to go up to a gallery and out to the cloisters is disgraceful.

Tour of Lisbon. There is so much to see beginning with the architecture. It is jaw dropping & you can lose you time - something we would want to return to if we go back to Lisbon so we can see so much more!

A magnificent look into another time. No trip to Lisbon is complete without a trip to Jeronimos. The architecture is complex and amazing. You are left in awe of how it all came to be. Even with crowds there is a sense of peace.
lovely afternoon. we went because it was raining and has a lovely afternoon,,,so much to see and no hurry for you to go around....
An architecture marvel. In Belem this beautiful monastery is characteristic by the "Manuelino" style inspired in ocean and navigation themes. Beautiful and very very grand

Make sure you visit if you can. Beautiful building inside and outside.The church is free to enter but the inner courtyard (the Ccloisters)has a charge but we had the Lisbon Card ,which by the way is good as it saves a lot of hassle and gives either free or reduced entrance to many of the sires and is great for trams,the metro and some local rail links eg to Sintra.If you take the lift up to the top of the Padrao Dos Descobrimentos you will get a magnificent view of the Mosteiro and the city and river.

Beautiful church. The biggest part of the monastery is now occupied by a museum, so the parts open to the public are the church and the cloisters. The church is beautiful and the cloisters are interesting because in the centre is an archaeological dig taking place, with finds back to very early times. You can walk round above the dig to see the excavations.

Go if you've extra cash to spare. Disappointing experience despite the wonderful reviews we've read. There's two parts to the premises: the church and the monastery. The prior is free entry while the latter charges 10€. I remember remarking when I first stepped into the church that it's not charged. Visit the church but skip the monastery - no doubt it has a beautiful facade which you can sufficiently admire from the exterior; it's overpriced and nothing much to take in (lots of huge empty rooms). I finished the walk in an hour and that's after convincing myself to read every single word on the exhibits just to make the trip worthwhile
worth seeing. its very very beautiful, I recommend you to visit it. First you can eat nata in belem patisserie than visit here

The Beauty of the Belem District. The Belem District is along the Tagus River, west of the old downtown. There are at least four important tourist venues here. It is easy to get to by Tram #28 from downtown. It is about a 30 minute ride from the heart of downtown. The 4 sites are the Mosterio dos Jeronimos, Berardo Arte Moderna, Torre de Belem and the Discoveries Monument. All four of these attractions are in walking distance from one another. The Tram leaves you off directly across the street from the Mosterio. The entry fee was minor with the Lisboa Card. The structure includes a Church, a Monastery and a wonderful Cloister. The crowds, even early in the morning are pretty overwhelming. My emotional reaction to this building, was subdued, as is the building. It is a high example of Manueline architecture which is a world away from the Gothic architecture of a different era.After walking around the perimeter of the church, make sure to stop in the Cloister, which my wife said is more beautiful than the one in Inwood (Manhattan, NYC). It provides a nice element of quiet and place to be somewhat pensive. The whole time needed here is not be more than 1 hour. Then walk across the street to the Berardo Art museum - a museum and complex that is good as it gets.

Well preserved monument. Monestary is well preserved and in good condition.Avoid crowded times.I did the visit in approx. 1 hour though some people recommend to spend more time. Depending on your interests.....The grave of Vasco da Gama is visible in the church.Entrance fee is 10€ which is in my opinion too expensive. For 2€ more you get the combined ticket including the Belem tower.

See the Church. There are two parts to the Monestary. The first is the church which has free admission. The architecture was lovely, the art work was good and the tomb of Vasco da Gama is there. The monetary consists mostly of seeing the cloister. There is an entrance fee there. Skip it if you're on a budget.

Stunningly beautiful inside. Must see on a trip to Lisbon, take the train, tram or bus to Belem. We waited in a rather long line thanks to excellent weather, but we were so glad we did. It's so beautiful. Be sure to see Vasco de Gama's tomb as well as Camoes' tomb (he was described as Portugal's Moliere, not sure how accurate that is). If you are into architecture and/or churches, it is an inspiring place to visit.

A cultural gem!. A fascinating monastery with incredible art and history. We took the bus from Lisbon to Belem on a Sunday morning and arrived in Belem late morning so we didn't expect such a long line to get in. Turns out that alot of tour buses go in the morning. Since we were on our own and flexible with our itinerary, we went to see the Tower of Belem and the Discoveries Monument first. By the time we got back to the monastery a couple hours later, there was no line and fewer crowds at Jeronimos. It is truly worth the price of admission. A cultural gem that is packed with amazing art and history!

A recommended visit. This is a most impressive building, with a fascinating history which is clearly set out in a display in both Portuguese and English. The church which is part of the complex really should not be missed.
So cool. This place is really cool and I really love all the detail that was placed in the building of this place, I took a lot of pictures of this place.
the cloisters are a must visit.. very touristy, but worth the visit, the museum have combo ticket with the tour de Belem tower for 12 euros per person, very good price.

Architecturally Memorable. The cloister particularly stood out and was worth paying to see, the church itself was worth the trip and it was interesting to see a medieval cathedral with a Portuguese perspective (the artichokes, consumed by sailors to prevent scurvy, decorating the pillars were especially memorable).

Monastery + church--if beautiful structures thrill you, plan for more than 2 hours here. The church adjoining the monastery, Church of Santa Maria de Belem, is a beautiful structure containing the tombs of the famous explorer Vasco da Gama and of Luís de Camões, considered by many to be Portugal's finest poet. You can expect to see lofty, vaulted arches and lovely stained glass windows. When you tour the monastery, you will be able to access the upper choir area which will allow you a marvelous view of the church's interior from a higher perspective. When you're up there, be sure to note the carved wooden stalls used by the monks. On the day I went (midday on a Tuesday), access to the church was immediate, but I had to wait about 15 minutes to enter the monastery.The monastery is an incredible edifice of repeating arches and scallops and carvings, along with colored tiles. The tan-colored stone seem to have been carved to simulate a filigreed, wedding-cake type of effect. There are also wonderful arched walkways that are open to a courtyard. One room holds an elaborate timeline exhibit which, I regretfully confess, that was interesting but provided far more information that I could process at one time. I did not participate in any sort of tour. I just wandered through the church and monastery at my leisure and tried to immerse myself in imagining the history and religious significance of these buildings. It was a terrific experience.
Very Impressive!. The Monastery is really impressive and a great place to visit (Entrance Fee required)! The Church is free to enter though!
Gorgeous!!. Did not expect to be so impressed by this place. It was so extremely beautiful inside, that I could not stop taking pictures.!!
Spectacular.. An amazing building inside and out. Especially liked the cloister. Could see its influence on Gaudi.

Great side trip when visiting Lisbon. Belem is only a short train ride from Lisbon. The Monastery is a great visit to Belem, with great architecture and history. I suggest buying a combination ticket (to include the monastery, Belem tower, and museum) for a great value. Also don't forget to visit the pastry shop around the corner.

Beatiful historic building in the midle of Lisbon.. A place to visit, this is one of the landmarks of Lisbon, as you entrance the place you feel like diving in the Portuguese history, so many beautiful details to appreciate.
did the fast track. quite the place; worth the time and effort to get there. Plus of course, once there are many other things to do and see in area.

Great of example of Manueline architecture. A beautiful example of the iconic style of Portuguese architecture, and well worth a visit. The cloister is open to visitors at a fee and is adjacent to the church can be entered for free. Both worth a visit, especially the cloisters which are beautiful.

Stunning architecture, don't miss this while in Lisbon. We took an early bus from the town centre and, with our Lisbon cards entry was free. We were fortunate to appreciate the cloisters with very few people around - recently renovated, it sparkled in the sun - a magical and peaceful space we found enchanting. There are rooms off the cloisters including the impressive refectory lined with ornate tiling depicting bible stories. The cloisters were gorgeous, transported to another time (or a Harry Potter movie set!)We were also really impressed with the architecture of the Church and its absolutely monumental space, ornate pillars and stained glass. There is of course Vasco de Gama's tomb which we had a quick look at. All in all, a great visit - we finished it off by walking down to the Tower of Belem , well worth a visit too. Tip - go early!

Impressive!. We took a tram from Lisbon's city-centre to see this Monastery. It has to be one of the most impressive (in terms of sheer size) we've seen. Sadly though, as its a UNESCO World Heritage Site, the queues to go inside were ridiculously long so we never got to see inside, and instead decided to take a wander around the outside.

Stunning!. From the outside the sheer size of the Monastery is over-whelming. The first stop should be the church which is to the right and free. The architecture is beautiful and there is a sense of reverence when you walk in. Definitely wander around! After the church and get your ticket for the monastery but don't be put off by the "lobby". The true treat waits just around the corner and you won't be able to stop yourself from saying WOW. Again, beautiful architecture and a very peaceful place!

One of Lisbon's Jewels. This tribute the Portugal's zenith has stunning work and key associations with Portuguese history. Parts of the facility require an admission, yet most of the building is open.
Eh. While the outside is beautiful the wait and the price for the tickets may not be worth it. The cloisters are somewhat disappointing and much can be seen for free.

A nice stop, more of a destination than a cathedral. You'll see more people there for the tomb of Vasco Da Gama than anything else, so almost more of a museum than a church. Still has some wonderful vaulting and details but lack the presence of a "working" cathedral. Definitely worth a look.

Shame that Tourists are treated so badly!!. Following a wait of approx., 75 minutes (in an outdoor queue, in the baking heat of the sun), we finally reached the ticket desk (to enter the Monastery) to find ONE assistant at the desk. To add insult to injury, he was in 'no hurry' to improve matters - his laid-back attitude was clear!Incidentally, some people (perhaps locals) seemed able to 'skip the queue' and gain immediate access (no signage existed to explain 'the system' - if there is one?).Once inside, the Cloisters were lovely and having been recently restored, the carved stonework was sparkling in the sun. Disappointingly, there wasn't much to more to see.......except a new exhibition (timeline of the Monastery against world events) which was presented in pictorial and written format (Portuguese and English). Whilst extremely interesting, I picked-up a glaring error in the written detail...'Englishman' James Watt (Engineer) was in fact a 'Scotsman' (born in Greenock, near Glasgow) and as a result I would have to question the factual validity of the information presented.The Cathedral (located alongside the Monastery) was serine and impressively large but not particularly ornate or memorable.All in all, a visit of HUGE disappointment and a waste of valuable (and limited) time, as a tourist in Lisbon.
Great place, beautiful building. Wonderful place to visit but better in the morning as there are few things to see around... Nice pastry shop too not very far from there...

Beautiful Church. We got there close to closing time and did not have a lot of time but what we did see was beautiful. It was a short walk down the street to the pastry shop Fabrica de Pasteis de Belem for some pasteis de nata, delicious custard tart sprinkled with cinnamon and powered sugar.
A Late Gothic Manueline style monastery in Lisbon. This timeless beauty is priceless, but it is cheap. I took some photos the gargoyles of the courtyard.

The most beautiful monument of Lisbon. The Jeronimos Monastery is the most beautiful monument of Lisbon, with 5 centuries of existence. Near the Tagus River and near Belem Tower, is worth visited unhurriedly.

Love the Jeronimos. There's something about the Jeronimos Monastery that I enjoy. Perhaps it is Vasco de Gama's tomb, perhaps it is the lovely columns that look like palm trees. It is one place in Lisbon that I almost always visit.

Exceptional experience. From looking at the pictures it seems everything in the neighborhood is part of the monastery. The fountain area is its own entity. The monastery holds the Marine Museum and the Museum of Archeology as well as the Monastery and church. The only Sunday entry that is free is the 1st of the month. Yesterday it was a sunny warm day with a breeze and the line wasn't bad. Seniors 1/2 price! Considering these monks did no manual labor these are some impressive buildings. The King's mausoleum being the 1st goal, and having monks pray non stop for him paying for everything is how the thoughts went in those days, buy your way to heaven. The architecture is phenomenal. We spent 3-4 hours inside. The chapter house, only the doors are from the 1500s but the room is awesome. The refectory is filled with tile work showing the feeding of the masses and events of Jesus' life in Egypt, The wall tiles are really colorful. the cloisters, surrounding the courtyard shows how peaceful and reverential an atmosphere the monks lived in, Everything was spectacular, then we entered the upper choir room of the church. What a gorgeous space. The light coming through the stained glass windows streaming into the sanctuary below was breath taking. We went through the church on the way out and it was equally awesome. The chapels along the sides were simple or super ornate. Great visit while in Lisbon.

The can't miss Manueline gothic. Pictures are all very well, but the reality blows them away. The church is free, the monastery too for holders of the Lisbon card. Even if you have to pay, the cloisters are worth the money, as well as the view of the church from the upper choir.

Have you seen one, you’ve seen them all. This place looks like so many other monasteries which is quite natural since they use the same principal design. This place holds a few surprises after all which makes it well worth visiting. Access to the monk’s balcony in the church is a nice treat. So is also the history line room which depicts the Monastery’s history side by side with world history and Portuguese history. The place should be a natural visit if you are in the area which contains both the monument of the discoverers and Belem Tower. The ticket line is a bit confusing with lines for groups, pre-paid, access to the next door archaeological museum and the free of cost access the church bottom level. All squeezed into the same entrance. Photo without flash allowed in the church and monastery.
A historic place. One of the most historic places in Lisbon. From renaissance bishops to modern treaties - a lot has happened in these walls!

Don't go on Sunday!. Free entry means there are hoards of people on Sunday and the place is overcrowded. You follow round in a line with hundreds of others! It is well worth a visit but unless you are on a tight budget go in the week.
Exquisite. Beautiful architecture, excellent exhibition on it's history placed in context with other words events. Good value at 6 euro for an adult ticket

An architectural jewel.... Located in the Belém neighbourhood of Lisbon a trip to the Jeronimos Monastery can be planned along with the nearby Tower of Belém. An exquisite example of Portuguese Late Gothic architecture, it is a prominent site in the Lisbon tourist itinerary and is crowded as such. To reach this place you can take the regional train, but my preferred mode of transport is the Tram (route 15E).
Amazing!. Absolutely gorgeous! I can't get enough of this. It's a powerful building, with so much history. Loved it.

Spectacular. The monastery is simply stunning. The cloisters are made up of carved arches and columns and are beautiful. This place is a must see in Lisbon. There is a really interesting display of a timeline of the monastery along with one of Portugal and one for the rest of the world.If you are visiting both the Torre de Belem and the Monastery it's best to buy the combined ticket which saves you €4 and you will not have to queue for the place you visit second.
Worth a stop. Great for history and architecture lessons. Flea across the street has interesting finds that make great souvenirs.
Stunning architecture. Not to be missed, spectacular church, don't miss the very beautiful cloisters, wide and airy, especially the intricate carving on the pillars, no two are the same.

Well worth the visit. . One of Lisbon's highlights. One of the stops on the hop off/ hop off buses and within a short walk from The Discoverers Monument and Bemel Tower. Very close to the famous custard tart shop. The monastery is very impressive with beautiful cement/stone carvings throughout. Be sure to visit the room where the diorama tracing the history of the monastery, Portugal, and the world is located. Highly recommended.

Exterior as good as interior. A beautiful building, demonstrating Portuguese architecture of the period at its best. Queues to pay and get inside the monastery are only worth it if you have the time. The church is free to enter, tomb of Vasco de Gama is a highlight in the church. If you do go inside the monastery the tiled refectory is stunning.

Well worth the wait - cloisters are free 1st Sunday of the month !. Amazing carvings throughout church (free) & cloisters (worth queuing and paying). Big enough to seem not too crowded even when busy.

Stunning building. Closed on Mondays - easily accessible by Tram but can be crowded. Custard tart shop (the original) is nearby and Balem Tower within a short walk. visit the monument on the river front for an ariel view of the monestry

Manueline carving at its peak. The highlight of this ex-monastery is clearly the cloister with it's lovely coloured stone and unusual Manueline carving. Shame about the area inside which was messy with the grass needing to be cut; the area really needs to be developed to present the cloister in its best light. The south portal and the church (for which entry is free) also has superb manueline carvings with the columns in the church surely being unique. The refrectory is also worth a look, and lastly don't forget to pay your respects at the grave of Vasco da Gama at the entranceway of the church. The monastery as a whole is well worth a visit to Belem but you should of course also consider visiting the Torre de Belem, and the Padro dos Descobrimentos. The maritime museum next to the monastery also seems to be very underestimated; it's an excellent little museum.On a practical note, consider taking a tax. It's not expensive and without the crowding and risk of the number 15 tram - my wife had her wallet pickpocketed the day we went to Belem and it's clearly not an isolated case.
The loveliest cloisters. We loved this old monastery, especially the exquisite cloisters, carved so finely and with such a beautiful aspect.
Beautiful monastery. beautiful monastery on the edge of Lisbon. the wait for tickets was a surprise but the glory of the sight was worth the wait.

Nice architecture. Before you go, check opening hours and days.
I wouldn't recommend 100% to go in. Unless you love such monuments.

Stunning architecture. I visited during a heavy rain. Beautiful building to explore even in such weather.
Included in the Lisboa card, accessible using the tram service.

A spectacular building - well worth the visit. Visit both the cloisters and the church for some exquisite stone carving and a surprisingly open and bright building complex. See Vasco da Gama's tomb and some good tiling in the refectory. One of six or more key attractions in Belem all within walking distance of each other. Two other museums are just next door.
Fascinating. Great place to look round but some strange small exhibitions when we visited. The cloisters are worth seeing

Absolutely Stunning! One of the NOT TO BE MISSED Historical Attraction in Lisbon!. We just returned from a vacation / horse riding lesson vacation in Portugal, with several days based in central Lisbon and on our last full day we went out of the central core area to visit and tour the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos - It was a spectacularly wonderful experience!!!We went out on a Sunday late morning - 'went out' mentioned as the site is a fair distance from the central old town core and our original plan was to take the rail tram car (as the prior day we had purchases a one day tram/ bus pass).TIPS: It proved difficult to get an old style) tram at all - let alone one that was not full / packed like sardines. We then walked blocks to a central tram / train area only to have to wait / waste almost an hour and still no tram / train came by that took you to even somewhat close to the site. SO - (advice) - take a cab. it proved to be worth the limited cost for four people, the cab took us right to the front entrance (rather than several blocks away which us where the nearest tram stop was located) and it got us there VERY FAST! A trip by one of the motorized bike 'Tuc Tucs' might also prove very enjoyable - and certainly faster, more direct than the tram system.Also - as far as going on a Sunday morning:TIPS:1. When you arrive, there may be a mass / service as it is Sunday. if you wish to see the main monastery area first - ensure that you are in the correct line. The line up to get into the mass service and / or those waiting to get into the cathedral area first even while there was a mass going on - was blocks long.Go right up to the entrance doorway and take the line that goes into the monastery area 1st - no line-up, no waiting. This gives you the chance to walk and tour the cloister / monastery area 1st - which architecturally stunning, and despite the possible crowds - is a photographers dream location.2. Sunday walk-in access (at least for the time we arrived) was FREE. 3. Also on Sunday...there is a very good flea market / antique market in one area of the parking lot / park area. Many of these vendors were also at the massive Saturday flea market that floods the streets and alleys around the Santa Clara Cathedral in the east end of the historic core.We toured the cloister / monastery area when we first arrived - architecturally world class and awe inspiring, and a photographers dream area... beautifully stunning at every turn... almost ever inch intricately detailed... a historical gem.THEN... thinking that our visit was over... doors opened after the mass service and the public could enter the main cathedral - massive, more awe inspiring, beautiful every where your looked - in every photograph I took.You may not hear much about the Monastery prior to your trip, and may take it for granted as 'just another church'... . but it is well worth the visit. It was actually from the advise and recommendations of several locals and from the instructors an staff at the horse riding school out in the countryside that we attended before venturing into Lisbon for several days that we decided to visit the monastery on our last day rather than several other key historic tourist locations, and the decision was a wonderful choice.Definitely a highlight of the trip, and will be revisited if we ever get back to Lisbon!!!

Beautiful Cloisters - Top Sight in Lisbon. The courtyard is beautiful. Pay attention to the details and you will see the amazing handiwork that went into building the monastery. Every column is carved with a different design and there are a lot of columns. The church was closed as we were there on a Sunday and a service was being held. If you visit the museum (it has a separate entrance) first, you do not have to wait in line at the monastery as you can buy your monastery ticket at the museum and bypass the line. And if you are using the Lisboa Card, the museum is also included so no extra costs to you. The timeline of world history was a great sight also. I wish I would have had that in history class.
Highlight of our trip. Amazing Manueline architecture. I enjoyed the tour of this monastery. Despite the crowds, we could find some quiet spots to take the beauty of the monastery in.

Truly awe inspiring. You don't have to know the history behind this place but it is worth the time with out a doubt. An incredible structure and so much history at every turn. Will go back again and again.
must go,even line up. now a day, long line ( i went to 15yrs ago, no line), this is 2nd time to come, but still worst to line up to see. so many nice spot to take a picture !
must see in Lisboa. This is a place that cannot be missed in Lisboa. Very turistic, but worth the visit. Like going back in time...
Interesting but not spectacular. The highlight of this visit were the pastries at Belem not the monastery. Not much to see (only two rooms open to public), but the church is nice.

One of the Big Highlights of Lisbon. The church itself is free,but the Cloisters costs €10. Five euros for seniors.The Cloisters is definitely a highlight, but there can be long lines to get a ticket. We got a ticket online and printed it out at our hotel. Then you can bypass the ticket line and go straight in.

Nice walk in a nice area but beware of the gypsies. Nice gardens with a fountain, nice building but it is hard to walk peacefully with all those gypsies badgering you with their counterfeit watches or their scarves.

very small. We visited this monument with our family. The cloister is very beautiful but very small. The Church can be visited free of charge and there is nothing in the cloister which cannot be seen from outside in terms of art or architecture. I would not bother to pay the fee again.

Worth the trip - Interesting and great photo opportunities.. Easy bus/metro access or quite cheap by taxi/tuk tuk if preferred. Lovely architecture with great photo opportunities. Was quite busy mid October but still enjoyable. Can do this and Belem Tower easily in a few hours.

Fabulous location. Great place to visit in a very historic part of Lisboa. Didn't enter the place itself but loved the structure from outside and felt was enough . Get a pastiche from the local favourite round the corner, sit in the park and enjoy the building and the surroundings :-)

Interesting monastry. Not the best ticketing system in the world with only 2 staff on duty so queue was quite long (40 mins). If short of time just go the church (which is free to enter) but you will miss a very attractive cloister

Historic Monastery. This is one of the most visited Places in Lisbon do not go at the weekends apart from the tombs of Vasco da Gamma and Lois de Cameos there is some stone surprises study the carvings on the stone pillars in the nave and you may come across exotic plants and animals along with some exquisite human faces and a few mythical figures. very nice visit

Wonderful palace, 20 mins from Lisbon centre. Free admission on Sundays. Beautiful location and architecture, the 2-story cloister is magnificent. the Church and the 2 museums (maritime and archeological) are also interesting. 2 more Lisbon monument can be reached on foot (approx 10 minutes walk): Belem Tower and Padroes doe Descobrimentos
Amazing historical site!. The building itself is stunning, with the detailed architecture. Went there during Easter and the weather is absolutely perfect for a day out.
A surprising building - Gothic like nowhere else !!. Well worth a visit the cloisters and church are stunning, very unusual Gothic style architecture; Manueline.
Beautiful architecture . A stunning building by the water in Lisbon, definitely a must see upon a visit to the city. There was around a twenty minute wait to get in but it is worth it.

Nice, but overpriced.. Worth a visit, but way overpriced and still packed with crowds of visitors. Visit if you don't mind touristic places, but keep in mind that the visit is short and price rather high.
Good Tourist Spot. Worth a visit to see a great monastery along with the excellent Monument of Discoveries and the Tower of Belem.
Vasco de Gama's tomb. You will learn a lot about Portuguese history at this beautiful monument. The church is lovely, with many fine details.
beautiful church - interesting museum. The museum has a simple history of the world / history of Portugal exhibit that shouldn't be missed.

Excellent Monastery Experience. The church itself is like many other roman catholic grand churches, except it also contains the tomb of Vasco da Gama, a pretty important man in World History, as well as tombs of few royals with less memorable name worldwide. The monastery, however, is the highlight of this complex. It is beautiful, less crowded so you can relax in the marble seats, a walk back in time of the monks who once lived there. The entire complex is a must visit when in Lisbon but beware of pickpockets especially the surrounding areas.
Just take the train.. This monastery had all the bells and whistles that one needs for a short religous outing. Beautiful, great visit.

Awe inspiring & not to be missed, even if you're in Lisboa for only 2 days!. Visited once during the day as part of a Viking River Tour group and again at nite with just 3 others to see what a spectacular site/sight this is! Glad we had a local guide who helped us understand what we were seeing & the history behind it all - including the crypt of the explorer Vasco da Gama. While this was a definite "plus", being part of a tour group also meant that sadly, we couldn't stay longer ... thus our return on our own so we could see the beauty of it all once more at nite, at least from the outside.Located near to both the Monument of Discoveries and the Belem Tower, you can easily spend most of the day in this area of Lisbon. And should you enjoy custard tarts & be lucky to have the time to do so ... don't forget to stop by the Casa Pasteis de Belem - THE shop to get the famous and most delicious Pasteis de Nata in the world! Just go at nite when the crowds are gone!
Imposing and impressive building buzzing with visitors.. Lovely gardens in front and many other museums in the area. The whole area warrants an entire morning noon and night to be spent here.

Nice location, attractive building and its got Vasco Da Gama's tomb. The area the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos resides in beside the Belem Tower is attractive. The building is interesting and worth seeing if in Lisbon. The highlight to me was Vasco Da Gama's tomb that surprisingly is not made much of a big deal.

Highlight of Portuguese History and Culture. Impressive whether spending an hour or an afternoon. It is possible to trace the nation's history here. Considered the apex of late Manueline design, with much Renaissance updating. My favorite was the empty tomb of young King Sebastião who died in battle in Morroco. But beware the bus loads of tourists and go very early or late. Consider the audio guide or a detailed guidebook if you are really curious, there is no meaningful signage.

Dark and imposing. We went to see the cathedral and not the monastery which was free. It was quite dark inside as there were not many stained glass windows and the walls reached up almost to the ceiling with small undecorated windows near the top. The stone work is very beautiful and intricately carved with religious and occasionally bizarre motifs. It houses the tomb of Vasco da Gama.

Quite crowded, but it's a really interesting old building.. Lots of pillars and vaults and gargoyles, and a few grotesques thrown in for good measure. Nice for a casual stroll for a couple of hours. As a tip, the queue for tickets was quite long, but there was an alternate queue to the left which was way faster.

Well worth a visit. As part of our visit to Belem, which is just about compulsory, we visited Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. The queue for tickets is a bit long, but apart from that, it is an impressive place.
Beautiful place. Beautiful church and cloister. Very ornate. Vasco de Gama's tomb is there. There are also two kings and queens and their children buried there. Well worth seeing.

It's a must. If you are interested in Architecture associated to a monastery then enjoy every detail of this fine work of art - Lisbon, near the river and very close to the famous "Pastéis de Nata de Belém" - after visiting Jerónimos go there and try one - Yammyammmm

Crowded, but worth a visit. It seemed like all of the tourist in Lisbon were in line, but the line moves quickly enough. The late gothic monastery is worth the wait. I would try and spend the day in Belem, see the monastery, the tower and the CCB all in the same day.

Imposing. By far, Lisbon's best historical attraction. If you are buying the combined ticket for the Torre de Belem and the Mosterio, visit this one first. The queues are way shorter here. The chapel is free, you pay to see the monastery. Inside, the cloisters are beautiful - intricately carved and awe inspiring. You can wander around a bit and admire this Portuguese celebration of Vasco de Gama's discovery of the sea route to India. Good to even escape for a couple of hours on a rainy day. And the trams and buses stop right outside

Must visit place. We were there last Friday and visit to this place is free of cost and It is an interesting landmark in Portugal and easy access by public transportation. You can also visit the church that is attached to the museuem

Do not miss it!. This is really a very beautiful place to visit in Lisbon, so do not miss it! If there is a long waiting line to get in, no worries. Walk a bit to the left and there (also in the monastery) you find the entrance for the archeological museum. They also sell tickets for the monastery as well as combination tickets for both places. Then you can go back to the entrance of the monastery, pass the waiting line and walk right through.

First Sunday ofthe month Free. Get the Lisbon card, for one , two or three days, and you can take tram 15 to visit the following sites for free:Start after breakfast, at the Praco do Comercio, take tram 15 and stop at the Museum of ancient Art.- free entryTake Tram 15 and get off at Mosteiro de Jeronimos and visit the cloister for free, the church is free even without the card!Avoid the long queue at the Pasteis de Belem go sit at a table and have lunch consisting of pasteis de Belem tea/coffee and shrimp pastry-the bestVisit the Belem Tour if the queue isn't long- free entry with the Lisbon cardVisit the Monument of Discoveries and climb to the top for some splendid views including Belem Tour- discount with the lIsbon CardAfterwards visit the Couch Museum cross the street and instead of taking the 15 E- tram 15, go down the steps and east an excelent ice cream at SANTINI, as a prelude to dinner!

Beautiful but overpriced and looooong queue!. The monastery is a beautiful place but let's face it: it is NOT worth the now 10€ charged! We went there at 10:45 (opens at 10) hoping that there would still not be too many people but although we are in the end of October, it's crowded as hell! You have to wait a very long time to get a ticket, then make your way through the building without stepping on other's feet. The building is fantastic, the sculpture work, the tiles, it's all very beautiful. I imagined we would be able to visit more of it though, the building itself being huge but it houses two other museums so of course the historical visit part is limited. The church is accessible for free and it's very beautiful.In conclusion, visit the monastery if you have the Lisboa card as the visit is then free (but you can't cu the queue). Do visit the church in any case (evening around 18:30 is less crowded).The Lisboa card is not worth buying if you are a student!!

Crowds did not lessen the experience . We were there on a Tuesday morning and the tour busses had just arrived. We toured the free cathedral first and took the time and the euro to spend time in the sanctuary- fewer people and wonderful space. However, the nave is enormous so the crowds dissipate quickly. The crowd was very quiet giving even a more magical quality to the visit.The cloister also has a huge scale and I missed some of the peaceful nature of smaller venues. From the second floor you can enter the high choir loft of the cathedral, well worth the visit. There were two major exhibits: one on Alexandre Herculano who's life could be a model for us all; and one on a timeline of the Monastery in relation to both Portugal and the world. We took almost an hour on this alone!
Immaculate place. Really nice place, but I would suggest a little bit more information because there are no sign under the monuments!!

worth the visit. I was very luck to visit in the first sunday of the month (for free!). the Mosteiro itself is nice, as well as the church. You get to know a few Portuguese personalities who contributed for Portugal's history.

Overpriced but worth a visit. Not an awful lot to see inside but what is there is excellent. Don't be put off by the queue. It's not because it is busy just that the Portugese queue management is poor.
Well worth the queue. The elegant narrow pillars of the cathedral nave create a wonderful space while the extravagance of the detail around the cloister is amazing.
Atmospheric. This is an interesting monastery with an exhibition room. Entrance was free with a Lisboa card. Worth doing if visiting the other attractions in the area
amazing church. well worth a visit, can be visited along with Bellem Tower and Maritime Museum close by. Cross to the coast to see the monument to all the explorers setting sail from here.

Must See!. Beautifully restored (not always the case with many Lisbon landmarks) with intricately detailed stone carvings and tile work. The Mosterio is worth the price of admission - make sure you don't skip it in favor of only seeing the beautiful attached church (which is free).

Overpriced and overrated.. One of the more expensive entry fees in Lisbon, and not at all worth the money. If you were planning on seeing a few other historical sites in Belem and did a package deal then it might be worth it, but otherwise I'd advise skipping it. The cloisters are indisputably beautiful, but that's about it. Honestly seeing them in person was not much more impressive than seeing the pictures, and they're about all there is to see... If you're a big history buff then I'm sure there would be a lot more to the visit, but for me it was a big let down. My advice- Instead of wasting time here, grab a box of custard tarts from Pasties de Belem and have a little pastry picnic beside the Discoveries Monument on the edge of the Tejo river.

A must see !!!. A must see monastery . Free access with the Lisboa card. Easy access by public transportation ! Stunning architecture. Vasco's de Gama tomb is inside the monastery/ church. You can combine visiting the church that is attached to the monastery and also see the museum next door .

Very Very Busy on Sundays.. Very Very busy on Sundays, if you can choose another day do so. Even the tram getting there was crowded, not a problem for those who like standing for 20 minutes while smelling strangers armpits.The bus back was terrifying but fun, it was so crowded, the only place to stand was next to the driver, holding onto the ticket machine and trying not to be flung against the windscreen when he braked.

Most impressive building. This was a 'must see' for anyone going to Lisbon. It is architecture, history and geography of the world. A feeling of serenity and the past lingers in the beautiful building. It is beautifully preserved. The history of the world is told in snippets!!! Must be seen.....
Wonderful interior. If you think the outside of this monastery looks beautiful then wait until you get inside! The stonework and flying buttresses are worth the entry fee.
stunning cloisters. This monastery is well worth visiting for the stunning cloisters alone. The intricate stone work is fabulous. Anything you see after that is a bonus.
Jeronimos. A good place to visit, convenient to reach with public transportation. lots of other attraction near by.

Must-see for Lisbon. The monastery is not huge but is fascinating and the cloisters are stunning
I particularly liked the historical exhibition putting it in context of world events
Great value when combined with Belem Tower

Good visit, but busy!. Great place to visit. We went on the first Sunday of the month (it's free!) which was busy. Queues moved quickly. Watch out for the people trying to sell tat (sunglasses, shawls etc.) to you. They can be quite pushy! The monastery is really impressive, particularly the cloisters. Do visit the church too. When we were there there were interesting antique stalls in the park opposite.

Attraction worth the lines and price. Portugal, as other European cities, has plenty of churches and monasteries. Jeronimos is definitely one to visit! Both historic and artistic elements make this an enjoyable and rewarding place to spend a few hours, especially the cloisters.

Definitely worth seeing!. This is definitely worth going to. The church part is free, and that's worth seeing. But make sure you pay to see the cloisters. They were really amazing and it was absolutely beautiful. Especially on a nice day, you could just walk around and around it looking at the beautiful detail of the architecture.

amazin Arabic type monastery but not the highlight. I guess I've seen other monasteries that have amazed me more.is two floors, but not much to see.to me 10 euros for a patio type attraction is expensive. I hasD higher expectations.they don't give you any information board, or little description book.I had to open google and do my personal research.if you love monasteries and haven't seen much I would recommend otherwise come when it's free or with student card better and if not just be prepared what to expect.Don't get me wrong architecture is amazing.

A 'must see' on any trip to Belem. This is on most people's 'must do' list on a trip to Belem. We were fortunate as we hit it on the first Sunday of the month, when apparently, lots of otherwise charge to get in attractions are free entry. That did mean, though, that the hordes were far more, so we waited until late afternoon and found it a bit quieter. Nice church, nice cloisters/courtyard, nice refectory room and a calm and peaceful feel to the whole place. Good for a couple of hours of your time, I'd say
Archictectural Masterpiece. This is one of the unmissable sites in Lisbon. Beautiful example of the unique portuguese style of the time.

impressive facade - but too crowded. The exterior was wonderful and we wanted to go inside but it was closed for Mass for 2 hours. The whole area was heaving with tourists, like us. The queue for tram 15 was huge, with everyone pushing to get on, so we took an ordinary bus to the Museum of Arte Antigua - and had the place to ourselves.

Beautiful outside- couldn't go inside. . It is a beautiful building on the outside. The gardens in front with the water fountain as well. You have to pay €10 to enter which we thought was a bit high compared to majority of Europe. However, there was a funeral happening at that moment in time so if we wanted to pay the money we would have had to wait. Located in a lovely area slightly away from the bustle of the main city center.
Nice place to visit while in Belem. Try to get here in the morning, as the lines get longer after noon. Nice church with the monastery. Vasco de Gama grave makes you feel the history here.

One of the best sites in Lisbon. A real check to some of the more flamboyant sites. From our Spanish experiences we had associated Catholic sites with ostentation and over the top extravagance but this was not so. Yes, there was celebration but it was relatively muted and the decoration blended well with what the memorial was trying to do.Vasco da Gamas tomb was especially impressive, This site has a lot to teach others - especially in Italy - about keeping the human element involved. Impressive and humbling, even to people of no faith.
Nice place to see. Very nice worth a visit. October was a good timing, not too many tourists. Difficult to find the right transportation, we took tram and it was easy.

Quick entrance tip. We went to the torre first and got the two ticket option...you can then use that too fast track into the monastery rather than queue. It's also cheaper. For retired people there is a discount and you can buy a double ticket still in the Torre. Monastery was nice to see. The church is free so you should go inside. Check the times so as not to miss. The monastery did not take long once inside.Note: the museum's are only free on the first Sunday of the month and not every Sunday.
Beautiful cathedral. On the waterfront.Very crowded on weekends, but worth seeing this ancient church and monastery. In the Belem area.

Wonderful detail. An easy trip from the city centre on Tram 15 (the modern tram) takes you to Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. This is the burial spot of Vasco da Gama, among several other important historical figures. Fantastic detail to view, and even more amazing realising that the work was completed over 500 years ago.

Time's Change. I have visited many times and I always regarded the cloisters as one of the most tranquil and beautiful spots anywhere. The last time I was there they were free to enter and I was the only one there. How times change, now there is a queue, you need a ticket and there are lots of people visiting. Still its good that more people now get to see this lovely place.
Way too many people. It is an impressive building from outside but inside it needs some repairs and it will always be full of tourist no matter what. The cathedral is very beautiful.
Breath-Giving!. Holy, Holy this is an amazing place! If you go early in the morning you can take the best photos because people don't begin arriving usually until after 9am.

beautiful entrance to church, lots of busses. Toured only the free portion (church). Entrance is very detailed and beautiful, and nice inside, stained glass, etc. Overall, night a big church compared with others throughout Europe.Noticed a lot half plus full of tour busses. so if you do the other sights, suggest to arrive early in order to maybe miss that.
Morning in Belem .. This monastery was beautiful way to start the day. We were there @ 10am and beat the lines. Church has tomb of Vasco da Gama. Pretty church.

Majestic beyond words.. Once you approach this majestic Monastery your mouth will drop in awe. One of the most breath taken locations I have ever had the pleasure of visiting. This is truly the most beautiful work I have ever seen. This is truly a work of art that shows what man can build when they have talent and vision. This is a must see for anyone. You can not miss this historical site.

A must-see in Lisbon. One of the top sights in Lisbon this is a very imposing building. Step inside into a dark but very airy tall interior, stone walks and tall columns with a carvings everywhere. Beautiful chapels, gilded wooden carvings and beautiful stained glass windows. Plus the tomb of Vasco da Gama to see. Well worth the visit. No 15 tram from central Lisbon or a stop on the blue route (Tagus) of the yellow hop-on hop-off bus. Within walking distance of the Monument of the Discoverers and the Tower of Belem so make it part of a three way visit.
Stunning building!. Stunning building with amazing history. Don't forget to look up at the ceilings, they are realy beutiful.

Don't miss out on this beautiful ancient monastery!. This beautiful monastery was built in 1499! The cloister is simply incredible. What a beautiful work of art! I bought a combination ticket to also visit the Torre de Belem. Just please keep in mind that the Torre is quite a walking distance away from the monastery. It is also good to stop by at the Pasteis de Belem for any sweet tooth ;-)

Beautiful architecture. Lovely monastery highlighting beautiful architecture. We did the museum(fee) as well as cathedral portion(free). We took the 15E tram to Belem from Commerce square stop. Beautiful parks in the area as well. I would definitely recommend.
Interesting .... Well worth a visit when in Lisbon. Some great architecture. You will see the tomb of Vasco de Gama. It can get crowded depending on the time of day.

Enjoyable Visit. Wonderful place to visit, free entry to church, close to the Torre De Belem and Padrao Dos Descobrimentos, so give yourself a good half day to visit.Can use Red route "CitySightSeeing Portugal" hop on /off

Beautiful. We were on a bus tour and decided to stop in Belem and see this beautiful Monastery and are so glad that we did . The architecture is unique and wonderful. You can purchase one ticket to also see museums all in the same building but the Monastery is the main attraction.
Magnificent Monastery with high vaulted ceilings.. Place where explorer Vasco da Gama is buried. High vaulted ceilings which take your breath away. Across the road takes you to the river side.

A must in Lisbon . If there is anything that you do in Lisbon you must pay the monastery a visit the architecture alone makes this place fantastic. You can also go to the other two museums along the way. Plus there are some nice restaurants as well.

Amazing Monastery. A year ago I was sitting on a tour bus that passed by the Jeronimos Monastery and saw a long line awaiting to purchase admission tickets. This year I was on foot and entered. Thechurch is free of charge, and so there was no line to enter. Admission toThe Monastery cost a reasonable amount. Did you ever wonder why people stand in line in order to purchase a ticketto an attraction not yet seen? It would seem more logical to stand on line for something you have already seen and admired.The church and monastery were built 5 centuries ago. Big massive structures with lots of stone carvings. These churches which are also found in many other cities in Europe cause me awe just trying to imagine the logistics and engineering problems associated with erecting such a structure without the help of cranes etc.I enjoyed the visit.
A total must!!!. I have never seen anything like it. Gothic, but different. Exotic! Spacious, airy, simply beautiful. And spiritual experience, too.

A Cultural Masterpiece. In the west of the city, located near Belem is the Monastery of St Jerome, the finest exemplar of the Manueline style of architecture and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Although rather over-the-top for my taste, it is a masterpiece of intricate carving with a splendid façade. there are two main parts - the Church which is free entry and the cloister for which there is a charge. The richly (over) decorated church contains some royal tombs plus that of the explorer Vasco da Gama and a famous poet. The double-decker cloister is magnificent and is well worth the entrance fee.

What a gorgeous example of regional architecture!. Since the Mosteiro was on our tour bus route, we decided to get off and have a look around. It's a truly stunning building with fascinating sculpture and history. I have a weakness for church architecture, especially anything remotely resembling Gothic. The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos did not disappoint.

old classic cathedral architecture. spent hours there. the stained glass windows were out of this world. the above ground burial places of there prominent people. the history behind its existence. let me speechless and in awe. i cant say enough about this beauty and not far from there prized tigress historical river also.

Stunning closters but very popular with coach tours. This was the highlight of the cultural part of our trip, beautiful church with Vasco de Gama's tomb and magnificent cloisters with a superb view of the church from the upper choir. But parked opposite were 50 plus coaches disgorging their passengers.

Stunning Interior. A pantheon for some of Portugal's royalty, and housing the tomb of Vasco de Gama, this magnificent baroque beauty is well worth the sort train ride from Lisbon. Do visit the cloister, too, then stop for lunch at one of many inexpensive eateries nearby.

gorgeous monastery. The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos in Brown is an awesome sight with an amazing history. While no longer a monastery, it is now a beautiful church with the graves of Portuguese kings and explorers such as Vasco day Gama who made the first voyage from Europe to India in 1498. A must see.

Lovely sights. Beautiful sight, interesting architecture. The church equally beautiful. The whole area is lovely, Belem tower and monument to the discoveries across the street make for an enjoyable promenade. The famous pastry shop where you can sit and enjoy some lovely pastries and coffee after your long walk is heavenly!

Stunning architecture . This beautiful landmark was once populated by monks of the Order of Saint Jerome. The architecture of the columns are amazing, all different carved with ropes to sea monsters. Outside in the front is a beautiful fountain within a garden sculpted with coats of arms of Portugal. It's absolutely beautiful.

Impressive monistery. We went to visit it at the end of the day. We were able to see the inside and then got kick out because they were going to close. Overall, we would recommended because it was very beautiful. Too bad we didn't get there earlier.

Intricate architecture and history. If you don't even want to go in, at least have a look at the awesome gate with all the murals. There are two sections, one is free for visitors and the other has to be paid for, and there's usually a long line for the paid one. The free one is full of fantastic ornate arches and has the tombs of some of the great heroes of Portugal, including Vasco da Gama.

Historic Monastery and tomb of Portuguese explorer Vasco Da Gama. This Is a very ancient monastery. The building has intricate stone mason work on the exterior and elaborate decorative work on the interior of this large building. It is a beautiful building that also contains the tomb of the Portuguese maritime explorer Vasco Da Gama.

Visit if you can. If you are visiting Lisbon, this is one of the historic sites you must see. This is a UNESCO World Heritage Site as it is a primary example of Late Gothic Manueline architecture. The style is named for King Manuel I and distinctively references maritime motifs and the discoveries of Vasco da Gama (the first European to reach India by sea) and Pedro Álvares Cabral (the first European to sail to what we now know as Brazil). It celebrates the age when Portugal was a ruler of the seas. The "cloisters" was smaller than I imagined, but its stonework was beautifully ornate and the maritime motifs were fascinating. Don't miss visiting the Church of Santa Maria de Belém; Vasco de Gama's tomb is here. Mosteiro dos Jerónimos is in Belém, which has many other attractions worth visiting, such as Torre de Belém, Padrão dos Descobrimentos, Museu Nacional dos Coches, Museu Coleção Berardo, Pasteis de Belém and more. The area sits beside the Tejo River, and fantastic views abound. Belem is easily reached by Tram 15 from Praça da Figueira or suburban train from Cais do Sodré railway station. A few buses also stop here. Plan on spending several hours in the area. Avoid 11 a.m. to 1 p.m., as many tour buses arrive at this time.

Hugely busy. We only stayed for about half an hour because the tour groups were clogging up the Monastery, hitting people with selfie sticks, talking loudly (when signs specifically ask to be quiet) and generally being inconsiderate. If you have the patience, however, marvel at the columns, and the main door exterior, boggle at the fact the great adventurer Vasco Da Gama is buried there, and take pictures of the stained glass. We were too cheap to pay to go into the cloisters, and by which time humanity was testing us, so we left. The park over the road overs quiet sanctuary.

Absolutely stunning!. My husband & I stopped here in September while on our Mediterranean Cruise...what a stunning Monastery with a ton of history. We were blown away at all the beautiful sculptures and enjoyed learning all about this 16th century Gothic masterpiece. Very happy with all the amazing pictures that my husband took of this beautiful monastery....memories to last a life time! You can't visit Lisbon without stopping here!
Gorgeous Church. We saw many churches in Europe and this one was right up there with the best. Beautiful both inside and out. Very crowded though, so watch your belongings.

Awesome Architecture . I visited this site as part of a tour. Just standing outside and having the sculptures explained was mind boggling. Once inside you can sit in a pew and listen to more explanations. The interior is stunning and everything is overwhelming in size. So much history! Vasco de Gamo is buried here and you see his tomb at the back of this church. Definitely worth a visit while you are in Lisbon.
Impressive. Wandered around wide-eyed! Loved the cloister especially - so beautiful. Only downside is getting stuck behind slow-moving tour groups.
Beautiful. Beautiful historic location. Easy to get to from central Lisbon and well worth it. We enjoyed the sights.
Wonderful Monastery at the heart of Lisbon. This Monastery is a wonderful building of the XVI century and a World's Heritage site classified by UNESCO. If you have a Lisboacard the entrance is free.
Monastary. Only saw the impressive outside due to holiday closing to public. Lots of symbolism in the facade. Beautiful architecture

Crowds on Sunday. Situated on the outskirts, get the train from the city centre. Ornate exterior and interior. Visited on a Sunday with large crowds, access denied from 11am to tourists for a couple of hours while Mass takes place.
Stunning architecture. Stunning architecture. Staff quite helpful. We had beautiful weather so walked along the river after visiting the Mosteiro.

Wonderfull building. Spectacular buildings to visit and admire just outside the city centre along the river tagus take a bus or tram from the city centre,enjoy the whole atmosphere within the wals of the monastery.

Monumental and wide building, facing river Tejo, close to Belem tower. Now further from the shore then when built.. Interesting buildings in sandstone clours. Monumental inner yard. Left when entering is Vasco da Gama's grave.
A must see when in Belem. With free entry this is a must see in Belem. The monastery has a stunning interior and interesting history.

Worth a visit. Simple in some respects, ornate in others.. Interesting architecture and cloister area with very extensive and intricate carvings. Chapels are fairly simple by Spanish/Portugeuse standards.
Nice visit. Nice place to visit. Very beautiful architecture. The resting place of Vasco de Gama can be found in the church.

Really nice cathederal. Like most European cathedrals, the interior is spectacular and worth a visit. The cathedral is part of a larger group of harborside attractions in Lisbon so you're within walking distance of several other points of interest. The cathedral and these other attractions, make for a pleasant few hours in Lisbon.

The perfect model of Manuelito style. If you would like to see something unique in architecture of Portugal you should seJeronimos Monastery. The monastery was designed in a manner that later became known as Manueline: a richly ornate architectural style with complex sculptural themes incorporating maritime elements and objects discovered during naval expeditions, carved in limestone.

A beautiful monastery and chapel in Belem. Jerónimos Monastery is in the neigbhorhood of Belem in Lisbon. It's about 1 block up from that long line of people waiting to purchase pastries in Pastes de Belem ( its a thing). The monastery is huge and the designs of the rooms the courtyard and the huge chapel are not to be missed.

Stunning. The architecture is really stunning and unique, unlike anything I've seen elsewhere. We only had one day in Lisbon but it was absolutely worth making a stop in Belem to see this and the tower.

Wonderful architecture. Wonderful architecture, columns, history - a must see. A cool oasis after being in the hot Lisbon sun. A fantastic exhibition around the history of the world. Definitely recommend.
Don't miss this attraction.. Amazing architecture! Make sure you arrive early as this is a popular stop on all Lisbon tours and it gets crowded quickly. Glad we took time to visit the mosteiro.

Religion at its best. Our opinion may be bias since we have seen many cathedral, churches, and monasteries in our many trips. This one is good but not unusual. However, if it is your first time, it does deserve a visit. It is a good beginning to all other Catholic cathedral, churches, & monasteries.

Stunning! A must see!. We visited this and we were blown away by the nave. Absolutely incredible inside!!
We thought initially you had to pay 14 euros to enter and were glad we investigated further, as this turned out to be for the museum.
The highlight of our sightseeing in Lisbon. A must see!

Unmissable!. When travelling to Lisbon there are some places that you must visit and Mosteiro dos Jerónimos is definitley in the list. Built in the begining of the XV centrury, it is an incredible masterpiece with an unique arquictetural style. Situated in Belém it`s a great place to walk around. There you can visit it`s church, the cloister and some other rooms that are incredibly beautiful. An amazing experience.

Beleive Everything Positive You Hear and Read About The Mosteiro. This breathtaking building is absolutely worth the hassle to get out to it. A tip - take a Carris bus - get on at the the east side of Rossio square - way less crowded than the sardine tines (trams) and quicker and more comfortable. Everything positive that is said about this place is true - spend some time in the comprehensive historical timeline in the small chapel upstairs - and orient yourself in time (and space) to the sites around you. Sure it's crowded, and sure the entrance procedure is mildly chaotic, but it's definitely worth the trouble.
impressive building. closed when we wanted to visit so we couldn't go in, however the nearby patisserie more than made up for it

Spectacular. This is a must see forestination if you are in Lisbon. Granted the UNESCO WORLD HERITAGE SITE for its superb architecture and design it's worth paying the price. However I recommend purchasing the ticket for both this and the tower of belen in order to avoid standing on the queue. The cathedral is also the burial place of Portuguese explorer Vasco de Gama and it has no entrance fee.
Impressive :). Great place to walk around! The church is beautiful but the cloister is the place to be. Nice atmosphere. Combine a ticket with the Belèm Tower.

One of the must sees of Lisbon. It's quite a train or tram-ride for the center of Lisbon , but well worth the trip.While you are in the neighbourhood go for a pastel de nata and a coffee just up the road.

amazing building. A must when visiting Belem, it's free with the Lisbon card if you get one. Lovely two level cloisters, rooms off the side of both levels with temporary exhibitions about the history of the building.
Go to the back. The church is free and a wonderful place to visit. But do queue to go to the back, the heart of the monastery. It is just beautiful and well worth the queue and cost.
awesome. Jerome monastery visit was enormous in scale awesome. iwish I will be back again sooner/ Recommends that you do not lose your visit

Impressive. If you are in Belem and you have the time, it is definitely worth the visit. It is a bit on the expensive side, so you can weigh that into your decision. But once you are in, it is very impressive. There is a very interesting exhibit on at the moment, in one of the rooms, showing the history of the Monastery and the history of Portugal, alongside the history of the world. Helps put things into perspective.
A landmark to be sure to see. This is a major landmark of Lisbon, which has been there for centuries. The attached church was part of our four hour Grey line tour.
