Belem's most beautiful building...... It is like stepping back in time when you enter this awe-inspiring monastery. I was extremely lucky to get a personal tour by a friend and historian who works in the Monastery of Jeronimos . Giving me a unique insight into the story behind this gravity defying building from the 1500. It’s so overwhelmingly big it’s impossible to miss if you visit Belem. It is even free on sundays , making it a perfect cultural double date when visiting the CCB (The Cultural Centre of Belém)
Exploring Lisbon. This is a worth while visit. Go early as the crowds get very large after about 11:00. Lots to see in the area as well

Beautiful. Worth seeing! Gorgeous architecture the history of the first expeditions to discover the New World are here !
and then eat Pasteis de Natas at the local Café!
Interesting visit. Very interesting! A little windy but a fantastic old building, beautiful details and a fascinating insight into life "way back when..."
Not very exciting . Built to impress, but it didn't do it for me. The architecture is interesting and on a grand scale but it lacks human interest.

Amazing. A great collection of sculptures, windows and styles in one place. Our guide had set us the task to find a couple of particular pieces, so I probably missed a lot, but it was really interesting

Stunning!. The monastery at Belem is absolutely stunning. It's vaulted ceiling and ornate carvings and columns are just breathtaking. The whole frontage on the monastery looks like it's been iced by a master confectioner. Though busy, we did have to queue to get in, you do not feel hassled to move along quickly once inside and so can gaze at the beautiful reliefs at your leisure. The archeological museum and Maritime museums on the site are well worth a visit or sit outside in the wonderful park and admire the fountain, the view and the architecture

Beautiful Attraction with Sublime Carved Stonework. Mosteiro Dos Jeronimos & the Adjacent Church sits on an Attractive, open Area just back from the main Lisbon Highway in the Town of Belem. The Building can be seen from just West of the Town Centre & is Very Well Sign posted so is very accessible. The Exterior is Styled with a White Carved Stone Facade that has almost Impossibly fine Detail on almost every Window, Door or Niche. I Went on the First Sunday of the Month when Entry is Free & although there was a lot of Tourists here from Early Morning it took only Fifteen Minutes to gain Entry.  The Tomb of Vasco De Gama lies inside the Adjacent Church but is only Open during certain Hours outside of services so maybe check these times at the Church Entrance First to Ensure you can gain Entry.  The Monastery itself has an Absolutely Stunning Courtyard surrounded on all Four sides with a Cream Stone, highly Ornate Cloister on two levels that makes for a Wonderful Ambience, removing You from the Outside World in to a place of Peace & Tranquility. There is also a Museum here which houses some Great Artifacts of Lisbon & Belem History & is well worth a look. This is an Absolute Must See on your Lisbon Trip that certainly has a Wow Factor.
Very pretty church and monastery. Really pretty building with some exhibitions included and just beautiful to visit. Get your cameras ready for awesome pictures!

Fantastic but expensive. The building is simply fantastic but the price just to enter and walk around is a bit excessive. I highly recommend to go there the first Sunday of the month because it has free access!

Grand Religous Building. A grand and very decorative church - high stone portals that incorporate carvings of saints, complex shaped pinnacles & other decorative features. Inside you have spindly columns that support massive vaulted ceilings and a unque 2 level cloister, which over looks a large stone covered courtyard.Surprisingly, the courtyard area is very peaceful even when a large number of people are present.Not all areas of this attraction are wheelchair accessible - the chapel can only be accessed via stairs and according to my husband is very nice but a bit dark, so unless you are a professional photographer don't expect to get that perfect photo.

Wonderful cloisters. Obviously one of the sights to see in Lisbon. Little to add to what others have said. The cloisters are really interesting and we'll worth the visit. Try to get there early. We arrived at 10:15. Passing by later in the day we could see the queues snaking for a long distance. Whilst the hop on hop off bus is a good way to get there the least expensive way from the city is the No 15 tram. But be warned, this can get packed.
So so. Upon entering I was immediately reminded of the design of Salisbury cathedral. Its expensive to visit for what you get to see, which isn't much.

Breathtaking courtyard. Beautiful courtyard with some exhibitions displaying the history of the place. Kind of pricey though, it is ten Euro's entry fee and the site itself isn't that big. But if you love great classic sculpted architecture, this is your place.

A sea-themed monastery. Mosteiro dos Jerónimos was built as a tribute to the ones who contributed to Portugal's age of Discoveries. References to the sea, navigation and the conquered territories are scattered throughout every element. Camões and Vasco da Gama, two of the most important characters of these times, are entombed here.The church has free admission, so expect crowds. The cloisters and the museum have an entrance fee of 10€, not cheap but definitely worth it. A conjoint ticket to the cloisters and to Torre de Belém goes for 12€, which I considered a fair deal but it’s available only until 15h30.

The starting point of ALL the explorations and discoveries by the Portuguese.. Spectacular architecture... The significance of the Monestry of Jeronimos is unbelievable. Apparently all exkplorers spent the night in that monestry praying before embarking on the journeys that the Portuguese are so well known for. Oh and dont forget to visit the Royal Coach Museum...

Great place. This is a nice church and garden. Inside the church you can find the tomb of Vasco da Gama. The access to garden is free with Lisbon Card. Just get the ticket at Belem Tower where the line is smaller in the morning, and here you do not need to wait, just go in front and show the ticket.

A must see on your Lisbon visit.. The architecture and history of this facility are incredible. Be prepared for hoards of people as it is so unique that it does attract a lot of tourists. There are no pictures inside but post cards are available. It is such a dominant building when you are flying into Lisbon. Allow 1 to 2 hours for your visit. If this review was helpful please give me a helpful vote below.

Nice. So we got to see this beautiful monastery after our painful, burdensome and annoying wait for the Torre de Belem. I strongly suggest you to arrive before the opening of the monastery since you can buy both tickets for the monastery and the tour of Belem and only wait in one line. IT'S A VERYYYYY STRONG SUGGESTION since we waited more than 3h in a small line (what looked like a 20 minutes line). Otherwise, the monastery is nice, but takes litteraly 30 minutes to go around.

great architecture. You will love the great architecture and the history found here! I find the monastery itself to be quite amazing as it was build so long ago and it's still a place to call people to prayer!

A wonderful attraction-a must to see in Lisbon. The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is a little too far from the center to go on foot but it is worth to visit it. It is the best to take a Hop-on hop-off bus and spend some hours there and around. Since there are many tours visiting it I recommend to visit it as early as possible.
Try and avoid the crowds..... A must see but get there early to avoid the wave after wave of tours, which made the visit a battle......
Impressive church. Montero is quite large, crowded with tours. However, worth seeing for the architecture. Belen interesting area.
Historic 14th Century Monastery. Beautifully restored 14th Century Monastery in a beautiful part of Lisbon, close to the river, and Pastel de Belem- where you can visit the home of Portuguese Tarts.

An Interesting Lisbon Sight. The monastery and church are prime attractions on a visit to Belem. The church contains many fascinating sights, not least of which are the tombs of Vasco da Gama and poet Luis Camoes. A visit here can be combined with seeing other noteworthy sights in Belem and makes for a very nice day out.

Nice place. Lovely building! Full or architectural details. Easy access by public transportation and a good option for rainy days.
There a nice garden in front of it. Family program for sure! Save some hours to visit everythihng.

Amazing architecture. A great example of gothic architecture built around 1500 to 1600. The sculptures and differently designed columns we found very interesting and the main courtyard must have some stories to tell.The church contains Vasco de Gama's tomb which sets it apart from others its size but still quite impressive.Yes, you do need to go early to avoid the que's but there is a very worthwhile shortcut to avoid them. There is a museum next door called the museum of archeology which we found very interesting at a cost of EUR 5 or 6. You can purchase combined tickets for the Monteiro dos Jeronomis and the museum and avoid the que's.
Definitely worth a visit. €10 is a good price for this attraction. There is loads to see, a lot of history. There's plenty to explore, my favourite bit was the church and the stainglass windows.
Beautiful Cloister. UNESCO site this has a church where Vasco da Gama's tomb is located. From the 15th century the cloister is tranquil. Ornate designs on the columns, gargoyles, sea monsters abound.

The best of Belem. The monastery is much more impressive than the Belem tower and makes the short trip out of Lisbon worth it. The journey is simple - it only takes seven minutes by train from Cais de Sodre and there are around three trains an hour. We had to queue outside for some time but this may have been because we arrived at a busy time - if you're on a tight schedule, consider booking the tickets in advance to avoid this. If you do plan on going into the Belem tower (I personally don't think it is worth it), take this opportunity to buy a joint ticket. The monastery has stunning architecture and the visit is rounded out by some very interesting exhibits in English and Portuguese about those the Portuguese icons buried there.
emotional. Is very beautiful place with lost of history been at the tomb of Vasco Da Gama was very emotional for me.
" One of the Wonders". You will be amazed by these unforgettable sights,which should definitely not be missed by any visitor to Lisbon

Amazing but go early. We went to the Mosteiro early on a Sunday morning. When we arrived it was shortly before 9AM. There was no one there so we got some good photos of the front and were able to get into the church before mass. We left to look at another site and came back around 11AM. Wow, suddenly there were a lot of people around and the crowd just got bigger as the day went on. But the clostiers were definitely worth the visit. The restoration work makes of a truly remarkable experience. There is a lot to see here with other exhibits inside. We spent about 2 hours here.
Interesting place. Historically Rich. Interesting place to visit, and take a walk in the nearby monuments by the river.Fast access and one of the top places to go.
Stunning. Great visit to the Mosterio - full of interesting history and a hugely impressive building. The stonework is wondrous and awe inspiring.
Worth a visit. Amazing place, the chatedral is beautiful, the cloister a little bit too much for me.The visit is free on Sundays, until 2pm.

Tomb of Explorer Vasco Da Gama is one reason to go!. Interesting combination of Moorish architecture, Romanesque, and greek all in the same place! Tomb of Da Gama is a beautiful example of sculpture and the bastille font is massive. Definitely worth a look and so close to the Belem pastries which are a must a short walk away.
Jeronimos. Very good start to our tour of Lisboa. Lot's of history and beautiful architecture. Cathedral is amazing and the tour guide was excellent.

Impressive!!. Belem is a must of your tour of Lisbon and the Monastery is a must of your visit to Belem. Impressive architecture, impressive place. You will find here the respect payed by the Portuguese nation to its artists and heroes.

Step back in time. The church connected to the monastery is beautiful. The arched ceilings alone are worth the trip. The explorer Vasco de Gama's crypt is in the church too.The downside is that there was a long line to get access to the monastery. But it was awesome too.
Beautiful place. Definitely worth visiting. Incredible place, very peaceful. Go on a Sunday morning when the entrance is free.
Good!. Impressive! Well worth a visit, but the central garden is a little bit disappointing, just some poor grass but maybe its not viewed as too important.

A fascinating and yet serene experience. To travel to this site ,use the hop on/off bus. It stops right outside and it very frequent(about ever 20 mins). This is only one stop on the tour. It is a magnificent structure both outside and especially inside. To describe just how wonderful it is would play it down. Sometimes less is more and I think this is one of these times. Go, see and enjoy. I am convinced you will not be disappointed.

must-see architecture. It's gorgeous on the outside, but not so much to see inside. With the ticket you get access to the courtyard (quite nice), refectory (huge, interesting wall paintings), room with tombs, upper tier of the church. You can get inside the church without any ticket (or standing long lines, even with Lisboa card), but only the ground floor.
Great. The place is professionally prepared and the staff is friendly and helpful. The place looks amazing!
Go here! You will be amazed. Magnificent place in Belem! The pastries are a great reason to visit but this place is a better reason. Huge, majestic, historic and fascinating. Just go see it!
Beautiful and Peaceful . Its one of the rare places where you can feel the connection with GodThis place has a good wifi connection with God A must visit while in Belem

A Lisbon gem. Only 15 minutes walk away from Belem Tower, so one can plan to see them together. The church was nice, but the monastery was excellent! Beautiful architecture, carefully sculpted details, lots of symbols. There was also an exhibition that was showing the history of the monastery in parallel to the world history - very interesting.
Beautiful place. The architecture is just amazing, and I loved the whole atmosphere. There was a choir performing also, it made it even better!
Gorgeous Manuelin Architecture. Huge monastery close to the Belem Fortress. Divine Manuelin architecture with attention to details. Superb inner court and nice to see!
Fantastic architecture. This monastery features fantastic architecture and entrance to the church is free - a must to visit! It can be conveniently reached by bus.

In the footsteps of Vasco Da Gamma. This is a riot of a building, just standing outside and admiring the haphazard somewhat eclectic style of architecture is a day out on its own, add the maritime museum, the church itself (with Vasco da Gamma's tomb, and the cloister and you have a great visitor attraction.

A beautiful church. I did buy a ticket to view the cloisters courtyard and inside church from above in choir area, the best overall view of church and its stained glass windows , Tip -$2 euro extra buy ticket to Belem tower saves queuing again later.

Good Place to see (If you enter free with Lisboa Card). We went here on one of our many tours of Lisbon, we were able to go for free because of the Lisboa Card. I think if we would have paid to go in the museums we would have been disappointed. The museums were underwhelming, however the monastery and church part were very nice and worth the stop.
Don't miss it! . Very impressive building with beautiful architecture, don't even consider missing it when visiting Lisboa!
LOVELY CHURCH......................................... Former monastery and church. Beautiful on this inside as all churches in Europe seem to be, but worth a visit.

Do not bother with the entrance fee .. The church is free and the really interesting bit anyway.I do wish some people would remember that these are living Churches ,places where some come to pray an contemplate and SHUT UP.

Must see. This is an amazing place full of atmosphere and architectural highlights. Even if you are not interested in history, you will enjoy spending some time in the courtyard. Imagine what it would be like to eat in the former refectory. Apparently there are occasionally concerts in there.

Impressive church. Well worth a visit. You can visit the church for free and it's well worth the trip. Absolutely beautiful and you can see Vasco da Gama's tomb. You pay to visit the monastery. The cloisters are lovely.

Oozes Wealth. This is a magnificent monastery, with spectacular gothic architecture, very ornate, especially on the outside. The inside of the church is the final resting place of kings and poets, but the one more recognisable to the rest of the world is the tomb of Vasco da Gama, who died in India, but his remains were bought back to Portugal.
Beautiful. Vasco de Gamma tomb inside, very impressive, impressive other tombs and breathtaking interior. Being refurbished in this period, only the church is available for visiting.

Incredible monastery . There are two sections, the church which is free and the monastery which is €10 or €5 for students. The architecture is remarkable and in the monastery part there are two separate exhibitions and a gift shop. There is plenty to do in the area so if you are there I highly recommend to take a look.

Disappointed. Disappointed I had to pay 14 euros and only see a third or less of the area, because they divide it into another paid museums. The inside main garden is worth a shot, but too pricey for what you get.

Interesting and well worth a visit. We travelled here via the metro, an easy and inexpensive way to explore Lisbon. We spent all afternoon in Belem, and really this was nowhere near long enough. The Mosteiro is one of the most interesting attractions here if you enjoy a cultural visit. It's also nice and cool on a hot day!

Beautiful. Beautiful old monastery with remains of Vasco da Gama among others. It's also close to the Monument to The Discoveries and Belém Tower which is handy.Man outside the monastery was trembling and mumbling, not sure if he was mentally ill or a drug addict or possibly using it as a sympathy story. Either way he was definitely homeless and in a bad place which is obviously always sad to see.
Beautiful. Free with the Lisbon Card. Tram 15 left you at the front, most of the time it is crow, I recommend going by train or bus

Late Gothic Masterpiece. A masterpiece of Portuguese late Gothic style it is one of the few surviving Manuelin style architectural pieces in Portugal. The Church with the Vasco da Gama and Camões tumbs is a required visit for any visitor, the two outside doors are important pieces of decorative work in the early portuguese rennaissance but a visit to the Cloister, with its garden and light/shade aspects cannot be missed. Of great beauty, on the first floor the visit to the choir.

Architecture brilliance. This building had spiral pillars influenced by India, fantastic stain glass windows and bats in the belfry moment! You could almost feel the monks walking around in silent prayer
Church is amazing. Based on what we read and saw here, we opted to only visit the church and save the entrance fee. Glad we did - church is really worth a visit even though it jammed with tourists.
Unusual building worst seeing. Awesome example of a very unusual style of architecture which survived the earthquake 1755. This is very beautiful architectural style you can't find anywhere else.

Beautiful building . I visited here while staying in Belem but it is also easily accessible from the 15 tram and the yellow bus tours. I visited around 11am and there was a huge queue which took me an hour to get inside. €5 on a student discount (50% off) was definitely worth the effort. Beautiful old building an surrounds. I spent approx 1.5hrs exploring inside. The cathedral is also amazing

Amazing architecture. We caught the number 15 team to Belem and were greeted by this imposing structure on arrival at the terminus. Wonderful example of church architecture. The main spire is being restored but it is free to wander into the main transept and adjunct areas.Stunning carved stone interior work and high vaulted ceilings provide a view into the workmanship needed to create this church. They request silence within the church, we attempted to comply while other ruder groups treated this place of worship like a theme park - disappointing.

A monument with different architectural styles from XVI Century. It's one the most visit place in Lisboa. and always full of tourists from Monday to Sunday and in all year! Everytime I go there, I find always people coming from all the World. I can say that Mosterio dos Jerónimos it's a mini meeting of all five Continents!
Beautiful monastery. One of the most beautiful places I've ever seen! Both interior and exterior worth spending time to investigate carefully!
Manueline fantasy. This is a brilliant example of the Manueline style which was unique to Portugal and flourished in the early 16th century. Don't miss the beautiful cloisters.
Outstanding monument. World Heritage and a most-go place in Lisbon. Beware of the queues. Get around in the park and on the riverfront
Beautiful monastery . This is beautiful and if you do go you have to have a famous Portuguese tart at the cafe de Belem. Wonder round the port and park

A wonderful Experience. I visited this place yesterday, having taken the No 15 tram from Lisbon to Belem. There were a considerable number of coach tour visits, so I would recommend going there as early as possible in the day. We got there at 10 am and, even then, it was pretty crowded. It is a most interesting place to visit - the church is beautiful. Well worth the time and effort going there.
architectural delight. well worth a visit, very nice place to take awesome pictures, even if it is a bit crowded. nice visit even for younger kids.
very crowded. It´s a most beautiful place, but you have to be there very early to avoid millions of tourists,a visit to the church is free
Must visit!. After a stroll along the habour and the beautiful garden outside the Mosteiro (it was quite hot outside) Amazing place, and a lot of interesting history -beautiful and all worth a visit!
Amazing Building. If you are near the are then it's worth taking some time to admire with beautiful building. It is massive and the surrounding gardens are nice to have a walk around.

Beautiful but not great value for Money . Although it's recommended you should visit here (if only for the custard tarts around the corner), I would be in inclined to say the entrance fee is too high. 10e to walk around a courtyard with 3 very bare rooms is a little extreme. If you enjoy superb brick work, then this is your thing. If you're a couple looking for things to do, just visit the church next door for free and move on. Wasn't out thing.
Belem. Impressive old monastery in Belem. Beautiful church as well as a Marine museum and an archeological museum. The area is near other attractions in Belem. A nice place to spend the afternoon.
Stunning History. The monestaries stunning buildings and well curated exhibits make it an absolute must visit while in Lisbon. Try and pre book the queue can be very long

breathtaking stone carving. Well worth a visit. What a beautiful building. Well worth a visit, and Is situated amongst a number of landmarks and galLexie's so you can spend hours in this part of the city.

Really Crowded - but worth a quick look. It was free when we went - it has a lot of history - worth going in dont follow the crowd - cut threw the pews and go around the tombs on the other side of the crowds = pretty from all four sides
A must-see in Lisbon.. Beautiful, cool, moving, orderly, amazing photography, Vasco da Gama's tomb etc etc. Allow at least 1.5 hours.

The Most Beautiful Monument. One of the most historic place to visite,very well known for the history of Portugal ,from the times of war and Monarchy,the Castles the place were Navegatiors hide and faught to liberate the country..Beautiful monument ,amazing archicteture,and statues,beautiful work on the stones of the monument .This is one to visite when in Lisbon.

Stunning and Spectacular. Don't miss it if you would enjoy Portuguese culture! A very nice building design and construction which can also tell you the history of Portugal. Very long queue (over an hour) but well worth for the wait to enter the Jerónimos Monastery. Do wear a pair of the comfortable shoes!

More interesting from outside than inside. Interesting historic building. Not much to see, but a good way to kill a couple of hours. We could not go into the cathedral because it was closed for service, but we enjoyed our visit nonetheless.

Lovely cloisters . The inner cloisters are grand with intricate works in stone. In some way it resembles al hambra in granada Spain. Walk through the building. Afterwards go down the street and stop to eat the well known pasteri of Portugal in belem.
Beautiful Jeronimos. Amazing architecture and the museum gives you the detail of history across the road is tore de Belem easily accessible by public transport from city.
Don't miss the cloisters. A very dark and atmospheric church, some very nice stained glass and soaring ceilings; but the cloisters are full of light and lace like sculptures.
Gorgeous!. Stunning grounds offered a look into a different world. Very well restored and offered interesting views in the Cathedral

No queues for free winter visit.. We visited in February, on a Sunday during the free entry period. It was absolutely the best time to go. No long queues & no cost, perfect. It is well worth a visit, enjoyed it very much.

Beautiful and unique. The Monastery of Saint Jerome is a great example of the Manueline style in the architecture. Beautifully decorated courtyard means that you can spend a lot of time to watch it. You should also visit the church, which is also severe in the decor and stunning. Inside of the church is the tomb of Vasco da Gama.

Fascinating building. Fascinating building well worth queuing to look around. The church next door is free and very attractive. A good day trip from Lisbon with plenty of other interesting sites in the area.
Historical grandeur. Take your time to marvel at the stained glass and architecture. Entrance is free so expect to line up to get in.

Astonishing. Going to Lisbon and not seeing this...is like you didn't see anything.
It is absolutely beautiful outside and inside.

Beautiful and Impressive Building. It is difficult to take in everything you want to see on a whistle stop tourist bus trip around Lisbon. But make sure you give yourself enough time to take in this wonderful building and everything around this beautiful area.
Great area to visit.. Belem is a great area to visit including the mosteiro dos jeronimos. Went to the museum which was worth a visit seeing the old ships medals etc.
Grandeur. This place is really impressive, I had no idea how big it was! You can visit the Church for free, the best thing to visit or you pay to see the whole thing, which is really worth it.

Take your time and marvel at this peculiar/ornate manuelin style. I think it should not be missed in any trip to Lisbon, to marvel at this late gothic very specific portuguese manuelin style which was influenced by the maritime discoveries; unfortunately the line to enter is always huge, it became too popular. I guess most people do not have then time to wonder at the cloisters, do not miss them in awe!

Historical and Impressive . Coming from Canada, my sister and I do not see World Heritage Sites that often. We were impressed with its understated beauty and relative simplicity. Unlike many of the sites we have visited in Spain it is free, too! Seeing Vasco da Gana's crypt was an added bonus.
Impressive Place. We visited one Sunday morning in August. The place has very nice architecture and is a must to see when in Lisboa.

Well remembered monument. Well designed monastery and church it's in Belem area faced by gardens and a monument for the sailors and explorers. Worth the visit. Early mornings the tickets queue is shorter

Impresssive. A large building, a monastery with unique architecture in Belem. Highly recommended. But you don´t have to queue to get the tickets, you can get them in the adjacent buildings of museums.
Extraordinary. Amazing example of miguelin architecture. The best thing to do is to stay in the porch and to leave the eye go around.

must see visit!. Pay the entrance fee and visit the Beautiful courtyard and balcony of the church. The right long waiting line is to visit the church (free) but you will miss the beauty of the rest of the complex.

Impressive Building. Yiu can get here on tram no 15, we went into the church only which is free to the public. It is as beautiful inside as outside. It's also a short walk to the Famous custard tart shop in Belem. Worth spending a few mins at least here. Just be aware that there are lots of street sellers trying to sell you necklaces and other things, however a polite no often suffices.
Beautiful. It was free the first Sunday of the month which was a pleasant surprise to me. I definitely would have paid the money anyway because the inside was beautiful and peaceful. A must see!!

Don't miss the surrounding town. There is a lot of ambience in the little town surrounding the fort but beware of Africans dressed in robes trying to bless you on behalf of Fatima but they really want to force cheap bead bracelets on you for way too much money

Long queues, inefficient ticketing, more to see on the outside.. You see a lot more of it just standing in line and going to the free entry church. Also don't imagine the Lisboa Card helps you to skip the line - you still have to stand in line to get a 0 eur ticket. That's a bad joke.
Not to be missed. It is gorgeous, from the outside and inside. The were long queues to buy tickets, so my advice is to try to buy them in advance together with the tickets to Torre de Belem.

Very pretty - queues too long to visit inside. Made the trip to Belem via public transport to visit this lovely monastery and although it's one of the loveliest that I've seen in Europe, the queues were so long that we were not able to see inside. Maybe better on weekdays? Worth a trip if you have the time.

Breath-taking stone lace. it's one of the biggest monasteries I have ever seen and for sure the biggest in Lisbon. What strikes you is the way the stone is carved: so beautiful and airy, like you see lace. I'd say that if you are in Lisbon, even for 1 day, you shouldn't miss this place. And very close to it is the Pasteis de Belem where you can taste the famous pastries.

Beautiful. We went as part of a tour group from a cruise ship and we were amazed at the sheer number of tourists. The church is lovely, with a mix of architectural styles. Really breathtaking inside and out. Lots of photo opportunities and plenty of places to stop and take it in. They were doing some restoration inside, so it was scaffolding on one side and quite loud at times, but it was just so beautiful.
One of the highlights. Amazing architecture and well worth a visit. This was one of my favourite parts of Lisbon, however we only took a brief look inside, we didn't pay for a tour.
Beautiful but a hassle. This is really beautiful but it was hot and overwhelmed with tour groups. If I went back I would try to get there when it opened.

Huge and very interesting. A UNESCO World Heritage Site so this is a must in Lisbon (I am sure that by now you've read about it) but here is a tip - arrive early (ish) because the queue can be very long and if it's sunny and hot, until you get inside, there is no shade. The Monastery is huge so afterwards we went straight tothe famous shop selling Pasteis de Belem (5 minutes walk away) to rest our feet and load up on sugar. Delicious!

A must see in Belem. Incredible architecture! It is a bit of the way out of central Lisbon, but once you are in Belem there is plenty to see in the immediate vicinity. Be on the look out for Skinny Bagel, a great little food truck behind the gardens.
Impressive, shame about location and tourists. This is a huge, ornate building with lovely grounds, but the whole surrounding area lets it down and there are just too many tourists!

Most Amazing Arctecture...WOW. I stood in line for about 30 minutes to get a ticket and spent 3 glorious hours taking in all that I could of this place. The museum had two exhibits (2015)...a temporary Egyptian display and artifacts that were recently discovered underwater at the mouth of the Taber River. These were Portugal's own special history and culture. The cathedral was amazing. I walked around giant pillars looking up and up thinking about the glory of God. I am always awe struck just thinking about what went into building these structures. It had to be a labor of love. I'll go again if I return to Lisbon.
Beautiful!. Fantastic church with an interesting mix of artistic and architectural styles. The church itself is free, so go as early in the day as you can, before the tour buses roll up.
Amazing construction.. Facades are very impressive, amazing construction. Unfortunately I haven't seen it from inside, maybe next time...

Expensive for what it is. The place is beautiful, but it doesn't have much to see for 10€ it's really not worth paying for it. You can make lots of nice pictures but that's pretty much it. There is no furniture, just an empty building.

tips for visiting. It seems like the line is shortest around 2pm. We did not find out till we were almost to the door,they also sell tickets at a window in the front/middle of the building, then you dont have to stand in the long line.
Stunning monastery. Great architecture reflecting historic exploration and Portuguese identity. Take your time and enjoy this gem.
Lisbon vacation. Beautiful landmark of the city. The Belem area is a worthwhile daytrip. The church is spectacular. Interesting historic timeline.

Disappointing. The whole family was looking forward to visiting this place during our stay near Lisbon. We queued for 40 mins to pay to get in and there was very little to see. The courtyard is indeed beautiful with the building in Gothic Manueline style, but apart from a couple of rooms to visit, with info that you could read literally anywhere else, there wasn't much to see. However, the church itself is beautiful, but you can go in for free during masses for that, without paying the full fee to see the rest. So I would advise to go in the church as that is the best out of everything.

It's worth! Go and visit Vasco de Gama's tomb!. It is worth. It is a masterpiece. The church is a seductive gothic cathedral enriched by a Chorus (go to the museum!) and a cloister perfectly restored.Go and visit Vasco de Gama's tomb! It is a rare opportunity.Pay attention not to go when there are weddings or baptisms: the church is forcine and you can remain outside for hours!

Loaded with history. Great architecture and a historical treasure. Loved the courtyard and the intricate stone carvings. We also enjoyed the archaeological museum. Avoid mid-mornings when the tour buses drop off by the 100's and the lines are ridiculous.
Gorgeous Church. Beautiful monastery and it has an adjoining museum but the line for the museum was so long we did not have a chance to go in. The church was gorgeous!

Best sight in Belem. No visit to Belem would be complete with a visit to the monastery.
Easy to reach from Lisbon, quick hop on the tram and you are right outside the Monastery. You don't need to organise a guided tour, Belem is easy to do on your own.
Beautiful mosteiro. Big and powerful mosteiro, did not go inside though. Did see the church next to it and it was beautiful.

A piece of history of Lisbon and Portugal. An essential place to visit if you stay in Lisbon. It's a bit of history of the city and Portugal .Take an hour and get to know a little better a beautiful space in Lisbon.
Lovely building. A most see.... Buy a combined ticket with the tower to reduce queuing time... So full of history recent and ancient.

Worth the trip out to Belem. The monastery is a beautiful structure. You experience it at multiple levels... when you first walk in, you are overwhelmed by the magnitude of the structure. You are standing in the courtyard of a very large, two layer wedding cake of stone carvings. Then you start looking at an individual archway among the many of the wedding cake. Then you start looking at the carved details in the archway. Then you begin to notice that the carvings in each archway are different. Eventually, you make your way up to the second level and find more details to explore.There is also a display in one of the side rooms, that has a timeline showing history on three tracks stacked above each other: the history of the monastery, the history of Portugal and the history of the world. A good point of reference.The church is also impressive and worth getting into another line for, but it is the monastery that you come to see.You can take one of several buses or the 15E tram to get out there from downtown. We took the train from Cais do Sodre (a train, metro and ferry terminal). Fast and comfortable. Three stops (about 10 minutes) and 2.50 euro R/T. On Sunday, the trains every 20 minutes. We went on the first Sunday of the month, so entrance to the museums was free.

Avoid the queues!. Buy your joint ticket from the museum next door for both venues and walk past what can be horrendous queues from coach tours and cruises. Once at the door, the organisation and directional signing is chaotic and if you are not careful, you will still think you have to queue to get in. Carry straight on to get into the cloisters, do not turn left or you will be in the maelstrom of confused people with tickets in the queue to buy tickets. Once inside, the two level cloisters and views into the church are stunning.

Poor balance between effort and experience. Queue for an hour to visit a small fraction of the building - only the courtyard and surrounding gallery is open, while the rest of the building serves other purposes.Recommendation: visit the church, it is worth visiting and needs no queuing. To grasp this architecture peacefully visit Batalha monastery instead. It is a true gem, you can visit all of it sharing the place with far fewer visitors.

Spectacular building, beautiful cloister and church. We visited the church and the monastery cloister, they are fine. The only observation I make regards the price (10 Euros) that is perhaps too high (If I remember well the price of the tickets for the Uffizi in Florence is 12.5 Euros). Anyway it deserves a visit.
Amazing Architecture. Very impresssive, church next door was free, monastery was €10 but we used Lisboa Card and got in free.
Worth a visit. A bit expensive, and there are 2 places you can buy tickets from so you could stay in line twice. The building is truly impressive.

Fascinating attraction. Incredibly impressive building and absolutely massive when seeing it up close. Great for a relaxing wander but also for an education of the monastery’s, Lisbon’s and world histories at one of the exhibits here. Definitely one to visit.
Not to miss!. Once in Lisbon this is a "must do" place to visit... Great monastery in the "Manuelino" style, significant for the city both for its historical and its artistic value.

Good time to visit the church of the Mosteiro. If you want to visit the church, try to go when the mass starts, ie at 9:30 am or 6:30 pm. You will have a full 30 minutes to visit, listening to the mass, without the hundreds of tourists who enter the church, right after the end of the mass.

A must see in Lisbon. Whenever I go to Lisbon I always stop here. It's beautiful and easy to find your way around, everyone is always extremely friendly. Be sure to find the "Queijadas" shop, I always have fun trying to find it (takes me a few tries) but they are worth it.
Impressive but expensive. The architecture o the Mosteiro is beautiful but there isn't much else to see. For €10, it's on the pricey side for what it offers. But worth a visit!

get your tictickets at the museum to left of main entrance. As advised on TripAdvisor jump the long queues by getting your tickets at the museum a few yards from the main entrance. This morning the queues where horrendous we just walked state up to the desk ànd got our tickets straight away. As we came out I did try to tell others at the end of the line ( I guess they would have at least 40 minutes wait) of there other option but they just didnt believe me. The church was free not the most ornate I've seen, the cloisters were breathtaking. Well worth a visit but so glad we took TA advice.

Beautiful place, a great visit. It's an amazing place... There's a church (free entrance) with a somewhat gothic, somewhat renaissance style, with the tombs of Camões and Vasco da Gama. Adjacent to the church you have the Jeronimos monastery, with a rich decoration (the manuelino style), a nice hard, and the tomb of Fernando Pessoa. Very peaceful and very beautiful.If you intend to visit the Belém Tower later, be sure to buy the combo ticket and avoid the huge lines in the Tower.
Impressive architectural ensemble. A must see attraction if you are in Lisbon for more than a day. The petrified visualization of 16th century Portuguese dreams of wealth and pride as a global power.
One of Lisbon's treasures.. A very poignant and emotional place to visit. The church itself is free to enter and the alter pieces are stunning!
Monumental. Among this type of buildings this one is a memorable and unforgettable one. Truly amazing spaces and decoration.

A must see!!!. Not much is emphasized about this attraction in the guide books, and I had not put it on my top list of must sees, but glad we did. The architecture of this historical place is indigenous to the typical Manueline Portuguese architecture you see all around Lisbon. It is breathtaking, and we were able to get a lot of beautiful pictures of the grounds. It was interesting to find out, that this was the last place Vasco De Gama slept, before taking off on his voyage to the New World.

A not-to-be-missed site in Lisbon. Fantastic monastery with a beautiful chapel, approaching the size and grandeur of a cathedral. The attached museum is outstanding, with large displays of Egyptian and other ancient artifacts.
Beautiful both at daylight and in the evening. Very beautiful, but quite crowded in the first part of the day (in the summer season). You should visit it in the afternoon

An exquisite building full of history. Amazing. Well worth a visit! THis was built to commemmorate Vasco Da Gama and is truly a thing of beauty. He was lucky enough to return from his voyages to see it. Amazing history and easy to get to off the tram system.
Worth a visit. This monastery and church in the Belem area of Lisbon is well worth a visit. Be sure to go very early or around 1/2 o'clock to avoid the queues.
Difficult to get in if you go later in the day. Beautiful place to see.Very large lineup of people to get in on the first day we arrived. Suggested that you get there early and wait.
Don't miss. Can't miss! MUST SEE! This is beautiful, the whole monestary, the museum and the curch where Luis Vaz de Camões lays. Fantastic! Amazing!

Majestic Monastery with a full-of-detail cloister. It is a pity you can only visit the cloister but it was worth it. A two-storey full of enriching, delicious details cloister. You can almost feel the energy such renowned Portuguese figures emit as you wander. And then there's the church with the portuguese classic heroes Vasco da Gama and Luis de Camões alongside the entry. So you can imagine it: It is Portugal's Westminster Abbey.
Really nice. Buy you tickets in the museum next door for this place and for the tower then pass the queues straight in. View Vasco de gamma's tomb and the old monastery.

Afternoons seem quieter and the church (in the right) was free. Huge queues of coach tours in the morning ... but much quieter in the afternoon (as the guide books had said. The church on the right had an even shorter queue and was free ... it was busy inside but an impressive building, PLUS this is where Vascoa da Gama's sarcophagus is.
Very nicely renovated monetary . This monestary has long queues in the summer but the inside garden is really worth the visit in its own specific Manuel style.

There is nothing like this style of architecture, the whole of this pale grey building is heavily decorated.. The interior is no less impressive, there is almost no colour, all the same silvery stone and the entire building is a wonder in stone lacework. The central nave is held up by pillars of which everyone is in a different style of Manueline architecture. The monastery has very large gardens in front which lead to the Tagus and other historic sights. A real day out.
Dos Jeronimos. Fantastic place to go, very interesting convent. Well kept, you do need enough time to see it all as it is big. But a woek of art

Jeronimos. We took a taxic ab from Fourth Season Lisbon,I tell you got to be careful with those people, cause they take you around and around in town.. Our guy was older ,act like he did not speak english, and been an hour in the cab, although Jeronimos was 10-15 min max from our hotel. we ended up calling the hotel and get our money back, but our whole morning was just a waist. but once we got to Jeronimos it was fascinating.amazing place, the energie inside is just wow ! highly reccomend.Wasco De Gama's tumb inside:)!

Amazing. This monastery is massive and beautiful! Outside is way more overwhelming than the inside but definitely a must when in lisbon. I recommend purchasing the lisboa card which includes numerous sites and transportation for free or discounted, this attraction is free with the card

Good day out. A beautiful place, we have history, architecture, gardens, the river and the sun all together on a mix of the past and the present to add to the experience. And don't forget to eat the do delicious Pastéis de Belém.
Very special architecture.. Wonderful architecture - not quite like anything I've seen before - don't miss the cloister! It's gothic but with an organic quality, like something from a fairytale.

A must see. Very interesting history and many other attractions nearby make this a must see. Belem (the neighbourhood where the monastery is located) is about 15 minutes away from Baixa downtown by tram (#15 from Figiero Square)

Fantastic cloister - worth queuing to see. We had to queue in the very hot sun to gain access to this monastery. Fortunately the visit to the adjacent church first was cool inside. Once we entered the Stunning Cloister it took your breath away and we all said "wow" as we entered it together. Worth queuing in the heat to see this.

Portuguese history at its best. I did this tour with some friends and they were extremely impressed with the entire presentation, I was in awe to find some history I did not know about when I studied in Portugal. This monument is extremely beautiful a must see while in Lisbon

Lisbon's Greatest Church. This fantastic church offers a vibrant glimpse of Late Gothic Manueline architecture. The church was built during the Portuguese 'age of discovery', which was marked by a booming economy and funded the construction of this massive church.

Outside and inside superb. Yes, you will probably encounter a lineup. To give you a tip you can purchase tickets to this attraction at both ends of the building. This place was recommended by a friend who lived in Lisbon for a while. Not cheap at 10Euro per adult, but worth it. We especially enjoyed the exhibit on the top floor that compared the history of the monastery against the history of Portugal and the world. A great education on Portugese history as well. You can take your time as well as it is self-guided. Lots of spots to sit and reflect or just people watch. No need to rush. Some old and interesting practical exhibits to enjoy.

Certainly the Lisbonne Must to visit. Really beautiful and nice. This place has to be visited to discover an exceptional architecture, a past an history.. What a pity there is no audioguide to tell us its history..

Wonderful experience. A wonderful experience! Loved it! Huge building where you can walk around for an hour or two. Packed with tourist taking photos which is not easy to avoid. We sat down in the church for a while and listened to a man playing the pipe organ. Amazing architecture, of course!!!
Beautiful really old monastery. Really old monastery, around 30 mins from city centreClose to two other popular tourist attractionsThe trams to this area are mostly crowded
See ALL the Museums here, not just the monastery. The monastery is very good - but even better when you walk just around the corner and take in the Maritime Museum as well.
Beautiful and enjoyable!. Nice and worth an hour or two! Cut the line if you have toddlers or babies and walk across to Discovers statue and Belem Tower!
Beautiful inner yard. Beautiful building, very historical but the best part was without a doubt its beautiful interior court. Great timeline of the Portuguese and world history.
Wonderful building full of history. Wonderful building full of history. It's Manuelin style and has a huge Basilica and a Museum. From here departed the portuguese navigators.

Great architecture in a fantastic location near Belem Tower. This place is worth seeing alongside the Belem Tower as its very easy to walk across. This place has fantastic architecture and history and is in a nice open location.

Beautiful views!. Only viewed from the outside which was absolutely beautiful with tons of picture taking opportunities! And lots of 'pop up' stores with food and souvenirs (little cars or vans). As well as great landmarks of Lisbon!

Don' t miss this one.. Both the exterior and the interior are beautiful. The museum and the loiseter combo ticket is the way to go; the church itself is free. I missed the sacristy because it closed. From the cloister, you can look down into the church but you still want to go inside the church to see the interior and to see Vasco da Gama's tomb. Lots of information on boards in English. The boards in the museum were written in English .. The guy can't write for a toffee... The words are there but a lot of it makes very little sense overall. Not a big deal... Lots to see and learn and exeperience. The delicate architecture overall is beautiful. Prices are reasonable. Not far away are shops, small restaurants, a pastry shop and - praise be to God in the highest - a Starbucks. The Tower of Belem and the Monument of the Discoverers are within walking distance, as well.

STUNNING. Don't miss this spot! The monastery is absolutely beautiful! So intricately detailed, I almost didn't want to leave. I recommend hitting this one first thing in the morning since the line gets quite long for the entrance. The church is free admission though and there's no line. Entrance fee is also convenient for families (50% off).

This is a must for any visitor of Lisbon. Exceptional example of the late gothic style unique for Portugal, the Manuelino. Do not miss the main church and the cloister. And, not far from there, go to the Belém Tower

Bella Vista. Board the tram at Caisson de Sodre it takes about ten minutes, the Monastery is worth the visit for the stained glass also Vasco Da Gama tomb. Next to this is the museum of Royal stagecoaches again worth a visit. You can walk through Belem Park to Belem tower. There is also a modern art museum with Dali and Warhol.Finally you can get a famous custard tart at the cafe in Belem
Amazing Architecture . A must see when in Lisbon. The grandeur is simply astonishing. Try to get there early to avoid the queues.

Gothic Wonder - no pigeons. We had to do the Touristy thing whilst in Lisbon. The Jeronimos Cathedral - cum Museum is a must. Its a beautiful Gothic building, beautifully maintained and somehow the Portuguese have found a way to keep the pigeons away. That was something that was really noticeable and nice... The actual monument consists of a church (Free Entry) and then a series of various museums depicting Portuguese History through to the Planetarium- various entry fees and rates - Plan the trip to take quite a few hours to do it full justice.
Must see!. This place is very beautiful, quite unusual and well preserved. I recommend the free guided tours to fully discover the place

A Must See in Lisbon. The free bit is the church. I would have paid for the church alone. The contents are astonishing. You pay for the cloisters, the chapter house and the refectory. the line was worth the wait.

Impressive Monument. This monastery has among others things a principal objective when it was erected, back in the discovery times: the motivation of those who went over the oceans in order to discover new lands and routes for the spices commerce.All the vessel departed, at the time, from this point, as the water line back in those times was very near to this place.Near by there are other atractions worse a visti.

Historical architectural wonder!. One of my favorite places in Lisbon. One never tires of the ornate and detailed structure. It's beautiful and peaceful to wander around the courtyards and admire the architecture. It's one of Lisbon's best Keepsakes and not to be missed.Take time to relive history and go in the early morning or late afternoon during the week to avoid crowds. Nice to attend a Mass and be in awe as well as absorb the spiritual experience!Well worth a visit and to spend time.

Do you have to pay for this?. A typical monastery like there are 13 in a dozenTypical square hallways and a bit og grass in the middle.I can't believe this was over 10 Euro's entrance.There is a free part, a church to visit, which was the most impressive of all.

Beautiful !. A really impressive achitectonic masterpiece. Lots of history and the rest place of Vasco da Gama ! Be prepared to wait in line if you didn't purchase tickets in advance ! Totally worth it !
Great visit. We found the Mosteiro to be well worth queuing for tickets. The impressive cloisters with the variety of carvings depicting sea motifs from the age of discoveries.
Beautiful really.. So much history and intimate detail. Definitely worth the trip, plus you can take the famous streetcar 15 and see more of the city.

So much history at San Jeronimos. This was one of my favorite places. I was raised Catholic and connected with so much of the art and history here. The stained glass windows in the chapel are gorgeous. A must see to understand Portuguese history and culture.

Allways a pleasure to reenconter Portuguese history. If you enjoy arquitechure and history it's a couple of hours well spent, if you ane not a Monuments fan, only go if there is a temporary exhibition that might interest you.

Brilliant Architecture!. If you are in Lisbon, you will definitely head to Belem, if you are in Belem you need to visit this amazing building! Make sure you look up! Either go first thing in the morning to avoid long queues or book online!@instabuilt

Wonderfull and huge. Very nice Renaissance architecture, semicircular arches, huge construction, in Manueline style, a style of art that served to glorify the great discoveries. It replaced the church formerly existing in the same place, which was dedicated to Santa Maria de Belém - its construction was during 100 years periodOutside there is a big garden with a fountain in the center.It was built to commemorate Vasco Da Gama's voyage and to give thanks to the Virgin Mary for its success Vasco da Gama's tomb was placed inside by the entrance.With Lisboa card you have free addmission.Must visit.

Captures Portugal's history. The whole area of Belem is stunning, clean and touristy. As with any major tourist attraction we were warned to be on the look out for pick pockets! There is a beautiful fountain in the grounds in front of Jeronimos. The history that is captured in this monastery is simply amazing. The Moorish influence is evident, travels by ship to far away lands is depicted. Whether one approves of the history or not, history is history and this place depicts it all. I loved the many references to both Africa and India. Lions and elephants all over the place. Tombs standing on four lions heads for example. Do not miss this. Well worth the price.

It's even possible to find a calm space!. Swarming with tourists but possible to find relative quiet and reasonably priced cafes for replenishment before going around this beautifully decorated church. Go early to avoid long queues for its treasures.(Charge for the latter).
Great Lisbon sight.. Amazing place, but make sure you book online. Very large queues. Definitely one of the great sights of the city.
Start your day at Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. A must see! Get a local to help you buy the entry tickets online in advance to avoid the very long entry lines.

Truly beautiful and unique. The Belem district is delightful; the gardens, the old Torre de Belem and the Padrao to the Discoverers. But the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is absolutely spectacular. Don't be put off by the long queue - there's a reason why so many people want to visit. In fact the queue moved quite quickly and we were soon in the cool cloisters of this magnificent building. The tiled refectory and the cloister areas are very impressive, but the church, especially when entered from the upper level as we did, is as magnificent as anything I've ever seen. There is also something rather moving about viewing the tomb of Vasco da Gama just a few hundred meters from where he set sail on his daring voyage of discovery. If you like art, architecture and history this building is a must.
Beautiful Cloisters. Very impressive monastery and the cloisters are beautiful. I would highly recommend a visit. Just be aware that not all the guide books tell you it is closed on Mondays.

Lisbin Main Attraction. Thos is the portugese name for the grave of VASCO DE GAMA, it is a MUST visit, for indians, you will see the final abode of the man who sailed so gar in difficult times and discovered INDIA, for the Europe... there is also the grave of a contemporary sailor of equal importance in the same building,.... so do go here, as a free gift you will be newr the Ocean or maritime museum, the Electric Museum, the Foundation Monument and the Belem Tower... and also the 25 april bridge, one shot and a lot of places covered
Impressive must see. Happily surprised about this visit. Impressive building. Rather well preserved.It also host an exposition on generic historical facts on a fun timeline.

Amazing and historic - but busy and expensive. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is an amazing sight, situated in the Belem area close to Lisbon.First things first, if you are travelling here from Lisbon, catch tram number 15 from Praca Figueira, a modern style tram, which accomodates more passengers than those normally seen in the city. Whilst this is very good, it does get caught in the city centre traffic and you may wish to consider catching the train to Belem station from Cais de Sodre instead.The building is a fantastic sight and is a 'must-do' however the queues were a little large and slow moving on our visit. The cost was 10 Euros each, not too bad until you factor in the cost of paying for a full family.The main thing to see as you enter is the cloister, a superb and very decorative sight, but I would imagine best seen when the crowds are a little less busy as it would be better seen 'in the quiet' as it was initially indented for.There is also a church, accessed directly next to the entrance which is free. This includes the tomb of Vasco de Gama and Luis de Camoes.Overall, this is a great piece of history and worthy of a visit, just try to catch it when the crowds don't overpower its beauty.

Impressive. This is one of the most beautiful religious buildings I've ever seen. It has the detail of Sagrada Familia in Barcelona. In terms of design it should be more renowned, in my opinion. I didn't even go into the cloisters, just the chapel (which was free). Just that alone was impressive.

Interesting History.. It is a must when visiting it. Stunning building with so much detail and interesting history. This has been under construction since every detail; it is easy to miss details. It is impossible to describe this masterpiece and shouldn't be missed.
Brilliant synthesis of European late-Gothic style. Nice few hours visit of monestery, church and museum. Very beautiful. We had a Lisabon card, so entrance was free.

The Place where History was Made. Breathing Portugal's history, including the signing of Portugal's accession to the European Communities (now Union). We were there on May 9th, Europe's day. You cannot understand this country and its beauty without paying a visit to Jeronimos.
Long wait. Wish we knew we could buy the combined tickets for this and the archaeology museum from the museum next door and not wait under the sun for an hour.
Very beautifull. One of the most iconic monuments in Lisbon and in Portugal. A must see in the riverside zone of Belém. Very beautifull.

Awesome place to visit. A work of art, the detail and architecture are amazing.. Loads to see when visiting. The church is so beautiful as is everything here. We just couldn't take our eyes off the detail. So worth the visit.

a unique monastery building that helps you travel back in time. a must see if you visit Lisbon. Built in a Gothic Manueline style, a style that is unique to Portugal and that incorporates maritime elements - a reflexion of Portugal's naval expansion.
one of my favorite places to spend time in, the cloisters garden is both peaceful and mystical, and in a hot summer day, refreshing to be in.
Must see!. What beauty and history! We would recommend visiting with a tour or group, as the lines for admission were quite long. Stunning architecture with its intricate columns and arches.

Here you will find Vasco Da Gama. Beautiful church at Belem. You can take tram 15E from downtown Lisbon to get here, but be prepared, as the driver does not stop at all stops. From here you can walk to the Tower of Belem, and have the Portuguese famous pastries at Pastéis de Belem.
Magnificent. Built when Portugal was a rich country. One of the most beautiful monasteries in Europe. Do not miss the nearby 19th century coffee house that specializes on "pasteis de nata".

An imposing building. Monastery intriguing, fascinating buildings, fascinating interior. Indescribably beautiful relief in stone, as if it were all woven lace. Spacious interior with arcades and central fountain. The church is monumental, view bark is beautiful. The vaults are incredibly nice and high. An imposing building.

BEAUTIFUL !!!!!. Very long lineups in the very hot sun. We stuck it out and were glad we did, but couldn't believe that there was only one guy selling tickets. He said one guy called in sick other on break. UNBELIEVABLE. Anyway it was beautiful once inside. Lots of information boards to explain the history. The only way for us to get here was tram 28 which is jam packed full.
One of Lisbon's top monuments. It's absolutely majestic! A great representation of King D. Manuel architecture. And it's just across the street from the tasty 'Pastéis de Belém'!
Some more information would be great.. It was closed and we discovered it only once we got there... even the taxi didn't know it. We specifi alla asked and they were sure it was open.

Interesting but too expensive. Definitely interesting but too expensive. 10€ per person is too much. I enjoyed the stone carvings and history information. The mosteiro is something for people who have seen everything else in Lisboa and have some time and money left over before they go home. 3/5
The church!. Decided not to pay for the ticket and just visit the church beside which is for free, it was so worth it, probably one of the prettiest in Lisbon.

Interesting architecture. Pricey at 10euro a visit, plus the queues can be crazy to get in. But I took the free walking tour offered inside which was pretty interesting. Worth a visit as it is spectacular to look at inside and out.

Loved the Gargoyles. A very beautiful and ornate Monastery. The building was grand and spacious. The cathedral was beautiful. What we liked best were all the gargoyles of different designs that were to help the rain water drain. It would have been amazing to be here during a downpour.
Go for the cloisters. Nice cloisters.You have to pay extra to visit evrything. Sometimes long line ups. The cloisters itself is worth the visit. The church is huge...
Nice and cool inside on a very hot day. Impressive building. From the inside is was in parts reminiscent of a giant, intricate sandcastle. Certainly worth a visit.

Beautiful building. Top Tip: There are often long queues waiting to get tickets for the Monastery. However, the museum which is on the left also sells tickets to the monastery. Confidently walk down the line and cross into the Museum and you save yourself about half an hour!There is no furniture of any kind in the monastery which makes some of the rooms seem vast. The central courtyard surrounded by two levels of cloister is a real highlight. The cloisters are wonderfully cool. On the upper level there is an entrance to the balcony at the back of the church. The views down the church are not be missed.
A must in Lisbon you can't miss. Na hystoric monastery of the XVI century with a lovelly stone work, located near the river Tejo, and very close to othe interesting places and museams of Lisbon

Beautiful but a bit depressing. Beautiful, inside there is a massive altar made with gold from Brasil (You are welcome, Portugal!) which is simply stunning. It is close to the main entrance so as you leave the monastery almost blind with all the gold, you have to watch your step otherwise you might collide with the people begging at the door. Gotta love organized religion!

Stunning . Of course it's crowded in the most touristy periods , you have to be aware of that before you choose the date of your visit. If you have a Lisbon card it's free , go in the morning and if there's already big queues get your tickets in the museum beside it and skip the big queue. It's absolutely stunning , reminds me a bit of Harry Potter. There was a wedding on when we were there , they're so lucky to get married in such a magical place.
Beautifull monument. Do not miss Vasco de Gama's tomb at the exit of the church. Lisboa card is accepted. 10 min of walk from Bélem station.

A beautiful place of quiet contemplation. My friends and I visited the monastery in the late afternoon which turned out to be very fortunate since several people have told me since that the queue to get inside can be a bit daunting at times. But not so for us as the place was practicly deserted when we got there. But even with a bit of a wait I would still recommend visiting this old cloister if you are even the slightest bit interested in architecture and history. The building itself is simply awe-inspiring. The inner courtyard, the walkways, the church, ... all are simply amazing to gaze at. And for only a nominal fee well worth the visit.

Quite beautiful. you pay to enter the monastery, but the church attached to it is free entry. the earthquake that devastated lisbon in 1755 (?) did not manage to fell this beautiful structure. so given what lisbon went through with the quake and resulting tsunami, it's amazing to consider how well this monastery was built and the stories it's walls could tell. we were there after lunch in the early afternoon of mid-jury and had only a very small queue to deal with. there's a large and beautiful courtyard inside and an entry to an upper level of the church which offered a great vantage of the church.
Beautiful but crowed on a Sunday . Beautiful but do not go on a Sunday, ques were very long and it was too crowded, it spoils the experience.

Amazing architecture. If you are planning on visiting the monastery and visit Lisbon in the summer, I would recommend getting there in the morning. You will likely have to queue to go in, which took us about 15 minutes and was unsheltered in the heat of the day. Once inside, however, the monastery was incredibly impressive, reaching over two floors with stone carvings in every direction. A tip if you are planning on visiting the monastery and tower of belem or other sites: you will be able to buy a joint ticket which saves queuing as much at the next site! Also, if you are planning on visiting Sintra, I would recommend visiting the monastery first as it seemed slightly underwhelming; however, I'm convinced that if we'd visited the monastery beforehand we'd have been highly impressed. In any case, a lovely hour exploring this famous site.

Rich in history!. The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is a UNESCO world heritage site and is well worth a visit to explore. Allow at least two hours to look around. Be warned though it is very popular and the queues can be lengthy, particularly in August when we went. There is also little shade, so a good idea to have a bottle of water with you. It is also a good idea to buy a joint ticket for the nearby Torre de Belem, allowing a fast track entry so it isn't necessary too queue twice.
Watch the queues. Watch the queues. We found a ticket office just on the right hand side which saved time but still queued fir nearly an hour. Get there early

5 stars I say for the architecture!. A generous 5 stars because I personally found the architecture of this Unesco listed site exquisite. They provide 3 guides for a 30 minute visit. He knew enough to make the visit exciting. Every thing is translated in English and French so gives you time to wander while it's not in your language. A recurrent theme in Portugal seems to be chaotic organisation and one had to be very inquisitive to know where to stand in order to attend the guided visit as different staff say different things. There is a very large and very well done time line covering several centuries worth of world events. Entrance fee is very reasonable (24 euros for a family of 4 which also included Torre de Belem (valid for 48 hours). Another King-requested expensive monument but it makes for happy tourists down the centuries. Plus another Unesco box ticked.
Amazing building. Amazing building with gourgeous architecture.Close to Belem Tower in a nice neighborhood. Small fee to pay at entrance.
Beautifull. Must see! We visit just the church (its free). The interior is beautiful. Lots of details. Make sure you take of your hat! ;-)

Fascinating and engaging. We went there not quite expecting anything. The train trip was easy and the walk along the front was eyeopening. Unfortunately the chapel was closed but we went into the main area and could look down into it so nothing lost. The ticket access is confused at best but be patient. We wandered around at our own pace without crowds and it was incredibly peaceful. The architecture itself is simple but large and quite overwhelming. Its a great place to relax and think.

Beautiful . The monastery is beautiful and really a sight to see. If you have a Lisbon city card or other pass it will be better because lines can get long in summer and €10 i think is too much to see this place. It's not that big and not a lot to see inside.

Portuguals history lies within. Lots of history in this place. An exhibition is held in one of the castle chambers which resumes the history of the world and the history of the monument itself which is interesting to see. A student fee may be available once a student card is shown.

Amazing!!!. One of the most beautiful and rich buildings in Europe. The manueline architecture achieves his pinnacle with this marvelous building. The carvings on the stone are unbelievable. I thinks is the number one attraction in Lisbon (beautiful city).

Good!. We decided to start our second day in Lisbon visiting this monastry in Belem! Its was so nice and interesting as we discovered the Portuguese culture. The fact is that we had to be waiting for a long time and the price of the ticket was a bit expensive. Otherwise, I recomme d you to visit it.

Worth a visit. This landmark is a little way out from the City centre but is definitely worth visiting (but not on a Monday when it's closed). We had expected a long queue to get in but we got there around 4 p.m. & didn't have to wait for long at all Inside it is very impressive & there is lots to see You can visit the cathedral for free if you are short on time & money

Gorgeous example of classical manueline style.. First, avoid the lines (they can be VERY long and in full sun too), buy a Lisboa card or go on Sunday when it's free. It's very close to the city with direct bus lines or a reasonable taxi ride. The details of the cloister are remarkable, with fantastic sculptures of mythical animals. There are a number of beautiful rooms belonging the monastery with various exhibits. The church visit is free, if I remember correctly. The great Poet Pessoa is buried in the cloister.

Must do in lisbon. After restauration very Unique mosteiro with beautyfull garden Avoid peak hours and combine with the environment with torre de BelemDon't forget to by nearby the only real pastels de belem
Nice place to start a trip in Lisbon. Beautiful cathedral and cloister, the landmark that you cannot miss when travelling to Lisbon. You can skip everything but not the Jeronimos and Belem.
Great place to see in Lisbon . Monastery is a must see in Lisbon. Save time by buying your ticket for the monastery in the museum next door to it and you skip the long queue and go straight in.

Highlight of Belem. Ornate monastery with a very distinct Portuguese style that was striking to me even after a couple weeks visiting cathedrals in Spain. Tombs of Portuguese hero Vasco da Gama was of course a center of attraction, but don't miss all the other details. I actually went on a day when there was no entrance fee, and there was almost no line at all, but if I wish to visit the cloister I had to pay.
A view into the past.. This place is small but very pretty. Not the entire building belongs to the monastary, but it is still worth the visit.

BELEM. Visited the monasteririe via tram 15- slow but beautiful trip. Went to the Lisibon riders accross the way - beautiful. Cost to take elevator to the top not worth it. Went to the pateis shop and enjoyed the restaurant.. Nice to sit and get a coffee and water instead of the long take away line outside.

Three days of Museum's. Starting in the Naval part the first day and it is very large it will take a long time to go threw it . The next time we went to treasures part which is very interesting . The final one was the church which is simply amazing . It is very huge and a marvel to look at .

Must see in Lisbon/belem. Every european town has its must see church and this is Lisbon's classic church. Lovely church which you can visit for free, or you can also pay and go inside the cloisters as well. Resting place for Vasco Da Gamo and nice architecture.Wrote about our full time in Lisbon if you need more travel tips on chiliandtart.tumblr.com.

Must see. There is an option to see the church for free. And this is a great marketing trick. When you see it, you know that leaving now would be a great mistake. The fireworks of baroque and classical designs make impression on poets and engineers. Great place for a photo-shoot sessions ...

Beautiful place to visit on your trip to Lisbon. Great place to visit on your trip to Lisbon, can be reached easily by tram or bus and is perfect for families with younger or older children and also for couples. Not expensive to get in and you can use student discount. We went in the monastery section not the museum section but wished we had! Doesn't take too long to go round so you could go in the museum on the same day and/or stroll up to the modern art gallery. Also if you walk a short distance there's some lovely cafe/restaurants overlooking a park.

A photographer's paradise!. We reached this beautiful building by the hop on hop off bus. It's then convenient for visiting the Belem area. Beautiful carvings and gargoyles make this building attractive to photograph. Can get very busy with long queues although we only had to wait for about 5 - 10 minutes. Beautiful cloisters. Contains the tomb of Vasco da Gama. Well worth a visit and we bought a ticket which allowed you to go in the Torre de Belem also.

Busy Place. Even with our Lisboa card we had to stand inline to get an admission ticket. Took about 15 minutes in the morning. The cloister is very ornate and you can go on both levels. After the cloister, your ticket includes going in the church. Someone was playing the organ when we were in there which was very nice to hear the sound while touring. Saw Vasco de Gama's tomb.
Not worth it. I can sum up our experience pretty quickly - long line, short visit, not much to see, expensive. Spend your day at one of lisbon's pristine beaches instead!
Beautiful!. There isn't a lot of things to see inside but the interior is so amazing you just have to go there. One of my favourite places in Lisbon!
My lastest visit to Lisbon. The Mosteiros is an old monastery which houses the remains of some of Portugal's famous such as Vasco Da Gama and Luis Camoēs.

Beautiful. We read in the guide book that it was free entry every Sunday before 2pm. This is not the case. We queued for approx. 30mins to get in to find that it is only the church that is free to get into and not the actual grounds of the monastery. However, it was well worth the money as it is beautiful inside. Steeped in history and architecture. A must see when in Belem.
Stunning!. One of the most beautiful monuments in Portugal, a must see. It's also very near some museums and the famous Belém pastry house.

Great building but crowded. It is really amazing with its white rock and its gothic style, but the queue for entrance was too long and tiring under the sun. So I advice you to go there early inthe morning or in the late afternoon to skip the queue. The chirch thereby can be visited for free and it's amazing, well worth a visit.

Outstanding example of Manueline architecture.. Walk round the cloisters of this ancient monastery and visit the beautiful church. Quite a distance from Lisbon, in Belem, the gruelling journey took 45 minutes on a packed bus, but worth it for the beautiful architecture. Tip: if you buy a joint ticket for the monastery and the Belem tower, don't leave it too late to go to see the tower. We arrived at 4.45 and they wouldn't allow us in. Couldn't face the journey a second time so disappointed.
A complete delight. A magnificent edifice. We went during afternoon when the crowds were far less and waked straight in.
