Worth a visit. This is definitely worth a visit if you're in Lisbon and is very close to the Torre de Belem. The courtyards are nice and the church is beautiful, although they were doing renovations to one side when we were there.

Difficult to get in unless you arrive early. The line to go into the monastery was as long as a football field. The lady in charge of making sure you had "tickets" to go in was very rude. After almost two hours waiting in line, we gave up and left.

Good - but not much 'wow' factor. Was very keen to see the monastery as it is said to be one of the masterpieces of Manueline architecture. And from the Belem waterfront, some blocks away, its facade makes a mighty impression. However, in the end was fairly disappointed with our visit, which was spread across three days - maybe that fed into our lessening of appreciation. On day # 1, a Sunday, the monastery was closed for an event though the church was open and free. It was busy though highlight was tomb of Vasco da Gama. That was good.On Monday the monastery is closed so returned Tuesday morning. Even at 9.50 - ten minutes before opening time - there was a depressingly long queue. Despite what appears to an official policy of making entry as inefficient as possible, the queue actually moved reasonably quickly. Ten Euros each to enter and what do you see? A stroll around the cloisters, plus entry to a few other rooms. There is lots of exquisite stone carvings to admire in the cloisters as well some fine 'azulejos' tiles in the refectory. For all that, we were out again in less than an hour. Thought it pretty expensive for what you get.
Must-see in Lisbon. Most beautiful building and fantastic exhibition about its 500 years history cleverly presented in parallel with the world and Portugal's history. Not to be missed!
one of the best place in lisbon. this site is must visit because it shows history and culture of lisbon and i was so impressed by this places.

Stunning!. I love it, this place has an incredible art and design, this place has been in portugal for a long time and this place has the bodies of two of the most important people in Portugal, Vasco da Gama the explorer and Luis Camoes the famous poet.

beautifull architecture.. we had the Lisbon card but line was long. The museum next door safe us some time as the line there was much shorter and they can sell up to 3 tickets (Belem tour, museum and Mosteiro).
Nice. I really enjoyed this place. The aura is good. It is very calm and relaxing. The building is very beautiful.
Phenomenal. Beautiful, majestic, almost overwhelming when one considers the age and time in history that these structures were built.

Beautiful inside, but long wait. There was a side entrance to another museum, archaeological one I think. You can get tickets here for here and belem tower, wished I'd know before queuing for 30 mins (and would have been an hour by the time we'd have finished queuing). It's nice inside around the cloister, but not much more than that

Ornate and beautiful. This is not a monastery for Jesuit monks. Lavish and beautiful stone work throughout the cloisters, this speaks as much of power as it does of heaven. The line to buy tickets can be long. Much faster to go to the archeological museum next door and buy your tickets there. Well worth the trip.
Beautiful. Great history! Beautiful monument and gardens. One of the most beautiful places in Lisbon. Dont forget to try the pasteis de belem near by
Very interesting. The monasteriro dos Jeronimos is worth visiting, especially the cloister with his well ornamented stones. It is also nice, to see the church from the upper floor.

amazing!!. The Monaster dos Jerònimos is a must see in Lisboa. Wonderful cloister, amazing achitecture and a nice way to spend some hours surrounded by art and amazing buildings.
I also liked the park in front of it, a nice walk along the rive Douro!

Impressive Architecture!. We got to the Jeronimo's Monastery around 4:30 and the tourist buses were just leaving! It made the whole experience so much nicer with a smaller crowd. Admission for the Cloister is 10 Euros for adult and children 12 and under are free. Church admission is free. This is a Must-See in Lisbon.The church is impressive with tall tall ceiling and beautiful stained glass windows. It houses tombs of Vasco da Gama and Luis Vaz de Camoes. If you go to the Cloister, you can enter second floor of the church which affords you a view down to the church, which was really nice. The Cloister is impressive! Beautiful architecture and so pristine. It is worth coming here! After enjoying the beauty of the Monastery, walk 5 minutes to Pasteis de Belem and enjoy their natas!!

A must see!. Absolutely magnificent architecture and view across the grassed court. Enjoyed looking through the small market stalls. We were able to purchase some beautiful coasters based on the traditional pavements of Lisbon.
Historic and memorable.. Interesting attraction, deep history, interesting displays all open and no line up as we purchased the tickets previously.

Athiest in Portugal. If I had any feeling for religion I would be taken in by the Mosteiro. The smell, the statues the ancientness and even once went when t here wasa a midnight Xmas mass. Very spiritual and a nice story exists for those who would like to hear the origin of this fascinating place. Don't forget the Pastelaria Belem nearby. Your walking after all, deserves a Pastei de Nata, wiht a coffe of course.

Outstanding!. I only visited the Cloister and didn't have time to visit the church. The Cloister is absolutely outstanding. I have been to so many places in Europe before, but never seen a cloister so pretty.

The might of Portugal on display. Spent a couple of hours after a visit to Torre Belem. Plenty to see and be awed by. The beautiful cloisters, the architecture with many different styles and embellishments, tiles, woodwork - all a testament to a powerful and wealthy worldwide empire.
Very nice but expensive. The building is beautiful with an impressive architecture and lots of history. I do think that is a little too expensive for what it has to offer.

Pretty. church was free, 20 minute wait Sunday at 3, cover bare arms
attractive
"cloister' required tickets, another wait (buy the optional joint tickets to Torre de Belem a walk away to avoid another line there)
Maritime "Marinha" museum in the same building is a special interest for me, was good not great

Beautiful Monastery. There are two queues when you get to the Monastery in Belem: one for the Cloister and one for the Church. When I got there, the queue for the Cloister was quite long but the one for the Church wasn't. It was confusing, because I wasn't expecting two different queues, so I got in the one for the Cloister. After probably 20 to 30 mins we approached the front door, but I didn't see the ticket office and some people were getting out of line to go into a little alcove on the left, then came out, showed a slip of paper to someone and got right in. I feared, though, that I was going to get to the entrance and find out I needed to purchase a ticket before I got in line, so I did the same. You don't need to do that. The ticket window was just a little farther in, up some stairs. Don't Panic.If you are going to go to several things in Belem, especially in one day, I suggest getting a Lisboa Card. You can pre-order them (they come in 1,2,and 3 day values) or buy one at either a tourist office or any booth where you see the Lisboa Card (it's purple) displayed, and around a major attraction such as this, it's easy to find one. They are also good for the train from Lisbon to Belem, and all public transit in Lisbon (metro, bus/carris, tram). It gets you into the Monastery free, you get into the Torre de Belem for free, and it gets you discounts other places in Belem, Lisbon, and Sintra.The Cloister is very large, and has two levels, with lots of interesting carving, and great places for photos and selfies. There is huge new display which shows the history of the monastery in connection with world history, a very informative and well done exhibit.There are several other museums and monuments nearby, and lots of places to eat. Plus, a must stop is the Pasteis de Belem for the famous Nata custard treats. There is usually a queue there, too, but there is an awning, and the line goes quite quick. You can get a pre-packaged half-dozen of Natas for just over 6 Euros, a good price for an excellent treat.

Really enjoyed this!. We only went into the church because of time limits that day. Admission was free. We were amazed that Vasco Da Gama's tomb was in there. The architectural style (Manueline?) is distinctly Portuguese and different from anything we've seen before. The ornate columns and archways that told stories from scripture were beautiful and detailed. The surrounding park, fountains, museums, and monuments were well maintained and interesting. I could easily have spent a whole day enjoying this seaside location.
Very different architecture. Well worth a visit - amazing complex of buildings. Try to visit early in the day before the coach loads arrive.

Stand out attraction in Lisbon. A beautiful masterpiece of a building. Fantastic cloisters, wonderful architecture. This is an excellent visit. I'd have liked an orientation room - details about the history of the monastery are there and are informative where present but, are scattered throughout the building. Something to introduce it would be good. The church is also beautiful and interesting to see the luminaries of Portugese history!

Centre Attraction. The monastery is one of the main highlights of Lisbon and located in the Belem region. It is a 14th-15th Century monastery which over looks into the Tigres river. The church that is attached to the monastery contains the tomb of the famous Portuguese navigator Vasco Da Gama who discovered the new sea route to India. The old structure, the doors, the walls, the ceilings are a visual treat. Most days the queue to get in is quite long so please plan your trip accordingly or get your tickets early.

Can't miss sight in Belem. A can't-miss sight in Lisbon. . . amazing architecture. I recommend buying your ticket at the Museum adjoining the Monastery . . you can buy a 3-way combo ticket that lets you skip the entry lines at both the Torre Belem and (breathtaking) monastery (which are usually both VERY long), and see the museum as well. Do not skip Belem is you visit Lisbon.
just beautifull. All the Belem area is just wonderful for a walk on a sunny day. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is just simple beauty from outside or inside. Next door is pasteis de Belem, a must

Beautiful architecture, great history. The tour is in one portion of the huge monastery. Allow time if you don't have prepaid tickets. The architecture is absolutely beautiful and as the information says it took so long to build that it has 3 different styles throughout it. There is a comprehensive history in many different languages that show the history of the monastery, Portugal and the world for centuries. Dress properly if you want to visit the church or go to mass.

Pay the ticket to go in the interior courtyard. The monastery it is beautiful outside and spectacular inside but what I liked most is the interior courtyard - a peaceful place where you can sit on the grass and eat some Pasteis de Belem (the shop is near the monastery), relax and cool a little bit. Most important is that the entrance is FREE with Lisboa Card.
a jour masterpiece. We were here in the first Sunday of month, so saved 12Euro per person. The monastery is a majestic a jour masterpiece!
A "must see" in Lisbon. Situated in Belem at walking distance of Belem Tower and in front of the Vasco da Gama Bridge, this old monastery is impressing by its architecture, cloister and paintings.

Excellent . A great historical and art piece. Highly recommended. The general admission includes the upper floor of the church. The lower fool is free but the queue is so long. The nearby area is awesome.

Grand Historical monument. The monastery present the wealth of the golden age of the Portugal era, from the amazing architecture outside, to the grand decoration of the details inside, so beautiful cloister completed in 1544, what a wonderful building which is the must see in Lisbon.

It was nice but nothing extraordinary. I liked it but preferred other sites. It does not have that much to see and the guide only just dropped us off and told us what was already in the ad for the tour.
Portuguese Jewel. Spectacular church. Definitely worth visiting if you're in Lisbon. So much history. The architecture (Manueline) is fascinating.

Best sight in Lisbon. In my opinion this is the best attraction sight in Lisbon. It is far more impressive and beautiful than even the photos of it. Try to go during a weekday in the late afternoon like we did to experience it at its most peaceful.

A worth while experience. Although usually pretty busy with tourists and groups, the Monastery is the highlight of a visit to the Belem quarter and the Manueline carved stonework of its cloister is perhaps the most beautiful to be found in Portugal. After your visit you may sample some pasteis de nata at Pasteis de Belem, the city's most famous pastry shop, followed by a good cup of coffee at the nearby Starbucks.

Simply Gorgeous, worth the visit. One of those churches that simply take your breath away! It's the closest we can come to time travel. I loved being able to see the detail on the door, and imagine all the explorers that came through those doors on their way to conquer the new world. By the way, there is a shop to the right of the church that sells the best pastries. It's worth allowing a little extra time for a snack.
A beautiful monastery in Belem. Belem is full of monuments with stunning architecture.This monastery is one of the gems. Intricate details on the outer wall and grand inside.

Beautiful Monastery - worth the trip. Even though in this area there is not subway, there are other things to visit around (Torre de Belem, Padrao dos Descobrimentos Monument and the Museum of Carriages). It closes at 18.00, we barley made it :DThe inside of the church is very interesting, in a very particular gothic style, completley diffrent from the ones in France or Germany. And the warm light of the southern sun gives a diffrent feel to the entire experience. Anyhow, I consider that the cloister of the monastery is much better and it's worth the visit. I do recomment you to visit it at the end of the day in order to enjoy it to the fullest.
Portugal Holiday. Lovely church with very interesting high altar. The silver altar is also worth a visit. The history of the church is very educational

Stunning stone work! The perfect building depicting portuguese Manueline style. The best of it is the free part: specially the outside! The long queue is only for visiting the cloister, and you can actually skip that (beautiful but not worth waiting in the long queue)

Beautiful but busy. Our visit was in the week but still very busy with large groups including school parties. Nevertheless, we were glad to see this beautiful monastery church which epitomised the splendour and grandeur of places of Church worship. Our visit was enhanced by an interesting and well-versed city guide and I thought that, although there were many groups present, their guides managed the flow well, using systems that minimised disturbance for others.

Great afternoon trip. we happen to go on the first sunday of the month and the adjacent museum was free! July has an exhibit on ancient Egypt and the surrounding areas which was very cool. Make sure you bring something to cover up your shoulders when entering the cathedral (all genders). They do provide shalls but might be easier just to wear a tshirt.

Would have been outstanding had it not been overloaded with tourists. This is definitely worth a visit, but we went on a Sunday and waited nearly an hour just to buy tickets and enter. Then it was very crowded inside. Totally ruined the experience. Don't go on a weekend!
Historic building. This monastery was a great example of early 17th century architecture. The cloisters were beautiful and the church was impressive with wonderfully carved pillars.
Interesting place. Lots of people, so get there early. The site is free of charge on sundays. A great place to visit for those with an interest in history.

Interesting. The Monastery + Belem Tour ticket costs 12 Euro. When you visit the monastery there are 2 places to consider: 1. The monastery itself, nicely ornate but not as big as I have imagined it. Not too many places to visit inside. Nice walk but I wouldn't pay twice to visit it. 2. The church with the Vasco da Gama tomb. The church can be visited for free. In my opinion, if you don't want to spend a lot of money -you should only visit the church. Near by - the tour of Belem and te Pasteis de Belem These 2 - are on my must see objectives list.

Amazing monument. The story of the Portuguese discoveries began in the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos 500 years ago.the beauty of architecture, the river and the gardens around are a inspiration of the portuguese history.Quem vê só fora nem imagina o que tem dentro

the visit. This is a place not to be missed ,it is so important to go, even if you have to pay to go inside ,but it is worth it,take your time ,you really need to spend a couple of hours at least to be able to see most of it ,then close by it is (Pasteis de Belem),another icon from Lisbon
Vasco Da Gama. We went there to pay homage to Vasco Da Gama. Of course, the Monastery was beautiful and elaborate. Would recommend it as a must see.

The main church is enough. Jeronimos is a very beautiful monastery in Manueline style and it's really Worth to visit. The sculptured ceiling is very impressive as well as the sepulchre of Vasco de Gama and Luis de Camoes. All this is free of charge, visiting the cloister was a disapointment. It's beautiful but there's not much to see and the 7€ entry fees are exagerated.I suggest other visitors should visit only the Church, free of charge. If you want to see a beautiful example of Manuelin monastery, then you should visit Batalha (100 km) or even more beautiful Tomar (in the same area, where you can spend easily 4 or 5 days)
The Cloisters!!!!. Whatever you do if you are in Lisbon you mst visit the Monastery. Be sure and pay to go and visit the cloisters.
Breath Taking church. Amazing designed big church with very beautiful statues... loved it and it is one of the places must see in lisboa

Beautiful building!. What a beautiful building and architecture! It's just amazing and located on a beautiful part of Lisbon facing beautiful gardens and the river called "Tejo" where you can see the beautiful bridge as well! If you're in town visiting I suggest the "Mosteiro dos Jerónimos" for a nice day surrounded by a beautiful place.

Spectacularly gorgeous. The monastery is so beautiful! Amazing carved stone and well thought out exhibits. The ticketing was a bit confusing... there were two lines where you could get tickets and they were only marked right outside the door. When the lines were long, you couldn't tell which line was a good one to get into. It was also a bit confusing get in, but once you were there, it was well worth the effort.
Great. This Museum is amazing. It will take you a few hours so plan well. Taxis are quite difficult to pick up from the location. It is close to many monuments. Take advantage
Impressive cloister. Short but very nice and mandatory visit, and easy to combine with Torre de Belem which is at walking distance along the river

Worth a visit . While getting in is not overly organised worth getting ticket for this and belem Tower at the same time as this will save you queuing again at the tower. Great scenery and outside you should visit the bakery with the famous tarts ( you can't miss it long queue / blue yawning / 300 meters to the right as you look at the mosteiro) tram stops not far from it if you are coming from the centre of Lisbon.

Our most amazing monument. . Mosteiro dos Jerónimos stands for the fact it belongs to a type of art interely portuguese - manuelino (from King Manuel I). And it is indeed a sight to see. If you have a chance, take a moment to appreciate the door ornaments that this monastery have.

Interesting Site. Went on a first Sunday of a month when entry was free to see the cloisters. The Church is always free entry but on Sundays, when services are held, it is more difficult to enter. The architecture and design were very interesting and it amazing how the workmanship is so detailed and yet fragile. Not sure what the cost of to see the cloisters is normally. The outside is also very awesome without even going inside.

An experience not to be missed. This church, a miracle of architecture, is impressive even to non~believers. The delicacy of the stone work has to be seen to be believed. Our eight year old grandchild was struck dumb!_-
exquisite stone work. exquisite stone work with beautiful inside patio and awesome cathedral area that makes you feel small

Worth visiting. The monastery architecture is awesome!It's from the time of the Portuguese Discoveries, Manueline style, a sumptuous late Gothic, incorporating maritime elements and representations of the Discoveries brought from the voyages of Vasco da Gama and Pedro Álvares Cabral.
Worth it!. Amazing architecture. It is worth a visit for sure! Tip: Buy a Lisbon card upon arrival at the airport and avoid the long lines.

Solemn and Portentous. The solemnity of this Monastery is almost unmatched, at least in the Iberian Peninsula. Built through the 16th century in a very original style that later became known as Manueline, here you actually feel how strong and powerful Catholicism was in those years when other european countries were involved in the religious wars against Protestantism. The cloister can leave you breathless, and it’s almost impossible to withstand the call of a picture: try NOT to shoot a photo here, you can’t. But the air stinks too much inside the church because of incense, human bodies sweat and dust in every corner.

Final home of a great man. What an experience to see the final resting place of Vasco da Gama, the great Portuguese navigator known to just about everyone. The Mosteiro itself is impressive, but seeing Vasco's tomb even more so.

A must during your Lisbon visit. A Unesco World heritage site to visit while in Belem. Better that the Tower of Belem.
Well worth the small fee. Visit the church and closters.

Stunning. Beautiful monastery, lots of ornate carving and amazing stained glass windows, well worth the extra to see around the cloisters (get the joint ticket) - in fact I think that was better than the main monastery.

Beautiful monastery and church. I enjoyed the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, but I wish the historical information for the site was a bit more well-organized. The monastery and the church were very beautiful to admire though, and it is worth the trip, especially if you are in the Belem area. The archaeological museum is also right there as well.

Wow spectacular architecture. Arrived here on a tourist sightseeing bus. When we arrived at the front of the building it was amazing. The architecture of the building is second to none. Unfortunately due to the numbers of people waiting to go inside we decided to return for another visit when there were less people
Not to be missed. One of the most fantastic places to visit in Lisbon, The enviroment is also a must and the architecture of the building is amazing!

Beautiful detailed historical building. There are a lot of very fine details in both interior and exterior of the building. This complex located in a group of tourist points. You may want to purchase a ticket to visit five different place close by, instead of get in line at each places.

free church visit. all the churches in Lisbon are free and beautiful, and this one is Lisbon's biggest church. The architecture and Statues carvings are worth the trip. The Monastery is closed on Mondays and they charge 10 euros, Read the 1 star reviews about that.
Great place. Very beautiful architecture, very impressive, important historical place and very interesting. Don't miss the Vasco Da Gama tomb.
Beautiful building. Low key, exquisite monastery. You walk around yourself. There is a gorgeous cathedral attached. A must see in Belem.

Over priced and not much to see. I was really disappointed about this visit. I really thought this was going to be the best attraction in Lisbon, but it turned out to be very uninspiring.The ticket costs €10, giving you access to the monastery courtyard and a few bare rooms which, whilst being nice, are nothing that special. There is also a second floor where to look at the said court yard from one level up. That's pretty much it.Maybe I have travelled too much and seen too many places, but this was really underwhelming and found the ticket price outrageous for what was on offer.

Phenomenal architectural marvel. What a beautiful place. Amazing the vastness and attention to detail that was possible 600 years ago. The Cloister and grounds were impeccable. Crowds were decent and polite.
Great Visit. Well preserved cloister, resting place of Vasco de Gamma. Short visit but good spot to go look at on the way to Torre da Belem.
Short Visit but Beautiful. Beautiful place but we didnt have much time for viewing. Lovely craft market across the street......
Great visit. Great place to visit on Sunday. Beautiful service and a gorgeous church. Don't miss out on the gardens out front and other Lisbon landmarks all within walking distance.

beautiful place. you can imagine the monks walking at the cluster.beautiful building preserved amazing.the inner place, the 2 floors clusters, the hall and the stairs , all was unique and interesting. it worth your time...
Spectacular. This is really a very impressive building , well worth seeing in Belem, along with many other places to visit here.
Beautiful monastery. This is a beautiful monastery. The entrance price was a bit high for what you get to see though. Its about a 30 minute visit. The chapel is free.
Feel the history. The mosteiro jeronimos is located in Belém and you havê to dedicated one to this local beecause is the center of the monuments Feel the portuguese history and enjoy the view

Nice architecture!. Took bus 711 and 714 to Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. Bought the combo ticket with the Torre de Belem. There wasn't much of a queue when we were there at 10. Nice photo opportunities. We were able to go into the church without a line up.
Beautiful. Beautiful! Although the queueing system is somewhat confusing! We went in the left hand queue which seems to be quicker flowing. Architecture is stunning. Definitely worth a visit.

Marvelous architecture. It's a marvel of human architecture, and a historical site. The tomb of Vasco da Gama is a must visit! Very nice archeological museum but not something to remember. Mind your steps outside the convent. You might step on the names of those that signed the Lisbon European treaty!!!!!! I did.....

a landmark of an era not to be missed. humbling, beautiful, this place takes you right into history. The architecture of the churches and monasteries are astonishing to a person brought up in the simpler world of the US

A gorgeous tribute to centuries past. A must see! Splendid architecture in beautiful Belem. Only pictures do this church justice. The stone work is breathtaking. If you want the senior discount, be sure to have your passport with you. The lady who sold the tickets was a stickler.

Impressive from the street. We took a hop on hop off bus tour but didn't have enough time in Lisbon to get off and visit any historical site. All I can say is this monastery looks impressive from the bus and street view.
Impressive building worth the visit.. impressive building , across from a beautiful park and next to a magnificent church, a short walk to the bay and the Torre de Belem.
Great castle, great view. Definitely worth a visit on a nice day. The view of the city is unbelievable and you can spend hours exploring this castle and it's exhibits.

good impression. We got a really good impression if Mosteiro dos Jeronimos during our visit in summer. unfortunately the queue to enter the monastery was too long and as we don't like to wait for hours, we got the impression just from outside. We fetched the inside impression from folders and from the web as our alternative.

Wow!!! and double wow!. I had not looked up a head of time what this place looked like and when we got off the trolley (15) I was just amazed! It is absolutely stunning! Well worth the trolley ride out! Don't miss this if you go to Lisbon. We purchased the Lisbon card and that made the trolley ride free as well as the monastery and Belem tower. Well worth a visit! The archeological museum there was not really worth the time unless you have a strong interest in this type of history. The coach museum not too far away was unfortunately closed when we visited.

If you only visit one historical site make it this one. This monastery and the attached church are well worth visiting. The carving of the columns is incredible and the church has a beautiful interior. The church also houses the tombs of the great navigator Vasco da Gama and the historian poet - Camoes.

Jeronimos Monastery. An impressive building with huge spaces. A must if you are in Belem.
I would suggest doing a walking tour of Belem for at least half a day including the pastries, Discovery Monument, Tower etc. You can see them from the outside but the walk is nice

Nice building, the monastery a bit expensive. While we passed by with the train to Cascais we saw this building and went a other day to Belèm to visit it and to taste the pasteis. The church is for free and very nice to see. A bit busy with loud tour guides, but it is one of the highlights of Lisbon. After that we doubted whether we should visit the monastery, because we read a price of 6 euros per ticket in our guide and they charged 10. As we were in Belèm for these buildings, we entered the monastery.It is beautiful to see, but it felt to little and also to little information for the ticket price. We were leaving within 30 minutes and not really knowing what we have seen. A guidebook or audio tour would have been helpful.

Take a cab and get there at 10 AM to avoid lines. Well worth a trip from central Lisbon. If you are a senior, bring a copy of your passport and you'll pay 1/2 price. Walk around the cloisters and special exhibits. Visit the church. Quite amazing. While in the neighborhood, visit the Maritime Museum which is adjacent to the monastery, the explorers monument and the Pasteis de Belem for the treats of the same name.

The best example of Manueline Architecture. On of the better examples of Manueline architecture (Portuguese Gothic) in the country. It hosts the tomb of Camoes, the definitive poet in Portuguese history, and boasts beautiful cloisters. You can also visit the Archaeology Museum.

very deceiving. The most magnificent church in Lisbon. However there is some fanatic, ridiculous priest (José Manuel) and a stupid, ridiculous sacristan who will do everything to impeach you from doing a proper visit of this true marvel. Idiots!

Paradise for photographers.... This is one of the most beautiful buildings I've been to. Highly recommended if you like photography, not only for the buildings but also for the interiors, mainly the church which has lots of details and amazing light sources. Plan to arrive early as it is crowded of tourists by noon.
Impressive. It's a truly impressive building, the architecture is such a beautiful mix. I also enjoyed very much visiting the grounds, which are also beautiful. Definitely a must see!

Stunning historical building. A beautiful attraction, well worth the small entrance fee (also free with a Lisboa card). The queues can get long and the entrance system isn't particularly well organised, but the monastery is well worth the wait!!

Great piece of history. Being a local, I insist that every friend who visits me goes here. The structure is a real work of art and although there's always many many people around it's worth to cue a bit to get in.
Beautiful! A must-see. It was a beautiful monastery, a must see. The cloisters are nice, I'm not sure if it's worth the 10 euros to get in but still a must do.

Pleasantly surprised. This was one of my favourite places in Lisbon. Although there were many tourists visiting it felt like the place was big and tranquil enough for everyone to have their own space. I really enjoyed the display outlining the monastery's history alongside world events and the development of Portugal as a nation. It was very well put together and very informative. The monastery also provides some nice reprieve from the sun if you decide to visit Belem tower and Padrão dos Descobrimentos (across the road) in the same trip. You can purchase a combined ticket for the Belem tower and monastery, the tower is roughly a 20 min walk away.
A definite MUST to visit. Spectacular structure, real work of art. Those who are interested in history should also see the tomb of Vasco de Gama inside the cathedral.

stunningly beautiful place. this is well worth a visit and easily accessible through the excellent bus service from lisbon. whilst many people queued for pastries we prefered exploring this UNESCO heritage site. take time and enjoy. the timeline in one of the rooms explaining heritage of monastery, of the world and of portugal was interesting and imaginative.

This is a must see. When we vacated to Estoril we had no idea about the small town of Belem until we caught a train from Lisbon to Estoril. On the journey was the splendid view of this historic beauty as well as a number of other attractions to the area.The church is free to enter and is the grandest I've seen in my journey through Europe. Included in the premises are also a museum, a library and gardens display which are ticketed. We opted to enter the museum (5EUR) and the monestry total ticket price was 12EUR per person which was modest for what was on show.But with all of its contents, it is the grand scale of the building that marvels most and is worth the entry price alone.

Amazing building . The building itself is amazing and well worth a look. There is a few displays inside for u to look at but nothing special.The building is the main show. The church that is attached is also magnificent housing the tomb of vasco da gama. Buy the comined ticket that includes belem tower for €12.

Very interesting, but very crowded on Sunday afternoon.. Go early or be prepared to wait. Long lines to buy tickets. I suggest buying your ticket at the archeology museum when there is a long line at the monastery. You can buy tickets for both and for the Belem or just one of these.

Fantastic!. I have been in many churches and few monasteries around Europe as I admire art and architecture. Monasterio dos Jeronimos will be one I will always remember. The cloisters architecture is just beautiful but the one thing I will remember the most is the unexpected, jaw dropping experience I had when walking from the second floor of the clostiers building to a top hall of the Church which gives you a unique and fantastic view of the its inside...it is incredible...so my recommendation, contrary to some other reviews, is to not go to the Church first but start with the Monastery....Even our 14 year old daughter thought this was one of the best places she saw during our 15 days trip in Spain and Portugal!
Stunning. An architectural marvel, ideal for fans of art and architecture. Avoid the archeological museum and go straight for the monastery!!

Amazing for architecture and history lovers . We are a family of four with two children 7 and 9. They thought it was ok but liked that it was cool inside because it was hot outside!The adults enjoyed the history and architecture. We opted to solely tour the church given the kids were spent. It was free and worth the 5-10 minute wait.

Interesting Excursion. Very well preserved and enjoyable to roam around on one's own and explore the various nooks and crannies. Worth the visit, particularly as we were surprised that there was no entry fee on Sunday.
Grand place but not worth the long tram ride.. Also, the famed custard pastries at patisserie Belem are only marginally better than what you get elsewhere.

Spectacular. Beautiful building, I was amazed by the sheer scale of the building, my boyfriend really enjoyed the historical aspect of it with a fantastic history timeline room. Well worth the small entry fee.

Very Cool!. We got to the Monastery just as it opened so the crowds were manageable. It's a beautiful place, so photogenic. My husband and I spent two hours photographing different aspects of it from the colonnades to the gargoyles. The old library has a wonderful display of history from the 1500's on -- world history and Portuguese history. Very well done. Don't miss it.

Impressive architecture!. This place is BEAUTIFUL! We enjoyed the gorgeous architecture. But this is what you need to know: You will get here and see a long line. The long line is to enter the church (free) not the monastery (not free, but cheap). Since everyone was waiting in the church line, we thought the church must be something that we should do. We were pretty upset to finally get into the church after about an hour in line and learn that you can't really even explore all of the church, there is just a small area at the entrance that you can go into. The line was a complete waste of time. We went into the monastery next, and this place was stunning!!! You can also go into the church from the monastery (second floor). You get about as good of a look at the church from the monastery (and not waiting in line) as you do from waiting in line. Unless you are a very, very devout Catholic that really wants to see the relic of the saint in the church, don't waste your time in the church line! I think you can also book tickets online in advance, but we didn't find this necessary since the line was for the church, and not the monastery.

Beautiful and interesting. About a 20 minute tram ride from central Lisbon, (tram 15) this site is definitely worth a visit. The church is free to get in, and includes Vasco da Gama's tomb and is beautifully ornate, and a magnificent example of Gothic architecture. The cloisters attract an entrance fee, although for 12 euros you can get a ticket for here, and the Torre de Belem. Again, the architecture is fantastic, with many gargoyles (or grotesques, I can never remember) and the Manueline style is intricate and pleasing on the eye. The cloisters also house a fascinating exhibit which is a wall, containing 3 historical timelines; 1 of the monastery; 1 of Portugal, and 1 of the world, in general. Very informative and extremely interesting to a Portugal novice, like myself.

Unesco flagged site. Well worth a visit, great run through history in one of the rooms,glorious architecture. buy the joint ticket for belem tower. take a copy of your passport if 65 plus . discounts everywhere.

Very nice and beautifull. This monastery is situated close to Belem tower and Monument for pioneers. You can go there by tour tram 28. Next to the monastery is a splendid fountain and park where you can relax.

Easily one of the Most Distinctive Monuments to Portugal's Age of Exploration. In the region of Belem, the debarkation point on the Tagus River for Prince Henry's expeditions to Africa, India, the Spice islands, Japan, and Brasil, is a great monument to Portugal's Exploration of the World. Prince Henry and his successors devised navigation tools and improved designs for sailing vessels that allowed Portugal to pioneer trade and settlement around the world, which made this small nation the envy of Europe.Sailing the Oceans is dangerous enough today, but in the 16th Century, it was more like space exploration, in that many a sailor never expected to return successfully. It was undertaken by brave adventurers who were strengthened in their resolve by deep faith in God and the afterlife. Before their departure, they would stop at the church of Saint Mary of Bethlehem (BELEM) to make peace with their creator and to pray for the welfare of their immortal souls.They were indeed successful and Portugal became rich beyond anyone's expectations. In gratitude, the monarchy established a 5% tax on the sale of imported pepper and spices, with proceeds used to fund a convent and monastery on the site of the medieval church. Today, the enormous cloister is a museum of the period, but the adjacent church is a a gem of Portuguese Manueline Architecture and is a UNESCO World heritage site, for reasons of beauty and historical importance.The style has a very ornate and emotionally-charged type of Gothic detail and holds the graves of many of the country's most important monarchs and explorers, including Vasco de Gama, the first to lead an expedition around the world.Other sites of note in the region are the Tower of Belem, the Museum of Modern Art, and a more contemporary monument to the Explorers on the harbor.It is accessible by modern trams from downtown Lisbon.

Not open Mondays. Just went to the outside (on the last day of our trip (a Monday)) as we were staying in the area. However, it was still lovely and we took heaps of photos! I bet the inside is fantastic!

Feeling Gothic Architecture. To feel and understand has experiencing Gothic Architecture in is Portuguese version : " Manuelino" in is decorative style with sculptures of maritime motives of the discovers like Vasco da Gama, and the course to India...

Beautiful monastery. Good transport connection from city centre.
Amazing interior.
Beautiful church.
Belongs word heritage Unesco.

Strongly suggest. The cathedral is free, the cloisters are not. Vasco de Gama's tomb is thus free to see. This also serves as a great prelude to the incredible Maritime Museum, exit, make a right, at the end of the building.
Lovely and peaceful. Did this and Belem Tower. Beautiful inside. A nice break from the heat. Only needed about a half hour. Beautiful gardens surrounding it.

Well worth a visit. This is a magnificent church and monastery full of Portuguese history. Simply a must see. Go early as the lines are long and see the church before entering the monastery. Walk across the road to get a look back at the building.

History Surprise. The changes in Portugal's history is most interesting.
Their travels and explorations were awesome.
Vasco da Gama's tomb is there.
Astonishing. Great architecture. A place full of history. Portugal was the first nation to go on global expeditions and the sailors used to come here to pray for a good trip.

Beautiful church and cloisters. As mentioned in the other reviews, the church and the cloisters are beautiful. If you are going in the summer, it can be a nice respite on a hot day. There is a very interesting museum exhibit on the second floor of the cloisters that is easy to miss if you are not looking for it. The entire exhibit is a multilevel timeline showing the history of the church, Portugal and the world. If you are not hugely familiar with Portugal's history, it provides a great framework for understanding how Portugal's history fits in with the world history that you might already know and an interesting explanation of events in Portugal's political history that you might not know.
Jaw dropping. Into the cloisters and a jaw dropping experience. Like nothing else I have ever visited and I am a regular visitor to churches great and small across a number of countries!

Excellent place. Don't miss this Monestary. It was so unique. We were surprised how much we enjoyed it. The architecture is breathtaking. It was nice just to be able to walk through the Monestary and Church with no crowds. We timed it perfectly (our tour guide did).
Impressive. This is an example of amazing architecture. Nice for families too. Quiet and pleasant surrounding. Easy to navigate.

Beautiful cloister. We arrived at Belem late one sunny afternoon, in time to spend as much time as we wanted at the stunning cloister. By the time we got to the church, around 6 pm, a service had started and it was closed to visitors, but the cloister alone was completely worth the visit. The Manueline style, so inventive and fanciful, keeps you looking at detail after detail, with the overall effect of lace made of stone. This is the first cloister we visited in Portugal, and others were very beautiful too, but this one remains the most vivid in our memory. It's an easy trolly ride from Lisbon.

Stunning!. This is simply a stunning building. The church and cloisters repay the visit a hundred-fold. Access to the church is free - Vasco da game's tomb is here and worth any trouble to get here in itself. You pay to go into the cloisters, but I've never seen anything like the carving of the marble pillars, ceilings etc.But either go very early or after 3.00pm when most of the large-group tours are yet to arrive or have been and gone.

Grandious architecture. Monastery of Jeronimos in Belém, Lisbon is a fantastic architectural proof of the fact that people had the science to build grandious things, even sevaral centuries ago.It was rainy day when we visited it, but we had no lines or crowd inside.Must visit is if you are in Lisbon, combined ticket with Belém Tower is worth to buy.
fabulous church. we arrived and we had the luck that mss was starting with a beautiful choir. what an experience, and the dumb of Vaco de Gama !
Majestic!. Great architecture, the church was amazing. Highly recommended. We bought the combo ticket for torre de bellem.

Buy the 24 hour Lisboa card and you can easily do Sintra and Belem together!. We bought the 24 hour Lisboa card when we were in Belem.You can take tram 15 from either the victory square or the commercial square in the centre of Lisbon to Belem and visit the monastery and the Belem tower for free with this card. The card only activates the 24 hour free transportation when you first use the card in the tram or metro so we used it in the afternoon because the card also includes the train to Sintra and so this way we could do Belem today and go to Sintra the next day and back late afternoon all for free.When you are in Belem you must try the nata at pasteis de Belem!! I am a nata lover and this is the best!! Believe me, I tried at least 3 more places in Lisbon and none can compare to the one in Belem!! Yum yum!!

Impressive building !. You have to experience to believe it, amazing place ! Great history and great location, the church is impressive, some areas we were not able to see, restoration work being done in some of the areas. Impressive.
Beautiful architecture. Great place to visit in Lisbon. Purchase ticket with Torre Belem. Great historical location and a must see in Lisbon
Magnificent. A gothic cathedral constructed by Manuel I. Very impressive. Must be visited. Contains the tomb of Vasco de Gama.

Jeronimos - good for photos and history. Worth a visit. We caught the train to the end of the line then walked back to the main Sodre train station finding lots of interesting places and scenes along the way

Nice complement . Visited this monastery after visiting the tower of belem. It was beautiful but the cloisters are without any furnishings or furniture.
Nice to see it but not an absolute

Gorgeous architecture. I research alot prior to all my trips, and inevitably I have seen plenty of pictures of all the places that I will be visiting BEFORE I even leave home. The only disadvantage is that I do not get the "WOW" moment when I finally arrive to the attraction since I have already read and saw pictures about them.Well... let me just say the pictures do NOT do this place justice. When I first walked in it took my breath away. €12 will get you a dual ticket to this and Belem Tower (Torre de Belem). OR if you have a Lisbon Card (which we did), admission is included (I recommend the Lisbon Card). The monastery is also connected to the Church of Santa Maria (no admission fee). NOTE: June 13 is a public holiday for Lisbon, and every is closed (including this monastery & the Belem Tower) - however the Church is open... please plan according if you are to visit during that time (Saint Anthony Day)
A must visit. This is a fantastic place to visit. We bought a dual ticket for this and Torre Belem. It is a fantastic historic building with beautiful interiors.

Amazing UNESCO and World Heritage Site. In the Portuguese seafaring Manueline style, this monastery is a must visit site. It is across the road from the Monument to the Discoverers, and easily accessed by tram or one of the hop on, hop off bus tours.There is a small entrance charge. Timing is important - try not to arrive when a large cruises ship group descends . We had a drink at a cafe in view of the entrance to wait for the queue to disperse.It currently has a very large and impressive exhibition of the concurrent history of the monastery, Portugal and the world.The church is free to enter but again there may be a queue. It is a heavy, dark and ornate church, in many ways best seen from the balcony above accessed from the monastery cloisters.

Maybe the nicest cloister in Europa. We have benn not once in this marvel. The cloister was built in the 15. century, damaged in the big earthquake, repaired and it is today one of the main attraction of Lisbon. Gothic Manueline style, a lot of decoration, the columns and the column capitels are beutifully carved. Before you enter the portals itself are worth to watch, like "stone-lace". You can spend here hours.

Awesome. A completely wonderful building. Cloisters, monks cells, chapels,The scale is enormous and enjoy a Pastel de nata at the nearby cafe for a break before the Maritime Muesum also great display of craft from this maritime nation.

Fascinating!. The monastery tour was fabulous, and it allowed us to visualize life in Portugal during important periods in its history. Although it was crowded at the time of our visit, the venue is organized to facilitate an efficient flow through the areas of interest. Don't miss it!

Fabulous architecture. Beautiful place to visit if you enjoy architecture! It is an impressive place. Best way is to combine a ticket with theTorre de Belem, if possible buy your tickets online to avoid the line.

impressive architecture. The complex is really amazing. You should book for this place around 2-3 hours, depends how detailed you are during visits to such places. There is old impressive Cathedral, make sure you visit Vasco da Gama thumb is there. In my opinion, Church, internal court is enough to see especially if you travel with kids or have limited time.

Impressive Monastery. Lisbon was one of the ports we visited on a cruise. We used the hop-on hop-off city explorer buses and stopped to see this monastery as it has the tomb of Portugal's most famous explorer, Vasco da Gama. The pillars, ceiling and stonework are all very ornately decorated - a true work of art. Our visit was at the start of the tourist season towards the end of April and it was swarming with hundreds of visitors. If anyone particularly wanted the tranquillity in which to study some of the architecture I would advise visiting in the winter.

Interesting tourist trap, almost. Actually is not that bad. It has some very interesting architecture and inner cloisters, and the nave of the church is also worth of a visit. The tomb of Vasco Da Gama is located here.

Best Part of Belem!. Our first- and best- stop in Belem was at the Monastery where we spent an hour or so- no lines, quick admittance. The church is beautiful and free, but do pay for the extra admission to the cloister- so much to see in there, including the view of the church from the choir level.There is a great exhibit upstairs, which shows in English and Portuguese, a timeline of the world, Portugal and the Monastery- really interesting to see how the events of each coincide.

Manueline Architecture is all its glory. Amazing, preposterously overdecorated architecture, made me think Gaudi but in the first degree. He must have been inspired by the exaggerated kitch and made fun of it.

More than meets the eye. The outside of the huge building is impressive, but the inside is gorgeous. The architecture is unique and beautiful. The cloister area is well worth the cost of admission. The attached church is also quite beautiful. The history of this huge building, which houses several different attractions, is detailed in a current exhibit. This is definitely a must-see if you are only in Lisbon for a short time.

Stunning architecture. Had been to this place when we came to Lisbon first, 35 years ago but had given it a miss on our more recent (shorter) stays in the city. Really glad we went back this time - the place is even more impressive than I remember (restoration work tastefully and respectfully done) and can hold its own with any ecclesiastical building in Europe. Also had an informative exhibition linking the history of the place with the history of Portugal and a few smaller exhibitions - worth the entrance on its own.Watch out for the queues - this place is on the tourist trail, but lunchtime onwards seemed better, and the place is vast, so can easily swallow crowds.It's also in Belem on the seaside, which is itself worth the tram trip from the city centre. Make time if you can.

Awful. The monument is splendid but this is what I went through. I got there on a rainy sunday morning (when the site is free), we were assaulted by abusive street vendors and beggars. Of course the staff stays well hidden and doesn't even try to help visitors. All of them were rude and spoke - or pretended not to speak any English. I had bought a Lisbon card paying a lot of money but this granted no priority. On the other hand we noticed other visitors motivated by the staff to buy some "tickets" and allowed to skip the line. I suspect if instead of buying tickets they left some pocket money to the staff.As tourism professional I am really shocked when not disgusted!!!
Beauties of Belem. A "must see"... beautiful monastery, cloister...don't lease Lisbon without a thorough visit of Belem!

A beautiful building with fascinating history. Go early to avoid the long queue for entry. The building is beautiful and an oasis of coolness on a very hot day. Lots to see and learn - did not know that writer Fernando Pessoa is buried there. There is a wonderful historical timeline display placing the history of Portugal in context with what was happening in the rest of the world - this was an outstanding exhibition and absolutely fascinating. There is also a leafy courtyard where one can take a quiet break. We very much enjoyed our visit.

Nice to see, but not *that* special. This monastery is 30 mins drive from Lisbon. The large church on the right end of it is free, the cloisters you pay to get into. Note there’s underground parking in the modern building opposite to the right – the Centro Cultural de Belém. The entrance is on the north end. It’s nice to see, but I don’t know why it’s number 2 for Lisbon on TripAdvisor. It’s not that special. Whilst you're in the area check out the electricity museum, and check out Mr Wrap for a lunch spot.

Beautiful - a must see while in Lisbon. There is lots to see in the Belem area of Lisbon, so I highly recommend planning to spend at least a morning or afternoon in that area (possibly a bit longer!). And this is one of the must see places while you are out there.The Mosteiro dos Jerónimos is made out of limestone (which was quarried nearby, but not the stone I would have chosen so close to the water!) and has the Manueline Style of architecture (Portuguese Late Gothic). As such, it is very ornate and light - particularly on the "white" stone.There are two parts to the structure: what I think of as the actual monastery (cloisters, the refectory...) and the church of Santa Maria de Belém. The church is free, but you pay a small fee to visit the monastery. So the church is typically full (I've visited multiple times) and people keep forgetting/ignoring the requests to keep silent. It is an active church, so you can attend mass there on Sundays. There is much to see and absorb, so I'd plan on 40min minimum inside the church (though you can go in and out in 15 min if you just want to walk through it).The monastery is much less crowded - and to me immediately peaceful. There are only 2 floor levels, but lots to see (I'd say minimum 2 hours). On my first visit I was lucky enough to catch a children's orchestra playing in the central courtyard - I spent 30 minutes just enjoying that show! But even without the orchestra (my subsequent visits) I just want to linger in that courtyard - particularly on very hot summer days. They have an exhibit titled "A Place in Time" in the library of the monastery that shows major events in the monastery's history in parallel to Portugal's history and World history. That alone is worth an hour of your time - and I came away wishing for similar timelines being available when I travel and visit different countries.With other highlights near by (the famous Pastéis de Belém, Belém Tower, the Discoveries Monument...), make sure you go out to that way at least once during your visit to Lisbon.

Lovely evening visit . We visited around 5.15pm and found it a lovely time to go as there weren't too many tour groups around and the evening light was beautiful around the cloister. The student rate was very affordable.

Magnificent Building. This building is very grand and ornate. The statutes and stained glass are beautiful. However this attraction was the first time on our trip that I felt was overcrowded. The walkway area is roped off to keep everyone in place. Not only was there a line to get in there was a line to get out and then a line to get to the cloister which was much less crowded. However could not appreciate the cloister as it was being set up for a concert with chairs. The crowds are the reason for 3 stars instead of 4.

Stunning, Palacial yet Delicate. A nice change from the earthquake-fortified churches in downtown Lisbon. Close to the train stop with little walking required. Very nice cloister inside with some great gargoyles above the arches in the cloister. A cool respite on hot days.

Stunning, but overpriced. The exterior of the building is absolutely gorgeous, and totally worth the visit just to look at that. The church part is free entry, and is very detailed inside with lots to look at. However, the inside was quite disappointing, with not much to see, and we had finished looking around within 40 minutes or so. In comparison, for a little less money the Belem Tower has much more to explore and see, with beautiful views of the river and the surroundings.

Stunning cloisters . It is worth making a trip out to Belem to visit the monastery, perhaps in conjunction with a visit to the nearby Museu Colecao Berardo or a train trip to Cascaix. The church is free, which means that it can be heaving with tour groups who are unwilling to spread out and view the other areas of the monetary (which attract a charge). This slightly spoiled our visit to the church, although we did enjoy visiting to tomb of da Gama. We much preferred the cloister area of the monastery, which is ticketed (€10 from memory). The cloisters are extremely impressive, having been cleaned and restored quite recently. They are on two levels - an unusual feature.The cloister area features a couple of exhibitions, as well as visits into side rooms and onto a viewing gallery over the church. Our favourite exhibition compared the history of the monastery with events of world history. The monastery is closed on Mondays.
Very nice. Nice place to visit. We only visit the church. Too much people taking pictures. I thought it was too much tourism. People should respect more the history and the place why means.
beautiful.. Interesting history, architecture. Too touristy however still able to visit. Have enough time to visit the paid and unpaid areas.
Historical SIte. If one is into hostorical churches related to the early explorers this is a great place to see with Vascp Da Gama"s tomb and the marine motifs worked into the facade.

Truly Excellent Visit to - Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. We went here early on a Sunday morning as it is free on this day. Went to the square at the front for the 15 Tram and the trams were exceptionally busy as you would expect. We used a taxi from the square where the trams depart. Good call as the taxi was 7 Euros and got us to the front of the queue for both the Church and the Monastery. A choir was playing in the courtyard which was a well received concert lasted 30 minutes or so. On a Sunday there is an interesting market with around 50 stalls selling local antiques and interesting pottery across from the entrance.One of the best venues in Lisbon. Many of the venues offer free entry on a Sunday, so worth making an early start on Sundays. Most of the venues offer reduction for over 65s.
Spectacular. Huge building and very attractive to walk around. Well worth taking the number 15 tram from the centre of Lisbon to see.

Big and impressive. We have visited a couple of beautiful monestaries outside Lisbon, so had we known, that the Belem Tower and the monument out here was so boring, we would never had gone all the way out here.Thw monestary is big and beautiful, but it took us an hour by bus to go there, as there is no metro around there.If you have not seen Alcobaca and Batalha it is worth a visit.A taxi to the Saldanha Metro cost us 8,5 EUR.
It looked great. we didn't get to go inside as it was closed...Monday's are the days they close so take note...however it was a sight to see from the outside. Magnificent

Very beautiful but slightly overrated. Thismagnificent building is worth having a look if you have a free 2-3hours in Lisbon. It is a 25 minutes trip From Caido with the tram n15. The gothic architecture is absolutely amazing and full of tiny details which look so fragile on this white building. Inside, you can have a very nice view of a cloister-like building similarly decorated. However, the place right in front of the building is not so nice since it is full of large busses, cars etc (so taking a picture from the park in feont of it is quite a challenge). Also, the entrance fee is really expensive (unless you have a Lisbon card, I would not recommend buying the ticket to go inside). Then, aim for the Torre de Belem and walk back on the riverside to enjoy some tranquility (if you are lucky, you can even hear the bridge sound when you get close to it on a windy day).
Ok . The place is really beautiful, but after all it doesn't take very long to explore it. I don't think that it's worth 10 euros, there's not that much exploring.
Beautiful bit of History. Magnificent in it's architecture and grounds, this piece of Lisbon history was truly enjoyable and a must see!
medieval at his best. It is not cheap, but really worth the while. Portugues gothic at his best. Do search for the details and you will be having a great discovery.

What a beauty, but pick your time. This is a beautiful monastery, built out of gorgeous stone with delightful details. It is also top of the list of things people want to do, so pick your time to arrive. We met friends around 1.30, and as suggested in guide books, lunch time is when the tour groups subside just a little, so you get to see things in a less harried way. The Church is also a good spot to see.
Amazing!. Such a nice place to visit!! Totally amazing architecture and so beautiful. Not a huge amount to see but really worth it!

Fantastic. We spent a morning here during our recent visit and were very impressed with the monastery. It was up there with some of the best attractions and architecture that I have seen anywhere in Europe. We arrived around lunch time and there was a queue which moved quickly. Our Lisboa Card allowed us to entry for free. We possibly could have avoided the queue had we popped into the ticket office for the archaeology museum next door which we saw a number of people do.

Beautiful!!. This is a beautiful building - the details inside are amazing - beautiful paintings and architecture! The ceilings are amazing!! We enjoyed seeing where Vasco da Gama was buried. Big crowds of people, but we had no problem getting close to see anything as the building is so big.

Gorgeous church. Reserve tickets ahead of time if you can to avoid the crowds. The church is beautiful and a big part of Lisbon's history. It's easy to combine a visit with other important sights in the area.

Interesting Old Site Full of History. Disappointed that one could not get into the cathedral from here. You pay to go into the monastery and then have to wait in line a second time if you want to go into the cathedral, which is free. Didn't make much sense to me.

One of the most emblematic Monuments of the new world. Amazing, beautiful. It's the monastery of the new world Brito in 1500 to celebrate the new discoveries of portugal, India, Brasil, China, Africa ... It's a world symbol !! The beginning of the globalization. YOU CAN'T MISS IT ! Near the famous pastry known as "Pastéis de Belém"

Unesco World Heritage site. Magnificent monastery occupied by the Order of St. Jerome . Resting pace of Vasco da Gama. Explorers prayed here before setting off for their discoveries. Get a famous pastry of the area. Just follow the crowds!

Terrific structure, very crowded. We visited on a Sunday morning as part of a city tour. The place was a zoo with people and mass was being conducted in the sanctuary but we got to go in. It is the outside that is what makes this place so spectacular. The tomb of Vasco De Gama was big plus.

worth the visit - pensioners get in cheaper. A point to remember is Portugal if you are over 65 - ask for pensioner rates - it usually halves the price. This is certainly worth the visit for the central colonnades and their carvings. The church is much like any other and I preferred the one at the tile museum. Can be long queues and there is the usual tourist trap shop at the end.

Beautiful experience!. Took the tram to this spot and it was crowded but a short ride. The Monastery is absolutely beautiful inside and out. Amazing architecture and artwork. Waited in line for a while but worth the wait. If women's shoulders are not covered they will provide you with a shawl. Did not get to the cloisters as the line was too long. Would definitely recommend a visit here. The grounds outside are pleasant with a nice water fountain display. Short walk to the water front and other interesting monuments.

Beautiful and atmospheric. There was a long queue to enter the monastery when we went (about 2PM on a weekday). However, it was worth it. It wasn't very crowded inside - we wondered why there was such a wait to get in. The stonework in the cloister is amazing, it's so detailed and ornate - the stone seems like lace. The refectory with its tiled walls is very impressive. There are two levels of the cloister to visit, plus some additional rooms. You can look down from the upper choir into the body of the church, a fascinating perspective. I am interested in history, and found the information a bit basic and sparse, but this is true of most historical sites in Portugal. There was a room with a display giving more detail, but it was upstairs at the end of the visit.
Must see. One of Lisbons best attractions. Easily reached by 'hop on hop off buses' allowing you to spend as little or as long a time as you wish.

amazing architecture. amazing building, unfortunately could not enter on this visit as closed due to official visit but cloisters impressive if you have time or just look from the street whilst visiting the monument and Torre de Belem.

A Must See!. Wow -- worth every penny to see the inside of the monastery! The architecture is captivating. You have to pause in the courtyard for a good while to take in all the details. The chapel was equally beautiful. The fountains and park outside the monastery are a nice place to sit and enjoy an ice cream, and the kids had fun playing in the spray of the fountains.

Disappointing. The Monastery itself is worth the visit but the crowds of noisy disrespectful and rude visitors detract from the splendour of Manueline architecture. Some method for restricting numbers needs to be established - perhaps charge more?
interesting. buy all of your museum tickets ahead (when possible) to avoid waiting in 30 minutes or more in lines. Wear comfortable shoes.
Incredible. The Jeronimos Monastery is the maximum exponent of Manueline architecture. the church and cloister are incredible

Very beautiful!. There is a free entrance to the church but that is usually a long line. With the free entrance/line you cannot see the 'mosteiro' itself.We also visited the paid entrance and it's worth it!!! Very beautiful and you can also enter the church from above so if you decide to do the paid entrance, do not go to the church first and wait in the long line as you will see it anyway.
Spectacular Heritage!. It's a wonderful example of Portuguese Late Gothic architecture style with magnificent columns and arches.

Impressive. In a country full of amazing Churches, Mosteiro de Jeronimos can be most impressive. Also take your time to see Belem, with lots of beautiful museums and architecture. Dont forget to eat one pastel de Belem, just next door.

Fantastic site!. Do not miss this beautiful monastery. The design is so intricate and detailed and has been preserved most sympathetically. You will need your camera! Very interesting displays of information and timelines in the the exhibit.You can learn a lot about the history of Portugal. Get there as soon as it opens at 10am and note that it is shut on Mondays. Best route to get there tram 15 from town. My number 1 site in Lisbon.
Grandious architecture. Grandious architecture representative of the time it was built. The time of expansion and of prosperity in portugal owing to the discoveries of new land and good fortune

Quite fascinating. Like the Torre Belem, very evocative of past glories and well worth visiting. Beautiful inner courtyard with an upper walkway off which there is a room with dates & photos/paintings and comments relating the world/European and Portugese history. Very clear and well documented.

Beautiful and very interesting. What a stunning place, on arrival the fantastic facade with lovely garden and fountain sat in front of the main building.There is a very large queue for the church as this is free, please go to the left of the main queue and pay 6 euros to see the cloisters. It is well worth it as the architecture is stunning, two floors of beauty with ceilings to enjoy. The peace and solitude of this site is delightful.
Magnificent monastery. This grandiose monastery is a delightful to walk through, full of amazing arches, twisting turrets and columns. The size and beauty of this site is awe inspiring.
Wonderful and profound Unesco site. Very worth the visit which is easy to access by tram. This timeless space has a sense of spirituality to it

Really really big!. Awesome architecture the enormity of the building is amazing. Line was way too long to go in but the pictures we took from the exterior are fantastic. Take the hop on hop off red line bus to get there.

Impressive architecture. Maybe not the grandest monastery I've ever visited yet still a place well worth seeing, especially due to the architecture. Visiting during lunch time (12-14) seemed like a smart move given how the queues looked before noon with all the tourist coaches pulling up.
A very impressive monument . One of the most impressive monument in Lisbon. It's a must see place in Lisbon. It's located in the area of the Belam. You arrive there with the tram 15

An architectural " Must See". The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and this area are the most popular attraction visit area in Lisbon. The history snd architecture are a very worthwhile stop. The huge cathedral portion is much more impressive than the downtown cathedral. There is again much history and the "Manuelino" architecture is lovely and unique. If you plan to see the "big 3" attractions, be sure to buy your combined ticket to both the Monastery and Belem Tower and save some euros over buying the tickets to see each separately at each door. The " Discoveries" is free to view. Take time to read of the rich history.

Fantastic Monastery. One of the best monasteries in Lisbon that took more than a 100 years to construct. My favorite's part of Lisbon, Belem, it is indeed travelling to the times when the great sea explorer would come and worship before setting their voyage.

Beautiful!. We used the Rick Steve's Portugal Guide to tour around the area and get good history information. Definitely check this monastery out in Belem. You can take the train from Lisbon (about 30 minutes). Go early in the AM to avoid the crowds. Down the street there is a pastel place that is super popular - if you go before the monastery you won't have to wait in the long lines!

Fantastic. What a spectacular building! The architectural details are amazing. The interior and exterior are incredible. There is a fabulous exhibit covering the history of the monastery together with the history of Portugal and of the world.

Worthwhile. We went to Belem today on the way to CasCais to see the Monastery and to wait on line for Belen pastries.. We had absolutely no trouble getting into the church and monastery. Though there seemed to be a lot of tour buses, we just walked right in. Yes it is worthwhile. Would I go out of my way to see it, probably not. It's a lovely town that's worth a trip if you have time.

A monastery that is a monument. Facing the river, Monastery of Jerónimos is the most precious exemple of the "Manuelino" style, a unique portuguese type of architecture from the 16th century which is based on the ocean and the ship materials.An outstanding church and marvellous cloisters are seeing everyday by thousands of people. Attention: it´s closed on mondays

Impressive Convent & Chrurch. A beautiuful and massive building, restored to sparkling clean outside. The convent is worth the visit the architecture recalling Islamic buildings in it's interior courtyard + a lot of very ornate sculpture and turrets.

Stunning trip. you can either visit the spectacular church for free or see the whole thing for €10 although that's free too if you have a Lisboacard. It is a superb piece of architecture and worth a visit.
Wonderful artchitecture. The vaulting and tracer are very fine. Easy to rach by bus or tram. Give yourself time to see all the sights in Belem once you have gotten out there.
Big beautiful monastery!. Enjoyed the walk through the monastery specially the history timeline.. Monastery, Portugal and the World!

Fantastic. My wife and I visited last month.the chAppel was absolutely beautiful and well worth a visit. If you go up in the cryp and treasure room add a considble time to allow you to do this as it's very worth while.highly recommended. Stunning
It's OK. Nice building and the gardens surrounding it with the gigantic fountain is great but nothing too exciting. I didn't feel like it was something I would go out of my way to visit.
Impressive. A magnificent building with an astounding variety of stone carving and sculpture. Good facilities and very cool inside, which was a boon on a 33 C day as when we visited.
Cultural. Historical place, a must see. A representation of the Portuguese glorious times of the Discoveries. Splendid archicture
serene and reflective. if you're a serious theological student…you will appreciate the importance of solitude and quiet…it was a walk back through time.

A stunning legacy!. You have to visit this wonderful complex with the cloisters, church and other areas. In spite of the crowds of visitors there is a sense of the contemplative life that dominated the building for centuries. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is part of a most impressive area in Lisbon. From the front of the building you walk down through formal gardens with fountains, under the busy road/ rail/ tram by underpass to the river Tejo (Tagus). The Monument to the Discoverers rises above quay. There is an elevator to the top and the views are wonderful. Further down, a short walk away by the river, the Torre de Belem completes the tour. While you are in the area, don't forget to go the institution Pasteis de Belem (turn left when you come out of Mosteiro - it's a short walk). Lunch finished with a coffee and a gorgeous flaky creamy pasteis ( custard tart!) is a must. We love Lisbon.
Very crowded with tour groups.. Saw some of the interior but it was difficult because of the large crowds. Many religious and historic artifacts.

Rather mind boggling. This monastery is beautify, well preserved and with good information available. Recommend the sound system. The whole area was beautiful. Be careful of pick pockets on the tram--my husband lost his phone.

Beautiful cloister but victim of its success. The cloister is very beautiful and worth seeing. However the queue is usually terribly long unless you aim for the lunch-time soft spot. After queuing and paying your entrance ticket, you realise that it's almost as crowded inside the cloister than in the queue. It's still worth seeing but would definitely recommend to aim for week days in order not to have your visit ruin by selfie-poles and back-packs in your face. You can also climb to the second floor from which you can look down into the square-shaped cloister and see it from the top. We bought a ticket that included the visit of Belem tower too, which is not far from the cloister. However, we never made it inside the tower as we the queue to enter was almost as long as for the cloister. We ended up having lunch at a very nice terrace at the foot of the tower, enjoying it from the outside. Overall, these are beautiful places victims of their success.
Beautiful cloister. Great stone work already on the outside of the church (which contains the tomb of Vasco da Gama), but the cloister is even more beautiful

Interesting but.... i think it is probably one of those 'must sees', it's just that when we went (mid morning) it seemed like the whole world was waiting to get in to look at this place.Yes it's a fascinating old building and it's worth seeing but when you're being herded around (and admission is on a timed only, one way only basis), the sense of wonder can inevitably be replaced by a sense of 'get me out of here'.

worth the pain. ok it's a pain to get to as every tourist in Lisbon seems to want to go when you do, and the tram will probably be packed, and when you get there, there are hordes of people, but walk through the church and then go to the cloisters and I defy you to not be impressed. Painful or not to get to ...this is a special place to be...and you are lucky enough to be there. Do yourself a favour, go and see this....as we know from the devinyls song ...it's a fine line between pleasure and pain..it is worth the pain for this pleasure.

A beautiful birthday cake and candles!. Several years ago I visited here and took a picture of 35 of this church and cloister's spires. It looks a bit like a fluffy white birthday cake to me. :)This time we had just landed and this was our first stop in Lisbon, still jet-lagged.
