The weather was perfect and warm and the line a bit long to get into the church (free) which was beautiful, but nothing compared to the cathedral here, nor many other churches in Portugal and Spain, but it is lovely, especially when a service choir is taking place.The real delight of the place is the cloister (10 euros), especially when the weather is nice. It's gorgeous and there is so much detail you could spend an hour or more finding all the little nuances. Dozens of folks take pictures of themselves in the open air middle section, but you can still get fantastic pictures of all of the facades nonetheless.It looks even more beautiful from the park across the street.I think of this as a must-see part of Lisbon. Also check out the visual historic timeline on the second floor of the cloisters.

Hugely amazing. This is one of the biggest structure you can find in Lisbon. It's fully decorated with the classical 'manuelino style', and the internal garden are nice aswell. The church is really evocative. The ticket was low thanks to the fact I'm a student.

Stunningly Beautiful.. A combined ticket to Mosteiro Jeronimos & Torre de Belem is €12 per adult.
Use your Viva Viagem card ( €6/day) to travel to Cais do Sodre on the Green line and take the 15E tram to Belem.
A lot to see, we particularly liked the vaulted nave, refectory, and cloisters.

Long line for Cloister. Had to stand in line for 40 minutes ( had the Lisboa Day Pass) for the cloister. Seemed unnecessary. The church is free, so if you don't want to stand in line, just go into the church. It's good enough.
Historical place. It will take app. 1 hour to do this visit a little bit difficult whit small children but there is a lot of places to visit beside there. So plan 2-3 hours visit in total.

Great architecture to photograph. Stunning multi story structure to walk through and great photographs to add to your travel log. The arches and vaulted ceilings are a thing of beauty, Incredible tile in beautiful colors depicts life from century's ago.
don't miss. stunning both inside and out. surrounded by beautiful parks and gardens well worth visiting. easily accessed by tram from central lisbon

Gorgeous cloister and building. Spent a happy 1.5 hours wandering around this beautiful building. This and the Tower were certainly my highlights of Belem. Extremely easy to get to on the 15 Tram from Placa da Figueira, takes approx 30 minutes.
Worth the trip. The whole area around Belem is impressive, but the scale of the building will blow you away. As warned line ups are long, though the church on the right is free.
Amazing Building. Wonderful and in a nice area to see other sights but oh the queues to get in went on forever. This is on the Red Route down towards the Belem area

2nd time in Lisbon, 1st experience in Jeronimos. That's one of the nicest places I'd ever seen, with a transitional architecture (gothic-baroque). The monastery is huge, then spare time to see at least the church (no charged). However, pay attention that this place is closed on Mondays, in my 1st visit in Lisbon I couldn't see that place due this...

Beautiful site. We really enjoyed our visit of the monastery. There is ample parking in the area if you decide to drive there. The architecture is fantastic. It would be nicer, and a perfect score, if there was furniture inside and better explanations of how the monks lived. Still highly recommended.
Beaultiful. Really Worth the visit ! The view of the church is amazing. Check the exibition of the history inside.

Vast, impressive. First, a tip: Buy the combo ticket for this and the Torre of Belem to avoid standing on VERY long lines at both sites. If you go at opening, it will save a lot of time waiting as well.
The monastery is vast, impressive, and beautiful.

On Monday it is closed! :(. I gave a bad rating because I did not have had the chance to see the Mosteiro. On Mondays it is closed and unfortunatly we only had Monday to see that area of Lisboa (Mosterio+Belem+Pasteis..etc). It is a pity..I think it should be open everyday..this means no unhappy tourists (there were a looooot of people that did not know that is was closed) and people to be hired...so work for potetial unemployed people.

Visit the church and pay for the cloisters. The church is free to enter and it is a wonderful sight with the decorative stonework. Importantly, the church gives you a taste of what you can see in the cloisters. In the cloisters you can see the stonework close up and admire the upstairs of both cloisters and church. Also upstairs is the timeline exhibition which charts the history of the monastery, of Portugal and of the world. This display is very interesting (in English and in Portugese) and greatly enhances the whole visit. (Can you spot that the world history was selected by a big fan of Alexander Dumas?... just for fun)
Great monument. We've started out tour with this great monument and it looks magnificent. Don't miss photo there. Definitely go inside, there is plenty to see.

A pure beauty. The Mosteiro and the Tower are just a pure beauty. It is a must to visit when you are in Lisboa. The beauty of the cloister and all the details are just astonishing. end your visit by a stop at the pasties de Belem for a pasties de bata and a glass of white porto.
History at its best. i was in portugal for 5 days and this was my first target.amazing place.explains a lot about portuguese history and expeditions.

A true monument to Portugal's history. . This monument to the greatness of Portugal in the Age of Discovery reflects the architecture of period of Manuel I and is a celebration of its wealth and strength. Well worth the visit. This entire area around the Belem Tower and the Monument to the Discoveries, and the "Mosteiro" require a half a day to really explore. This is the site of so much of Portugal (and Lisbon's) history and should not be missed. The pictures of the Trip Advisor site for the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos has the best pictures and so well portrays this marvelous structure.

Beautiful and Worth Every Minute. We visited around noon on a Saturday. The line for the Church, which is free, was long. I think because there was an event in there. To get into the monastery, the longest part was getting the ticket. I recommend this to anyone visiting. It's beautiful and amazing and educational.

The beginnning of the Monastery Trail. Getting to Belem is very easy and the monastery is easy to walk around. Also a few other sites there. We continued our trek to the other 3 monasteries in central Portugal. Great to compare and see the workmanship.

Stunning.. You need a lot of time here to really take it all in. There is a noddy train which does a little run around, but it's far better to use the hop on hop off bus for about £17. There are fantastic walks all along the surrounding waterfront with lots to do without even venturing into the centre. Have a great day out without the usual shops and bars. Full of fascination and culture, an absolute delight.

Time and Money Saving Tip. Well worth the long lines and €10 entrance fee.My guide book suggested visiting lunch time or near the end of the day to avoid the crowds. An hour would be adequate.What the guide book didn't say was the church, the most interesting part, is free to enter and no queue when I was there. This is clearly marked and is to the right of the main entrance. Some might think this a worthwhile compromise.

Impressive. We arrived here at around 10.00am and the line was about 40-50 metres long to get tickets. It didn't take too long and we bought a combined monastery/Belem tower ticket which saved a couple of euro, but more importantly we were able to bypass the massive line at the tower.The cloisters at the monastery were very nice but the best area was the church, which is free entry. Very impressive indeed. Just remember the right hand line at the front is the church line. We'll worth a visit.

Beautiful site - save for a sunny day!. Beautiful site surrounded by lots of worthwhile other tourist stops (Pasteis de Belem sweet shop, Tower of Belem, maritime museum, palace gardens). Definitely worth paying to see the cloisters.

Great example of Manueline architecture. In Mosteiro you will see the yard which is really bautifully decorated in specific portuguese historic style. You can also visit the upper floor of the church and nearby rooms, where are small expositions. The visit will take you approx. 40 minutes

Great look back in history. I took the trolley from the main square down to the entrance of the Monastery. Since I'm a senior, I got in for $5 and I was very impressed by the art and architecture in this place. Most of the things to see are on the second floor and from there you can get a good look at the magnificent architecture of this building which is about 500 years old. Make sure to look at the refectory which has some really great religious art on the walls and done in tiles.
Brilliant architecture. Architecture is amazing. timeline over the centuries absolutely fascinating. Well worth a visit. Near to Belem Tower and patisserie

Beautiful. This place is less than a 10€ can rude from Lisbon and so lovely to walk around for a few hours. The church is gorgeous and the monastary is simply stunning. Buy the joint ticket for the tower for the best value.
Good for Historical Architecture. A visit to Lisbon should include this monument. It has been kept up very well and has fairly easy access. Go in the early morning to avoid crowds.

I was expecting more. The building is stunning and huge. I recommend going to visit, but would pass on the tour inside unless you are really interested in its history. Frankly, there is not much to see.

Absolutely fantastic!. We went Sunday morning so we also cached the ceremony, which is superb! I think the church is the best: the construction is amazing and together with the chorus...just divine!! Just go and listen!

great atmosphere, expect miles of queue!. we visited the monastery on the first sunday of May and it was free (yes, they do this every month!!!). there are actually 3 lines (for the monastery, the church, and one for smt else i dont remember) so make sure you are queuing in the right one. on that very same day there was an orchestra playing there and it was amazing! imagine walking in a UNESCO world heritage having classical music playing in the background, you'll feel like being in a movie ;)
Must go. Everything Looks fine, must go one of the finest historic place if not the best example in Portugal. Sometimes long queues can des courage not to enter.

Amazing architecture with an educational room. Queue for the Cloisters using the left hand line , the right line is for the Church. We bought a combination ticket for the cloisters and the Belem Tower. Do it in this order and save yourself time at the Torre and walk past queues using the right hand line there. The Cloisters are absolutely incredible and still in such detailed condition. There are various rooms containing information. The one we spent most time in gave a fantastic timeline of Monastery, Portuguese & Worldwide news, stories and dates so you can compare all 3 against each other. Definitely worth the visit for photos and knowledge.

This is a great place to see. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is very close to Torre de Belém and Padrão dos Descobrimentos. It is a really nice architectural monument to visit. If you intend to also Visit Torre de Belém as well, make sure you purchase one ticket for both attractions.It is cheaper this way.
Nice. Avoid mondays: it's closed. Very close to pasteis de belem. Good communications with tram and bus. The view is beautiful

Stunning and worth a visit. Well worth visiting but go later in the day when the crowds have thinned. We took the bus from Praca Concordia, but if you also want to visit the Torre de Belem don't get out at the monastery - go two stops further to the Tower and then walk back along the river to the monastery - much easier.

Go early and enjoy the seaside town of Belem. This monastery is beautiful. The architecture alone is gorgeous. The inner courtyard is beautiful and in the church itself lies the tombs of the kings and queens as well as Vasco Da Gama. Definitely worth while.

Grand building. What a lovely place to wander around on a sunny afternoon. Once you get over the initial shock of the long queues and make your way in, it is a grand and serene place to visit, despite the crowds. I loved the architecture and the layout of the place, you can imagine how much quiet time was spent in prayer here. There was also a very informative time line, we learnt more than we expected to, taking some time out to read that!You can walk into the church for free (right hand queue) or pay 10+ Euros for a visit to the rest of the monastery and combine your ticket with the museum of Archaeology or the Belem Tower. The sullen ticket vendor didn't tell us about the audio guides which you could have for free though and there isn't much in the way of useful historical information in any of the rooms or courtyard so we pretty much were left to our own devices which cut our visit short. The toilet I used had no lock on but served its purpose, I'd bring your own hand sanitizer though as there was no soap either. Still, it's a mighty fine building and a must see if you're in Belem.
beautiful monastry. take the train to belem, get off at the 25 April Bridge and walk along the river to belem to visit this beautiful monastry! Attention: closed on mondays!!!!!

Number 2 on my Lisbon List. This monastery was built during the 1500s with a 5% tax on commerce from Africa and Asia. I would rank it a close 2nd behind the castle on my list of places to see. It was about a nine Euro cab ride between Rossio square (a short walk down from the castle) to the monastery. I'd rank the Belem tower, which is a short walk away from the monastery, 3rd.

Stunning!. When my husband said monastery I expected some dull grey little building but was blown away by the scale and craftsmanship of this wonderful building. A bit of a queue to get in but worth the wait to marvel at the skill and design from the 1500s. Don't miss it!

Beautiful historical building. The architecture is notable. This is a huge structure but there are fine architectural details to be found throughout. There is information in English at many spots, helpful for understanding the history of the building and of Portugal. There are several royal tombs, as well as the tomb of Vasco da Gama. There was a 30 to 40 minute wait to get inside. Certainly the most impressive site we saw in Lisbon.

Monestery. Best cloisters in the world. Just stunning. I have seen different architecture in France, Italy and Spain but this is too draw. The fact it is also from an age where Portugal was ahead of the pact in terms of discovery makes it even more interesting.

Architectural Masterpiece. Don't miss it. It's an architectural masterpiece. It's a UNESCO World Heritage Site, along with the nearby Tower of Belém.The existing structure was inaugurated on the orders of Manuel I (1469–1521).Richly ornate architectural style with complex sculptural themes incorporating maritime elements and objects discovered during naval expeditions, carved in limestone.The church interior is now under restoration,
Beautiful place. It is really worth to come here while in Lisbon, you may use a tram 15 or buses from the Praca do commercio. Highly recommend!
Majestic!. Amazingly grand. Make sure to go around the structure as each side has different beauty. Travel tip from hotel was to take the tram to mosteiro as cheaper than touristic bus.

Chaotic ticketing and queues. Long queues not helped by only having 2 slow staff serving tickets then everyone having to go in and out of small entrance where someone else checked the tickets. Could do with much better system to organise queue as museum is also at same entrance and only one unhelpful guy trying to manage everything. Is a sign to split queue for those that have Lisbon cards and those that don't but then one line has to cross the other to get in and other people just ignore and go to the front anyway and have to then contend with all of the people coming out of same doorway. Should be much better organised considering this is one of the main attractions in the area and it was only April, would be dreadful in the summer and when much hotter.Nice to visit once you finally make it inside.

Worth a stop. 12 Euros to get in the place. Go early to avoid the bus tours which show up around 10 am. Ticketing is problem free. There is a special lane for Lisboa card holders. Clean restrooms inside. Plenty of photo-ops of the buildings. Gift shop.

Church Visit in a Historic Area. While we didn't have time to scope out the entirety of this breathtaking building, we did manage to enter the Church area. One cannot arrive to Lisbon as a tourist without at least visiting this monastery and the area it's located in. You can hop in a cab and ask for the "big Monestary" and in 10 minutes (7-9 euros) time you'll be at this attraction. There are also a few more attractions around, so the ride is worth it if you're in groups of 3-4, as opposed to paying for the tramlines.The Church visit portion is Free. It'll take you approximately 45 minutes to really take in the Manueline Gothic architecture of the church. The style is quite something to behold and the staff do allow plenty of picture taking...BUT it is a church, so tourists are sometimes "shushed". The outside "south portal" is incredibly detailed, and on a hot day I would recommend refueling on your water while making out the intricate workmanship.This is a great attraction for those that want to keep striking those UNESCO heritage sites of your bucket list!

lots to see.. Buy the combined ticket - it is worth it. The cloisters are facinating but the church is rather plain, but the latter is free to enter. Don't be fooled by the long queue for the main entrance and ticket counter, use the side office to buy tickets, which seemed to be relatively quiet when we were there. Also remember to take proof of age if you are over 65 since this gets you a 50% reduction!The coach museum is well worth a visit and is included in the combined ticket.

Don't miss, but online booking is a must!. It is fantastic place, due to the architecture, you visit to Lisbon would not be full without itBut to avoid queueing I greatly recommend to buy the tickets online in advance, it will save you lots of time as the queue is enormous.And it is better to come at opening time to avoid crowdsEnjoy!
Must see place. Get the tram - not far out of the city. Wonderful building and good exhibition which tells the history of the monastery against a timeline of Lisbon and the World

Monastery of St jerome. It looks lovely from the outside .10 Euros but free with the Lisboa Card. Queue was only about 10 people. The cloisters were really impressive. Only takes an hour to look about

Pretty Amazing. All of the monasteries and convents in Portugal were secularized in the 19th century and they have all become museums or hotels but abandoned by the religious orders who once lived there. This is a museum but still looks and feels like a monastery. Some beautiful artwork and architecture can be found. It is popular so you also find crowds. Our visit was included as part of a tour so no idea what the entrance fee was but there is a fee. If you are in the are it is worth a visit and the custard tarts found nearby are not to be missed.

Beyond expectation!. such unusual architecture and a delight to the eye. The highlight of my trip to Portugal. A great circle of information showing a time line of the building, Portugal and the worlds
Brilliant. Just loved the place. Very interesting and historical. The location at Belem is good. And the pasties de Nata at Belem is so near.
Breathtaking work. It is a place worth seeing specially for those who love Art History. Precission of details, and the combination of styles is amazing.
Not to be missed. I loved the history and the archtecture.You have to insist if you need to use a ramp and an elevator. They are sometimes well hidden.
Top 5 things to see. Beautifull building, impressive architecture, lot to see even more to learn. Worth waiting in huge line!

Spectacular Architecture. UNESCO world heritage site, this huge monastery was built in 1501 and contains Vasco da Gama's tomb. Free entry. I'd say this and the Castle are the 2 best sights in Lisbon. Get tram 15 there.

Grand Beauty. Just an awesome display of architecture and history! Had to take the train from Lisbon to Belem which was about 25 minute train ride. Even if you are not a religious person the architecture and statues will definitely humble you.

Church only visit. We just visited the church and not the monastery, as it was free, there was no line, and we were on a bit of a budget.It was incredibly beautiful. The pillar carvings and the ceiling-mounted escutcheons were particular highlights. The Church was under renovation, so a re-visit is definitely in order. As it was, the delicate monumental gothic of the interior and the sculptural encrusting of the doorways were really fascinating.Go!

Get there early. This is the top place to visit in Belem. We arrived around 10:30 and waited in a long line that moved quite quickly. Make sure you decide when in line as to which one of the multi site tickets you want considering the amount of time you want to spend in Belem. We chose the Jeronimos and Torre ticket then paid the extra 6 Euros for the Coach Museum which is all we managed to do in a day. This was with a bench break for a picnic lunch and then a coffee break. Jeronimos is a most beautiful example of the Manueline architecture. Take advantage of the free audio info which was interesting although not arranged in any specific sequence. Put in the number at each major stop. Take your time, walk around the whole site and visit the church, which is free if you do not have time to see the inside of the monastery...although the point of visiting is to see the Manueline architecture. Not sure if you can buy tickets on line. We chatted with some folks in the line up who said that the Sunday free time has horrendous line ups so do not bother waiting for that.

Impressive roof structures. Vaulted roof structures were designed 500 years ago without modern computerized methods and survived the earthquaqe in 1755. It seems that the builders had something more than we have today - experience?

the best Lisbon monument. Indisputably, Jerónimos is the best monument Lisbon has to offer its visitors. It's this 500 years old monument in itself and it is the environment, beautiful beyond belief, close to Tejo.

Beautiful and really à must to visit. IT,s worth visiting. A long line but when you are in Belem, you should see the monastry. In the right part, you wil find a couple of graves. One important grave is from Vasco de Gama.
History and Architecture. No visit to Belem would be complete if you did not visit this monastery. Amazing architecture, history, and religion, make sure you stop by during your visit to Belem!
Beautiful cloisters. Well worth a visit - a really lovely place. It's a good idea to get a combined ticket for here and Torre de Belem to avoid having to queue at one of them.

An absolute must. This is the finest survivinbg example of the architecture and overwhelming decoration of Portugals "Golden Age" under Manuel I. The church and especially thge twostoreyed cloister are unforgettable.

Impressive Site. First of all, the white ornately carved facade is impressive although a little worn. The church or monastery stretches along the road and this makes it appear huge. As the resting place for Vasco di Gama, we had to visit as we had actually visited Kerala, the area of India where he landed. He was one of the first explorers that I learned about in Grade Four, Social Studies! In Portugal, he is lauded for finding a sea route to India which resulted in the countries growth to become the center of commerce in the years that followed. The interior of the monastery and church are impressive with murals and carved arches and columns. Definitely worth an hour or so.

Not To Be Missed!. A UNESCO World Heritage site and with good reason. Huge and with beautiful architecture. Plan to spend a minimum of two hours - preferably 3-4 hours. Has an attached museum and church.

UNESCO heritage. Very beautiful. Go there early in the morning before the numerous tourist groups. Enjoyable and stunning. Please note that the WC are in different floors for F and M. I enjoyed the church (free entrance) and do not forget to buy combined ticked with options for Belem tower (12EUR) and also with archeological museum and others.

thumbs up. When you visit the Mosteiro don't forget to go see the museum and the claustro. After the visit stop by Pasteis de Belém right next to it and have a capuccino with a pastel de belém. Your visit will not be complete without it!!!

Really beautiful place. Every stone is carved in this wonderful monastery.I imagined a more "severe" place for monks and prayers but this monastery is incredibly sophisticated and "rich"; it is really an art piece!

simply beautiful. Worth the trip, amazing complex, very nice view and walk to Belen Tower! 2-min from the famous pastry shop where you can have delicious and various types of salty and sweet pastry for few euros!

Worth a trip. This fabulous example of Manueline architecture is in Belem in the outskirts of Lisbon, about 15-20 minutes from downtown Lisbon by taxi, twice as long by trolley but more like an authentic, non-tourist experience (although the route is not scenic). We went by taxi to the Tower of Belem first and then walked back to the monastery along the riverfront, but if pressed for time, I would skip the tower and go straight to the monastery, which is much more interesting. Best visited on a fine day to do justice to the magnificent view of the exterior; also, the interior would be gloomy in the absence of sunlight.

Do not miss this beautiful place!. Of all the iconic Lisbon attractions that we visited, this is the most outstanding. The architecture and history is very beautiful and interesting. Do not miss the history timeline which compares World history , Portugal history and Mosteiros dos Jeronimos history simultaneously. It really puts things into perspective!

Stunning. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is a must see when you visit Lisbon. Take time to look at the exterior before you enter. It is so ornate & beautiful too. It was quite busy on our visit but it didn't detract from the atmosphere. Top tip: be aware of the beggars & pick pockets!
Nice couple of hours. Variety of displays - if you like the blue and white ceramics; this is the place for you. Nice gentle place

amazingly detailed piece of work !!!. I didn't go inside but it was really interesting to see from out side even.. brilliant architecture..!!
So detailed.. amazing ! You can close this by using the tram from the Arco Triunfal..

wonderful spot. a place not to miss ... lovely visit, beautiful chapel and very interesting architectural details for a construction style which is not common anywhere else. Take the train from Praca do Comercio, very handy, plan to devote at least a half day and finish a perfect visit combining with the Naval Museum, Belem Tower and DO NOT miss a visit to Pasteis de Belem, 200 mts from Jeronimos, trust me, you will never taste something as delicate and delicious like this beatiful and perfect pastries.

Just a cloister.....avoid it if you are on a budget. The church next door (free) is really cool, but the cloister is just that.....a two level square around a courtyard for €10! . It had a couple of really boring exhibitions that simply had too much text, I guess they were trying to create some value. We didn't see the library (I assume it was closed) and they closed off the cathedral balcony for the service. If you can afford it, give them the money to support the place but don't expect too much, I thought it was the worst value of our entire trip. Try the cloister at the cathedral near the castle where you also get access to a good treasury with some interesting objects and great views for only €4.

typical. While the Monastery is very famous, i must admit i found the one in Batalha more beautiful. They are in the same architectural style, just that this one is more expensive and more crowded. However, worth a visit if you are in the Belem area.

Stunning. This place is stunning...massive imposing building..definately a must visit monastery ...gorgeous architecture and lovely ambience....you can get a tour guide to explain its history..a real surprise when visiting Lisbon

Fabulous building. Very interesting and stunning architecture dating back to the 15th century. Well worth the visit to Belem from central Lisbon. Worth getting the joint visit ticket although I had the Lisboa card so it was free.

Massive monastery and well preserved. This monastery must be seen, when you are in Lisbon. Especially as this has the tomb of Vasca da Gama. But besides from that, you can wander a full day to view the beautiful surroundings and buildings
Interesting place to visit.. Great "Manuelino" style Architecture, well preserved, also very close to Bell Tower.On the Hop-on Hop-off route. Don't miss the best pastel de nuta

Beautiful. The best of its kind, for me one of the most beautuful buildings I have ever seen. Deffinately worthwhile a visit and if you get the chance, get a tour guide, they can explain everything there is to know about the monastery.
Spectacular Monestary. Unbelievably beautiful Monestary. Highly recommend you take a quick walk around and inside. It's gorgeous.
Impressive. It's very beautiful on the outside but you should also take a look on the inside where the architecture is breathtaking. It's also a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

A excellent example of christian architecture. It's a Lisbon highlight and worth visiting. It's sheer magnitude impresses, but you also get impressed by the surrounding landscape over the river tagus.

Superb World Heritage site. This is the Must See of Lisbon. Even if you are not interested in religious buildings, THIS is an absolute gem of architectural design which demonstrates the magnificent attention to detail medieval stonemasons afforded their work. You see highly ornate cloisters, tiled walls, alabaster supports, inspirational stained glass in the church and altogether get a tremendous feel for the priviliged life led by monks in the days when ordinary people lived in squalor and poverty.
Imposing & Impressive. This ancient monastery is such a beautiful building & is quite imposing & impressive. Well worth a guided tour, where you'll hear all the history of the monastery & church.

Beautiful building. The cloister is absolutely beautiful and should not be missed. The cathedral is also definitely worth a look. The archaeology museum is interesting for those who are into that type of thing.

Dissapointing considering the long waiting time. It looks really impressive in the inside (altough it's just the inner courtyard), but definetely not worth the 12 euro I paid and the ~2 hours spent in the line.

Beautifull ! Don't miss.. The church of the convent can be visited for free. It is very interesting. You can also visit the sacristy for 1eur. You can reach the upper choir from the cloister. The entrance fee of the cloister is 10eur for adults and 5eur for students. The cloister itself is wonderfull. We spent some time just sitting there and absorbing the atmosphere.PS If you have read the book from Steve Berry "The Alexandria link" : the church is mentioned in the book.

Take a cab. It's cheap.. We liked the surrounding sites, but not the ride back on the tram, which stopped in a rain storm due to an accident, so we had to walk a mile to a bus stop. Take a cab. It's fairly cheap and you don't need to change from the metro to the tram.

Must do in Lisbon. This place is a mandatory stop if you're heading to Lisbon, and for good reason-- it's just fantastically beautiful. We paid to go inside the ornate cloister, which was well worth it. We arrived first thing at opening and went inside the cloister first (which worked well, since a lot of larger tour groups visit the church first and the cloister second; by the time we moved to the church the cloister was swarming with people). If you're traveling on the trams, the signage is very clear, and once you reach the stop it's pretty obvious where you're supposed to go.

Fantastic cloisters. Although we had to queue for about 15 mins when we got in there was plenty of room and you could stay as long as you wished. 50 % reduction for oldies but must have proof of age. Also audio guide included in the price. This fact was not very clear

One of my favorites of Lisbon. My third time in Lisbon and my third time here this time with all family. I love the unusual warmth of the gothic cathedral and I can spend lots if time just being there.

A great example.. This not that easy to get to, we used the hop on/off tour bus. It is very interesting with two story cloisters, and we wished you could see more of what is there, cells etc. a discount for seniors. The church is free to enter and we were treated to a short performance by a touring choir, they sounded as though they belonged there.

Awesome. The monastery is gorgeous. The cloisters were beautiful, and seeing the church from upstairs was very cool. The exhibit showing world events over the centuries in connection with Portuguese history was very well presented.

The Church is much more impressive than the moisteiro!. Exremely crowded! Nice to see, but too expensive for the visit. À pitty that only à (very) small part was open for visit. Do not forget the Church that is kuch more worthwhile to visit (and free).

A Stunning Building with an Interesting History. This Monastery is found easily by catching the tram from Lisbon to Belem, the imposing building proving unmissable. Its construction was funded predominantly by taxes on the spice trade through the port; as this was a lucrative trade, no expense was spared, and the resulting architecture is well worth a visit.If I had to list three highlights, these would be: the graceful, fine pillars supporting the roof above the nave; the elaborate stonework adorning the striking two-storey cloisters; the tomb of Vasco da Gama, one of the seafaring explorers whose discoveries laid the foundations for the lucrative spice trade.Go and judge for yourself (and the best custard tarts in Portugal are only a stone's throw away!)
amazing place. Gothic Architecture was amazing in Jerominos manaster and the garden in front of it was so relaxing..

Worth to visit. This is a must-see attraction in Lisbon and well-worth the trip just outside the city. The architecture is excellent, as are the stained glass windows, and internal designs. This 16th Century monastery celebrates the great Portuguese explorers and attached to one end of the building is the very good Maritime Museum and extension.The surrounding area is worth visiting too.

Nice place but not much to see. Architecturally speaking, it's a beautiful building but given the entrance fee (10 euros) and the scarcity of things to see inside it may not be worth it to enter unless you are an architecture enthusiast or you are tired and are looking for a place to sit and rest
gorgeous!. The beautiful monument, architectural masterpiece of Lisbon. I was impressed! It's located in Belem - my favourite district of Lisbon. I do recommend seeing it. It's a must.
Stunning building. This was a beautiful building. We had a little trouble getting in as you can buy your tickets further along but no signs to let you know that you can then skip the queue.

Beautiful and ornate. Word of advice when the queues are long, especially as the weather gets warmer, you can buy tickets at the museum next door to the monastery. Most people don't realise this as it is not advertised anywhere. Once you have your receipt, walk to the front and show the staff.If you choose to purchase a combined ticket for the torre de belem then again, walk to the front of the queue with your receipt to skip the queue.

go after the city tours. crypts of vasco de game an other dignitaries are easy to see, however it was after learning more about lisbon and portugal that i came to appreciate the monastery. i'd recommend seeing a few other areas first, and then going.

The unexpected. The church is rather dark but has ornate decorated columns which are very slender. I did not get the breathtaking sense of space the guide books refer to. Staff were very polite despite it being very busy.The cloisters were stunning. Light bright and double decker and well worth the entry fee 10 euro. The sacristy was a real gem and just as good as the guide book photos Fee 1 euro.
Beautiful!. A must see on your trip to Lisbon. The intricacies of the entire structure are something to behold. Very serene setting in the middle of a large city. A must see if you are in Lisbon.
great architecture. this attraction was awersome, tottaly recomendable!! The architecture of the building is amazing - the only thing i did not like so much was the audio guide.
Great arhcitecture. Huge complex with towers, halls spires and pleasant gardens. Maritime museum is in one wing. Great location easily accessible by train, bus or tram.

Very turistic. It worth a visit, but there is not a lot to see inside. The most interesting things where a display about the main events of the Portuguese history since the construction of the monastery and the cloister.

Queued for 40 mins to see it!. I really wanted to see this place; they are closed on Mondays so Tuesdays are probably the worst days to go or maybe it is always so busy. Anyway, I really enjoyed it. Inside the cloister is so rich with intricate details, it is so peaceful even though it gets very busy. The church is a Gothic gem. For me it was worth it!
beautiful. visit the church for free, but also visit the Monastery. What a wonderfull place, amazing architecture.
Beautiful and worth a visit. Lovely and cool for a warm day!If possible, book tickets in advance as it gets busy.You can buy a multi-ticket with other sites which is good value

A fantastic example of mid-age architecture. Although we spent some time in a queue to get in the building, but it was worth doing that - The place is nice and, for me, it is one of those which you should visit in Lisbon: Nice, fantastically decorated building with a interesting history behind it. Price was 10EUR p/p (April 2015)
Manuelino. Excellent example of Portuguese late gothic style, Manuelino. From the church to the cloister every detail that makes this style so particular of that Portuguese era!

Try a Saturday morning.. You may catch gorgeous singing.I love the refrectory. If you take the tram there watch out for pick pockets. They are elderly and the trolley drivers must take a cut of the winnings because the problem has existed since the beginning of time on that line.

An extraordiary example of Maudeline arch. Spend some time roaming this monastery and enjoy the superb architecture and lovely tiles. Even on a busy day the place is big enough to not feel crowded. Do yourself a favor and if there is a long line to get tickets, go to the other entrance down the way to get tickets, no one knows!

Worth a visit. The church and monastery are so extravagant in style and face the river where it was possible to imagine what impact they had on sailors returning from their explorations during Portugal's golden age of discovery. The church contains tombs of kings, queens and explorers and to walk around brings history to the fore. The cloisters are so peaceful and, in their own way, unique.

Explenderous. If you are visiting Belém, the most important monumental part of Lisbon, you must enter in this monumental church. Inside, visit the tomb of Luís de Camões the King of Portuguese Literature, and enjoy the "Manuelino" style, created by the architectures of King Dom Manuel, the first, inspired on the Renaissance Style and the nautical Portuguese discoveries. Outside, enjoy the beautiful garden os Praça do Império and right in front you can see and visit the monument of the Portuguese discoveries.
Fabulous cloisters. Cloisters were stunning. The cathedral was lovely too. Great place from which to explore Belem and Monument of Discoveries. . Good access with tourist bus

History, Architecture, Crowds. First...the Church is actually free to go to. You can see the tomb of Vasco de Gama for without paying a cent. The real highlight though is the cloister and the courtyard. The beauty of the stonework is absolutely breathtaking. Finding Manueline buildings is tough around Lisbon due to the 1755 earthquake, but it doesn't get much better than the Monastery. It is very crowded with a line, but again, well worth the visit.

Don't let the queue put you off. We were greeted by a long queue and if you only want to see the church and not the cloisters you can bypass it. But we resisted this and were glad we did. The queue moved relatively quickly (certainly by Portuguese standards) and the cloisters are definitely worth queuing for

From here the Portuguese ships have sailing to discover new worlds. This is one ancient convent and church dedicated to the portuguese that sail around the world in ancient times to discover the world. A Must see in Lisbon!

Cathedral of St. Jerome. The tomb of Vaso de Gama - Royal Tombs.. The church and monastery are built in the Manueline Style, described as an excessively exuberant baroque style with maritime themes expressing the Age of Discovery - Portugal's Golden Age. The church and the monastery must be about about 150 yards in length. The Order of Saint Jerome was a military order to protect the explorers The South Portal is the more extravagant than the Axial Western Main entrance. The tombs of two Kings and their Queens are held on the backs of elephants.Brian, from Perth. W. Australia.

Highlight of Belem. Very majestic church, with a high decorated door facade which reminds me of the Sagrada Familia. I visited on a Sunday with free entry. There were two queues, one for visitors and one for those attending the mass, so make sure you get in the right queue. Definitely worth the trip to Belem to see this church!

Hop On, Hop Off Yellow Bus Trip. It was a tall, large monastry where one could walk around the cloisters. My friend walked around it but she said it was pretty much the same thing. You couldn't go inside anywhere except the toilets! If you like studying architecture, which is not my thing really, but it's good for spotting gargoyles and taking pictures.

Get there early to get ahead of the queue.. A great place to see. There is currently an exhibition showing a timeline of the world, Portugal and the monastery's development from the middle ages onwards which was very good.

TRULY MAJECSTIC. It is a must place interested in history. It can be quite busy when tourists from all over visit it. For so many marvels the entrance fee has been kept quite low. There are various discounts available too.

Well-preserved, a must-see .... Beautiful monestary in good condition. You'll feel the atmosphere from the old days. It also shows a travel through time, where the history of the world is compared to the history of the monestary.
Must see. The first time we walked there we just looked it from outside and it's great. Since we had time we also went in and its spectacular. It's a don't miss visit

Great place but long queue!. It is really beautiful and a must seen in Lisbon but try to get there like 20 minutes before it opens or you will face a queue of more than an hour below the sun without a shadow!!!
walking in the Belem area. Nice galleries and central space. The arches in the square demand to be photographed. Here you can also find the famous bleu tiles from Lisboa
splendid architecture. Wonderful architecture - well worth seeing, and the tram journey there & back is interesting. We had pasteis de Belem in the original cafe nearby. A lovely morning altogether.
An iconic site. Plunge yourself in history and visit both the church (free entry) and the monastery (free with the Lisboa card).

Great architecture. This is a must see in Lisbon. Purchase tickets in advance if possible because the line is long. take time to visit the rooms as they give you information about the place and the history around it.

Wonderful and peaceful. In March early in morning for best queues. The cloisters are wonderful with the sun spilling in. Also access the cathedral from the monestery. Do go. The Lisboa card is great value reducing costs for travel and entry.
A fascinating building- well worth a visit. As part of your tour of Belem - this is another must - an old building with a beautiful façade and a delightful church too. Add it to your itinerary.

Impressive. We waited until the queue was almost non existent, about 3 p.m.
The cloisters are well worth seeing.

Beautiful. Every city and country has its own history of how it became about and Mosteiro dos Jeronimos isn't any different. From the outside, it's gorgeous architecture draws you to see it, but the inside is just even better. The place is so majestic and had a gothic, yet comforting feel to it. The feeling you get when you're in a church. However, this place is just so grand, you can't help but awe at its beauty. Definitely worth a stop for you to check out.

Lovely church. Beautiful old church architecture is stunning with the tombs of past royalty and adventures went with a guide which really helped understand the whole thing it's free entry to the church but 10 euros to enter the courtyard in the monastery well worth a look

PEACEFUL CLOISTERS. A beautiful collection of acient buildings , portugese gothic is like no other gothic, the detail is extreme, the central cloister is magnificent and a beautiful cool place on a hot day, even if you are not religious this place will inspire a sence of peace, well worth the visit.

Exquisite!. You could spend days here looking at each individual carved detail on this beautiful monument. We only had one afternoon to spend in Belem but we will go back and spend more time here. It is peaceful, and inspiring!

Could be better. Architecturally it's stunning!But for a 10 euro entry you get to see a courtyard and a chapel - considering how vast the monastery is, you get to see maybe 2% of it. I was simply expecting more.

Beautiful Church, nice area. Well worth a visit on your tour of Lisbon. 2 hours will allow you to take in monastry and beautiful architecture and its also close to river bank which has more great musuem's and monuments with a great view of bridge

Ornate exterior. Close to the river and close to Pasteis de Belem. The church is ornate on the outside. What I found especially interesting was the tomb of Vasco de Gama who first found the sea route to India. Think about doing that in a sailing ship with no maps.

Wonderful architecture. Visiting the Mosteiro takes a little work as it is just outside of Lison (in Belem) but not far. It is worth the visit to head over here. Admission to the church is free while the rest of the Mosteiro will cost money. It is a little pricey.

Breathtaking Monastery with a terrific neighbour. This was just the most stunning monastery that I have ever visited and is an absolute must see. If you can give yourself at least half a day which I highly recommend visit the brilliant maritime museum next door for a couple of hours too.In the monastery are numerous beautiful rooms, amazing cloisters and a simply stunning church/chapel which you can first view from on high and then go down onto floor level. A breathtaking monument well worth a visit. By the way, the tram stops right outside.

Worth a visit. Interesting historically and architecturally, could be very crowded I imagine in season so going early or later a good idea. Close to bus and tram stops and to Paseis de Belem for a good value lunch and fab custart tarts!

Should not be missed out!. I went there before I entered the church, and it was wonderful! It was like a wind with awe blew over you when you entered the square. And you just continued to be amazed over the details in the stones. I highly recommend this, take your time, relax, maybe spend the whole day here and enjoy the view of architectural greatness. To bring something small to eat and drink would probably be good, since there are no places to buy food in there.
A Beautiful Building. This is an interesting place with beautiful cloisters. It's quite expensive but a visit to the lovely Church is free (situated to the right of the queue for the cashier's desk).

A beautiful spot outside the city center. Our family of one adult and 3 children ages 10-13 visited there yesterday. It was a trek to get there and we finally gave up on catching a train from the port and took a taxi for €8. It was worth the fare as you drive by the presidential palace. The cloisters are amazing and there were some nice historical markers for reading. The monastery is fairly small though. We probably spent less than an hour there. Fortunately it is just a short walk from there to the Pastries at Belem where they have world famous cakes.

Fabulous. This church in Belem is one of Portugal's most significant historic buildings; it also includes the tomb of Vasco de Gama. It should be included on aany tourist's visit to Lisbon. Belem is easily accessible from the centre of Lisbon by tram 15 or by train from Cais do Sodre station.
the city's most incredible monument. We couldn't believe what we see. Amazing structure, incredible gardens, one of the most unbelievable fountains. It's a must to see it.
Worth a Trip. A nice way to spend a bit of time outside of the city center. Some nice exhibits, an amazing building and lovely grounds.

lovely piece of History!. Loved walking around here at a leisurely pace and soaking up the atmosphere of what it must have been like for the Monks back in the day. There are lots of Guides if you prefer a group tour. We preferred to walk around on our own armed with a wealth of information that is available at the cashiers desk. One tip, wear a cardigan or jacket, because even though it was warm outside it was very chilly once we entered the monastery.

Really beautiful. The cloister of this monastery is one of the most beautiful cloisters I have ever seen. It has been recently restored and is now very clean, so it's easy to appreciate all its features. The church is also very beautiful, with big stained glasses and other works of art. We went there at around 11 and we only had to wait like 20 minutes to enter, although it was a working day.
Nice but expected more of it.. Nice and beautiful but we expected more of it. And too expensive for the time we were visiting inside it.
Astonishing. Definitely one of those places one must see before dying. Amazing architecture, loaded with history and Portuguese pathos.
Impressive. A masterpiece. A must if you like history, art and/or religion. Unesco World Heritage. Be early (before the crowds arrive).

Number 1 in Lisbon. Out of the top 3 tourist attraction in Lisbon (Torre de Belem, Monastery of Jeronimos and George's Castle).. the monastery is the most interesting. Great architecture, with lots of details.This is a perfect day trip, and a first thing to do in Lisbon. Especially when combined with Tower of Belem and Pastries of Belem. All are in walking distance of each other.

magnificent. This place and grounds are amazing!!! The natural beauty really is fantastic. So effortlessly grand, inside is out of this world. You can visit inside for free -its the right hand side of the paying entrance. The left you pay for the full tour. Had such a lovely time here, will definately be returning

Beautiful cloisters. Because the complex is divided into two Museums (archaeology and maritime), and the Monisterio complex itself, it's a bit difficult to get an impression of the whole layout - but it's an impressive Church and the two story cloisters are stunning.

Beautiful architecture!. Although the mosteiro seems very large, you only get to visit a small part.When you guy your ticket, you can buy a combo of the Mosteiro and the Torre de Belem. When you do, you skip the line at the other attraction. We did the mistake of going to Belem first (which can only take up to 150 people in its tower), so we waited for quite a while at the Tower. Going to the Mosteiro first, we would have skipped the line at the Tower. There are more people that can go into the cloister, so less wait.The entry to the 'tourist' part is in the middle on the site, do not try to enter at the front or back!When you go, you visit the Church (normally free) and the cloister. Both are beautifully decorated. It is so impressive to see the attention to details of the monks that crafted the Mosteiro in manuelline style. It is beautiful and so impressive.1 hour to one hour and a half if you're not an expert in architecture.

Unique architecture. Aside from a few school groups who were touring at the time, we had the place to ourselves. It was very peaceful and quiet, and we were able to enjoy exploring the monastery. The free audio guides had a wealth of information regarding the architecture and history (just make sure everyone has their ID so no one has to share a guide!). There was also a nice timeline exhibit on the history of Lisbon and the monastery.

A must do in Lisbon. I didn't know much about this monastery before I went there. I just knew it was on all the lists of "must do's" in Lisbon. I was blown away when I got there. The architecture is beautiful. The entrance fee is a little steep but if you have a Lisboa card the entry is free. It is right next to the famous pastry shop Pasteis de Belem, Discoveries Monument, and the Belem Tower so you can do a solid 1/2 day in the general vicinity.

Well worth a visit. We liked:It is located on a tram ride out of town.Stunning cloisters, with a level of decoration I had not seen before on such a scale.Walking distance to Belem tower and BCCAdjacent to the famous Belem Pasteis factory/cafe - yum!Warning:Get here early as queues are horrendous at coffee and tea time.

A Must see. This is a must see of Belem (Lisbon). Everyone comes here to see the grand cloister and architecture. The ticket line is always long. A trick, if you also plan to go to Tower of Belem, is that you go to Tower of Belem first and buy the ticket for two sites (the Tower and the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos), so you could save time lining up at the Mosteiro. The line at the tower is usually shorter though I can't guarantee. No matter what it worths the lining up so don't miss it.

Discovery Memories. This is a church, a monestry and a museum, a memory of portugueses sailing discoveries around the world.Very nice environment. Easily a one day tour at the Mosteiro and suroundings, by the river.

Awe-Inspiring. Well worth paying the entry fee to explore this magnificent monastery. There is an excellent exhibit which compares the timelines of the world events, events in Portugal and the monastery timeline (c1500-2010) which is both interesting and educational.For those not looking for a history lesson, the architecture and grandeur of the decoration is still worth seeing.

Worth visiting although dear. The building from the outside is wonderful and inside is really impressive too, especially the cloisters. Cameras at the ready as a lot of great pictures to be taken. The monastery is worth visiting although the admission price at €10 per person is pricey. However the church is free.

Very good, but not sensational.. Well worth the visit, if only to see Vasco de Gamma's tomb. The interior is impressive, but you are only seeing the Church, you do not get to visit the Monastery. Well worth the visit non the less, even if not the most impressive Church or Cathedral you will see !

beautiful but pricey. The monastery is definitely worth a visit, though bare in mind that though it looks huge from the outside you can only visit the cloisters. And it's £10 per adult which is quite expencive compared to other attractions. On the other hand the church is free but if mass is on, you can only visit the back of the church.

Must visit. Packed with photo opportunities, this is one of the main places to visit in portugal. Worth waiting the line to enter and worth being there with guide tomkmow the history behind what you are looking at.

I was expecting more. From the outside, you think you are going to access a lot of rooms in the Monastery. You don't. It was a court yard, small museum with pictures and write ups and a beautiful sanctuary. The architectural work is beautiful. There are very few artifacts or furnishings. It was ok.

Very well preserved. A must see historical building when visiting Lisbon.Entrance to the church is free of charge,and the tombs of Vasco Da Gama and the poet Luis De Camoes are situated here.It is a very good example of a middle ages church.In the cloister area of the monastery,the arches and stonework are very impressive,and the exhibition on the history of of the monastery,Portugal,and world events through the ages is very interesting indeed.The Maritime Museum and the Torre De Belem are close by and also worth visiting.
Wow!. Unfortunately it was closed the day that we were there but the building itself is quite impressive. Lots to do in this area so be prepared to spend some time when you go.
Fabulous place. the monastery has amazing interior yard...with balcony...also the church it is wow...it is a must to see in Lisbon , as it is the only building that survived to earthquake from 1755

Beautiful Arches. Worth seeing when you're in Lisbon, it is a very pretty building with beautiful arches, each one ornately decorated.You can also access a good viewing platform of the church from the Mosteiro (on the left when you go up the stairs to the second level). The church itself is free to enter.There is a good exhibition on the history of Portugal, which is quite lengthy to read, but if you have time it is a great overview on the history of Portugal.Entrance was 10 euro or 12 euro combined with the Torre De Belem. (you can buy the combined ticket at either site - whichever you visit first.) When we arrived around lunch time there was a small queue to get into the church (around 80 people) and around 20 people queued for the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos ticket line. (note there are 3 lines right next to each other, the ticket office is the middle line)Afterwards we walked across the road (use the underpass under the road) to see Padrao dos Descobrimentos. You can easily walk from there to the Torre De Belem. Also right near the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is the Contemporary Art Museum (free entrance) and is worth a stop.There was plenty of parking around - we parked a few minutes walk away on the street and it was free. There was also a paid parking garage just opposite where the buses park. If you turn right just after the bus carpark there is lots of on street parking. There was also lots of parking around the Padrao dos Descobrimentos - which is on the opposite side of the street.If you're not driving take the #15 tram to get here.We also saw lots of people walking along the river to the sites in Belem, so that's another option if you like walking as it is pleasant along the water. But it would be at least 5 kilometres from the center, possibly more.

It´s a must.... Make sure it is open, because they close some days. Late Gothic architecture and it an UNESCO world heritage worth visiting. You will find ladies selling handmade pashminas. Other important monuments, like Torre de Belem are walking distance from the Monastery.
Stunning Area. Monastery is spectacular. Take a walk along the coast to the Torre Belem & Pay a visit to the Custard Tart Shop where they are still warm from the oven.
Loved it !. Great experience for both me and my 15 y daughter.When we first came, there was a awfull long line - so we went to eat lunch, and when we came back - almost no line. Little tip there :)

It was very intricate and delicate but nothing special. It seemed to be the most popular destination by all the tour companies and full of people so it was a constant wave of hundreds of people to take photos of the tombs, artwork and stone carvings. I think the nearby museums are more interesting than the monastery itself. (it is actually not a monastery, it just is a church full of sacred tombs)

As impressive on the inside as on the outside. A sight not to be missed in Lisbon. Ornate sculptures on the outside and beautiful interior. If you have time visit the cloisters- the line to the centre of the entrance, to the right is the church and to the left is the museum. A bit expensive at 10 euros but gives a beautiful view of the church from the second floor.

Amazing. This is a must to go see. The amazing skill of the crftsmen who made this cathedrial , hard to believe it was all done by hand hundreds of years ago . No power tools and no safety gear . Very impressive - a real must see. If you go on Sunday there is no charge, and also a craft fair across the street .
A not particularly interesting cathedral. A pretty large carhedreal with some interesting details, but not particularly impressive. Entrance is free on Sunday mornings.
Awesome. Loved to visit this monastery, the History and information is amazing, really recomend it if you are an arquitecture fan!

Impressive architecture!. You cannot miss this building when you enter Belem. It is truly awe-inspiring on the outside. As we were on a tight time restriction, we opted to wander around the outside and then skip the queues and enter the church. Our primary aim was to see the tomb of Vasco de Gama (and he's buried in the church). Take some time to marvel at the ornate furnishings and wonderful stained glass windows and, of course, the famous tomb.Well worth a visit. We will go into the monastery next time around.

Beautiful Architecture. Beautiful building and great for a wander and some great photographs to be had. You can buy tickets for this combined with some of the other attractions in Belem (we bought our ticket at the Torre de Belem).The chapel is also worth a look.

Pretty big. It is massive,really impressive size. Remember that on your right you have free entrance to church, normally I wouldn't be mad to go into one of these although it is charming inside. Really nice, beautiful church, it is worth the visit even to see that.
Huge building I wish we had time to see it all.. We just went into the Church as there was a long queue to get into the museum etc. will have to come back again

Worth a visit. Classified as UNESCO World Heritage Site, this place near the Tower of Belém is worth a visit. The architecture is impressive and after visiting you can have some Pastéis de Belém just a few blocks away.
Fantastic building. The facade of the building is spectacular and well worth a visit for that alone.We were short of time and only managed a walk round the church.
Well worth the entry fee. Superb place not to be missed when in Belem. Walk the cloisters and go up the stairs to explore. The main cathedral is free if you are on a budget
Reserve a whole day for this. Architectural enthusiast, explorstion history enthusiast, you may catch numerous weddings happening. Great location to spend the whole day
Beautiful XV century monastery. This is an amazing building from the XV century with a very big church. This site is a Unesco World Heritage site. If you have the time go and visit, it is very nice

Wonderful, go to the tower of Belem first.. The whole building is amazing. One of the signs indicated an old library which does not exist anymore. You can buy grouped tickets with the tower of Belem, but it does not seem to be mentionned at this site. If you plan to do both, start with the tower where you can buy the grouped ticket.

history of portugal. built to celebrate Portugal getting to the orient by sea, you can see vasco de gamas tomb and camoes portugals foremost poet who wrote the glories of the globalization of portugal
A yes on your programme. This is not a place to miss. For their 500 celebrations they have a very comprehensive and interesting historical exposition.
Church. Visited this church and enjoyed the details both inside and outside. did not go on the paid tour. Make sure to get pictures from across the street so you can get the full view.
Worth a look..... We had this on our to do list in Lisbon, It was definatly worth a look.... Tram 15E to Belhim makes it more worthwhile...

spectacular................... An historic site not to be missed. The artifacts are in great condition and the whole facade of the building is not be missed.
Truly enjoyable............

Magnificent. The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is an outstanding day trip away from central Lisbon but an easy car drive or bus to the location. The architecture is amazing for the time period and walking through the halls of the great church is breathtaking. To enter the church is free however a small free is charged to walk the grounds and see the museum.

Very nice architechture. The building houses a museum and a chapel. The museum is free all day the first Sunday of the month. The chapel is free all days. The outside of the building was more impressive to me than the inside.
Impressive Location to visit. Superb structure outside and in. Impressive displays on the history of Portugal, the monastery and the world inside
Stunning architecture. Worth paying to go in the cloister as well as the church ( the latter being free. ) Easy to get to by Yellow Bus tour
Beautiful. The cloisters look like something out of a fairytale and worth a visit if you are in the Belem area.
Beautiful cloister. We visited on a Sunday and the cloister was crowded. It was worth the wait to see the cloister. We had only a brief glimpse of the church.

Gorgeous and you can take photographs. This is certainly an impressive building but not dramatically different to other European Gothic cathedrals so if you have seen one you have probably seen what they have to offer here. It is free to visit on a Sunday morning but because of that and the fact that it is a working church the queues can be quite long but overall worth the wait.

One of the landmark in Belem. The building is stunning and with beautiful architecture. Our hop-on-off bus stopped right in front of this building and a short walk from here is the famous Pastéis de Belém. This place can't be missed and it's a must visit. You will need to pay an entrance fee if wish you visit inside.

The architecture is beautiful.. The windows, the statues the whole architecture is brilliant and meaningful. It is quite near to the Torre de Belém, Padrão dos Descobrimentos and the Pastéis de Belém, so this area of worth going as it is filled up by different historical tourists attractions.

must see in lisbon. Impressive building and easy to reach by tram or bus via cais de sodre or belem area. Can be entered for free with the lisbon card and recommend visiting the nearby belem tour at same time. Opening hours change in seasons and it closes early compared to other attractions. Entry closes 1hr before actual closing too so leave enough time. Round the corner is famous egg tart shop , everyone goes so famous place to stop.

Get there early for a quiet experience in the church. I arrived in Belem with plenty of time to wolf down FOUR pasteis de Belem and a large coffee for breakfast. I got to the church before 10. No queues. I enjoyed the church, stopping for a quiet prayer and a reflective moment before the bus loads of tourists descend. Sure enough, by the time I was really to leave, the masses were arriving. I could hear the guides talking from a distance as if they were tone deaf, so off putting. I wish they wouldn't do that. I wasn't bothered with paying an entrance fee to see anymore. I've seen a lot of churches and monasteries in my time. Beautiful building and an opportunity to take some lovely pictures outside.

Beautiful Architecture. Worth The Visit.. Should be on your tourist visit. Stunning and quite impressive. Go early on a weekend as the line can get quite long. Can see this as well as visit Pasteis de Belem, Belem Tower, and the Berardo Museum as its all within the same area.

Even if you are jaded by over the top churches, go!. we arrived too late in the day to get inside (5pm), but just walking around the outside and looking at the intricate carvings is worth the trip. Jaw dropping detail...

AMAZING- a must. probably the most interesting thing in Lisbon and a MUST.. it is in the centre of Belem where you have several interesting things to see and do. A stunning church and you can pay (or get free entry with your Lisbon card0 to go into the cloisters and museum at the back and above- worth it. Alongside and connected in the same building is the archaeology museum- additional cost (free with Lisbon card)- NOT worth it...
super. went on first Sunday of March, free entrance ; go early to avoid long waiting at entrance;best to be combined with church and nautical museum

Beautiful Example of Old Church. Excellent old church and architecture, very atmospheric and breathtaking, worth the short trip from the centre of Lisbon and the famous Pasteis shop is close by, apparently it was the monks from the monastary who were the best bakers.
Just amazing. The architecture is fantastic and the cloisters are a must do! We went on the first Sunday of the month so we didn't have to pay which was a bonus!

Beautiful Old Monastery. It is down in Belem...well worth the visit and the maritime museum is there too....don't pass that up. And you have to go get an egg custard down the block at the pastry shop...the nuns used to starch their habits with the egg whites and used the yolks to make these fabulous, hot out of the oven, custards!

Architectural marvel. This for me is the finest sight in Lisbon, if you like religious buildings. It's worth going to Belem anyway but this really makes it. Despite the queueing it is essential to see the cloisters, which are the finest anywhere, with breathtaking carvings. The church itself and the time-line exhibition are also fantastic.

fantastic !. it is really a place to see! i've visited the Monastery and it was amazing, so beautiful ! the church is also gorgeous ! You can also find, inside, the history of the monument, of Portugal and Lisbon, really interresting ! It's located in Belem, the district that I prefered in Lisbon because you can also admirate the Tower of Belem and eat the "pasteis de Belem" which are delicious ! :)
A fascinating place. A very beautiful and interesting placeThere was a bit of a queue to go in but certainly worth the wait and when inside there was so much to see - wonderful architecture
Wow. If you only visit one place in Lisbon, it has to be the Monastery. The carvings on the walls are so intricate and they all tell a different story.

Attractive exterior..... ... but there's very little of the building which is open. The cloisters are amazing but I'd recommend those at Se Cathedral (€4 as opposed to €10) which are much quieter. Or just go into the church for free as it's really not worth putting up with the enormous queues to get into the cloisters, which form just a tiny part of the otherwise inaccessible monastery.

Beautiful. What a delightfully beautiful place. We went on tram 15 from the centre of Lisbon. It is better to get on at the terminus as it gets busy.The exhibition of ' A place in time' is fascinating and links so many dates in history to the monastery as well as showing the relationship between Portugal and world historical events. I did not think it was made clear that the Portuguese version of the text was on the inner side of the exhibition and saw many local people struggling with the English version.Great example of Manueline architecture.

Skip the cloister if you're pressed for time or money. The church was the best part but the cloister was nice to wander around. The facade outside is free as well as the church so if you're pressed for time or money that's probably enough.

Nice monastery.... If you are going to visit the Tower of Belem you have to pay a visit also to the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos... The church on the rightside before the monastery entrance is beautiful... The monastery itself is really stunning I love the cloister and the sculptures around it... Worth the visit...
well worth a visit. A fantastic piece of.architecture, and in remarkable condition. The time line exhibition is very well done and explained a lot about the history.

Lovely cloisters and church. We were surprised to find a long queue on a winter's day when we arrived. It took around 30 minutes to get tickets to visit the cloisters (cost 10 euro per adult but you can get a combined ticket for Torre de Belem if you have time to visit both in one day). You really need to have a couple of hours to spare if you want to see the exhibitions and wander around the entire Monastery, but we only had time to see the cloisters and church. It's great that you can wander freely around both levels of the cloisters and they really are spectacular. Make sure you check the times of the church services if you want to spend time inside the church and be able to wander around freely - we visited over lunch time on Sunday and there was a service in progress.

Mosteiro dos Jeronimos 2015. It is so amazing, what a wonderful architecture ! our elder was fascinating.. It must be visit and take lessons of art. And after this wonderful place go to please your stomach with the paisteis of Belem !! a day for joy..
Fabulous architecture. You could spend days studying the columns in the cloister (in the ticketed part) and in the nave of the church.
lovely place. beautiful monastery. Tip: buy combination ticket for monastery + Torre de Belem.Loved it, but very busy.

Amazing architecture. Eventhough it is far from town, but definitely it is a "must" place to go in Lisbon.It has amazing architecture from outside, but once you go inside it is even much better.To go there you will need to take tram 15 from Praca do Comercio.I suggest to go early morning because if it is late then there will be long line of queues for this tram and another long queues in monastery as well.Around the monasteries there are a lot of place to eat.It is quite close to sea as well so it is worth to walk along the sea.There you can walk to Padrao dos Descrobimentos or Belem Tower.

Well worth a visit.. There was a big queue when we arrived but only had to wait 20-30 minutes before we got inside. Touts selling scarfs, jewellery and sunglasses didn't persist too much trying to sell us unwanted items.What was annoying was that before we got our tickets from the main office a large group was selected behind us and forwarded to a quicker ticket office that had just opened up.

Impressive. Definitely worth a visit. The ticket includes entry into Belem Tower also. Combine the Mosteiro visit with a coffee and several of the paisteis on sale nearby. These little custard tarts are THE THING to eat in Lisbon. Don't stand in a queue outside, go in and find a table in one of the many rooms and enjoy the experience.
A Architectural Triumph. We went when it opened and there were no lines. It is history, architecture and beauty. It will stay with you so do not skip.
Beautiful!. We took a quick train ride up and I really enjoyed the inside of Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. Lots of beautiful things to see and it was definitely worth the money to get in.
Very Interesting. This is a great place to spend a couple of hours in Lisbon.The architecture here is amazing.The view inside the church is worth the entry fee alone.
Most beautiful building. Its the most beautiful building of Lisbon. It's definitely worth a visit. It cost 10€ or less if you buy a combi card f.e. together with the Belem tower.
Impressive. Without a doubt the most impressive building in Lisbon. Beautiful and impotent. You will loose yourself looking at all the details outside and inside.

where the 1rst boats to india departed. excellent manuelino style monastery, still active as a catholic church, the cloister, if you have the chance of a quiet day, deserves that you see and then close your eyes for some minutes

So overpriced. It's not worth it. The monastery is beautiful but small for the 10€ it costs, it only has a patio. The other rooms have nothing specially interesting. They have a room with some portraits of the monarchy but they are prints, not originals... Please don't throw 10€ away...

Interesting architecture, but not very extensive.. Considering the long lines to get in, we did not feel like there was that much to see in the building. The architecture of the building is very distinctive, but we expected more.
Nice. It's a nice place and not too far from Lisbon centre. It's a bit boring inside, there's nothing to do or see.
Must see. The cathedral is free to see and fantastic. Take time to see all details. The museum is worth the time as well
hidden gems. This area is full of cobbled steep stairway streets, hidden in all the streets are the most amazing restaurants offering typical Portuguese cuisine at very reasonable prices.

worth a visit. A building with stunning architecture both inside and outside. Spacious cloisters and exhibition on history of building. Beautiful church alongside with tomb of Vasco de Gama. If visiting worth checking combination tickets for other attractions in Belem . We came to Belem on train which is free with Lisbon card . Much to far from Lisbon to walk.

Beautiful!!!. When in Lisbon you shouldn't miss this one. A stunning piece of architecture. It's so beautiful that it's breathtaking. The queue system in Lisbon is very confusing. That was the only letdown really - it's badly organised, if organised at all actually! We live in London and so this was very frustrating to us :-) but once we managed to get in we had a great time!

Awe inspiring building. This monastery is an enormous building located in Belem, reachable by tram easily (15, i believe). there are some combo tickets with nearby attractions so you can save up some money. the building itself is truly amazing ..... not only by its size, but also with the architecture itself and especially because of tombs of Vasco da Gama and Fernando Pessoa.Really a must see in Lisbon, along with Torre and the monument to discoveries (pastelaria belem with the best natas is nearby too, go if you have a sweet tooth :) )

Don't miss this! - beautiful cloisters and church. This is the place that most impressed me on a visit to Lisbon. It's a huge monastery complex. The main attraction is the 16th century Cloister, built in a sumptuous late gothic style on two levels. You can explore the whole area including the side rooms (one has a fascinating exhibition on the history of the monastery). The church is equally beautiful, particularly the carved figures round the entrance portal.There's a variety of tickets you can get, combining entrance to the cloister with various other museums. It's worth researching this in advance so you get the right one. It's too far to walk from central Lisbon, but an easy journey on the tram (route 15E).
Impressive cloister. This is a busy monastery/museum but well worth tthe visit . Vasco de Gama is buried in the church which has free entry.
