A unique Late Gothic Manueline architecture style. Magnificent building from where Portuguese discovers had set to sea. In 1983 was classified as an UNESCO World Heritage site.It really worths a visit!
Outstanding. An splendid example of XVII Century architecture which remains awesome more than 400 years after its inception.

Great place to see. Beautiful monastery, breathtaking architecture! You will enjoy seeing it both on the outside and inside. And in case you get tired, you can go to a nearby cafe an have delicious pasteis de belem!

Very beautiful, exceeded expectations. This is a really interesting site, what's good is the contrast between the cathedral and the monastery, two very different atmospheres. I thought the history of the monastery display was good in orientating the site in the wider context of Portugeuse history, of which I know relatively little.
Beautiful place. Next to pasteis de Belem and monumento dos descobridores, if you plain to go to Lisbon, you must go to check it out! And of course eat some pasteis de nata!!!

A disappointment. The building itself is an icon of Portugal. Although I recommend it to any travellers, I was very disappointed by it´s dilapidated state and the lack of internal attractions. The wait on the queue is far much longer than the visit itself, so arrive early. Beware the entrance is free the 1st Monday of each month, so arrive extra early as the queue is longer that day.

Beautiful courtyard. Very interesting design and lots of carving in the stone. Nearby is a bakery that features a tart made from an old recipe recovered from the religious order. Do not miss that treat, hot out of the oven.

Poetry and Passion. Jeronimos is worth a visit. To the left is the museum, very modern but unusual. What struck me was the language used. A relic isn't found in the ocean, it is found in the deep, mysterious depths of the sea. The language itself is risque and passionate (so I'm told) and takes some getting used to. To the right you enter the more architectural Jeronimo with its beautiful balconies, cloisters and other exhibitions. Very peaceful, hugely interesting, quiet and magnificent in its way. We walked all the way there from Lisbon along the sea front, several miles, but a joy all the same if you like walking. The gardens opposite with their fountains are also worth a linger or two.
the world discover symbol. of course everybody who comes Lisbon doesn´t forget JERONIMOS, because if it happened it was like to go Rome and not see Pope

Print out your ticket. There was a huge queue, luckely we had online tickets. However, it took us over 30 minutes to convince the guards to let us in. Problem was that we didn't print out the ticket, but were showing it on a smartphone. Including the original mail and ticket that was sent by their own system. Although the guards stayed friendly, their refusal to let us in was close to ridiculous. Only when I made it very clear that the only two options were either to let us in, or refund our money immediately, they let us in (right to the ticket desk, where someone printed us tickets, that were scanned by another guard, standing literally one meter from the ticket desk. Go figure).As for the visit itself: the actual building (from the outside) is huge. Huuuge. The area you can visit (although extremely beautiful), as about 10% of that. Disappointing.

Beautiful building. Again a very beautiful building in a beautiful area. The sculptures in stone are spectacular. The surrounding area is very interesting with the river, gardens, a museum and restaurants and the famous crusted cream pastries - Pastéis de Belém
Brilliant! A must see. This place is stunning and gorgeous, one of the highlights of our trip to Lisbon. Would recommend seeing if you are in Lisbon.

Do not queue the church is free to visit. We refused to queue and visited the sea archaeology exhibition first we were then able to visit the monestary without queueing. However the church is actually free to get into anyway so do not queue!

The jewel of Lisbon. The monastery is worth every penny of the 10 euro admission. The architecture is drop dead stunning. It's easy to get to on the number 15 tram. It's also close to the lovely river walk and the Pasteis de Belem for pastries and coffee.

Gorgeous monastery in the morning.. We took the 15 Tram from Praca Comercio and it took us 15 minutes to get to the monastery. (Not the first Belem stop but the second). The gothic, Maunline church was breathtaking. The colors from the stain glass windows sparkled all over the carved pillars and vaulted ceiling. The Vasco de Gama tomb was lovely as well as the cloisters. If you like to visit churches in Europe this monastery dies not disappoint. Cross the street to the park and watch the fountain make the monastery sparkle. We walked to the Discovers Monument and Belem monument nearby on the waterfront within 30 minutes round trip. My teen daughters favorite part of a three day trip to Lisbon.
Worth a visit. Not a huge amount of info provided as you travelled around the site but a beautiful building and worth a visit.
A Place with history. Very good place to visit and know something about Portugal history.There are several ways to reach the place, but the one I recomend, is the City tour bus.
Beautiful Architecture. A good building to visit especially it is quite close to the "Monument of Discoveries" and you can access it by a tunner under the road tunnel.
Worth a visit. ..and worth buying your ticket in advance to avoid queueing. Stunning carvings and useful information displays. Shame the kiosk selling audio tours closes 12-2.

Amazing architecture but can do without going inside.... This place was a nice place to visit. It had the tall gothic feel. The inside was just a courtyard for photos. Not sure if it was worth the 10 euros. Can spend only about 30-1hr there without getting bored. Nonetheless, nice place to visit.

Stunning stone work and interesting exhibition. Well worth the visit (thought €10 is a little expensive for what you get). Can be done fully within 1 hour. Very impressive stonework, the chapel is very good (and free)
Jeronimos Monastery. Amazing building, definitely one of the top sites in Lisbon. Not to be missed. Not that there is any shortage of beautiful churches and palaces!
EX LIBRIS. A must if you visiting Lisbon. The surroundings are beautiful and the small restaurants and cafés serve the yummiest delicatessens

History!. Our tour group visited this famous monastery and we had a chance to appreciate it's architecture and historic significance. The architecture alone was worth the visit and seeing the tomb of Vasco da Gama (complete with sailing ships) was a huge extra bonus. It is one of a number of Lisbon sites which remind you of the importance of this seafaring nation in the history of exploration (and, of course, exploitation...but then they often go together, don't they?).
huge. it is an enormous monastery,nice gardens,beatiful chiostro(just this has free entrance)Belem area is great.
Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. A great place to visit. It is just a tram or bus ride from the city centre and it has so much to offer.

Small, noisy. We first looked at the church, which was nice. After seeing it, we hoped for a lot when buying a ticket for the monastery (10€ adults/5€students). We found it pretty, but very small. Also, there was a show of some sort going on for high school kids, which took place in the middle of the monastery. The shouting and echoing pretty much destroyed it for us.
Go in the church. Go on a Sunday, with a service you are welcomes to- with lovely singing and candles, then visit the monastery, where the architecture is awesome

Visiting Lisbon.. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos.This Convent is located almost on the riverbank of the river “Tejo”, the building of the convent who is being erected completely in the “Manueliner Style” started in the year 1501.You can see the Convent, the internal garden and the Church, the Church is admission free, but you have to pay for the visit of the convent.In the church you have the thumb of the famous Explorer by the name of “Vasco Da Gamma”, and the thumbs of “Manuel I, his wife Dona Maria, João III and Catarina” all of this thumbs are carried by elephants.It is a place who is every time well visited, you can complete your visit with a visit of the following objects who are only at about 10 minutes walking from the Convent by passing the small underground tunnel who is the nearest and best connection to this points, the “Belem Tower”, the “Pedrão dos Descobrimentos” and the “Museum dos Combatentes”.

beautiful and important historically. Loved the gothic cathedral and the chance to explore the inside of the monastery. Lots of interesting information in the audio guide which was free! Absolutely you need to see this!

Absolutely Brilliant... Classic Architecture. Monastery is beautiful, architecture was brilliant. Enjoyed totally.Remember to:1. Arrive early, I believe it opens at 10am in Sunday. By half 10, there were hundreds in the queue.2. Buy LisboaCard, it is free and best part is you can skip the queue.

Quite good in combination with Torre de Bélem. You get there best by bus or metro. The stop is called like the sight. It is worth going ibside the free church with the comb of Vasco Da Gama. Great ceiling and various architectual styles brought together to give the church a special flair.

Jan 2015 - Uklele exibition. This is like a normal monastery with a lot of exhibitions all round the year. We got to the Ukelele one. Good for pics or if you visit the Church, we were here on Sunday, so it had a huge que, which didnt want to wait for.

beautiful building and grounds. Of course the church an monastery are well worth the trip out of the center of the city, but it is the grounds and the adjoining neighborhood that make the visit complete. Some of the best pastries you'll find in Lisbon are just a few blocks back toward the city center. It's a 3 mile ride out and if you have lots of time and energy... it makes a great walk back.
Worth going when in Belem. We went the first Sunday of February so the entrance fee was waived. The outside is much nicer than it was inside but it's worth a visit.
Stunning building. Beautiful building, architectural delight. Cloister is stunning. Church next door also shouldn't be missed and it is free.
Worth a visit.. Get a ticket with the Belem tower included. This monastery is nice. Peaceful. Lots of it and easily accessible.Down side is the queues and the price. A little dear came in.

Stunning building. One of the most beautiful buildings I have ever seen. The queues to get inside are very large at times so arrive early.But it is a must see when in Lisbon, it's just so interesting.Easily accessibly as the tram stop is bang outside it in Belem
Fine architecture. This is definitely one of the architectural highlights of Lisbon and for those who are into art and architecture, this should be high on your list of stops.

Very impressive building. Ah yes, one of everything. This is the Manueline style of architecture. The builder wanted one of everything Vasco de Gamba and his crew described to him upon their return from their explorations. It's fascinating to go through this complex and see the palm trees, elephants, columns all interwoven into quite a spectacular building. Definitely worth a visit.

Absolutely huge. there are a lot of churches in Lisbon but this is the star attraction. It is absolutely huge in a unique Gothic style. Located in Belem district about 10 minutes by tram from the city centre. entry to the church is free and there are 2 other museums that incur a fee. even if you just spend 10 minutes at Jeronimos you can't fail to be impressed by the scale alone
Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. Beautiful church, beautiful neighbourhood and obviously close to amazing pasteis de Belém! Loved it.

cant miss. took the tram out here, get here early, usr your Lisbon card so you can bypass the line, sign the card 1st. can combine a visit here w/ the carriage museum and monument to the explorers and the Belem pastry shop, all easily walkable, allow a 1/2 day for all the above mentioned sites. Loved the architecture,you should research it and bring some info before you go ...Rick Steves, perhaps as we didn't have a tour here, we wandered on our own

Interesting Building. The building is well worth a visit to see the detailed architecture but the exhibits within the monastery were not great. I thought there should have been more signage to explain some of the rooms and features. There was a good display on some of the most significant events in European history but it wasn't linked to the actual building in any way. We bought a combined ticket at the entrance for the monastery, archeology museum and belham Tower, this saved us a lot of queuing. The church is free to enter.

Interesting...enough. The monastery is easily accessed in Belem, Lisbon. It is attached to a church which is worth a look. The monastery itself had beautiful architecture and it was enjoyable to wander around the cloisters. I say it is an average review as there is little information provided as to the background - there are a couple of rooms with extensive information but none which is succinct and easy to get a handle of in a short space of time - because of this I left feeling that I didn't really know the history.

ONE OF THE MOST INCONIC PLACES IN LISBON....A MUST SEE. Located at the beautiful area of BELEM - more worldly known by the pastry: "Pasteis de Belém" :) - surrounded by lovely gardens, this monastery It´s a UNESCO World Heritage Site, originally ordered to be built by the Portuguese King Manuel I (over a Church, the Ermitage of Restelo) at the early beginnings of 16th century at the Harbour of the beach of Restelo (still a beach,by that time..), it took 100 years to finish. The style used was, later on, called "Manuelino" (on behalf of the King Manuel), using "sea style patterns" (specially ropes), linked to the peak of Portuguese History concerned to the "Descobrimentos" (name given to the "Discoveries" of new lands, not known by mankind, at these days. Well...just pay for a guided tour :)) Watch the website, since is common to happen free events like beautiful religious choirs, that echoes on the stone walls, simply amazing...This is a must !!! DON MISS IT !! (If possible, reserve a whole day for this area and visit this Monastery, the National Coach Museum (astonishing !!...www.museudoscoches.pt ), the Centro Cultural de Belém - for those who enjoy Modern Art - , the Eletricity Museum, and eat in one of the numerous Restaurants, try a (you will..but several..) worldwide famous "Pastel de Belém" and rest on the surrounding free gardens)

Jeronimos Monestery. It was just okay. I generally don't enjoy self-guided tours and like more information. There was a room with a whole presentation in English and Portugese that traced the history of the monastery as well as world history that was somewhat interesting but overall I was disappointed and would have preferred either a human guide or at least some a recorded headphone tour to listen to.

Stunning, free to enter, tram 15. You take the so called supertram number 15 from the stop in Praca da Figuiera in central Lisbon (it only goes one way from here so get on at the stop on the south side of the square) and get off right outside the monastery in Belem. Its a stunning sight, every inch inside and out is decorated in carved reliefs and the main part of the church is free to enter or you can pay to go round other parts or the two museums. Eat lunch in park opposite and then go under the road to the waterfront and the Edward the Navigator monument

Beautiful. You can't miss this beautiful monastery, as it's the central attraction in Belem. Its beauty from the outside is almost as good as the architectural details inside. The columns have intricate carvings that extend all the way up to the ceiling. Simply magnificent. If you go towards the water, there is a park that has fountains that come to life a few times an hour, it's really neat to watch the water with the monastery in the background. It also makes for some interesting photos.

Beautiful. You can't miss this beautiful monastery, as it's the central attraction in Belem. Its beauty from the outside is almost as good as the architectural details inside. The columns have intricate carvings that extend all the way up to the ceiling. Simply magnificent. If you go towards the water, there is a park that has fountains that come to life a few times an hour, it's really neat to watch the water with the monastery in the background. It also makes for some interesting photos.
Must see. It deserves a restoration but the place is huge and full of history. The chapel inside is also beautiful.
Amazing. One of the best monastery I've seen in my life. When you arrive there the size and the brightness of the building is very impressive. Very nice both the church and the courtyard.
Amazing. Amazing decorative architecture in church and cloister. We didn't visit the museums. get the bus 728 or tram 15 from centre. NB Closed on Monday
Great historic landmark. This is a great place to learn more about Portuguese history. The building is very beautiful and is located in a really nice area.

Very interesting - just not enough of it!. The cloisters and church are magnificent and very impressive. There are a couple of excellent exhibitions based on the history of Portugal and it's conquests in a worldwide context, and it's explorers. My disappointment, on completing the tour of the cloisters, was to find that there was nothing more, not even a cafe for a cup of coffee. However, our 12 Euro ticket also allowed us a visit to the Tower of Belem, which helped to make up for it!

Great architecture. It is an outstanding UNESCO site and you will certainly appreciate the architecture, but there is something missing! There is however an exhibition showing the history of the monastery, Portugal and the world - the way it is done is just a horrible example of how not to present information.

LIsbon's attractions. Lisbon is a contrast to southern Spain, more diverse, though they share similar histories. In the west of Lisbon (Belem area) are many important sites (we don't take the paid tours): Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, an UNESCO World Heritage site, is a monastery reflecting Portugal's exploration of the world and housing the tomb of Vasco da Gama who made it to India unlike Columbus. This is the best example of Manueline style of architecture; a sea related maritime elements or moldings resembling corals, carvings covered with sea weeds and algae, elements in ships as anchors, stone ropes and cables and instruments used for navigation. Another example of Manueline architecture along the Tejo River is Torre de Belem where da Gama embarked on his voyage to India in 1497 and where Columbus was forced ashore in a storm on his way back from his discovery of the Americas in 1493. Nearby along the river is the much photographed Monument to the Discoveries built in 1960, a 17ft tall stone carved as a ship's prow with explorers climbing to the top. It commemorates the starting point of many voyages of the explorers. You will find many good restaurants along the West waterfront within view of a red suspension bridge reminding many of the "Golden Gate Bridge."  In the east of Lisbon near the waterfront is a real gem, the Museu Nacional do Azulejo, the ceramic tile (azulejo) museum, located in a beautiful 16th century convent with a collection of 7000 tiles. Though the art of making tiles is a Moorish inheritance, Islamic art forms did not use figurative motifs, only depicted plants or abstract designs, rarely animals. There is a 75ft. panel of blue tiles, removed from a palace, depicting Lisbon's waterfront.in about 1740 before the great earthquake of 1755, destroying much of the city center.  Our hotel was in the north of the city and within walking distance of a museum we really enjoyed, the Museu Calouste Gulbenkian and one of the top ten attractions advertised. They were right. It is a small private collection of oil millionaire Armenian by the same name, but filled with choice quality of artifacts and antiques spanning 4000 years of art history, including a large Lalique collection. We don't often spend as much time in museums but we did enjoy these. The city's centerpiece is Castelo de Sao Jorge, considered the founding settlement in the 6th century BC from archeological finds! Being very old not much to see, except wonderful views of the city and on a hot day a respite under the shady trees (may want a taxi to get there). Lisbon is on 2 hills and with cobbled (flatter stones than rounded) streets. It is not an easy city to walk but the trolleys, some old wooden ones, and the old designer elevators (oldest built in 1884) help you navigate the hills. The subway (Metro) is very good and safe. We didn't worry whether we were in one or more of the city's divisions: Bairro Alto, Chiado, Baixa, or Alfama. Unless you want to spend time shopping or night-clubing.  The Portuguese are more laid back, calmer less dramatic than the Spanish. Their music, "Fado," is a melancholy pining for lost seafarers or their loved ones. Even a museum for this music. The food to us seemed more varied than the Spanish. They share "Bacalhau" dishes but the sardines of Portugal are superb not to mention the wines. You can eat hundreds of the tiny clams in garlic oil at one sitting. Have you heard of Nando's restaurant chain in US and UK that serves a piri-piri (a very hot African chlli) chicken? Portuguese southern cities can rival any southern Spanish city so don't be shy about venturing to Europe's farthest west country that is reasonably priced. Read Frances Mayes' (Under the Tuscan Sun author) account of her visit to Lisbon in her book, A Year in the World:Journeys of a Passionate Traveler, to get a wonderful feel for Lisbon and her recommendations.
Sight seeing Lisbon. We took the Yellow bus for 48 hours. Visited this monastery and all city routes, at ease. Good audio tour of the city and atractions as we passed by.
Definitely worth the queue. Spectacular archtecture, especially the courtyard and the cloisters. Take the tram and come early. Combine withe Torre de Belem and watching the naval entrance to Lisbon.
A must and must have a guide. Full of history and important architecture. You need an expert of illuminate your visit, unless you are a historian/art historian or the like.

Worth a Visit if you are in Belem. When we visited the monastery we only stopped into the cathedral, which had no charge. We also had no interest in the paid tour. However, a visit to the cathedral is worth it to see the tombs of many famous Portuguese figures. This includes the tomb of Vasco da Gama.The Maritime Museum is also housed in part of the monastery buildings. That is well worth the 6 euro entrance fee.
Overpriced. Beautiful building, but not much to see. Never worth 10 euros. Lots of written historical dates on boards, but far too much detail.

closed on Mondays. cannot give this a good review due to the fact that it does not open on Mondays. Apparently this is the case for many public ameneties. museums etc. Maybe if we were able to have gone inside the review might have been favourable

Wonderful - definitely worth a visit!. This is a stunning site - definitely worth setting some time aside for a visit. The monastery is spectacular, and we paid to go inside which was very worthwhile. There is a lovely park situated in front which was lovely with the backdrop of the monastery. Very impressive.

Must see when in Lisbon. When in Lisbon, It is well worth getting the tram out to Belém to see this amazing UNESCO world heritage site. While there, you can also visit the Torre de Belém, Padrão dos Descobrimentos (Discovery monument), Maritime Museum, and Cultural Centre and have a pastel de nata (custard tart) at the famous Pastéis de Belém. Entry to the church is free but it is worth paying to visit the cloisters. This building is an example of the ornate Manueline style of architecture, with beautiful vaulting and carved pillars. It was built in fulfilment of a vow regarding the safe return of Vasca do Gama from India and the explorer, together with Portugal's epic poet Camoes, is buried in the church. I agree with the previous reviewer who recommended the Lisboa Card, which offers free travel on trams, buses on metro and free or reduced entry to many museums and monuments.
Beautifull!. Beautifull site! worth going even if you dont get to go inside. Across from "Los descubridores monument" and close to Belem tower.

Amazing place. This place commands a visit as soon as you see it. My wife and I visited this place and we managed to sneak in right around 4:45pm right before the 5pm closing time and we were not disappointed. It is such a beautiful chapel to begin with and it is such a gorgeous chapel to just sit and enjoy it. Once done, check out the cloisters and you will not be sorry. It is amazing that such a world treasure is still standing and I can see why this place is considered a UNESCO world heritage site. Amazing. I will come back.On a side note, visitors to Lisbon I recommend getting the Lisboa card either from the airport upon arrival or within certain spots in the city. My wife and I got the card which offers either free entry or reduced entry at many museums, sites etc. within 24 hours of being in Lisbon, my wife and I had already made back our 63 euros we paid for the two day pass that very day. Included with the card is:Free entry to all trams, metro, buses, suburban rail etcFree entry to this very monastery in this reviewFree entry to Belem towerIn closing, with one full day left with our passes we have already saved 65 dollars so it has been worth every penny. Get it!!
Stunning place. Get the train out to Belem to visit this stunning church and monastery...the church is free but it is well worth paying the 10e charge to see the monastery...exquisite!

Full of history. We didnt go inside because was late and we didnt want to come back other day, but even if you dont have enough time, be sure that a trip to the mosteiro is a must. The building is wonderful! Huge! beautiful!Next time in Lisbon I will definately pay to go inside.

Beautiful Church. Definitely make this a stop if you're travelling through Lisbon. If can be very quick if need be and is the worth the stop. Entry is free to walk through and see the old church and enclaves in the back with the tomb of Vasco de Gama and a beautiful alcove done in gold. Public was not able to explore the actual monastery portion of the building. Not sure if it's under renovation or if this is typical.

fantastic architecture. What an incredible piece of history and well preserved architecture. One should visit this while in Lisbon. Plan on a full half day here as there is an incredible amount of detail to admire. Just beautiful.
Wonderful church and cloister. Fantastic church and beautiful cloisters. You need a couple of hours to appreciate all the carvings everywhere. A true monument to the glory days of Portugal!

BELEM BEAUTY. The biggest site in Belem is the Monastery, but sadly much of it is now reused for other purposes and is not accessible to the public.We did manage to get into a church section which was worth a visit, but it is a pity that as an attraction it promises more than it delivers.Not much else around Belem, except the tower in the water's edge and the Columbus monument. It is good walking on the banks of the river and the park facing the Monastery has active fountains.

Exquisite. We visited the church which was breathtaking. Although free entry I would gladly have paid a few euros. We then went into the monastery and that was an equally stunning experience not to be missed. It is difficult to describe the artistry and splendour. We skipped the museum as it was not of interest.

One of the must visit places in Lisbon. The monastery is teh ex-libris of Portuguese Late Gothic Manueline style of architecture in Lisbon. The beautiful church houses the graves of famous Navigator Vasco da Gama and Portugal´s "greatest" poet Luis de Camões, among others. The main visitors entrance and wings house the Maritime Museum and the National Archaeology Museum which are worth a visit.Nice spot to take photos the surronding area is very beautifull and interesting. After the visit take a stroll to the famous "Pasteis de Belem" and try this delicious pastry. Jeronimos is simply a must visit spot in Lisbon.

Beautiful.. We went to Belem for the day with the purpose of visiting this monastry. It really has to been seen to believed. The building is absolutely stunning, sun shinning through the centre court yard just made it magical. You can have a tour guide, or just wonder around at your own pace. The chapel is free entry but to go into the grounds is 10 euro, but it really is worth the money.

It has to be seen. The place is very very nice even if the load of turists may be a little to much. I suggest to read the description of Saramago before going ther. It is very helpful in understanding the breath of this wonderful place.

500 year old architecture at its best. The entry to the church is free, if you want to have a look at the upper choir and cloisters you have to buy a ticket. They had interesting temporary exhibitions on the upper floor, but not very much about the cloister except for the richly ornamented stones.

State of art architecture. I did not go inside the monastory, but I saw it from the outside and it was a fine piece of art for me! Amazing design! Worth a watch. It is next to the Monument of discoverers and the Belem Tower!
MUST SEE!. one of the best attractions in portugal hands down. so beautiful. it helps it's right next door to the famous pastries de belem shop!

Good start after a red eye. Despite having told our hotel we'd be arriving about 9am, there were no rooms ready after our overnight, so my wife and I decided to take in some of the cultural ambiance of Lisbon before our siesta. I highly reccomend skipping the line for the tram from the center of the city and spending the few euros on the taxi; instead of waiting in a massive line, you're there in 10 min and it costs you less than $10. Live a little. The monastery is, well, a monastery. It is beautiful and the hisotry of it quite neat, but you don't need more than an hour or two to take it in. The interior garden is pleasant to relax in as well. All told, it was a good choice to kill some time and start out vacation. Don't worry too much about the long line, it does move quickly, we were inside within 30 minutes and there was a massive line almost to the end of the monastery when we got there.

you shouldn't miss this!. It's a lesson about portuguese diaspora and discoveries. We spend there more then two hours, folowing a group with a guide that explains every detail in a bilingual service. Don't miss this expirience.

Good overview of history. The visit is like going back in time. With some imagination one can understand the fascination the 15th century explores with the sea and their desire to know what Iwan at the end of the sea

Quick visit. The Mosteiro is not very big so it won't take that much time. But it is worth a quick visit in (and you can use the facilities if you are spending the day wandering the area). The outdoor court has some headstones and interesting things that have been protected and preserved -- the inside part is a bit small but like I said, it's worth a quick stop in to see the remnants of the Mosteiro.

Great photos. The guy on the desk tried to charge me twice, and then charged me for the tower as well. Little did I know that the tower is a 15 minute walk away. No pamphlets and very little information given. One plus is the display which gives a brief history of the world, portugal and the monestary.
Very nice grounds in Belem waterfront.. Went to visit the Monastery, but could not find the entrance to the public. Dissapointed. Walked the beautiful grounds and admired the water fountain.
Beautiful. The architecture is beautiful and haunting both inside and out. Also just by the tram stop from Lisbon, so easily accessible and not far from several places for lunch.

Best Architecture in Lisbon. Located in the Belem District, Jeronimos represented an impeccable architectural design. However, due to long queues and lack of pre - booked tickets, my group didn't go inside. However the outside is very beautiful to just admire and capture unique pictures. Located close to the Pastel de Belem shop, access to the sweet Portuguese delight was easy. Close by was the Maritime Museum and Planeterium.
nice place. The museum its free Sunday morning, on the left side at the entry there is the museum of archaeology very nice to watch and free too on Sundays

very beautiful. One of the most beautiful things to do When you're in Lisbon.With or without LisbonCard, you have to wait a very long time to get your ticket . The organisation is not so good or is this typical for Portugal? It was our first time in this country..

Amazing monument. Although there where huge lineups to get into the monument, it was well worth it.The cloister was amazing with all the details. Each arch has a different motive and with Lisbon´s the nice winter sun it truly “blossomed”. One thing that I learned later is that nearby you have the Archaeological Museum, and there you can buy a “ticket pack” to enter this museum and the Geronimo Monastery. Besides this, the good thing is that you have nearly no lineup and the ticket pack is cheaper…
A must to see. This place is magnificent, not just only for the architecture but for its history and surroundings too. Not to miss.

Definitive guide to Portuguese sense of beauty. It's a must-see for everyone who would like to understand how Portuguese percieve beauty and art. It is amazing Manueline monument but also a witness to Portuguese history from 12th to 20th century.

A Portuguese landmark!. This is a direct and beautiful contact with Portuguese history at its best!
Well preserved and amazing history behind it.
Worth a Visit. The sculpture work at this Church is remarkable. The reverence for Portugal's prodigal explorer is made abundantly clear.

Go To the Maritime museum.. Way To crowded !! Decided to go the Maritime museum. Not crowded at all. Very interesting !
But IF you wanna see the monastry which is nice GO EARLY. 10 o'clock in the morning. Otherwise you'll end up in a looong line !

Just stunning!. The Church and Chapel tour is free of charge. You have to pay 10€ to enter the inner courtyard and the exhibition area in it. There's allso a entry fee of 1€ to enter the inner part of the chapel to see all the paintings which was imo well worth it.Wonderful example of the fifteenth century architecture and art.Dont miss it.

Must see in Lisbon!. Instead of waiting in line for a pastry from Belem, use your time to visit this beautiful architectural site. Don't just go into the chapel, spend a few euros and take the tour of the entire Monastery. It's a wonderful example of Manueline architecture. If you aren't impressed by how ornate this site is, especially considering it was constructed nearly 900 years ago, then go back to the pastry line! We found it to be well worth the admission price, and enjoyed walking around the site for at least two hours. It was interesting to see how the monks lived and worshipped on a daily basis. One of my favorite sites in Lisbon, which is indeed full of things to see!
Wonderful piece of architecture. The whole spot is wonderful. And the architecture is breathtaking. Wonderful example of the fifteenth century architecture, a place not to miss!

Stunning. you enter the church first and uncle's a more limited decoration,, it is very impressive.The convent is a gem, every corner you see is of beautiful decoration and details. The cloister is lovely.

Stunning. the church at the entrance is already impressive, though fairly simple in its decoration.The convent is a pearl, every corner has beautiful details in the Manuel style, the cloister is lovely.

Beautiful Monument. We visit these monument when we were at Belem area.It is a big monument, with a unique kind of arquitecture and it is beautiful.We don´t like the Gypsies, always behind us in this area, and ask us money to buy something.

Not worth €10. I'm not sure if you can get enough for the €10 admission, which allows you to enter the court yard and only a small part of the monastery. Don't pay that amount but get into the chapel which is free of charge. Beautiful architecture but overrated. They tried to charge us double because they don't have a handset to scan the barcode of the prepaid ticket on my mobile phone.

How to avoid the queues. Get a Lisbon card We prepaid on internet you get into the monastery Torre Belem and museum for free and do not have to queue. Church and monastery stunning Queues horrendous. Take train rather than tram free with Lisbon card much less hassle
Historical. Lovely place, I always wanted to visit and I did it this time. Took some lovely photos and really like the architecture and the whole ambience.

Go visit Mosteiro lisbon. Fantastic, well worth the queue.We bought a general ticket for 10 euro each, well worth it.Brilliant architect/building, the cloisters/grounds inside where buitifull.The history section very interesting. a must when you visit Lisbon.

Impressive architecture. The architecture is impressive, very ornate and tranquil, definitely worth a visit. It is easy to get to by bus from the center of Lisbon and it is helpful to have the Lisbon card which included not only the bus ride, but also the entrance fee. A must see when in Lisbon.

Great historical site.. This is a true amazing site from the 15th century Lisbon. Visit also the convent, not just church where everybody goes. Also, if you have an interest in it, the Arqueological Museum is nearby.
expensive. expensive just to see courtyard, would like to have seen more of the inside of the building, close to other belem sights

Mosteiro dos Jeronimos + Torre de Belém. Magnificent architecture, lots of signs to explain the history of thr monuments. The only issue that I went on Monday at it was closed. Couldn't go other day. Still, it was great.

Richly decorated gothic church and monastery. Visit not only the church, but also the monastery, it is really worth. The opulent Manuelinic style has it's origin in the french Gothic style, but is far more opulent.
Look just outside. you don't have to go inside. We waited for one hour and it's not worth it. There's nothing to see inside.

Absolutely exquisite.. The monastery is attached to the Archeological Museum and the Maritime Museum and hands' down is the best if the three. You can get a combined ticket to the archeological museum and the monastery for 12 euros. It is so peaceful. There is no road noise. One of my (adult) children said she can see why people went for the religious life after spending time here. Highly, highly recommended.

Stunning! Maybe overpriced?. Moasterio dos Jeronimos is simply beautiful! The architectural style is unlike any other I've seen and the monastery is often reffered to as an example of portuguese 'late gothic Manueline style'. The church of the monastery was perhaps my favorite part of this attraction; it is huge on the inside and absolutely stunning despite the contrast it makes with the exterior facade! The stained glass decorating the church is also very beautiful. It is one of those places that makes you feel so small. Entering the church is completely free.The monastery itself is gorgeous as well, particularly when the sun is starting to set. The inside is quite beautiful as well although the areas you have acces to are actually few and thus, the ticket to the interior might seem a bit overpriced. If you are on a lower budget, going inside the monastery itself might not be worth the expense as the outside facade gives you a great idea of what's inside.Despite this, I would pay again to visit the interior because of the intricate details this style of architecture holds.

4-in-1 hit Monastery,lovelyChurch,Archaeology+Maritime Museum. Where - Belem, tram #15, get on at Praça do Comércio (Commercial Plaza) or Praca do Figuera Plaza (Figuera Plaza). It's 40-50 minute ride depending on traffic and get off at Jeronimo Monastery stopWhat- good for single hit, jam-packed visit to a Unesco site plus two museums. Fees can add up but all museums FREE on Sundays to 2pm; and cheap if you buy Lisboa card (multi-use museum, transport usage and discount) or combo tix. In one cluster - the lovely Church of Santa Maria (free), right next to imposing Jeronimo's Monastery (10 euro); and shares entryway to National Archaeology Museum. It's only 5 minute walk to entryway of Maritime Museum (5 euro) on same side of street, further west. First, the church - The Santa Maria is a single-vaulted church with lovely proportioned, slender 25m-tall pillars and gorgeous ribbed ceiling (hurt my neck from looking up an hour!) that from the far end from the chapel, it's one of the prettiest, soaring, airiest I've seen even compared to Roman churches. It's also cool that, in the lower choir, sits stone tomb of explorer/navigator Vasco da Gama (1468–1523) with his actual remains. Right beside church is entrance to Monastery (fees for this alone it seems pricey at Adults: €7Children: €3.50) - it's an imposing but empty structure. If not interested in architecture might take just 10 minutes to look around the 2-story square cloister, decoratively carved out of limestone and glowing pale yellow in the sun with rows of decorated arches, centered around a plain courtyard with a nondescript fountain. I guess monks were there to contemplate, not glorify. The cloister hallways are lovely with lovely ribbed and vaulted ceilings above, and the decorated open archways to one side. Wish they had hooded figures wandering round- too cheesy? - but what I mean is there should've been exhibit and some interactive display of who, how, what of the monk's lives cos there was NOTHING.The Maritime Museum was large, comprehensive and really interesting with detailed miniatures of shipping and naval vessels from the country's heyday as a seafaring superpower to WWII submarines, intricate sailor's knots, magnificent (if erroneous) globes from the 16th century, armor and dress through the centuries. There's a decent coffeeshop between the twin buildings housing the museum, with usual pastries, snacks if your kids get hungry or for your shot of coffee.Tip - Avoid public tram on rush hours as locals use for getting to and from school/work. It's narrow with few seats. Watch out for pickpockets! Museums very crowded Sundays as free.Tip 2- Lots of decent priced hop-on-off tour options if you dont want to tangle with local crush.(e.g. http://www.viator.com/tours/Lisbon/Lisbon-Hop-On-Hop-Off-Tour-48-hour-Ticket/d538-5391LISBEST3)Details - Please double check opening times. Note - there are discounts on multi-museum visits, in addition to option of discounts on the useful Lisboa card.Archaeological Museum, Praça do ImpérioAdults: €5, Children: €2.50Open - 10am-6pm Tuesday-Sunday (closed Monday)Jerónimos Monastery, Praça do ImpérioOpen - May 1-September 30 -10am-6pm Tuesday-Sunday (closed Monday); October 1-April 3010am-5pm Tuesday-Sunday (closed Monday)Adults: €7, Children: €3.50Maritime Museum, Praça do ImpérioAdults: €5 Children: €2.50Open - May 1-September 30 -10am-6pm Tuesday-Sunday (closed Monday); October 1-April 3010am-5pm Tuesday-Sunday (closed Monday)

Mosteirodos Jeronimos. Beautiful monastery-cathedral. The scale and proportions of the architecture is humbling. The skill and fortitude of hand labour required to build all these monuments in Europe is inspiring.
Not to be missed. The visit is too short, we can only see part of the building and the price is expensive for such experience
Great!!!. Definitely worth a visit because is so beautiful and huge!I enjoy my visit to belem.its easy to go there.Dont miss the opportunity:)
Our Visit. Great architecture and not busy in December. Entry covered by Lisboa card which is good as long as you get on and use it.
Jeronimus Monastery - Fantastic. Unique monument, simbolises the high period of portuguese discoveries. At sundays the queues are very big due to the messe.

Best site to see in Lisbon. The highlight of Lisbon for me. Beautiful monastery with much to see, and a much needed respite from the sun. By virtue of the fact this is the only review of an attraction I have written about in Lisbon should hopefully tell you everything you need to know. Beats hands down virtually every other attraction – go see.

Very very beautiful. It deserves the visit, the queue and each cent payed.extraordinary architectural work. Fernando Pessoa is buried there. Close to. The entrance there is the store with the most famous "pasteis de nata" in Lisbon. Delicious, really the best in the city (I've tried a lot).

Beautiful, but smaller than I imagined. This place is incredible and it might be the #1 attraction in Lisbon, actually Belem, but it is fairly small. It was built sparing no expense and is so well preserved it looks like it is 30-40 years old. The church is the most amazing part, and it is free, but spend the 10 euros to see the monastery as it is so peaceful I highly recommend it.
Not to be missed. Amazing. A stop on the hop on hop off bus. A must on your list of places to visit. There is a rearly good exhibition giving the time line of Lisbon

beautiful monumnet. nice display of early 16th century Gothic architecture. need to climb stairs to go first floor which was little difficult with our young children. However; it's worth vising Lisbon's most prominent site.

Took my breath away. An impressive building from the outside especially as attached to the museums. Spent a while watching the rainbow playing on the fountain and the gulls playing in it!. Once inside it was breathtaking especially the stone carving and vaulted ceilings.

This place is huge!. Pardon me for my lack of knowledge on history, but in my personal opinion this place is very beautiful. If you're into photography, the architecture is very nice and all the intricate carvings is very detailed. Beware of groups of people as they will approach random tourists for picture, and they can be quite persistent to take a picture with you (especially if you're Asian). Anyway, don't miss it!

Vell preserved Monastery and very close to all the Belem attractions. Well Preserved Monastery, and museum of archeology in the same complex. It is over 500 years old and it is a World Heritage Site. A very peaceful and serene environment in the monastery.

A display of grandeur!. Located write opposite the coast of Tagus and in the heart of Belem this monastery displays very detailed and stunning Portugese Gothic Architecture. It also has the National Archaeology and Maritime musuem. Its worth spending couple of hours in that area, walking by the coastline and seeing the 25 de Abril Bridge, monument of the discoveries or walking down the main road which leads to numerous street cafés and have the best Portugese custard tart from the most famous Casa Pasteis De Belem for only €1.05. You cannot go to Lisbon and not walk along Belem that packs so much culture and architecture in a cluster.

Memorable. With an exquiste and serene cloister, the Mosteiro has to be the top attraction in Lisbon. Having visites many such places in Italy, it remains among the most beautiful seen. Don't miss it.

Worth a visit. It's free on the first Sunday of the month, so go then! Beautiful building with tons of art and architecture...just like all other cathedrals around the world, but the size of the monastery is impressive.

Really Beautiful. We had heard good things about the Mosteiro and we were not disappointed. A quick trip by tram from our hotel took us out to Belem and it's group of interesting attractions. The Mosteiro is the crown jewel of all of them. I was stunned by the intricate stone work and it reminded my wife and I of the weaving of the natural and the spiritual in Sagrada Familia in Barcelona. If you are making the trip out to Belem this is a must see.

Ancient monastery. Located near the Torre de Belem (Belem Tower) and the Monument to the Discoverers (Monumento aos Descobrimentos). It was a nice place to visit with beautiful gardens.
I have been there with a tour group and, later, I went back there on my own for better enjoyment.
Average. Over expected this visit. It's ok to give it a miss just go to Belem for the egg tarts. Even with a queue so for to Pasteis de Belem.

nice old Monastery in Lisbon. This Monastery is actually a much larger complex, from which there was carved out space for the Museum of Archaeology, as well as for the Maritime Museum. So what is presented as Monastery of Jerónimos is in fact only the large cloister of it plus few adjacent rooms. The architecture, in Gothic style, is fantastic. One of the rooms contains some interesting tiling work - azulejos, so specific to Portugal. Also from here, there is access available to the choir of the Church itself (and which has its own entrance, free of charge). When I reached there one morning, there were people already in the line, even though it was almost an hour left till the opening. As it seems with the majority of such sights and museums in Portugal, the opening time was 10 AM, which I think would have been more useful from a tourist's point of view, if it was a bit earlier. The entrance fee I thought was a bit high, so one might consider getting a combined ticket with some of the other attractions mentioned above (the Museum of Archaeology, specifically) and others, within the same Monastery complex or nearby.

not worth the 10 euros.... dont bother going inside. Save your 10 euros, head to the Pastéis de Belém and enjoy their secret recipe Nata's and an espresso. then head to the Vincent de Fora Monastery instead.Otherwise, perhaps, grab the combo ticket for 12 euros? and enjoy the Belem Tor from the inside....

Beautiful Architecture. The Mosteiro is a trip into the past, with beautiful architecture and a very peaceful, relaxing environment. The cathedral is a great example of Portuguese Late Gothic Manueline style of architecture in Lisbon, and something to take in for the perspective. The tomb of Vasco de Gama is located in the cathedral, as well as the poet Luís de Camões (who celebrated da Gama's first voyage in his 1572 epic poem, The Lusiad). Also in the cathedral are the tombs of the kings Manuel I and John III, who sponsored de Gama.
Beautiful iconic building. Well worth a visit to this monastery. Can get crowded at times. Surrounded by beautiful gardens and water feature. Mind you dont get soaked from the spray.

Extraordinary. A remarkable mix of Gothic severity and Renaissance exuberance. There is nothing to dislike in it, apart from the absence of flowers in the patio. Yet I suppose that it is due to the season!
Great Monument. It was amazing to visit this monument. The church is fantastic.If you visit Lisbon, you have to go there.

Nice, but not worth the 10 euros. The Monastery is nice, not incredible though and not alot to see.... The 5 euro entry for the Monastery Fora is far better and more interesting and has amazing views of the city. Save the money, go to the Monastery Fora and have a couple of extra Nata's and Espresso from the nearby bakery.

Don't miss it!. A beautiful example of 15th century gothic-Manueline architecture and worth the short metro ride. It can get crowded so go mid-week if you have the opportunity. The tile museum is in route and the naval museum is nearby.

Wonderful Site in Beautiful Belem. A trip to Lisbon is incomplete without a stop in Belem. This lovely area is perfect for sightseeing, strolling, or snacking. The pastry shop to the right of the front of the monastery has incredible custard tarts. Be sure to reward yourself after touring. The monastery is beautiful. Don't miss it.
Vasco de Gama's crypt. Lovely buildings with stained glass windows. And the crypt. Portugal is proud of their seafaring history.

Wonderful architecture. Wonderful architecture inside and out and a very pleasant escape from the over graffiti covered city centre.
Worth the tram ride to get there. (Tram 15E from the city). On the opposite side of the road the there is far more to experience with the statues of the explorers and a wonderful park.

A 'Must See' when you visit Lisbon. We visited this superb attraction as part of an organized coach trip on a cruise stop in Lisbon. The architecture is excellent, as are the stained glass windows, and internal designs. This 16th Century monastery celebrates the great Portuguese explorers and attached to one end of the building is the very good Maritime Museum and extension. Both deserve at least 90 to 120 minutes of your time. There is a shop and café at the Maritime Museum.

Beautiful. This is a must-see attraction in Lisbon and well-worth the trip just outside the city. It's easy to access via public transport or the various tour buses that head out to Belem. The monastery is beautiful and the area round it by the estuary all lovely.

wonderful place. We easily spend a couple of hours taking in the sights of this wonderful monastery. Every wall, column, arch is carved is exquisite detail. Not a sight to be missed. We bought our tickets along with the Torree de Bellem, which offered a good saving, and as they are opposite to each other, you shouldn't visit one without the other.
Magnificent!. The place is full of history. It is so grand and out of this world. Architecture is amazing and one of a kind. The surrounding area is worth visiting too...

One of the most beautiful Monasteries in the World!. If you imagine a beautiful Monastery Jerónimos is the one. Located in Belém District it is na impressive XV Century building that used to have a hole estate arrounded with many hectares. Now reduced to the building and its cloisters it showcases the Archeology Museum in one of the wings and the beautiful Church. A most visit in Lisbon!

Unique!. When in Lisbon, you must visit the Jeronimos monastery!Massive monastery, around 500 years old. There are 2 different queues, one for the monastery and one for the church. You should visit both, but the monastery is much more interesting and beautiful. Is very close to Torre de Belem and the cultural centre in Belem. You can take the tram 15E from city centre(if you can get the tram from the first stop as it is always very busy) and there is a stop in front of the monastery, around 15-20 mins ride.Same tram to get back to town. If you don't have a Lisbon card you can get tickets inside the tram and the machine gives you change. You must go and visit this monastery
Visit to Mosterio Dos Joronimos. When we stayed in Lisbon we visited this place Very good place. If you are visiting Lisbon this is a place you must try.

Unique. A unique monument.
Art and history. Not only Portuguese but also worlds history.
Portuguese or not, you cant miss it!
Beautiful. We went for free on the first sunday of the month. Make sure you see the Claustro (better than the church imo... but then again I'm not religious) . There are two separate lines.
Beautiful and worth a quick visit.. Lots of history and beautiful artwork. Check out the pastel de natas at the bakery across the street for a treat!

Unique place. It is unique!
One masterpiece unique in the world!
With all the influences of the seas and the discoveries Portuguese did all over the world in the 15th century

500 year old monastery. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is one of the most beautiful monasteries you will ever see, a must see site in Lisbon and its near Torre de Belem and the Cultural center of Belem, you can see all three in one afternoon.

Magnificent. The monastery as an imposing exterior and beautiful interior. It's free to enter though there was a line to get in and it got crowded inside which slightly ruined the experience for me. The tram 15 stops right in front of the monastery.

Interesting. Gives a good overview of the history of Portugal. Beautiful monastery and architecture. In the town of Belem which is a great town with little shops and a large park. Close to the Belem tower and monument. Beware of the gypsies who seem to appear out of no where and are persistent. Great walking area and many photo ops.
Definitely worth a visit. The architecture is amazing. The cloister is awesome and so peaceful. Well worth a few hours of your time and the trip out to Belem.
Great architecture and ambiance. Lovely building and nice special exhibits. The church was in use during our visit so it was great to hear the choir.

A must visit building in Lisbon. Close to the Belem's Tower, the Jeronimos' Monastery is a famous monastery in Lisbon, built under the reign of Manuel the first. It's an amazing building that I suggest you to visit if you visit Lisbon, for exemple after visiting the Belem's Tower. It is famous for its architecture and for being the place where a lot of portugueses kings were burried (Including Manuel the first himself). Manuel the first used his own architectural style to build this unique monastery. This monastery has been included in the UNESCO World Heritage in 1983.
Beautiful and Historic. beautiful building. peaceful and gothic....We took many great photos here. Go early!! lineup starts around 10am

Beautiful! A quick experience but worth every minute. It's a beautiful monastery with a gorgeous church - loved the cloister inside the museum section. There are a few exhibits, nothing special, but the architecture itself is worth the whole experience.

Culture in centuries of Portugal. Special building located on the heart of culture area of Lisbon, Belem, near by Torre de Belem and Pastel de Belem Pastry & food, this epic architecture of catolic church, brings full journey into the history of Portuguese monarchy and important arts and characters.
A Typical Cathedral in Europe. Interesting but not as significant as some of the other major cathedrals in Europe. We prefer visiting some of the Italian churches over this particular one.

Get lost in the history. This church and complex was a wonderful experience. Apart from experiencing a traditional Portugese wedding ceremony, just walking the grounds and exploring the various rooms and chapels was delightful. Not to be missed is the refectory, where the monks ate, and the quadrangle (which was actual a slight octagon because the corners were clipped) with it's incredible feel, and intricate, well preserved stone carvings. Beautiful example of manuline architecture.It's also a treasure trove of burial spots for many Portugese explorers.
Impressive. Monumental building, worth visiting especially if you are around for the Belém tower. Couldn't get in due to late hours, but it's great to behold even from outside.
A must when you are in Lisbon. Great architecture, built in early 1500's. Must read the story inside showing the history of the discoveries.

“Very pretty and fascinating”. The Monastery is in the vicinity of the coach museum, the maritime museum,an archeological museum, the tower of Belem and the Monument to the Discoveries, so there's lots to see and do.The monastery grounds are beautifully maintained, which is no small feat given the site of the site

Iconic building + Vasco de Gama tomb !. The Jeronimos church and monastery, like the nearby Torre de Belem and Padrao dos Descobrimentos (Navigator's monument),all located in Belem area and symbolise the Portuguese age of discovery and are among the top tourist attractions of Lisbon.You can easily reach there by tram 15 from central Lisbon.The Jeronimos monastery has stunning outside view and peaceful environment inside. I was surprised when I found the stone tomb of famous Vasco de Gama in the church ! I strongly recommend to visit it.There are also maritime museum and archaeology museum in different part of monastery that worth to visit.

Impressive icon of Lisbon. Impressive, huge. 16th century white limestone church commissioned by King Manuel. Started in 1501 and finished 100 years later, it is done in the Manueline style. Beautiful architecture. The tomb of the important Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama is here.
Vasco da Gama's tomb. Steeped in history. There was also a special exhibit about one of Portugal's local heroes, which was fascinating.

Beautiful. Belem is easy to reach by tram, about 30min from Cais de Sodre.
The Monastery is beautiful and peaceful with a nice history of Lisbon, Portugal and the World in 1 room.
You can enter for free in the church but you have to pay 10euros for the visit of the monastery.

Vasco's resting place. There were a lot of tourists queuing to visit the monastery (which has an entry fee) so we just popped into the chapel.. actually it's large church.. plus you'll see Vasco da Gama's tomb. In Belem which contains the waterfront and the famous pastry shop. Take the regular style tram number 15.. from the main square, takes around 30 mins.. a nice stroll along the quai too, taking in the Monument of the discoverers and the lighthouse.

Stunning. Fabulous place. Amazing architecture, beautifully presented. Good value for money. the church is free, but do not scrimp on the 10 euro entrance fee, or else you will miss out on the cloisters and refectory, and pictorial historical/contextual display room. Do it!

Must see. A must see for me, incredible architecture and great detail. The church itself is lovely too but if you can spare the money for the ticket do get inside to see the yard and the exhibition of world and Portuguese history. That's it, though, nothing more, but recommended.
Beautiful Site. Beautiful site to see. The architecture is pretty amazing. I would highly recommend you pay the 6 Euros to see the cloister. It is truly an enchanting place.
Beautiful. Really stunning. Such a nice area as well so would love to eat outside and head in around for a look afterwards.
great architecture. nice mix of western and moorish architecture, typical for Portugal. and visit for free with Lisboa Card
Pretty cool.. Amazing architecture. Very pretty place to walk around with rich history. Got in free with the Liboa card.

Beautiful product of Portugal's prosperous era. A visit to Lisbon is incomplete without seeing Jeronimos. The details inside have Manueline touches, like rope ( part of their maritime past) carved around posts. It is really a product of Portugal's glory as a worldwide maritime power. We went into the cathedral and we also paid the fee to go into the Cloister. This is truly gorgeous. It is a white building, so ornately decorated. The gargoyles of animals fascinated me. It was worth paying to see it.

Beautiful, Historic & Gothic. A lot of sculptures and motifs used. Beautiful, historic and at the same time haunting. Other notable Manueline structures in Portugal include Batalha Monastery and the Templar Convento de Cristo in Tomar.

A beautiful building. We had a look inside and the architecture was amazing. There is an entrance fee if you would like to see further parts of the cathedral but we did not go. The place looks like lace.
Great architecture. Monasteries are amazing, they are really big and park in front with fountain is really cool. And in side chapel you can enter for free

Amazing. This is something you must have visited when you are in Lisbon. Its in Belem where a lot more is to be seen !! The architecture is amazing, do not forget to go upstairs and see the chapel inside from above ( to do this you need to buy ticket to visit the monastary) For people who love history , visit the thombe of Vasco Da Gama.

Very nice example of manuelin architecture.. This is place with very good location, because nearby are a lot of things you have to see. Betlehem tower is one of them. Monastery is good example of manuelin architecture, very typical for Lisboa.
Stunning!. This is an amazing monastery, the entry is 10euros, however me and my husband had a lisboa card and entry was free :)

The Masterpiece. In Belem you have this great monument facing the river and plain of history in the interior. Our great writer Camões is buried there and from there a lot can also be seen and don't forget the Pasteis de Belem, unique in the world.

Beautiful in Belem. Located in Belem, just a 10-15 minute train ride from Lisbon, it is a definite MUST-SEE. So beautiful and detailed and I can only hope that talent like that still exists somewhere in the world because otherwise it would break my heart to accept that there is no one else creating that type of beauty. From the outside walls to the inside ceiling, the detailed architecture is something everyone can appreciate. I did not enter the cloisters so I can't comment on that except that I was told I wouldn't miss much and would save a couple euros. Walking around outside and taking your time inside the church will keep you entertained enough. I thought this was more beautiful than the Sagrada Familia and I'm thrilled I made the trip to see it.
Don't miss this. Wonderful building, but very busy with tourists. While in the area you HAVE to visit and enjoy a treat at Pasties de Belem!

Worth a look in. The monastery has quite a high entry charge for the amount there is to see. Queues to get in can be long. I would recommend using the Lisbon card to get in as there are several other museums and the Belem tower in the area that if visited together would easily make your money back on the card (especially if using the included free public transport out to Belem).Within the monastery the highlight is the two storey cloister, which is genuinely impressive. There are a few additional rooms but, frankly, not a lot else to see. You probably only need an hour to look around and take photos. To note: you can go in the ground floor of the church (where Vasco de Gama's tomb is) for free.

Gobsmackingly beautiful. Real WOW factor. When you alight from the tram just outside the monastery, your jaw drops! This building has the most beautiful archway and entrance. Just stunning. Inside the cloisters are peaceful - in spite of the numbr of visitors and just lovely. This is one of the most beautiful buildings in Europe. There was nothing to dislike.
Amazing Cloisters. Well worth a visit Very well laid out and the architecture of the cloisters is amazing. Very interesting exhibition

Cloisters are stunning. Not usually 'into' churches but have to concede this is magnificent and reflects the GLORY days when Portugal was one the 3 'masters of the sea'..its sheer dimensions reflect the wealth..in the 16th c !!!Exceptional restoration work.Faithful.Church is typical with the usual array of paintings, ornaments and chapels.Read of an architectural genre unknown to me in describing this religious palace…" flamboyant Gothic"…apt.Cloisters another level of WOW.When you first enter one's breath is taken away..Two stories to see, with the lower being the most ornate.Expect to crane your kneck.Lovely gardens and fountain to sit after.Then a coffee and tart nearby.Much better to save the hour or two at the tower, come here and the nearby gallery.
Ex-libris of marine architecture. An absolute must for all interested in Portuguese history and marine Manueline architecture. Its tranquil aura and perfect shapes are dazzling!

Unmissable!. It is not often that a building amazes me, but this one did. The interior of the church is impressive but the real "wow" factor comes when you venture outside into the cloisters. The wealth of carved detail is overwhelming, quirky and beautiful at the same time. Forget custard tarts - this is the real gem of Belem!

Wonderful. It's a wonderful monastery with beautiful architeccture. The cathedral is stunning and the inner courtyard reminded me of the colleges in my beloved Oxford. Many breathtaking views and points of interest, this was one of the highlights of our visit to Lisbon. I would highly recomend visiting first thing in the morning as later the tour buses churn in and the place gets quite crowded.

Amazing architecture. The monastery is breathtaking. The architecture is stunning. The queue to get in however was unnecessary, a more efficient ticketing process would have saved us from spending over 45 minutes in the rain outside, in November. The combined tickets good value.
Grand design. A massive building which is a must see, set near a garden with spectacular fountains. Get in early to avoid queues.

Totally unsatisfied.. We visited Lisbon on our honeymoon and we took pictures almost everywhere in the city in our wedding clothes. When we entered the monastery, still in wedding clothes, we payed the ticket and we started to take pictures of us in different places inside. Suddenly we were stopped by some security people, who told us to wait about 15 minutes till somebody comes who speaks English to tell us that it is not allowed to take pictures dressed as bride and groom without a permit, which had to be applied for on the site of the monastery at least 3 weeks before. There was no information about this nowhere at the entrance nor the Web page. After we talked finally with the director, which was an excellent woman and an ambassador for her country, she told us that there us no way we get our money back as we asked, because noone told us what we were allowed to and what not, we left after taking a couple of pictures with the director. We left with the worst impression of the way they treated us.

Breathtaking . Visited the monastery today. We took the 15e tram from Lisbon straight to Belem. There was quite a long queue but managed not to get caught in their torrential rainfalls. The monastery is beautiful crafted and definitely worth a visit and so is the adjoining church.

Stunning cloisters. Amazing building and cloisters with an excellent exhibition in Spanish and English. Entry to the cathedral is free but there is a cost for the cloisters. If you have a Lisbon Card entry is free. There is currently restoration work to the cathedral.
Surely one of the unsung wonders of the world. A beautiful monastery with breath-taking architecture and a serenity despite its popularity. Much more worthwhile than the nearby Torre de Belem too!

The best thing we saw in Lisbon. In my opinion this is the best thing to see in Lisbon, if you like this type of thing :)The church is impressive and the stonework at the mosteiro itself is quite amazing. The amount of detail is breathtaking. There weren't big queues when we went, at about 16:00, but we had bought a combined ticket at the nearby Torre De Belen (which is massively overrated ) anyway, so could go straight in. We stayed for just over an hour, which was enough, but you could stay longer if you have more energy! It's closed on Monday, best way to get there is probably the 15 tram or taxi. Enjoy!

Gorgeous Manueline architecture. The monastery was 100% worth a visit to the inside. I found it very peaceful (not surprising, as it is/was a monastery), but also fascinating in terms of its architecture. The building is quite impressive from the outside and may deceive one into thinking it's not necessary to enter - but the interiors are another matter unto themselves. Walking around, you can see a few playful elements mixed in, such as woodland animals. It's much more than your usual leaves and flowers carved onto pillars. The Jeronimos Monastery is one of the few surviving Manueline buildings in Europe, and because of its uniqueness, it's a must-see. There is also access to the balcony, so you get a bird's-eye view of the attached church.If you're more interested in churches and not that interested in architecture, you could skip it. The exhibits inside were kind of boring and I didn't spend much time on them. But it's money well spent just to see the building itself. Also visit the attached church, as it's free!* If you like my review, I appreciate you clicking the 'helpful' button; those of us who take the time to write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more :) *

Stunningly Beautiful. We went to Belem Tower first, and bought a combo ticket for that and this.Beware, that walk was longer than it seemed like it'd be. Even on the map it looked short, but it didn't feel like it.Anyway . . . the church portion of this site is free. The amount of detail inside is breathtaking. I can't imagine the thousands of hours people spent in making this.The paid portion (the actual Monastery) was pretty cool as well. There's a nice little courtyard area in the middle, and two levels of various rooms surrounding it. There's a nice exhibit showing a timeline of the middle of it, along with everything else in modern history.I'd highly recommend it, if you like historical buildings and beautiful architecture.

Worth looking at but use your Lisboa card. We are not religious but you don't have to be to admire the splendour of both the church (free) and monastery (free with Lisboa card). It is the first point of call when you get to Belem before heading off to the sights by the water and if you have a bit more time than us then have a look at the exhibitions and museums nearby
Amazing roof... A great place to visit. Free to Go in ( can leave a donation ) and an amazing building with a great vaulted roof. Well worth a visit.

Portuguese Gothic Style and Very Lovely Inside and Outside. Very pretty, and historic, inside and out. Lots of photo opportunities. The church is free, and there is a charge for the monastery. Queues can be long and it is best to get there early or late to avoid crowds.The Jerónimos Monastery (or Hieronymites Monastery) is located near the shore of the parish of Belém, in Lisbon. The monastery is one of the most prominent examples of the Portuguese Late Gothic Manueline style of architecture in Lisbon. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, along with the nearby Tower of Belém.If this review is helpful then please indicate so below.

Should Not be Missed. This is a wonderful example of Manueline architecture. Construction was begun in the mid 15th century by Henry the Navigator. The cloisters are absolutely beautiful. There is a very good description of what to see in several popular guide books. Just a hint, buy your tickets here for both this and the Belem Tower saving you another wait in line at the tower to buy tickets.

Great. Very interesting facade in manuelin style. I recomend espеcially the church, if you can visit in sunday morning when is the mess. There is the tomb of Vasco da Gama. In sunday museums are free but you must go early in the morning.

Well worth the trip. We intended to take the 15 tram to Belem, but there was a marathon on that day so after waiting for 30 mins we took a taxi instead splitting with another couple (only total 10 Euros). We were dropped outside the monastery and just standing outside it is amazing. The beautiful architecture combined with its size make it something you need to see when in Lisbon, even if just from the outside.We visited the church first (free of charge to the right) - bring a cover for your shoulders. Then we waited in the queue for the Monastery which we thought would be free it being a Sunday....but its only free the first Sunday of the month. The ticket booths are extremely slow so expect a wait - and buy a combo ticket for the fortress at the same time as that enables you to avoid the queues there - you can just waltz straight through.If you can - visit this - its a must!
Passing visit is enough. Passing visit is enough as external is only good.Next to it is museum but worth for archeological lovers

Looks great from the outside. The monastery is an excellent place with a lot of history, free to get in however there were huge queues when we were there so didn't have the time to go inside, but did spend time just taking in the view. The outside reminded me of parts of Rome with the columns and domes.Be aware you must pay to go into the museum, which I didn't realise at first (surprisingly the queue was shorter for this!)Worth seeing, would have liked to have had the time to go inside hence the lower score.

Best tourist attraction in Lisbon. This place is amazingly beautiful. It is a Unesco site and in it's own way is as gorgeous as Notre Dame in Paris or St. Peter's in Rome. The style is different with huge carved stone columns in the cathedral and the cloisters were magnificient. If you only have one day in Lisbon this is where you should go.

Got in the Long Line. There are two things to visit here, the church and the monastery, which is a Archaeological Museum. As I have been to some of the best museums in the world, I opted not to pay 10 euros to see stuff I had already seen and got in the long line to get into the church. I only discovered why there was a long line once inside; there was a wedding going on. It is a lovely church and I am glad I saw it though I wish I could have seen more...

A must visit. One of the 4 things you really should visit when you are in Belèm!It is a beautiful church with a beautiful monastery. This in the portuguese "gothic" style. There are 2 queues; 1 for the church ( free ) & 1 for the monastery ( depending on the ticket max 10 euro - adult ).All very beautiful ( see pictures ).One tip: if you come with the public transport; USE THE TRAIN. 1,80 a ride - no queues and every 10 min a train. Also not many people in the train! You can pay the train with your viva Viagem or other ( metro ) card.

Nice place to visit. Impressive building, free entrance, the resting place of Camoes (Portuguese writer) and Vasco de Gama (navigator, 1st to reach the Indies from Europe through Cape Horn) both from XVI Century. Accessible by tram 15E from Cais do Sodré metro station (green line).Buy a day ticket for 6 Euros before using the public transport system in Lisbon. The metro costs 1.40 and the trams can cost up to 2.85 if paid on-board (and they only take coins).We had to wait in a queue (not very organised) and managed to get the second (modern and bigger than the first traditional) tram that passed.
Must see. Just stunning. We did not do the additional cloisters visit but did pay for the treasury. Quite one of the most spectacular buildings of its type.

Amazing stonework. There is very little information about the monastery but it is well worth visiting. The decorative stonework is outstanding and there is a good exhibition narrating 500 years of the history of the monastery and a time line to what was happening in Portugal and the rest of the world.

Not to be Missed. Walking the halls of Monastery of Jeronimos, I really had the sense I was visiting someplace very special and sacred. The architecture is so beautiful, especially when set against that vast blue Lisbon sky. There is so much to see in Lisbon, do add this to the top of your list.

Beautiful, but a bit pricey. The Monastery is beautiful and I completely enjoyed walking around to admire the architecture and take photos for an hour. However, if you are on a time and/or monetary budget, the 45 minute wait in line and 10Euro Fee are both a bit high. Many guidebooks note that the monastery is free on Sunday before 2PM, but that is not longer the case.

Beautiful . Go to the Church first, it is for free, than move into the monastary proper. Both places are part of the same building. Both are beautiful with late gothic architecture, the monastary also provides a comprehensible history where the old library used to be.
