Nice. It was a pleasant visit and the architecture is outstanding.Though we didnt like the area belem the monastery is just outstanding

If you do only one thing in Lisbon, visit the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. This attraction is a bit far from the downtown. We started walking but eventually took a taxi. Visit was 100 percent worth it as this is a world class attraction of great beauty. Includes an elaborate chapel and a cloister filled with breathtaking Manueline tracery and carvings. Chapel may not be open to visit, as it is still used for religious services. A reasonably priced attraction, with lots else to see in the Belem area, including the Tower of Belem and the Monument to the Discoveries.

Surprisingly Impressive. I guess this is one of the most popular attractions in Lisbon - with good reason especially on a nice day. The outside is stunning in the sunlight, as are the cloisters. There is a general point to note about trips to Belem - the tram can get very busy, especially at the Cais Sodre stop, so if you get a chance to board in Placa Figuera where it starts I would do so. Alternatively you can take a local train from Cais Du Sodre to Belem, although it's a bit further to walk.The monastery tram stop is one stop further than the Belem stop itself.

Absolutely stunning. By far the most interesting place Ivisited in Lisbon! The monastery is a huge place, with a stunning interior and lots of things to see. It's very different from other monasteries I visited, specially because of the style of the columns and ornaments. Don't think twice: go!
wow. WOW! The architecture is so beautiful and the inside is so peaceful. The cloister is a must and so is the chapel.

A monastery and a monument to faith!. The "Mosteiro dos Jerónimos" or simply the "Jerónimos" is one of the most beautiful monasteries in the whole world! Visiting is a must and should never be missed while in Lisbon. Its construction, commanded by Portuguese King D. Manuel I, started between the 15th and the 16th centuries, right after navigator Vasco da Gama's return from his iconic voyage to India. It would not be wrong to mention that this magnificent Monastery, in the lovely manueline gothic style, celebrates the grandiosity of the Portuguese discoveries, as well the huge profits obtained from the spice trade. Inside "Mosteiro dos Jerónimos", many of the Portuguese heroes and artists are buried: King D. Manuel I, Navigator Vasco da Gama and Poets/Writers Luís de Camões, Alexandre Herculano and Fernando Pessoa, and many others. "Jerónimos" is a Portuguese National Monument since 1907 and has been appointed by Unesco, in 1983, as a World Heritage. The entrance to the Monastery is free, but admissions to Sacristy and Cloisters are charged. I would skip the Sacristy (that you can admire from a certain distance), but the Cloisters are definitely a must see! Combine the visit with other nearby mythical monuments: "Torre de Belém", "Padrão dos Descobrimentos" and the "Museu Nacional dos Coches". A quick stop at the "Casa dos Pastéis de Belém" will be your opportunity to taste the unforgettable Portuguese National pastry: the delicious "Pastéis de Nata"! Enjoy!

Place of great beauty.. This is a must do visit when visiting the Belem district of Lisbon. The church is magnificent, no charge to enter. The Monastery,next door, has an entrance fee but is worth every " centimo". Take your time,soak up the ambiance. Don't be put off by the seemingly huge hoards of tourists,once inside there is space for all. Wonderful.

Don't miss. There was quite a queue when we arrived, but it was for the church which is free, but you pay to visit rest. Most people were only visiting the church. The cloisters were beautiful very photogenic, it is truly a beautiful place. Situated in Belem area, close to railway station, it's a nice area.

Monumental Monastery of Jeronimos!. We visited this lovely monastery and cathedral recently and were amazed by its beauty and breadth.It is right down from the other major Belem sites the Tower and the Discovery statue, just across the street. There is an underground pedestrian passageway to enable you to get to the monastery so don't fret about crossing the highway.You surely will want to visit the tomb of Vasco de Gama in the cathedral and you will find it there. I can highly recommend this site to you.

stunning. Started our Lisbon holiday there and wow what a beginning. The church is free, you pay for the rest & the museums alongside so get a combined ticket. I'm a keen photographer so was in heaven!

Stunning. Entry to the main building is free with a €10 entry charge for the rest of the monastery. This is well worth paying as it is absolutely beautiful. It is also incredibly busy so get there early. The other tourist attractions at Belem are within easy walking distance and are also a must see.

Must See, Even Tho' Crowded. If you want history and beauty, this is the place. We visited as part of a Viking river cruise so had a guide, which I think would be necessary as otherwise you don't know what you're looking at, and there's a lot to see. Near-by is Belem Tower and the Discoveries Monument, also both must-dos.

You must go here. The monastery is absolutely beautiful. It was 10 euro to get in which is a bit pricey and if you dont want to go inside you can still visit the church part for free, which in itself is stunning, and holds the tomb of Vasco De Gamma. From the church just walk across the road to Pastes De Balem and get a coffee and one of the areas well know custard tarts. Be prepared to queue at least 20 mins for the pastry as this seems to be the thing in this area. The whole area of Balem is really nice with a lovely esplanade and the wonderful Tore Balem that looks like a chess piece.

Spectacular, top destination Lisbon. I stayed Lisbon for 3 days and the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is on the top of my list (the other 2 of my top 3: food and the people of Lisbon). A very easy tram trip (#15) from Lisbon to Belem.The cloister is absolutely fantastic, get ready to take many pictures, but it will be hard to capture so much beauty. The building is fantastic, so you should allocate 2 hours to visit it in order to really appreciate its beauty and details.

An absolute must-see. This is an amazing gothic masterpiece, don't miss it. If you arrive by car and can't find street parking try the underground parking of a contemporary art gallery/museum - a modern rectangular building across the street. Don't bother queueing for a free church visit (on the right) - go straight to the ticket office and to the cloister. You will be able to see the most of the church from the choir and if you would still like to visit the rest of the church the chances are that as you exit the cloister there'll be no queue to the church.

See it for free. You dont need to see the whole monastery unless that is really your bagJust check out the Cathedral Church area on the right of the building which is stunning and includes the Tomb of VASCO DA GAMA!Afterwords pop in Pastes De Belem next door for the most famous pastries in Lisbon

Impressive - And totally worth the visit. This is one of the nicest monasteries in Europe. It is very crowded but totally worth the visit. If you have Lisboa Card, stay in line to get your discounted tickets for not only this site but for Belem Tower too. So when you go to Belem you won't need to stay in the long line since you already have your tickets and can just go in.

Impressive but expensive.. Impressive architecture, especially in the cloisters but in my opinion a bit of a rip-off at €10 per person. Not a great deal of information on display either, hold on - you can pay extra for an audio guide. Couldn't avoid the feeling that I (and every other foreign tourist) were simply being used as a cash cow.

Portuguese Government RIP OFF. Seriously, 10 euros for a freaking cloister and a couple of messed up exhibitions?Go to hell.If you pay half as senior or student, still a rip off but a lesser one.The explanations about rooms and architecture totally suck. For 10 bucks we should have a guide, a massage and a cappuccino included.Hey, what about that UGLY navy library built of concrete in the middle of the monastery?!? Are you nuts?!? That totally spoiled the monument!Darn... this was supposed to be awesome but Tomar castle is WAAAAY more awesome.Portuguese government, take action and make things right.

Disspointed. We paid €10 to go inside mainly to see the architecture and the old library. The architecture is amazing and for those who like architecture its one of the best places to visit. But the lady who sold us the tickets didnt tell us that most of it was closed including the old library. So I was really dissapointed. Also people where standing in a very long queue and were not told there was another place to buy tickets that was empty.
Stunning. Not usually over impressed with religious buildings but this is a must see. The cloisters are amazing. An amazing feat given the period it was built in

Back once again. Very important place to visit in Lisbon. When there think that it was from there that Portuguese queen used to blessed the ships and navigators before going into sea and conquer the world.

Beautiful and Stunning!. A must see while in Lisbon to gain a little knowledge about the amazing history of Portugal. Beautiful Gothic architecture with Renaissance features makes this a beautiful backdrop for photos. Inside the monastery, there is a room with an educational piece of world history.
Wonderful. This old building is really wonderful, the building with the garden and also the church... with it's huuge pillars it looks like Moria! :P See it
An amazing place well worth a visit. Visited in September 2014, such a beautiful building, amazing architecture and all round wonderful place to browse for an afternoon.
Beautiful. So rich in history and incredible architecture. Walking through the courtyard and rooms it is impossible not to be struck by the intricate stonework at every turn.

Route . Take the metro to Rossiotake the exit to Praça da Figueira and take public transport long tram number 15 in front of the hotel called The Beautique Hotels FIGUEIRA stay in the tram until you see the Jeronimos Monastery

CLOSED!. Showed up on a Monday. Monastery said it is open on Mondays on its doors.CLOSED! Lady nearby says, "Today, everything is closed."DON'T ADVERTISE THAT YOU ARE GOING TO BE OPEN, IF YOU ARE NOT.Waste of a day-trip to Belem.The door is nicely decorated.

A enormous piece of art. I visited it for a dozen times and it stil looks impressive to me today. It was built in the XV century and is a Portuguese Late Gothic Manueline style, perhaps the most impressive and genious "artifact" of that season. Is well located in the city and you have the Torre de Belém near to visit also!

Splendid Medieval Monastery. This is an old stone religious complex west of Lisbon's downtown. It has the archaeology museum which is interesting, a splendid medieval church and the monastery itself which has spectacular architecture and some interesting information. It is in the village of Belem which has a nice main street, a large presidential palace and the Belem Tower. You can enjoy coffee and a snack in the village before visiting the Monastery.The only downside is far too many people. I arrived early and even then I was in an enormous line-up that moved at a snail's pace. If you go to the front of the line you can find there are actually two lines and the one where you pay to see the archaeology museum is actually shorter and moves faster.

Beautiful architecture. This was one of the attractions we visited whilst in Lisbon, using our Lisbon card. We did arrive early, by tram, and were one of the first to enter the monastery. This monastery's construction was begun in 1501 and the architecture is beautiful and the carvings amazing. There is little signage as you walk around but one area is dedicated to the history of the monastery and that display was fabulous.The church was packed when we finished in the monastery, due to the bus loads of tourists who had descended on the place. There is a 'system' for entry to the church and make sure you don't get it wrong as the officals yell at you loudly if you do!Well worth a visit

underwhelming and crowded. The monastery is supposed to be one of the top attractions in Lisbon so we were eager to see it, but ended up underwhelmed. Its very beautiful architecture and a pretty cloister, but thats about it. I feel like you only see a small part of it. There is also the church, which is nice but again, not super impressive. The lines are also long, so get tickets at other landmarks if you go.
Nothing interesting. The church is great (and free) but the monastery is not worth the time and price, especially given that the ancient library no longer exists

Splendid. Save some money and time and buy the combined ticket with the Tower of Belem for 12 euros. This is worth visiting, so peaceful the monastery is an inspiration to wisdom, you literally feel like sitting down and opening a book. This is my second visit and this time I had the chance to visit the library recently opened for the public and the church which free entry and it is breathtaking.

Great site. Though ticket purchasing is confusing.. The Monastery of Jeronimos was one of the highlights of my trip to Lisbon. It is easy to get to on the tram from central Lisbon and is well worth the trip.One piece of advice is to no go when entry is free if you can avoid it. I was there when the church was open to the public and the crowds were very distracting. However, the cloisters are the more beautiful of the two buildings open to visitors.When we arrived there were very long lines and no clear instructions. One trick we learned was that you can buy tickets for all of the Belem attractions at the archeology museum next door to the Monastery. There were only a few people in line and we bought tickets without much of a wait. We did not have to buy for the museum - we just bought the monastery and the tower. With a ticket, we were able to head to the front of the one line at the front of the monstery (and the tower of belem as well later in the day).

Gorgeous Architecture! But that Line was Awful.... After waiting in line in the rain to visit the Belém Tower, I was not feeling up for getting drenched again waiting in line. When mass let out in the main church, my curiosity led me over to take a peek. Other people were going in and there was no line and it was inside, so why not? I'm glad I did, because it was gorgeous. When they say Manueline is a unique style, I thought "No it's not. It's just Gothic." Yes, it still feels Gothic, but it has a completely different feel to it. It's much more intricate and detailed, with more nature motifs. Plants, animals and vegetables (many from the new world) are nestled into nautical and marine elements, such as strings of stone rope or shells. Oh, and Vasco de Gama was buried over in the corner!After enjoying the church so much, I decided to brave the line and the rain on my second to last day in Lisbon. I refused to buy one of the overpriced umbrellas from one of the vendors around the monastery. Instead I struck up a conversation with a fellow traveler who already had an umbrella.Once inside, the sun came out and cast a beautiful golden light onto the intricately-carved honey colored cloisters of the monastery's inner courtyard. The space was much smaller than I imagined; it only takes a few minutes to walk around one of the two levels. But the dancing arches, spires and balconies entranced me into staying for much longer, like one of the monks who must have come here to study centuries ago.Perhaps I'm just crazy for architecture, but I do not regret waiting in line to get in. However, I would recommend any non-architecture buffs to either come early or late in the day, when lines tend to be shorter. If you do plan on coming mid-day, check the weather first. Belém is quite far from the city center and lines provide zero refuge from inclement weather. Nearby restaurants tend to be small and will fill up quickly when it starts to pour.

Avoid the queues - go in late afternoon & how to go to Jeronimos Monastery. We were there at 5+pm and there was no queue at all. There was only a handful of people inside so we managed to take our time to view & take photos of the monastery. The interior was unique & if you look closely you will see many different animals or faces carved into the pillars & columns. You can even access to the second storey via the staircase. Upstairs, there is even a door that leads you inside the church. You can view the interior of the church from 2nd floor and see Jesus on the cross. We were surprised that the actual space opened to visitors was actually pretty small. In fact, one can finish viewing the 1st & 2nd floor in less than half an hour if they are quick. But as it was listed as a Unesco World Heritage site, we wanted to visit it.Though closing time was 6pm, the staff gave us some allowance & closed the monastery at 6.10pm. Admission fee costs 10 euros per person. Opening hours was 10am - 6pm in July 2014.The adjoining church was free to visit. There was no queue there. The church entrance was just beside the entrance to the Jeronimos Monastery. Inside, you will find the chapel and the tombs of famous explorer Vasco da Gama & King Manuel & other Portuguese royalties. To reach Jeronimos Monastery, we took the metro to Cais do Sodre. Outside Cais do Sodre metro station, look for the tram stop with tram number 15E. Take tram 15E to Belem. The tram ride takes around 15 minutes. Alight immediately after you see the famous Pasteis de Belem pastry shop selling custard tarts. The tram 15E will stop just a few steps away from Jeronimos Monastery. Hope this helps

Amazing free visits, marvelous singing. Sundays are the days with the free entrance for lucky tourists who managed to wake up early and enter before 2 pm. I was there twice (every time tried to come at 9.40-45 am to be the first in the line), both of the times I heard wonderful singing (every time the singing started at 11am and was unreal), I liked all my visits.A good location for checking out the taste of pasties nearby!

SUGGESTION in order to skip the big line. When you will arrive close to Jeronimos, cross the street in direction of the park and stop at the small shop.First of all i will suggest to buy the LISBOA CARD 24h 18 euros or 48 hours for 31hours, why??- free enter in a lot of touristic attraction such as BELEM, Jeronimos, Musuem,....- free enter in BUS, TRAM also 28 and 12You will se at Jeronimos enter a huge line in order to buy tickets(at least 1 hour under sunny day!!!)Please enter at the musuem(archeologic musuem on the left, before the marine one), show your LISBOAcard and ask for all the tickets. 5minuts and you will have:BELEM, MUSEUM and JERONIMOS in your handEnjoy it!

Beautiful building. Our visit to the Monastery took place in the afternoon, where there were long queues of people were waiting to buy tickets at the main entrance. Don't wait, instead, go along to the National Archeology Musuem which is aso housed in the Monastery. We paid 6 Euros each for a ticket to both the Monastery and the Archeology Museum and we were able to enter both without having to queue.
Beautiful but ridiculously long and slow moving queue. Well worth the visit, but we queued for over an hour on a Tuesday morning. Two cashiers taking payments just wasn't enough.

Breath taking!. After touring much of the city on an open topped bus we arrived at the monastery to see a huge queue. Luckily it didn't take too long to get tickets and enter into the dimly lit hall. It is wonderfully decorated and it's hard to comprehend the age of some of the artefacts especially the robes on the statues. A fantastic visit.

Worth the wait. The architecture is really beautiful and it makes the wait in line feel not so bad. You just wonder how many hours it took to build such a beautiful building. The walk inside certainly feels serene, like a monastery should. Inside there is a history of the area that you could spend hours reading. It was really insightful and I am so glad we made the trip.If you are in Lisbon this is a must visit. Belem is not far from the city center of Lisbon and you can walk there if you like or take public transport.After your visit, you need to walk down to Café Pastéis de Belém and you will have a full mind, heart and stomach.
Fantastic. Really, like a fantasy. Unbelievably ornate and exuberant. Details upon details. No angels were singing in here. It's all about how fancy can we make this building.

Beautiful Gothic architechture. It is within walking distance from the Monument of Discoveries. It is home to the tombs of the kings of Portugal, Vasco da Gama, Henry the Navigator and Luiz Van de Camoes, the most important writer of Portugal.We went as a tour group and as such did not have to queue for very very long.By the side of one of the door frames inside the Monastery, there are 2 vertical columns featuring interesting diverse nationalities of the time. See if you can find them.

Excellent, if you don't mind standing in line for hours.. I have been here before, so I declined to join the seemingly endless line to buy a ticket. There was even a line of those who had Lisbon cards. I don't know if there is a tip on the best time of day to visit in order to minimize the wait--maybe other reviewers have advice. All I can say is that the structure is amazing, inside and out, and worth the entrance fee if you have never seen it. Since I had seen it before, it was not worth the wait on this trip.

Without doubt THE place to visit in Lisbon. I had been before. I knew the tricks: buy your ticket at the Archaeology Museum next door, buy a joint ticket with the Torre de Belem or other attractions you wish to see, don't turn up in the late morning. Still we had to queue for probably half an hour in the blazing sun (although we took it in turns to photograph the outside of the monastery, including the intricate stonework around the door to the adjoining church). But of all the attractions in Lisbon this one is the most worth the effort. It is simply astounding, breathtaking, amazing. Even on my second visit I got chills looking at the ornate, detailed stonework. If you're not into architectural beauty it is probably quite a dull, short visit, but if you appreciate being able to see up close the kind of talented masonry work that normally adorns cathedrals dozens of metres up in the air, it is the most incredible visit. We were also fortunate to see a wedding taking place in the adjoining church (the monastery has access to the 'gallery' - I'm sure it has a proper churchy name - overlooking the main body of the church). This remains my favourite attraction in Lisbon by a mile.

Impressive popular 15th century monastry. It is a very popular place visited by a lot of visitors so expect more time to spend waiting for entrance unless you visit only the cathedrale, in which part of royal family is buried and the famous Vasco Da Gama as well. Enjoy the small garder in front of the monastry and its fountain, pond and overlook toward the river and the big monument built to respect and remind the great Portugese sailiors and navigators. You can easily combine these two sites (monstry and navigator's monument) with the nearby Belem tower and of course watching the river, the nearby 25th April bridge and the big Cristo Rei statue on the higher hill just behind the bridge on the opposite side of the Tagus river. A good spot catching several sites by almost one sight.

Absolutely gorgeous!. This monastery is located in Belem, which is reachable from Lisbon by train or tram. The monastery is absolutely gorgeous! You do not have to pay to enter the church/cathedral, but there is a fee to enter the monastery part. There was a discount if you buy tickets to enter the Belem Tower and Jeronimos together. This is a must see monastery if you are in Lisbon!

Cloisters *****. Absolutely gorgeous cloisters, which are hard to see with so many people posing for pictures. I wish there were cords to keep the hordes outside. There a a child doing somersaults on grass whose delight was contagious

Impressive architectural treasure. Getting into the Monastery was pretty easy. We arrived about 40 minutes after opening and there was a fairly long queue at the main entrance. However, we were directed to the museum entrance where we were able to buy tickets for all of the attractions in Belem. The monastery's church is impressive, with large vaulted spans, great stained glass and tombs of kings and explorers. On leaving the church we visited the cloisters and refectory etc. all beautiful and not too crowded. It helped to have done some reading before arriving.All in all well worth a visit and pretty good value.

Impressive and inspiring architecture. So far the most beautiful architecture I have had a chance to see in Portugal. On a sunny morning, the sun passing through windows and openings create an incredible light and contributes to an inspiring atmosphere. The place offers a peaceful energy, making stay and contemplate a picture perfect blue sky.Manueline architecture gives the monastery a peculiar identity, one you will not see elsewhere.Come early to avoid crowds. Keep in mind you get free entrance every first Sunday of the month before 1.00pm.

Absolutely gorgeous!. This monastery is located in Belem (civil parish of the municipality of Lisbon). You can take a train or tram from Lisbon and it doesn't take long to reach it. It is absolutely gorgeous, full of detail and definitely worth seeing. It is for sure the most beautiful monastery I have seen so far.

Architectural Jewel!. Came here on the hop-on-and-off tour buss planning on spending an hour and then going on to the rest of the stops. But we ended up staying for about three-and-a-half hours walking twice through the interior of the church, paying extra to enter the sacristy. This place is dripping with history, power and glory, both human and divine. We took so many pictures. Afterwards, we explored the intricate facades and decided to take the tour of the cloisters where there is a very interesting time line detailing historical events since the church was first built. This will be one of the most cherished experiences during our visit to Lisbon. There are lots and lots of Gypsies all over the place, crowds form and thin out frequently.
Amazing. Beautiful! Definitely worth the bus ride. Must see the cathedral too. You can get a family package that saves you about 20 E

Unbelievable architecture!. It is incredible what you get to see when you go inside the monastery. The architecture is simply unbelievable. Though there is seemingly nothing more to see, but you can get lost just looking at the details of each column, each wall and even the smallest details are very amazing. Join the free guided tour where you get additional information on the monastery. That said, the queue to get in is horribly long in the hot sun in summer. One is likely to get sun burnt and if you do get a joint ticket to see the Tower of Belem, you will need to schedule time to see both of them. My guided tour was delayed and even though I got to the Tower of Belem at 5.30pm, we were all denied entry as they said it was too crowded and told us to return the next day. My suggestion is to start early to see all the sights in Belem.

Lots to see.. The Monastery is a must see. It is home to the tombs of the kings of Portugal, Henry the Navigator and Luiz Van de Camoes, the most important writer of Portugal. Very interesting and historic. BUT, the crowds are tremendous and the men controlling the entrance an exit are extremely rude. It was nice to get to the cloisters and get away from the crowd. We got our pastasi nata at the gift shop rather than the bakery all the guide books mention. Ours was very good and we didn't have to wait in line.

Spectacular cloister, bad ticket line. A spectacular piece of architecture and well worth the visit.However the ticket line is very badly organised and the main queue can take an hour or more on busy days. What I discovered (after the fact) is that tickets are sold as combination tickets with other attractions, including the archeology museum in the same building. The line is MUCH shorter there and the same price. So you can buy your ticket there and then go straight up to the entrance of the cloister. You may think you are cutting the line, but you are not. Just being clever.

fantastic and well worth the entry. We went first thing in the morning even before it opened. We waited 15 min. When we got in it was probably a 15 min wait and it looked about the same when we left a few hours later. I imagine it is better to go before 1 or 2 for shorter lines.There is a joined ticket for the Torre de Belém for €12 or €6 for students. So go here first then skip the line at the tower.The artistry and craftsmanship of the monastery is fantastic. There was a previous review that said that it wasn't worth the entry. I totally disagree. There was a free audioguide. This was very informative. There are various rooms with exhibitions in them. We spent nearly 2 hours here reading information, listening and taking in the beauty. Plus we got to go the upper choir. You can't go here unless you go in through the monastery.

Magnificent Monastery. I'm really confused. The Jeronimos Monastery has a TA listing separate to that of the Discoveries Monument and the Belem Tower. However, all three are within a stone's throw of each other, and all three are in the Lisbon suburb of Belem. Took me a while to find this review site. ;-)Jeronimos Monastery - a stunning UNESCO World Heritage Site! I love the place and visit it every time I'm in Lisbon.Looks as if some of the other reviewers have had problems with lengthy queues. (Had the same problem myself at Versailles and ended up leaving almost immediately after I'd arrived.)With Jeronimos, I guess I've been very lucky because any time I've been there, there have been no queues at all!If you're on an organised tour, then expect massive queues. Most tour buses descend on a site at the same time: between 10 and 10:30 a.m. If you're a solo traveller, then you have a definite advantage. You can arrive much earlier - while tour groups are still having breakfast - and have a truly enjoyable visit, virtually free of frustration.Opening hours for visitors officially start at 10:00 a.m., but I've never had any problem getting in earlier.It IS a functioning church, so best to check hours of service prior to visiting. Better to wait until there are no services in progress, as it's much easier to wander around and take pictures then.Another reviewer mentions 'entrance fee'. To my knowledge, there is no entrance fee to the church.However, there IS an entrance fee to the adjacent National Archaeological Museum (and to the Maritime Museum next to it).A possible problem for visitors is that the entrance to the church and the entrance to the archaeological museum are very, very close to each other. So, it's very easy to end up in the 'wrong' place.Still another reviewer says there is no photography allowed. Unless this is a VERY new rule, photography certainly IS allowed, although it's probably more respectful to refrain from taking pictures while there's a service in progress.Any time I've ever visited the monastery, the clicking of cameras - including my own - is very audible, along with the whispered 'ohs and aws' of people amazed by the staggering beauty of the interior.It really is worth the time and effort to visit this magnificent church!

Jeronimo's Monastery/ Basco da Gama Tomb. If you enjoy beautiful architectural, then the monastery is a must see. Located close to the City center along the water's edge.The tombs located within the church are intricately carved.Since it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, I would suggest that you arrive early to get in.

Probably ok just seeing the outside. It looks very nice on the outside and you are better off seeing it early/late when most tourists are gone. I stayed at a hotel around the corner so it was easy to get pictures of the outside with nobody around. During the day, however, there are hordes of tourists everywhere and a massive line to get inside. You can get into the smallish church part for free, and without a line, which is not bad. Seeing the rest of the inside is not cheap and generally has a huge line (standing in the sun so bring sunscreen).

Rip-off. Ok, 3 stars is probably exaggerated, but seeing the stellar review, I felt I had to lower the score.Yes, the building is an amazing piece of architecture, which stands out by his size and the refinement of its sculpting. Each pillar has different motives, each window its unique features...BUTThe queue to get the ticket and then the price of the entrance are just a rip-off for the only thing you can see inside which is the courtyard!! It is a nice courtyard, but 10 euros for that??? no, especially not in Lisbon which has plenty of amazing stuff for very decent prices (just go around Sintra and enjoy your palaces)? When we entered, we ran around everywhere, thinking we must have missed something, there is surely an open door somewhere from which we can access other rooms. We even asked the reception... but no. There is just nothing!In summary: if you have a card and this is free for you, go! Else, enjoy the outside architecture and leave!

A must see. The Jerónimos Monastery or Hieronymites Monastery, is located near the shore of the parish of Belém,the monastery is one of the most prominent examples of the Portuguese Late Gothic Manueline style of architecture in Lisbon. It was classified a UNESCO World Heritage Site, along with the nearby Tower of Belém, in 1983.Be at there as early as possible!
Wonderful architecture. Beautiful monastery, the details on the building are just amazing. I especially loved the cloisters.

Portugal's monument to exploration. The church, or monestary, sits well off the beautiful waterfront but, once upon a time, it sat directly on the water's edge. Over time, silt filled up the area and now there is a big street, (Avenida da India) and little park strips and harbor openings where the edge of the water was.Most impressive as a resting place for Vasco de Gama and a famous poet Camoes, who, Portugese natives say they were forced to memorize and interpret in school. Probably not too unlike modern-day Americans trying to read old-English "Canterbury Tales" without Cliff Notes. We did notice that our tour guide (Portugese) did wince when remembering the poet's legacy and the role it played in her Portugese education.The tombs are pretty fantastic, intricately carved focal points inside the church. The travels of Vasco de Gama furthered Portugese explorations and the church has many symbols in honor of these accomplishments. The central column/supports resemble palm tree trunks, with their branches or ribs flowing out from there. There are even elephants represented here, all giving that "nod" to Vasco de Gama's Eastern travels. Look around for the Eastern-influences, they are there. Kings and queens are also entombed here, like a mausoleum.Construction began in about 1502, Vasco de Gama lived from 1468-1523. The poet was born 2 years afer Vaso de Gama's death and he is said to have been a writer of Vasco's travels.
Mosteiro dos Jerorimos. Waw, the archteture is fantastic, the place have too the graves for the Kings of Portugal, covered with gold. And the arcs inside the building are so, so beautiful.

it's a must. It is absolutly a must - so I won't waist words .In order to avoid/shorten the standing in lines both here and in the Torre de Belem - try to do what we did : Be at the Torre de Belem as early as possible . Then walk quickly to the line infront of Jeronimos Monastery . Once you are through with the Jeronimos - you can relax and enjoy a stroll through the Jardim De Belem (beautiful) ,continue towards the waterfront promenade to look at and visit the top of Padrao Dos Descobrimentos . From there an easy stroll to the Museu Dos Coches ( Carriage museum , interesting ) and before taking the #15 tram back to Praca Comerciohave a sweet nash just like thousands of tourists like yourself are doing for years At Pastilles De Belem : There's a line here too , but it is really delicious !!!!
splendid monastery in manualine style. This monastery was build the return of Vasco da Gama - who has been buried in the church - and represents the golden age of Portugal

Fab architecture & history. Make sure you're at the front of any queue by getting there 10-20 mins before it opens. So much better getting photo opps without the world & his wife elbow nudging you.
Fantastic stonemasons work everywhere, especially in the cloisters. Make sure you enter the upper choir area in order to overlook the interior of the church.

Great attraction. An absolutely nice attraction to see - great architecture; Lots of beautiful details to be looked at.
Also lots of interesting attractions in close vicinity, so absolutely worth to visit this area if you are in Lisbon.

Quite a display. This is a spectacular Church and Cloister that really conveys the power and control that the Church had over Portugal in the past. The architecture is amazing. Part of the big three to see in Belem.

Beautiful Curch. This monastery is a short tram ride from downtown Portugal, right across form the Belem Tower and the Monument of Discoveries. They have a cloister area and charge for admission there, but the sanctuary is free and there was no line for entrance. It was a peaceful and cool visit with outstanding architecture

Breathtaking Architecture. Stunning piece of Manueline architecture; make sure you carve out time to see it. The stone work is incredible and the church interior is one of the most beautiful I've seen. We spent about 2 hours wandering around the grounds. You can by a combined ticket for this and the Tower of Belem which I would recommend!

amazing monastery. Beautiful building, really old. Great piece of cultural history, great value for money.
There was really intricate design on the stonework. Recommend.
Spectacular. This is a must see when you travel to Portugal. The beauty of this site is magnificent. I would come back again and again.

Monastery a real work of art. The monastery is celebrating 500 years and they have an exhibit up on the first floor that displays world historical events and key historical Portuguese events. Also a good genealogy of the Portuguese monarchy. Great exhibit. Overall the monastery is an architectural work of art and it's amazing to think how many stone masons must have been engaged. We spent about two and a half hours touring the site.

Magnificient! Especially for Lovers of Architecture. If you are an art & architecture connoisseur, the Jeronimos monastery will appeal to you, with it's unique Manueline style. The exterior of the monastery is magnificent, with extremely intricate work. The church is beautiful and serene.

Breathtaking. You need to pay to get into the cloister but absolutely worth the 5 Euros (student price) I paid if I'm honest. The place had a definite sense of calmness and peace that was very contrasting to the outside bits full of tourists trying to get a glimpse of the main church which was free.

Monastery and church magnificent and detailed. As a bonus is the tomb of Vasco de Gama pretty big name I would say. Church is large and the view of the inside especially from 2nd floor accessed from monastery is impressive. monstery is pretty large, easy to see its magnificence from the outside - it has large open space in front of it. I would say one of the top site in lissabon very close to the tower of Belem.

definitely have to visit.. Not one of the best places in the city but you definitely have to visit.Is the place where Pessoa and Camões, the two best poets of Portugal are buried, a lot to see in the inside with archaeological museum.
Nice place.. Interesting place to see something different, unique decorating, a piece of history in one place. I would highly recommend.

Don't Believe The Hype. Amazed to see this rated #2 in Lisbon! The queue was very long and only one woman on the desk, the entrance fee seemed steep at 10 euro (I think?) but the initial impression is 'wow!' when you see the intricate stonework around the inner courtyard, and then......well not much, downhill all the way, except for the tomb of Vasco Da Gama which is positioned like an afterthought near the exit, maybe I've been spoiled over the years by seeing stunning architecture all over the world but this was average at best and as a visitor experience it was fairly awful - a massive and quite boring exhibit about the historian Herculano and then just a little plaque about Da Gama, crazy! I'd go as far as to say don't bother visiting unless you're stuck for something to do. As we were leaving we felt like warning people in the now even longer queue not to bother and save themselves the trouble.

Nice building, not much in it. As someone previously commented, if you like architecture then it's a beautiful place to see but there's not much inside. The church beside the monastery it's very impressive (and free to visit) but you can see it from the upper level only by buying a ticket to the monastery since the entrance is inside the monastery on the second floor. You can see the thumb of Vasco da Gama in the church, as well as the thumb of Luís Vaz de Camões, a Portuguese writer and poet.

Our introduction to Manueline architecture. One of Portugal's kings presided over the development of an architectural style that combines the Baroque with the Gothic to incorporate symbols of the country's explorations. The best example is the 16th century Jeronimo Monastery, set back from the Taugus River in Belem. There are two lines when you get there -- one goes into the church and is free, the other goes into the monastey proper and has a small charge. See both. You won't be disappointed.

Delightful building. Great architecture. Beautiful from the outside and has an amazing cloister. The interior aisle is captivating and to see the tomb of Vasco de Gama (who as a child at school I had heard all about his seafaring trips) was humbling. Coach groups can be annoying as they can be so big and hindering so try to avoid entry as they are about to enter.

Final Resting of Da Gama and Good Architecture.. Firstly I am an Age of Discovery fan and this guy sailed far and wide. Maybe not the best person in history but still a significant one. The monastery is quite large and partially used for a museum. The other half is a large Church. Lots of stone, wood, and metal shaped to create beautiful works of art inside. While this is not the most impressive buildings in the EU it is one of the better ones in Lisbon. It is located near the Belem tram station and there are several destinations around the area in walking distance. I would say about 20 minutes will accomplish what needs to be done here.

Beautiful building and magnificent church. The whole monastery is very big so it's hard to take picture of whole building. Visiting the church is free but entrance fee will be needed if you wanted to visit the monastery. The building of the monastery is very beautiful with its delicate carving on the columns and pictures on the tiles of the wall.

A must see in Lisbon!. Commissioned by Manual I in around 1501 after Vasco de Gama's return from his historic voyage. This monastery inside is simply beautiful but the museum visit that can be purchase separately or combo ticket with Torres Belem is worthwhile. When you visit also the outside the Monastery, the courtyard, it is even more beautiful than you can ever imagine, the detail, architect, the creative art and history.

just ok. This seemed like a must, We got there on a Sunday morning, it was opening at 10 and there was a bit of a queue for the cloisters (left queue, right is for the church) but nothing that seemed unmanageable.It took us an hour to get in. All the groups get past you but I don't even think that's the problem. There were 2 people at the ticket counter and they just could not be bothered. No hello, no thank you, very slow, talking on phones half of the time. The inside was actually pretty empty (it's not a long visit)...such a waste. People in front of us just gave up. The visit itself is ok, it is a bit cartoonish though...depends on your taste.When we came out, the queue was so long...it is really bad to organise things so badly.

Nearly 400 Years Old. If you visit Lisbon, please see this place. Lots of history but quite a que. If you can get a tour group, might save you some time. Admission was 10euro or 5 if over 65 years old. The church is not as elaborate or extravagant as many old world Catholic churches, but impressive anyway. The church is free, its the cloister which charges admission and is unique, in my experience. Great picture taking opportunities. Right across the road is the Discoveries Monument, which is not old at all. We got here riding the 15E tram, from downtown at Rossio Square for 1.45euro each way. Lots of locals, but pretty easy to figure out. If you take it, suggest you get a ticket prior to boarding or you'll need coins for the machine on the tram.

VERY BUSY. Go early in the day. After about 10 the Japanese and the Americans arrive and it's very very busy. Coach after coach. However, the inside is lovely. It's peaceful and beautifully decorated. The refectory is really worth a visit.

Most beautiful building in Lisbon.. Jerônimos Monastery is the most spetacular building in Lisbon. It`s Barroc stile. There are sepulcre Vasco da Gama, Camões and Fernando Pessoa, three of the most famous Portuguais in over history. Place isaround 20 minuto by tram from donwtown, but it`s near Belem Tour, Pastéis de Belém factory and monumento aos descobridores.

Breathtaking. Manueline architecture,elements of gothic and renaissance buildings,stunning white cathedral.long lines of tourists,go earlyBuilt with trade in the east and Africa,started in 1501Magic to see,on all buslines
Absolutely Beautiful. This monastery is truly beautiful. We went in the afternoon and there was no queue. The architecture is amazing. Pictures don't do it justice. You must see it in person.

Beautiful monastery in Lisbon. The Jeronimos Monastery in the Belem area of Lisbon is beautiful and on a hot day, a lovely place for shade and respite. The line was quite long when we visited one morning recently. Later in the day it seemed shorter. The church connected with the monastery is quite lovely.

Beautiful.. This place is just beautiful. It may be a short visit for some, depending on how attentive to details you are. But the place is exquisite.Worth the stop and the ticket price. Plus, it's right next to all the main attractions in Belém so you might as well visit them all because they hold a lot of history within.

Beautiful architecture.. Beautiful architecture, a stunning cathedral and cloisters. While visiting the courtyard and cloisters, make sure to go to the second floor and access the balcony that overlooks the cathedral's interior. Easily combined into a half-day trip with the Monument of the Discoveries and the Belem tower (all within walking distance). Taking the 15E tram, from Lisbon's Cais do Sodre‎ train station, will bring you directly to the monastery.Entry costs 7€ per person and credit cards are accepted.

UNESCO World Heritage. Jeronimos Monastery is UNESCO World Heritage that lot of people wait to go inside the garden. Nevertheless, the admission was quite fast that I just took several minutes in the queue.

You must come here it's a true treasure. Did you know that the famous explorer Vasco Da Gama is buried here. It's such a true treasure dating back to the 15th Century. It's right across the street from Casa Belem, so you can run over and get some of their famous pastries. Stunning does not begin to describe this place a must see on your tour of Lisbon.

Possibly the highlight of Lisbon. We visited the Torre first and bought the combined ticket which allowed us to avoid the queue at the Monastery. Note also that the church itself was closed due to a wedding (Saturday). It was interesting to watch peoples faces as they entered and their eyes adjusted to the highly decorated cloisters - definitely a 'wow'. The total building is huge and now used as museums. This area of Belem is worth a long visit as it has museums, modern art gallery and beautiful outdoor areas.

Another symbol of Lisbon. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos or Jeronimos Monastery. Jeronimos Monastery is in UNESCO World Heritage List. You'll face with a long queue when you arrive the monastery. But please note that If you want to visit only the monastery you don't have to queue. But if you want to visit garden too you have to wait. But I recommend you to wait. It has a nice garden and interior. Admission fee is 6 euros but free with lisbon card.

Exceptional place ,exclusive and stunning. We saved our church visitation for this big-kahuna,the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and were titillated by the fact that this masterbuilt building was financed by a"pepper tax" levied on spices,precious stones,spheres and gold. the walls of the refectory are tiled with 18th century azulejos. Simply stunning. We paid homage to Vasco de Gama at his tomb carved with ropes,spheres and seafaring symbols. into the cloister we marched,marvelling at the delicate tracery and richly carved images decorating the arches and balustrades. My femme loved the nave with its spectacular vaulting,held aloft by slender octagonal pillars,rising like palm trees to the roof creating a feeling of space and harmony. Lovely place.
Impressive. Must see...very impressive, fantastic architecture. Very huge place. Every corner seems meaningful. Feel of the past. Well maintained, very clean. Historic, religious. Impressive...

Absolutely stunning. All the guide books tell you to visit this stunning monastery in the afternoon, we did not take their advice and got there at 1030 just after it had opened and joined the very long queue to buy our tickets, approximately 45 mins. However it was so worth the wait when you walk into the Cloisters, the sun was shinning and it was absolutely stunning as you walk through the door. This really is a must see if you are in Lisbon. I would recommend taking the guide books advice as we went past later in the afternoon and there was no queue at all. I would also recommend buying the combined ticket that gives you entry to the Torre de Belem, this ticket means that you don't have to queue at the Torre you can go straight in, at 10 euro for the combined ticket there is also a small saving too.
Visited all the monastery - amazing. It's wonderful to see a historic monastery that's complete unlike in the UK were they destroyed. Carvings are amazing as shown in my photo.

Very Neat Monastery. You can go in the church for free if you don't have time to wait in line. Also, when I was there the line was very long; I was able to avoid the line because I bought a Comb ticket at the Tower of Belem. Every column in the courtyard of the monastery was different very cool.

Didn't see it all but very pretty. The queue was huge and it was close to closing so we didn't bother going in fully - but as a tip the massive church to the right hand side of the church is free to enter, so if you don't want to queue but want to see some fab architecture and get a taste of the monastery, do that! It's also right next to 2 museums and the Belem monument so it's a good spot to head to in general.
Monastery of Jeronimos catheral well worth seeing. Do to a lack of time, I only did the church, but very glad I did! I was amazing, no line and it was free!

The one place you must visit in Lisbon. I didn't really know what to expect and was a little daunted by size of the queue when we arrived. There are no public restrooms close to the queues and it took 50 minutes to get into the cloisters so be prepared. However, the wait was well worth it. You never felt that here were too many people there and you were able to view the magnificent stonework of the cloisters and architecture in peace. The statue of Christ on the Cross with the vaulted ceiling behind is amazing. The tombs of Luiz de Camoes and Vasco da Gama are in the main body of the church below.

Wonderful monastery - beautiful views.. The line at this monastery is REALLY long. Go to the Belem Tower first and get the ticket for the monastery there and then just go to the entrance. We had a Lisboa card and went to the Belem Tower first. The monastery is stunning as are the views. A must see.

Hour and a half wait for NOTHING!!!!. The Monastery is highly rated so we wanted to see it. Enduring a really bad tram 15 ride from Lisbon we saw a long line but decided to wait because it would certainly be worth it. We waited and waited and waited at a snail's pace while bus loads of school children went to the head of the line. Finally, after at least an hour and a half we paid our 7 euros per person and went in expecting to see a lot of really nice things. What we saw was a courtyard and the above view of the church. Nothing worth waiting even 15 minutes for. The church was very nice and when we exited the monastery we discovered that we could have walked directly to the church with no line and IT'S FREE! So the only thing worth seeing was free and there was no line. WHY DIDN'T SOMEBODY TELL US? An employee at the monastery should have announced this. I am also disappointed that no Trip Advisor writer told us this. If you go to Belem see the church for free but do not wait in the line and pay a very overpriced 7 euros to see the courtyard. Better yet, don't go to Belem unless you have some extra time in Lisbon (the Belem tower wasn't that great either). I absolutely love Lisbon, Sintra, and Cascais. See everything there before going to Belem.

Beautiful detailing. The monastery just recently celebrated their 500th anniversary. There is an excellent exhibit showing the timeline of the monastery as well as other events at those times. Very affordable but if you're on a really tight budget, it's free on Sundays before 2PM. The building is very beautiful and there is an incredible amount of detail on the columns, walls, arches, etc. It felt like no two columns were designed the same. Highly recommended.

Inspiring architecture in a great setting. The monastery was built by Dom Manual I in celebration of the nation's explorers and was built in a large scale. The cloisters are very impressive and have excellent carvings and sculptures on show. The church is also worth seeing especially the dome. It is after all a world heritage site. Also along side are the Archaeological and Maritime Museums located in buildings added on to the Monastery previously. The whole area of Belem is a definite must do on your list with lots to see. Don't miss the custard tarts from a bakery across the road just to the right of the Monastery called Antiga Confeitaria de Belem, very tasty. This is yet another of the great value Lisboa card free entry sites as is the Archaeological Museum with the Martime discounted. Again we must recommend this card to anyone staying a few days and aiming to visit some of the sites on the card, check out the website to see if it will help you. I think you may even get a discount if you prebook.

Most Excellent Monastery. I won't be able to say anything new to what people have already loved, but this was certainly an excellent sight seeing activity (not one I'd have chosen but my mum wanted to go!!) I'd certainly recommend it!

A must see in Lisbon. This is a wonderful Unesco world heritage site, Manueline stye architecture. Everything is built on an enormous scale, very decorative, opulent, wonderful workmanship. It was built by Prince Henry the Navigator when Portugal was the leader in world naval exploration. Vasco da Gama and his men spent their last night in Lisbon in prayer there before setting off to discover the New World. His tomb is near the entrance. The square Cloisters (which are huge) – richly decorated with sea motifs - ground floor with cloister garden, second floor with views down onto the garden. The Refectory has tiles from 17th century depicting story of Joseph. The Cathedral is enormous – richly decorated.Hint - visit toward end of afternoon – no queue

A day trip must see. We were staying in the Algarve over Christmas and took the opportunity to visit Lisbon on a one day coach outing. The Monastery of Jeronimos was the first port of call. What an absolute treat! The architecture is superb, built by Henry the Navigator in the 16th as a celebration of the Portuguese Sailors achievements, and is home to the tombs of Vasco da Gama and Camoes. The entrance price was included in our trip, but I believe it is free to enter before 14:00 on a Sunday. So, if you are staying in Lisbon, or have the opportunity to visit as we did, do visit this wonderful Unesco site for a memory that will linger long after many others have faded.

Amazing architecture. You don't really see much better than this when it come to grand designs!! Definitely well worth a visit, and pay the 7 euros to go inside too. You'll probably be frustrated that you can't fit it all into one decent photograph, it's so massive! If you are going to Belem from central Lisbon at the weekend and you didn't get up early enough like us, I advise not to attempt to get the bus (no 15 from outside the metro station) the queues are crazy long and chaotic. You may as well get the train it is only 3 euros and it's quicker, no queues and more comfortable I can imagine. If you arrive in the afternoon, wander around the park, see the towers, have some cake first and wait for the queue to go inside to die down. We only had to wait until about half three and the queue was much, much shorter.

Very nice. Stopped off from the bus tour to see the monastery.
First went inside a museum located next to the monastery, ticket cost 5 euros and you can see many wonderful exhibits.
The monastery is a unesco world heritage site with wonderful architecture, it was very popular and full of many tourists.

Unesco site of the Monastery of Jeronimos. Beautiful manueline architecture. The monastery was built by Henry the navigator and is well worth paying the entrance fee and is free on Sundays before 2pm. The arches around the cloisters and the splendid chapel with the stained glass windows. Vasco da gama is buried here and she would come and pray here before he set sail. Close by is the maritime museum and you can wander up the road and have a pasteis de belem.
Excellent. Really great. The monastery is very powerful, as well as the cathedral. Highly recommended on any visit to Lisbon.

Really Beautiful. It's an easy train ride to get here, and it is free on some Sundays (as it was when we visited),The que was quite long but there were young people out front singing with guitars and tambourines which was quite enjoyable. The monastery is lovely and contains the tombs of Vasco da Gama and Camoes. It's worth exploring, there's a lot to see. When you are through with you visit, head behind the monastery and turn right. Let the blue awning and que of people lead you to the delicious pastries of Belem!

incredible!! A Must of the Must sees in Lisbon. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is the best place I've visited in Portugal and of my all-time favorites!!  It was built in the 16th as a celebration of the Portuguese Sailors achievments and is a unique building which should be visited by everyone! Inside it there are many important Portuguese people tombs, with names such as Camões and Fernando Pessoa.
Great architecture. Very impressive building. It is very easy to get there by the 15 tram or bus or the 728 bus. walking around on your own is quite sufficient. no need for the audio guide.

A must see on a trip to Lisbon. It's worth leaving the centre of Lisbon to visit Belem and in particular the Monestery. You can wander parts for free, but I'd recommend also paying the small amount for further exploring.

Superb. We had a wonderful experience visiting this Monastery. It was free to enter as we were there before 14:00 on a Sunday. We were even lucky enough to go in the Church and see mass. The architecture is classy and the history of the place is enchanting.

Must see. This is the most stunning architectural gem. So easy to get to - we took the 15E tram from Praça do Comercio and hopped off straight outside the entrance. We had a Lisbon Card to saved the €7 entrance fee but we would have happily paid this to see the monastery. Words aren't sufficient to describe the experience - it's just a MUST SEE!

Brilliant architecture and fasinating history. Inside as well as outside the monastery is simply fantastic. The architecture is great and it is informative throughout both in Portugese and English (there are guides available in several languages for 1 euro)The history thoughout is wonderful and a must visit when in Belem. It is free with the Lisbon card or a few euros cost.
A good experience. It was a very nice visit. Specially the room where there's the exhibition with the timelime, showing Postugal's history, Brazil's history and the history of the Monastery.

Simply Beautiful. This was a lovely area to walk around. The inside of the Monastery itself is quite stunning, and all the moreso when you find the graves of Prince Henry and Vasco da Gama. The Monastery also hosts a number of museums like the Maritime Museum and the Archeological Museum. This is a must-visit if you're in Lisbon.

Stunning architecture. We visited the church on a very rainy day, but the church was beautiful. I may be brighter inside when the sun is out, but the towering arches and pillars are majestic.While light is a challenge, we still managed to see everything clearly and there is plenty of room to walk about and see all the decoration. It may be a bit rough in it's finishes, but it's an impressive sight

Very impressive. Very Special local bakery with special little pastries "Pastel Nata". Very close to Torre de Belem, Centro Cultural de Belem and Fundação Champalimaud (with nice Restaurant to go, but a little expensive for Lisbon)

Wonderful. I agree with others, it is worth the time and effort. If you are considering a Lisboa card, this site is free with that card. If you want a fun bit from Lisbon to Belem have a go with the 18 E trolly to the Palace stop above Belem, then walk down the hill. I took the 15 E back to Lisbon. The Monastery reminded me of several places I saw in India, truly worth a look.

The scale is so impressive. We didn't have a great deal of time to see this attraction but we did get to view a small part of the whole area but the guide pointed out many things including the final resting place of Vasco da Gama. Thoroughly enjoyed but would have needed a bit longer to really do it justice.

Magnificent. The Monastery of Jeronimos is everything that you would expect when visiting a UNESCO World Heritage site! The scale of this immense structure is overwhelming on it's own - and mindboggling when you look at the intricate detail of the architecture both inside and out of the building!Lisbon is one of those cities that already calls me back again -- feeling like there was so much left unseen and unappreciated during my short stay!

A must see if you visit Lisbon. The monastery is absolutely huge and visibly stunning especially the exquisitely carved stone in the cloisters. One of the most beautiful buildings I have ever visited. When the sun hits the stone it has a wonderful golden glow. Lovely gardens and fountains to the front. Visiting it can be combined with a visit to the Discovery Monument accessed by a subway and Belem tower a short walk along the water front.

Beautiful and a place to contemplation. I like it more than torre de belem,wich is also beautiful but the monastery takes you back to history,a place where you stop to feel the silence,to make reflections and after or before the visit you should go to the fabric of pastel de belem.

Fantastic. This is possibly the most impressive building in Portugal. It's white carved walls just take the breath away and it is so photogenic from across the gardens and fountains in front. My friend who has been "everywhere", even the Taj Mahal, was wowed. Inside it is huge and jam-packed with the most wonderful carvings and paintings and glass windows. It is stunning and overwhelming. I would go back over and over again. The coach museum is in the same overall building and is well worth visiting. The tram 28 takes a scenic route to it, if you go on the 7 hills pass, the same tram going to the castle.

Magnificent. The size!
We took a group bus which took us to the Monastery, Tower of Bellem and the Monument of Discoveries. What a rush! The Monastery is huge. No fee is required. There is the tomb of Vasco de Gama and Camoes, the most important Portuguese poet.
Worth a visit.
A special place. This is one of the most special places we have ever visited. From here it's hard to go because it's so much to see ... tmosfera, mystique, dignity. Beautifully.

Impressive, huge, amazing architecture & history. Best to experience the monastery with a knowledgeable guide... I say that because after seeing many cathedrals and gigantic old buildings, they lose their significant character unless a person with knowledge of history - and nuanced stories to tell about the place - is available for filling in the cold blanks from written guide books.... why it was built, special things that happened there, how it has been preserved. The architecture, for something built so many centuries ago, is magnificent - this was an interesting history lessor in a beautiful place.
Visit. Great historic place to see. Easy to get by car, by red bus or by train. There are graves of Vasco da Gama and Camoes. Too old and too interesting place to see. There's a history of Portugal.
A highlight in Lisbon. A large and very impressive monastery and cloister. We walked throughout the whole area including the upstairs. It was very crowded. Took lots of photos (a few are attached).

One of the most impressive sites in Lisbon. We had just walked from Belem tower, which had been underwhelming inside, so we were pleasantly surprised when venturing inside this wonderful building. There were massive queues, even though it was pouring with rain, so we were lucky to have a combined ticket already bought from the tower, which allowed us to walk straight in. The cloisters are the real draw, with impressible architecture and art throughout, as well as some fairly interesting historical exhibitions. We then went into the church, where Vasco de Gama is buried, and which i think is free. Worthwhile though to pay to go into the cloisters too

Impressively amazing. Absolutely beautiful cloister, sacristy and choir area. Even in the rain, watching the water running through the gargoyle spouts was fascinating. For history buffs there is cool timeline trilogy of events during the history of St. Jeronimoes, Portugal and the world. This was on our top 5 highlight list over 10 days in Portugal.

Exquisite Gothic Detail. A must see; a masterpiece of Manueline-style architecture. One of the most detailed gothic churches I have seen. 16th century. A UNESCO Heritage site. Started by Henry the Navigator, it remains a church of special importance to sailors. Also, a monument to the riches that Portugal amassed from its seafaring history of exploration, exploitation and trade. The architectural details and exquisite carvings contain maritime references such as the carved roping on the columns. It contains several royal tombs as well as the tomb of Vasco da Gama.

Monastery and Cloisters. Monastry ( no entrance fee )Jeronimos monastry, a 16th century marvel built on the banks of River Tagus, is a unesco world heritage site. The monastry derives its name from the order of St.Jerome. King Manuel I had the idea of erecting a large monastery close to the site where Henry the Navigator had built a church dedicated to Santa Maria de Belém in the 15th century. With a view to perpetuating the memory of Henry and acknowledging his own great devotion to Our Lady and St. Jerome, Manuel I chose to establish the Monastery of Santa Maria de Belém outside of LisbonCloistersEntry fee of 7euro was charged but is well worth the fee. Photographers will have a great time shooting the second floor views and the decorated walls and hallsThe cloister had a religious function as well as a representative function by its decorative ornamentation and the dynastic symbolic motives, such as the armillarium, coat-of-arms, and the cross from the Order of Christ, showing the growing world power of Portugal.

Stunning!. This 16th century monastery is a true marvel.There's so much to see: the beautiful fountain on the ground floor, the refectory with its lovely tiles, the stunning south gate of the monastery with its beautiful decorations, the church with its impressive nave, and of course – the stunning cloister with its beautiful carvings.The entire place literally oozes photo-ops and a complete visit here ought to take 60-90 minutes.Free with the LisboaCard.Highly recommended!

Another incredible place. Inside or out, the detail of the Monastery is quite something. The opulence is evident in the paintings/altars, the fret work on the walls, archways and pillars and the size of the building itself. Just when you think you have seen everything you enter this amazingly large courtyard that is beautiful by itself. Definitely worthy of a visit - even if you love art/ architecture or seeing something different (rather than just religious sites.)

Breathtaking. I arrived just before closing time and was able to see all of it within an hour, however that does not mean I was able to soak it all in. The architecture was simply breathtaking with the best view being inside the courtyard. You can take a trip up to the second level and see the church from the inside. It was a bit crowded and I wish I had arrived earlier on in the day so I had enough time to enjoy the experience.

Beautiful (and crowded).. The church is free while the cloisters requires a fee, but it is all free with the Lisboa Card. It was raining when we arrived and there were loads of tour busses, so we appreciated that all we had to do was flash the card and they waived us through. There are some interesting displays in the cloisters so it is definitely worth seeing. The church is very pretty but the tour groups parked in front of the altar and the tombs were extremely annoying.

Spectacular Inside And Out. This is a Do Not Miss attraction is ever there was one. The Building is stunning even from a distance and the beauty of the courtyard and the interior is indescribable. Without a doubt one of the finest of all the old churches I've seen in Europe. It is located near the waterfront in Belem, close to the Tower and the Discoveries monument. The area is so beautiful and historic that it is a highlight of any visit to Lisbon. The Monastery is without a doubt the jewel in the crown though. Don't miss Vasco Da Gama's tomb near the entrance. Absolutely lovely place and fascinating place.

Worth a visit in Lisbon. The architecture of the monastery was amazing as were the grounds. We ended up paying to go into the actual monastery instead of just visiting the free church and it was well worth the cost. If you're not a fan of UNESCO sites or great architecture you may want to skip it. I however am a fan of both so I thoroughly enjoyed the visit.We made an afternoon of it by by staying in Belem a bit to have lunch and walking around the area. It was Sunday and there was a great outside artisan market to peruse and enjoy the wares on sale on a sunny day. We took a bus down to get to Belem and then we took a tram back to get to the center of town. We could have easily spent a few more hours there so this is definitely a great morning or afternoon of exploring. During your Lisbon holiday.

A Beautiful Monastery. By chance we went on Sunday so it was free as has been mentioned by other reviewers. It is a beautiful monastery. There is restricted access to the Church as if there is mass on but somehow when we finished our visit there was a gap in-between so we managed to see the interior of the church. A must visit place and i would put it over the Belem Tower.Wide open space with small exhibition inside one of the rooms.

A truly beautiful building. This is one of the most attractive religious buildings we have visited in Europe and it makes the trip to Belem worth it by itself, disregarding the added attraction of the Belem tower. The ornate stonework and the great architecture makes it a place one should visit if in Lisbon. Just take the tram or bus from the Black Horse Square.

Beautiful - and free on Sunday. Not sure if it's every Sunday, but when we went it was free on Sunday, as was the Belem Tower. We went early to beat the crowds not realising it was free, and it was well worth it, so worth checking out before you travel. The monastery is absolutely beautiful - probably the best place we visited in the whole of Lisbon. An absolute must see!!

Rich in detail of the Manueline style. Located in the suburb of Belem about a 15-minute taxi ride from downtown Lisbon, the Monastery is huge, and apart from admiring the exterior, we concentrated on the Church of Santa Maria. Work began in 1501, and took 100 years to complete. This late Gothic building has an airy feeling; Manueline symbols and elements cover the limited columns in the aisles and naves, producing an airy and open interior. Walk along the exterior walls and you'll pass tombs of both Portuguese and Austrian royalty. The tomb of Portugal's famed navigator Vasco da Gama also lies within the Church. But it is the detail of the building itself - both inside and out - which makes the trip worthwhile. The Monastery houses several exhibition areas which change regularly, so go online to see current offerings and to purchase tickets.

Worth the wait on line.. Yes, the line was long and in extreme heat but certainly worth it. Walk along its exterior, sit in its cloisters, admire the great paintings, tombs, and just do all you can to take in this great piece of history, art, and architecture. Done in amazing detail as the Manueline style dictates, there's just so much to see.

A Must. Just in short : a must when you stay in Lisbon. One of the highlight of my visit in Lisbon. With Lisboa card free without 7€. Sometimes long cues in high season. But do not miss it. Nice monestery. Build with money earned with trade in India. " faboulous wealth from India" .

Breathtaking!. We came here after visiting casa de Pasteis belem as we were nearby. The 7€ entrance fee seemed a lot to me but upon entering we were speechless. Inside lies a beautiful courtyard, which on a sunny day as it was when we were visiting, lights up. It was really worth it just to see that in my opinion. We then went upstairs where we were in part of the church and the upper tier of the courtyard where we could look down at this stunning haven. If you are in the area it is well worth the visit just to have your breath taken away if nothing else.

Gorgeous. This site in Lisbon is not to be missed. The cathedral is still open and draws large crowds but the monastery portion of the large building is now a maritime museum that is really worth the trip and the museum shop has a really great selection of maritime gifts (something for everyone).

Enormous and another example of the Catholic Church's excesses.. The overall size cannot fail to impress you when you first see it. It sprawls over an entire block and unlike most buildings, religious and otherwise, is actually in pretty decent shape.... not perfect but very good. As you would expect the cathedral part is quite cavernous but it is the cloisters that are most impressive. When you see the majesty of the place combined with the treasures inside you can just imagine how the church bled the people to finance such extravagance. All over Lisbon you see homeless people begging and sleeping in the streets but the churches lie empty at night.

Amazing. This is definitely worth a visit, so much to see in this area. The monastery itself has a fee but worth going inside and seeing the stained glass, tombs and the amazing architecture inside and carvings. While you are over on this side of town you should go to the Discoveries Monument and Belem Tour as well as the Coach Museum.

Restoration makes it noisy. There is a lot to see in this area but we must have hit the monastery on a bad day. Much of it was closed but the church was too crowded for peaceful contemplation. More importantly there is ongoing restoration work inside which is very disruptive and noisy. Nevertheless the tombs of Vasco da Gama and Henry the Navigator are world class. Entrance is free but it is worth paying €1 for the cloisters which are remarkable.

Amazing. The Monastery of Jeronimos in Lisbon, Portugal is truly worth visiting. From the amazing carved stone spires in the church to the amazingly carved cloisters this pace is fascinating. The monastery is is the Emanueline style which is unique to Portugal.

Amazing Architecture. We visited this monastery thinking it would be just another church but it is a large and beautiful building with ornate stone carvings around a central courtyard. There are also exhibits to see within the monastery which are very informative. Definitely worth a visit.

Must see in Lisbon!. Definitely take a trip to Belem to see this and the other attractions there. The architecture is not just beautiful, but really amazing! The detail is incredible. Amazing statue of Henry the Navigator and the tomb of Vasco da Gama inside!!
Beautiful place. Free entrance on Sunday mornings. We loved it so much. We didn't went to church. It's a must see when in Lisbon.

Beautiful and tranquil place. If you have more than one day in Lisbon, I'd recommend you to take the train to Belem and spend a day walking around seeing the beautiful sites along the waterside. The main attraction is Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. There is not an awful lot to see inside, but what makes it so attractive is the building style (Manueline style). It is a typical Portuguese style (you won't see it anywhere else) and this monastery gives you a really clear idea about what Manueline style is. It is a very peaceful place and once you've seen it, you must walk down the road to Pasteis de Belem for Lisbon's best Pastel de Nata (we got the tip from a local Lisbonese, and it is well worth taking. It is cheap, old setting with plenty of room in the back and, honestly, the best Pastel de Nata in Lisbon). For us Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and surroundings were one of the best experiences in Lisbon, so highly recommend you to go.

the best attraction in belem. this is the top thing to see if you pass through belem, the arhitecture of the monastery is stunning, especially the view from the interior garden. buy a combined ticket for both the tower of belem and the monastery it's only 10E and you can skip the line an the second attraction, i think there is also the possibility to book online. don't miss the tomb of vasco da gama and camoes, one of the greates portuguese poets, inside the church.you can get here from lisbon with tram 15 or the train from cais do sodre train station. i would recommend the train.
