Vasco da Gama. The outside's gorgeous, particularly the high, white Manueline entrance with the statue of Henry the Navigator, and the inside's fabulous too. See the tombs of Vasco da Gama, discoverer of the sea route to India, and Camoes, the greatest Portuguese poet (who also travelled to India). The cloister's lovely too. See what maritime motifs you can spot amongst the arabesques of the tracery - navigational instruments, sea snakes... Somehow I'd got the idea that there was a nautical museum in the monastery. Well if there was I couldn't find it. If you've got a ticket for the City Sightseeing hop-on hop-off bus it'll take you from here to Belem Tower, which is convenient if it's hot or raining, or you just don't feel like walking. Be careful you know where the bus stops.

Must see in Lisbon!!!. Beautiful!!! Not to be missed! The church and the monastery are truly a work of art. Tram 15 stops right outside. Be sure to get a ticket before (1.40 euro) otherwise it's 2.85 on the tram and the machine only excepts coin. There is also a Tram 15 stop just outside metro stop Cais do Sodre (green line). The Tram follows the coast so its possible to stop at the Museu Nacional dos coches, Padrao dos desobrimentos and further on Tower of Belem. It's necessary to cross under/over the busy street to get to Padrao dos desobrimentos and Tower of Belem.

Atmospheric and wonderful architecture. Really enjoyed our visit to this site in Belem. Architecture and atmosphere lovely. Spent a couple of hours taking some great photos. Only criticism was that it was a really hot day and, though there was a gift shop, there was nowhere to buy a drink or even a bottle of water. So get some before you go in!!

magnificient monument. Great building and I wished I booked a tour, so I could "see" what it was like at the time to live there. But it was good to wander about and see the workmanship. It was free entry with the Lisbon card and I didn`t have to wait on the line with card as well.If you go this monument, make sure to visit the Belem Tower and the Padrao dos descobrimentos.

Impressive Jeronimos Monastery. We visited this iconic attraction on 6 July 2013 during our maiden visit to Lisbon Portugal. On a sunny summer morning, we took the famous tram no.15 from Figuera Square and set out for Belem. We had purchased the useful Lisboa Card by virtue of which all public transport rides were free as also the entry to famous attractions such as Jeronimos Monastery, Belem Tower & Santa Justa Elevator.The comfortable journey took us about 40 minutes to reach the monastery.The Jeronimos Monastery is possibly Portugal's most historical monument located in Belem along the river Tagus. The monastery has an opulent church and cloistered garden built in the elegant Manuelian style in addition to the monastery quarters built in the beginning of the 16th century when Portugal was a great sea-going power. There are several sights in close proximity such as the Archaeological Museum located in the same premises in adition to the emblematic Belem Tower and the Monument of Discoveris located within walking distance. The setting of this historic monastery is quite scenic due the overlooking beautiful Praca de Imperio.This monastery will definitely feature in must do list when visiting Lisbon.

beautiful architecture. The monastery is a 30ish minute train ride from Lisbon (spend the day and visit a few sites). Beautiful architecture and example of Portugal's long ago wealth. 7 euro entry fee/person.

Lovely large Manueline building. Cloister shady with seating. Refectory and chapel quite large. I have to wonder why convents are less imposing and impressive. Be warned tourists are numerous in Belem and Sintrs

Very nice. Very interesting and beautiful example of manueline architecture. I especially liked the beautiful ceiling and pillars of the church and the wonderful portals. Do not miss the tombs of Vasco da Gama and De Camões.
A must see. Make sure you visit,beautiful building and surroundings,it really has the wow factor.Belem is a lovely area of the city not to be missed.

Very Impressive. This site is amazing. It's a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The architecture is wonderful. I really like the interior with its intricate stonework, stained glass, and massive ceilings full of art. What a treat to see this place.

Incredible!!!!!!!. WOW, Monastery of Jeronimos is Incredible!!!!!!! The architecture is unbelievable, especially if you take into consideration the construction tools available during the period in which it was built. My family and I were blown away when we first walked in and that feeling lasted throughout the entire visit. It's quite breathtaking and it's hard to even explain, it's just something you have to see in person. Go early to avoid the crowds, we did and it was totally worth it!!Highly Recommended!!!!!!!
beautiful monastery. Amazing monastery in the Belem quarter, not far from the Tower. Inside amazing architectural finesse ,wel preserve and beautifully presented...worth a visit

Impressed me much. I must say I was impressed. I like Gothic architecture very much and seen a lot, but I've never seen the Manuelin style before. Definitely worth seeing, if you fancy Gothic - especially main portal, richly decorated, with sculptures presenting famous Portuguese explorers.
Love BELEM!. Incredible and impressive monastery in beautiful Belem district of Lisboa. Long line around noon but it moves quickly. Free entry was a plus. Must see!
Gorgeous. Absolutely beautiful. The cloisters and carvings and history here are something to be marveled. Would recommend spending about 2-3 hours to really appreciate everything here.

WOW. Free Entry when I went (pointless as I had the Lisboa Card anyways). Absolutely incredible. The detail to the architecture was astounding. There was a bit of a long line in very hot weather but it was definitely worth it. I went on a Sunday and had to wait to enter the church as it was closed for mass. Eventually I entered and it is as impressive as the best chuches in Europe. Do not miss this Monastery.

lisbon culture for free. We went to the monastery on a Sunday as it was advertised as free entry before 2pm. (Normally approx. 6 Euros). The queues were very long to enter as we got there around 12 (earlier would have been better). we spend around fifteen minutes queuing but as it was hot (28c with no shade), it was harder than we thought. On entering the monastery we immediately realised what all the fuss was for.This beautiful gothic revival example was packed with architectural gems, from the ancient cloisters to the intricate carving. The exterior of the building is beautiful but its interior takes your breath away. You can buy gifts at the shop or go to the church attached if you want a more religious feel. Mass was going on so be aware there are restrictions on Sundays. Avoid the crowds and go early , but be careful if the market opposite is open as pickpockets operate there.Overall I am overwhelmed that I finally got to see one of Lisbon's crown jewels. A must see.
Amazing Cloister!. Beautiful place and huge. The detail in the Cloister is amazing. The main sanctuary is very old and pretty too. People need to remember it's a church! Whisper or just be quiet!

Beautiful Architecture and Photo Opportunities. Me, my partner and another couple visited in June this year purchasing the joint ticket with the Tower of Belem, which was much better value than buying separate tickets. The monastery has some very beautiful architecture and the stone work is incredible, our photographer companions were very happy to snap away for all of our visit. I recommend taking a look in the old dining hall as the tile work is very interesting and amusing. The only downside to this attraction is the lack of interactivity in the exhibitions, which were fine for me but my boyfriend found them quite boring.

A must see. Nice to know some things haven't changed much over the last 500 years. King Manuel 1 financed this beautiful structure with "pepper money", a tax levied on spices, precious stones and gold brought back from trade with Africa and the Orient.There are a number of outstanding areas. The Main Chapel is an excellent example of Mannerist art which is a contrast to the Church's Manueline main structure. Several of the tombs (including Manuel 1) are supported by elephants. The spectacular vaulting in the church nave is held aloft by slender octagonal pillars that rise like palm trees to the roof. One of our favourite areas is the High Choir complete with pictures of the Apostles and the Image of Christ on the Cross in painted wood. Another featured area is the Cloister, a peaceful place for St. Jerome's monks to pray and meditate. This is probably the most significant example of Manueline style architecture. The arches and balustrades are covered in delicate tracery and richly carved religious and royal symbols. Well worth a few hours tour. Can be combined with the Tower of Belem and The Monument to the Discoveries when in Belem. All are free entry with the Lisboa Card.

Beautiful and unexpected cloister. Well worth a short visit. The cloister is beautifully preserved and was a tranquil break from touring. Located next door to the cathedral and a short walk from THE pastry shop.

Definitely worth a visit. If you're in Lisbon for at least 2-3 days, spending half a day (or whole day) in Belem is a must. It's a pleasant and relaxing place to discover. The monastery was the most beautiful and interesting attraction there in my opinion. Don't miss the other attractions: monument of discoveries, Belem tower and amazing pasteis de natas!! By the way, if you buy the Lisboa card, you'll have free entrance here (and also at the Belem tower and free transportation from Lisbon) so it's worth buying it if you plan on going to Belem.

Beautiful Manueline architecture. Unique to Portugal is the Manueline style of architecture. I was not aware of this before I visited this monastery. The style consists of a combination of early Renaissance, Gothic, and Moorish and involves a lot of detailed and elaborate sculpture.The church is beautiful and quite elaborate, but the cloisters have the most Manueline sculpture and are just breathtaking. The Monastery is where the tombs are of both royalty and famous Portugese, and this is where the tomb is of Vasco de Gama. Wonderful place to visit.Across the park from the monastery is the Belem Tower, also part of this World Heritage Site. It is now on the bank of the Tagus River but was originally built as a fort in the middle of the river. Built in 1515, the river has changed its course over time, so the fort is not where it should be now. Most interesting.Visit both of these when you are in Belem as well as the Monument to the Discoveries, which we did not have time to see.

Beautiful Belem-Lisbon. There are three interesting monuments in this area and they are very close to each other so you can visit all of them once you are there. 1. Jeronimos monastery: Construction of this monastery started in 1501 and finished after 70 years. During this period 70 kg.s of gold had been spent each year to finance the construction.The architectural style of this monastery is called Manueline which is a mixture of Gothic and Renaissance.2. Torre de Belem (Belem Tower).This tower was built as a fortified lighthouse during the reign of Dom Manuel (1515-1520) to guard the entrance to the port.3. Podrao dos Descobrimentos (Monument to the Discoveries): Belem is the place where the great Portuguese explorers set off on their voyages of discovery. Vasco de Gama for India in 1497 and Pedro Alvares Cabral for Brazil in 1499.

Use " Hop On / Off Bus for 12 euros for Belem Tower, Jeronimo Monastery and Nice Gardens Opposite. We visited third week of June. Our Tip - We bought an 18 euro, two line ticket, valid for 48 hours, that covers two routes ( i.e. 9 euros per route), which includes the Belem Tower / Jeronimos Monstery on one of the lines. If you buy a single tour ticket it is 12 euros.The tower is worth the visit and has a beautiful view. The Monastery was also very nice.Very nice gardens across from the Monastery, where we relaxed between attractions.
Well worth a visit. We visited after the Belem Tower and before stopping by the Casa Pasteis de Belem. It was well worth it. A lovely place to visit and great view into Lisbon and Portugal's history.

Monastery of Jeronimos. When visit Belem Tower, you will no miss Monastery of Jeronimos and Discovery Monument, since they are so close and walking distance.Even no as impressive like Belem Tower and Discovery Monument, but together, they are represent the great glory past of Portugal, especially their contribution on age of voyage and discovery.The place the one really make me impression is actually those gallery and the central square inside the building. See the photo I shot.

Arrive early to avoid the tour groups. The tour groups clog up the ticket desk area and the guides seem to think that their party has priority over everyone else, particularly individual travelers. However once you cope with this minor inconvenience the church and the cloisters have amazing architecture and history. A good guidebook is essential to gain the most benefit from the visit.

You really didn't know this was a world heritage?!. Absolutely amazing architecture! An absolute must see when in Lisboa! Take the tram from the city (or the bus - a bit slower and more crowded) and you will be rewarded with an experience of one of the most dazzling world heritages. Take a look at my pictures - they say more than words. Go there!

Gorgeous!. we went on sundaymorning because most of the sites in Belem are free on sunday till 14h. We were there around 10.30 and it was very crowed, best if you would go around 12-ish. The monastery is really gorgeous! inside it looks really amazing and the church is also a real beauty. Just keep in mind that they do mass on sundaymorning in the church.

Spectacular! Loved the cloister most of all. There was a slow-moving line to get to buy tickets for the cloister at Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. But once a particularly large tour group moved along, it didn't take too long to get to the head of the line.And we were very glad that we bought the tickets, instead of just seeing the sanctuary/church, which is free. The cloisters were utterly spectacular - a wealth of Renaissance/Manueline ornamentation. No two sections of the cloister were alike, each was unique and spellbinding at that.By contrast, the front half of the church was dark, and it was very hard to take a good picture there, even for my camera, which usually does very well in low light. The view from the choir loft in the back was a bit better - there was some natural light as I remember, and you could get a good view of the extraordinary pillars - once again, covered like all else in gorgeous ornaments.

Beautiful Church and the Discovery monument. Belem monastery is very beautiful with intricate carvings and complex art work on the building. Its equally beautiful from the inside as well. The place is kept clean and tidy as visitors throng throughout all day to the church. The gardens opposite the monastery are splendid as well. The Discovery monument is just opposite to the church and is simply awesome.A great day out to Belem from Lisbon, which takes apprx 15-20 min by tram most of the attractions in Lisbon give discounts to students, you dont have to show any proofs for that.

Manueline Masterpiece! Best of Belem!. An absolute masterpiece built in 1502 by King Manuel I to commemorate Vasco Da Gama's voyage and to give thanks to the Virgin Mary for its success, the Jeronimos Monastery is rich in ornate design that incorporates carved limestone sculptural themes of maritime objects and items discovered during naval expeditions. Inside the monastery entrnce you will find the ornate tombs of Vasco da Gama & the celebrated Portugese poet, Luis de Camões.Don't miss the magnificent cloisters with its columns of carved ropes, coral, sea serpents & other sea motifs. Location: Praça do Império, Belem (Tram 15E)Open:10AM-6PM (Closed Mondays) Admission: Church is free - Cloisters: €6 (free with Lisboa Card) or €10 combo ticket (includes Jeronimos Cloisters & Belem Tower) - Senior Discount: 50%Website: http://www.mosteirojeronimos.pt/en/

Stunning. One thing I always find when visiting ancient cities in Europe is that despite the beauty and opulence of the churches you eventually get 'burnt out' on them after seeing too many in too short a time. If there is one church that you see when in Lisbon though, make it this one. It is quite simply breathtaking, beautiful architecture abounds. You feel in awe simply walking around.Pro-tip: if you do decide to visit be sure to purchase a LISBOA card from tourist information...the card not only gives you free admission to the monastery (and Torre de Belem incidentally) but free public transport to get you to and from Belem

Beautiful architecture. The Monastery was built in gratitude to the Virgin Mary for the successful voyage of Vasco de Gama to India. The architecture is manueline architecture, a style which has gothic, moorish and renaissance influence. The monastery contains the tombs of Vasco de Gama, King Manuel and other Portuguese royalty. Very impressive. Don't miss the Tower of Belem and the Monument of Discovery which are also in the same area.

A marvelous and beautiful monument. The monastery, today a museum, is above all else, a wonderful piece of architecture, encompassing history within it's several styles, because it took a long while to build: from the Gothic to the Renaissance, and the very specific Portuguese renaissance style, the 'Manuelino' thus called as a tribute to the King of its period, Manuel I (1469-1521) who reigned between 1495-1521, the Monastery contains the tombs of Portugal's Poet Laureate Camões, Portugal's Vasco da Gama, discoverer of the maritime way to India, and of Fernando Pessoa, Portugal's most famous modern poet, who died in 1935. The cloisters, the church, the gardens, they all provide a most wonderful visit and souvenir!
Great Views. This place is amazing... never knew how big it was. make sure u go at the right time as the queues are long.... and say hello to the horse outside

Very well done, tons of history, highlight of Belem. This is really THE reason to go to Belem. An expansive and impressive structure with some really neat views (including de Gama's tomb). Some very good ancillary historical displays that show how the monastery integrated with the history of Portugal and the world.

Best in Belem. The Belem area is worth visiting and the Monastery is the highlight. The coisters are beautiful and worth the small entrance fee. On the upper level there is a timeline of the history or Portugal which is fascinating. You also get a great view of the Church interior at this level. Watch out for the bus loades of tourists as they tend to swap the best viewing points. So take your time and enjoy.

Exquisite Manueline monastery, look closely!. Start your day in Belem with this exquisite place, which features elephants holding up sarcophagi and magnificent carvings inside and out. If you look closely, you'll spot a grasshopper flying buttress in the cloisters and the image of Saint Ursula holding her eyes on a plate. I kid you not. It all looks so symmetrical, but each and every inch of the exterior is telling a different story. Wonders abound. Too bad the original rooms of the religious are not on view, but one can't have everything. A find!

Amazing, amazing, amazing. You must visit this place. And go there when you have time to just enjoy walking around both outside and inside. Avoid long touristy lines and don't worry about taking photos. They will not reveal he splendour anyway. Just Enjoy the memories.
Great arquitecture. This is one of the most beautiful monuments in Lisbon. You will like the sun on the central garden and all the little details in every inch of this place. Discover.
A must in Belem.. The most important place to visit in Belem. The architecture is imposing. The church is stunning. The tomb of Vasco Da Gama is inside the church. Just Beautiful.
Fabulous Monastery. Gorgeous setting, definitely worth a visit.....beautiful architecture. Include this visit with the Belem Tower and a boat trip back up the river to the City center.

Masterpiece of the "Manuelino" style. This is one of the most amazing monuments in Lisboa. You can visit the church for free, and that will allow you to get a nice idea of the wealth that Portugal had at that time (early 16th century). You can also check the tombs of Luis de Camões (the greatest Portuguese poet) and Vasco da Gama.You have to pay to see the beautiful cloysters, but it is worth it.Please bear in mind It can be VERY crowded, so my advice is to go as early in the morning as you can...and after the visit go to the famous Pasteis De Belém...and have a couple of them...you have earned them.
Stunning. Worth a visit as its really beautiful, check for opening and closing times first. Stunning architecture.

One of the best place I have seen in Lisobon. I love it! But I like monastery buildings:) The way the monastery is build is fantastic - and the ambulatory - just fantastic - but the weather needs to be nice to appreciate it.
Impressive. This is a must-visit monument in Lisbon. Its architectonic style is inedit, and the dimensions are crazy.

One of THE attractions in Lisbon. An air of tranquillity pervades this place.You feel far away from the frenetic life of the large city.
The chapel and cloisters evoke a long lost era and are beautifully decorated. Do take photos of the cloister architecture a masterpiece of medieval Portugal.

Must see building in Lisbon. The monastery is one of these places that look like taken from a fairy tale. The mix of late Gothic style with the very Portuguese style "manueline", makes this monastery one of Lisbon most iconic monuments! The cloisters are superb and the chapel altar is beautiful!

Astounding architecture. We have seen many monasteries but this one is one of our top 3. The unique Manueline style is new to us and offered me, an iPhone photographer many angles, shadows and views to play with. We used the discount with our Lisbon card which we highly recommend for taking the subway and bus around Lisbon and for entries to museums and other sights. We were there easily for 2.5 hours.
Ethereal... Very beautiful, peaceful and worth visiting... if you appreciate religious sites, of which it is the best in Lisbon.
Magnificent monument. Facing such a magnificent architectural work, realizing the greatness of that workmanship, we are taken to think about the Great Portuguese people can be.
A real gem. I wrote the review on the "Belem" page and I'd not repeat myself. Just excellent and worth visiting.

Simply Amazing. In our weeklong trip to Portugal, this was probably our favorite location. The exterior and interior of the building are outstanding. Even though there were crowds of people, we found the courtyard to be strangely peaceful. The cathedral inside was also very impressive. Our only disappointment is that we were not able to attend mass, which occurs daily in the early morning and late afternoon. If you are interested, it would be worth checking the times in advance.There is a joint admission ticket available with the Tower of Belem, which is about a 15 min walk away.

Wonderful. It was a short journey out to Belem, and los Jeronimos was the best monument we visited in Lisbon.The interior of the church is beautiful (and free), you only have to pay to visit the cloisters, which were serene despite the visitors- the grass growing in the roof tiles and gutters brought a whole new meaning to "green roof".The timeline comparing world history to the history of Portugal was worth the entrance fee alone.

Exceptional. If you do one thing in Belem, it has to be this.. The scale and workmanship of the building are inspiring. It is useful to read a bit about it before visiting, and this adds to the experience. Don't rush round. The building has a calming effect and must be appreciated.
April in Portugal. The monastery is wonderful and make sure to find the Pasteis of Belem just down the street and enjoy the delicious local delicacy - warm creme cakes!!!!

Beautiful. Aside from the amazing exterior architecture, take the time and go inside. Very somber beauty. We ducked inside after leaving the Maritime Museum, which is on the opposite end of the Monastery.

Huge monastery. Beautifully carved interiors, and huge courtyard. Great for kids on a sunny day. They could run and laugh and play and nobody objected while we enjoyed the beauty. We heard they have a fountain in the summer days. Also saw Vasco Da Gama's tomb here and the beautiful cathedral. Loved our time here.

Beautiful!!. The monastary is very beautiful, the feeling of being in such a place is great. With the sun shining and so much history it was a great experience. We bought a Liboa Card the monument was free in that and we did not need to stand in the long queues for tickets.

Simply Amazing. The Monastery of Jeronimos is some of the most beautiful architecture we have ever seen. The place is very large and sits on the ocean front. The tombs inside are incredible. I suggest buying a 48 hour hop on hop off pass with Grey Line tours which will allow you to see any and all sites in Lisbon and surrounding areas. The price is only 25 euro! Very comfortable and clean. This is a must see site.

Beautiful Architecture. This church and surrounding buildings are worth a visit. The ornate architecture is very unique and the inside of the church itself is beautiful. Many of the nearby museums offer free entry before 2:00pm on sundays. We stopped at the Maritime Museum as well and were glad we didn't pay admission (it is mainly just models of ships) but it was a nice short walk through.
so beautiful!. Really loved this beautiful and historic church. So glad to have visited, very peaceful. Gorgeous art.
impressive. Very nice architecture , i definitly recommend everyone to go and visit it. The interior is very impressive you must see to believe.

Amazing architecture. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos was the most amazing thing that i saw in Lisbon.Amazing architecture.And also here you can learn a little history of Portugal.And it is close to Belem tower.Do not miss it.

Beautiful. Great structure, we took many pictures. The architecture is stunning. The tombs of the local heroes are beautiful. Another place I will always remember. Hard to believe so much history in one location. One word beautiful

Grand.... Awe inspiring and majestic, the Jeronimos Monastery was built in16th century and has been classified by UNESCO as World Heritage Site.Very well preserved, with internal open square is the best example ofManueline architectural style. Nearby is the Discoveries Monument built to commemorate the Prince Henry the Navigator. Do not miss it.

Highlight of our trip in Lisbon. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos was truly the highlight of our tour around Lisbon. We were toured around the place by relatives who were knowledgeable about the historical background of the monastery. There is also an area inside the monastery that serves as a museum. The church inside was not well lighted; the photos that we took did not come out well. What impressed me most was the intricate and attractive Manueline architecture of the monastery.  You can also buy mementos from the museum and the souvenir shop inside. We paid Euro 10 each to enter the Monastery. It was truly a memorable experience for us.

impressive monastery. this building is top class. full of history and with a special vibe. you will feel as if you are in a ancient time :) you won't miss this sight in Lisbon - it's absolutely great!
My favorite in Lisbon. Because it's history , art and beauty all combined . If you come to Lisbon you really can't miss it . and don't forget to eat a pastel de Belem near by
Amazing piece of architecture! Must visit!. Get inside and walk around the place in a sunny weather! It's really worth it. Quite a unique piece of architecture with an amazing internal yard!

Very big and impressive. A little on the dark side inside, but well worth the trip. Vasco da Gama is buried there as well as Geronimo. Our guide was very informative, explaining the carvings and that the "stained glass" windows are NOT stained glass, but rather painted glass. The original stained glass was destroyed in an earthquake.

Stunning place. Amazingly well preserved and quite stunning architecture. Although there is little in the way of exhibitions, just the ambience of the place is wonderful. Note: entrance is free with a Lisbon Card.
Well worth the visit. Yes - our thoughts concur with the other positive comments. Some good photography opportunities if you like architechtural photos.
Beautiful and worth every euro. A spectacular edifice with wonderful intricacies and detail. Take some time to wander through the entire building. It is certainly worth the entry price.

Impressive!. Easily my favorite site in Belem. The monastery is magnificent with intricate stone carving throughout. There is lot of signage throughout the site, so come prepared to learn. The grounds are well kept, clean, and super peaceful. Enjoy!

Major Highlight of Lisbon Vacation. It's impossible to miss the Mosteiro once you're in Belem - the building is huge and ornate. Take time to examine and touch the outside before entering the grounds. Guided tours are available, but strolling the grounds is easy. Special exhibits are available, including one showing the timeline of the monastery's history as compared with major events around the world. Although the structure is large and imposing from the outside, tourists are limited to just part of the area. Note: for dining, the visitor will find a number of small restaurants on the main avenue. Some are very crowded, so look for the smaller 'homier' spots.

Magnificent building. Okay so it's been trashed by the British, ravaged by earthquake and rebuilt, touched up more times than it cares to remember, but such a magnificent building, with really ornate stone carvings everywhere you look. Is the kind of restful and peaceful place you would expect to find monks wandering around, even with the large footfall of visitors very calming.Recommended for a hot day as inside is cool, and a cold day when there are many detailed exhibits inside the building, I would rate this as my number one stop in lisbon, informative for a first timer. Easy access from most tram/bus routes,The church itself houses the remains of Vasco de Gamma and other Heros of Portuguese history.

Beautiful building. Great place to visit. Lots of history to the area. Fabulous grounds.Would certainly recommend this for a visit.Clean, tidy location. Guided tours available. Fantatic building for taking picture of and its surroundings.

Beautiful and interesting. A beautiful place to visit. The construction is amazing considering the age of the building. A lot of history. You can lose yourself looking at the walls and ceilings. The upper choir and the main chapel are both beautiful.

A beautiful monastery and museum. You should definitely visit it. It is free if you have the Lisboa Card and you do not have to wait in line to get in. It is a truly amazing building. If your in Lisbon it should be on the top to visit list! It houses a museum, that shows the Roman history of Portugal, an exibition about Egypt and so on.

Stunning!. We visited Lisbon in January and this was one of the most beautiful places I have visited. Few tourists inside made it possible to really soak up the ambiance. Unfortunately, we were part of a guided tour group and could only stay for 15 minutes but it was well worth every moment. Don't know what the entrance fee is as it was included in the tour cost. A must see if you are passing through Lisbon.

No.1 attraction when in Lisboa. One of the most amazing buildings I have ever visited. Soo mamazing atmosphere inside. we visited in Januare 2013, only few tourist inside. So really amazing visit. We bought combo ticket (10EUR) for both Monasterio and Belem Tower. Evtrance to main chappel is free (also amazing building) with Vasco de Gamma tomb BUT I really advice to get inside monastery.

It's almost impossible to get inside. Situated next to the Tower of Belem the Monastery’s building is beautiful, impressive and very well preserved. The area around it is a beautiful garden with some statues.Why to go:. The monastery is an architectural and historical landmark.Why not go:. The queues are huge and it is only allowed to enter every few.. The church gets too full and it is impossible to appreciate the interior of the chapel.. To enter it is necessary to be at least 30 minutes standing in the sun on the outside.. No photography allowed.. Those working in the entrance are very rude.. The parking area is very small.. There's no subway to get there.

a little pricey. it costs 7 euros for a adult to enter but the small church to the side is free. i was not going to in but i got a senior discount to 3.50 euros which the tour much more afforable. really not alot to see except the inside of the court but very well built and kept in good condition i would say not worth 7 but a good deal at half off i went at 1300 and it was alittle crowded to get in but not so once you get inside maybe early morning would be better

Great achitecture. The monastery is in Belem area. It has an impressive design, I was really glad to see it. For me doesnt worth to pay the entrance, because the only spectacular thing inside was the court. It has lts of details, like the front of the building but the style a little different. Perhaps worth more the entrance for those who loves history. For me this building is the most beautiful in Lisbon.

Well worth visiting - takes more time than you think!. This is an absolute must to go an visit and gives free entry with your Lisboa Card. Of course the building is amazing, but oddly we really enjoyed the historic time-line which contrasted World events, the monastery and Portugal together in one big long display.

A World Heritage site worth visiting.. This glorious monastery situated in one of Lisbon’s most noble areas faces the River Tagus and is a World Heritage site (classified by UNESCO) and definitely a “must-see” on a visit to Lisbon. Some 500 hundred years ago, the monastery was the site of a modest chapel where the seafarers came to pray. *Guided visits are available.

Cost too much money for me, but the church was pretty. This is another traveler favorite I thought was too much and decided to forego. There was, though, a church to the right of the line for tickets that was free to go into, and I thought it was cool. It was a unique style I hadn't seen before, pretty simple, or at least lacking a lot of gold and sparkle. I thought the best part of the church was the ceiling and the columns. Stone, with beautiful designs, I thought their simplicity made the church a nice stop-in on our way around Belém.

Exquisite. Not to be missed.An architectural gem, built of stone, richly decorated with carved elements that you could spend hours just looking at them. The church, not big but definitely grand, shelters the remains of prominent figures of Portuguese history and culture like king D. Manuel I, Vasco da Gama and Luis de Camões.If you intend to visit Torre de Belém as well (and you should), buy a joint ticket (Mosteiro dos Jerónimos + Torre de Belém) and benefit from a discount.

Definitely worth a visit. Beautiful doesn't quite describe it. It's charming, elegant and intricate. I went on a Sunday, when admission is free until 2pm. I went in close to 2 (visited the Tower first as that took less time), and seems like most tours have departed at that time. While I can't say I had the place to myself, I was able to enjoy the tranquility that befits the location, and to snap some good pictures of the architecture. Don't skip it. If I ever go to Lisbon again, I most certainly will be back.

“Marvellous architecture and unique art. Monastery of Jeronimos is Historic Sites, Religious Sites, Landmarks/ Points of Interest, Architectural Buildings. is located at Rua dos Jerónimos, 3, in Belem. It is the most important monument in Lisbon and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The building construction started in 1502 under the orders of King Dom Manuel. his is an incredible monastery and one of the most beautiful places I saw in Portugal. It is also one of the most prominent monuments. . The admission fee for the monastery is 7 euros, but I recommend you. A beautiful monastery that sorts of tells the story of Portugal, as it was built near the point where sailors and explorers left or came back to Lisbon by sea - the monks' job was to comfort sailors and pray for the king's soul! You can either visit it quite quickly or spend hours there admiring the very intricate designs. This church was the main highlight of our Dianatours morning tour of Lisbon. The Monastery of San Jeronimo was really a magnificent.This museum not far from the Belm tower..

Marvellous architecture!. This is an incredible monastery and one of the most beautiful places we saw in Portugal. It is also one of the most prominent monuments of the Manueline-style architecture that is why was listed by UNESO as a World Heritage Site, along with the nearby Belem Tower. The admission fee for the monastery is 7 euros, but I recommend you purchasing of the combined ticket of 10 euros for visiting both Jeronimos Monastery and Belem Tower. If you prefer, you can opt for a ticket of 13 euros which allows admission to Jeronimos Monastery, Belem Tower and Ajuda National Palace. You may expect a bit of crowds which to my opinion is pretty common for famous and popular attractions like Jeronimos Monastery. There was a line-up when we went there formed of people buying admission tickets. But because we had the combined tickets (purchased from Belem Tower where there was no line-ups), we skipped the line at the Monastery. So a combined ticked is worth it: you save time and money.

Beautiful and intricate architecture. A beautiful monastery that sorts of tells the story of Portugal, as it was built near the point where sailors and explorers left or came back to Lisbon by sea - the monks' job was to comfort sailors and pray for the king's soul! You can either visit it quite quickly or spend hours there admiring the very intricate designs carved on the columns, walls and ceilings.

Magnificent Manueline Architectural Style. This church was the main highlight of our Dianatours morning tour of Lisbon. The Monastery of San Jeronimo was really a magnificent monument to the Manueline style of architecture. The stories of our guide made the relics we saw come to life, rather than if we just walked in by ourselves. The tomb of famed Portuguese explorer Vasco de Gama and a noted Portuguese poet Luis de Camoes were also there. There were just too many tourists there, even on the rainy day when we toured, to make this visit as solemn as I would have liked it.

Possibly the most beautiful monastery in Portugal. Another place well worth visiting. For those people staying in Lisbon, head for Praca da Figueira and take the number 15 tram or number 714 bus to the monastery at Belem (about a 30 minute journey). Go there early in the morning, before the crowds. The monastery opens to visitors at 10.00am. Spend time around the cloisters upper and lower levels, especially when the sun kisses the light coloured stone to reflect beautiful shadows over each walk way. The church is very beautiful, we stayed for sung Mass , enjoying the service, choir and organ music. this was perhaps the highlight of our tour.Next venture into the archaeological museum next door, a wealth of interesting and beautiful artefacts. By this time we felt we had seen enough for the time being and the crowds were building up too.

Outstanding!. Belem itself is really cute, with its parks, gardens and lovely restaurants.The Monastery has this wonderful architecture that impresses at the very first sight. Its interior is a trip through history. The beautiful tile-decorated walls are just breathtaking.

Wonderful attraction, but too crowded. Mosteiro Dos Jerónimos is a part of every sightseeing tour in Lisbon. It is rightly so.The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is the architectural representatives of a period in which the Portugal had a leading role in expanding the horizons of both Europe and the world. It was situated symbolically in Belem (Betlehem), which, in the 16th century, was the site of the port from which the caravelas and other large ships set sail on the great discovery voyagesThe monastery was commissioned by D. Manuel I. The magnificence of the building reflects the universalist vision of its founder and the powerful financial resources that the Portuguese crown then enjoyed.To see such a magnificent building you need time and space, and most tours do not provide you with any of that. The place was so crowded that you couldn't see anything properly, let alone feel the age and appreciate the beauty of the cloister. I advise you to go there by yourself and to choose the time of the day carefully. Belem, unfortunately, is not connected with the city by Metro, but take a taxi (not expensive) and enjoy the Belem monuments without the tourist crush.

A visitar. The monastery jerónimos is a fine example of Manueline. catederal monastery and together in a prime area on the outskirts of Lisbon. To visit those interested in art and Christian culture. Highlight the tombs of Vasco da Gama and Luiz de Camões.

Possibly the most interesting church in Lisbon?. A very interesting visit to the Belem district - about 20 mins ride from the centre of Lisbon - this monastery is very impressive with its intricate and beautiful facade, and amazing tombs of some of the most famous Portuguese such as Vasco de Gama.In addition there are nearby further sites to see such as the Torre de Belem, not to mention the absolutely fabulous custard tarts at the Casa Pasteis de Belem.A great half-day visit, most enjoyable.

Breathtaking - Portugal at its most glorious!. There are monasteries and there is the Monastery of Jeronimos which is in a class of its own. Superb architecture. It is a journey back in history - you even get to see the sophisticatedly carved Vasco de Gama's tomb! I recommend visiting this superb place towards 5 pm so that you can benefit from the right end of the afternoon light effects for your pictures, you will get a combination of shades and sunshine that will give an even more mystical atmosphere to your visit and this will be reflected in the shots you take!

Unbelievably BEAUTIFUL!. The detail that went into building this monastery is FANTASTIC! The ticket price is a little much with the site not being that large. It is certainly worth the visit if you are a shutterbug and are into architecture!!!! If you're on a budget and don't want to shell out the funds to enter then I suggest you visit the Santa Maria church right before you enter into the Monastery. It is free!

Elegance in architecture. One of the most beautiful monasteries that I have ever visited. Well worth the entrance fee. Its architectural style is full of intricate and elegant designs carved in perfect detail. The cathedral at the entrance houses Vasco da Gama's tomb.Situated at the far end is the Maritime Museum,which requires a separate entrance fee. I came back another afternoon to visit that and the Bernado Museum of Art.

A must see in Lisbon. This would be one of the most impressive Christian sanctuaries I've been in. A sense of connectedness with the spiritual world was, for me, inescapable here. The cathedral within is on its own one of the best you can see, the detail on pillars and the roof compare favourably with , for example, Milan's Duomo. Maybe because it is not quite so flooded with tourists, there is more of a sense of peace and tranquility, in the cathedral, in the monastery proper, and in the gardens. If coming out to Belem, this is generally on a list with the Tower of Belem and the Monument to Exploration nearby, but they can be quick visits. spend a bit more time in Jeronimos. If you have a Lisboa Card, entry is free, so you can take in the museum as well.

Feel teleported in time.... Awesome structure, remarkable architectural detail. The monastery is a great attraction to visit. If you are into architecture it's a no brainer. The Classic Manueline style transports you out of the present day into the 1400's.

Not worth the entrance price. Luckily we bought a combi ticket for this and the tower of Belem, otherwise it would have been a waste of money.The combi ticket was 10 euros, a single ticket for Mosteiro dos Jeronimos was 7 euros. It is a huge building and I was really looking forward to visiting it but apparently you can only visit a sort of patio outside with your entrance ticket. You have to buy another ticket to visit the rest of the building. The church outside is free to visit and that one is worthwile, really a beautiful church.
Amazing. One of the most important monuments in Lisbon and an element of UNESCO's World Heritage List! It's only a shame that we can't see all the parts of the building.

The most beautiful must-see in Lisbon. If you are in Lisbon, you have to take the train to Belem and visit this Monastery. The architecture is absolutely beautiful and the church is one of the most beautiful I've seen (and I've seen a lot). Do take your sunglasses, if the sun shines the whiteness of the monastery can blind you!

The jewel of Lisbon. One of the most amazing and impressive monuments in Lisbon. Located near the Tejo river and along green lawns, the mosteiro is an emblematic place to visit.
The architecture is typical Manueline and was built in the XVI century and now part of the UNESCO.

a gem for Manueline Architecture. Well deserves being the #1 attraction in Belém, even possibly also the #1 for Lisbon. Definitely a must-see, no Lisbon trip will be complete without a visit to Mosteiro dos Jerónimos. Once you reach Belém with Tram no.15 (first station is Praça do Comércio and you will leave the tram at Belém, simply follow the crowd) combine your trip with Torre de Belém, Padrão dos Descobrimentos (Monument to the Discoveries) and Museu dos Coches (Coaches Museum). If you have a tight budget, from 10:00 am till 14:00 all the monuments are free on sundays. These four must-see attractions are really close and can be easily discoved on foot. One more practical budget advice is to buy a day ticket just for 5€ (5.5€ if you do not have a card) from one of the metro stations which is valid for 24h after the first usage, the trams are even more expensive if you pay inside (2.85€ just for one way).

Just awesome. Really impressive architecture. There are a lot of people visiting so make sure you allot adequate time. Some spots require entrance fees, others do not. There are several restaurants near as well. Accessible via tram or bus.

Love this place. Beautiful place but recommend to get there early to avoid long lines to buy tickets and crowds inside. If you go by yourself try to engage with the guided tour, the student guides are really nice and will explain interesting facts in about an hour and then you can stay as long as you wish to admire the lovely cloisters.

Gothic lace in heavens above.... Should you have any doubt whether going or not going to visit this impressive, most beautiful church, just go with an "electrico" tramway, it takes maybe twenty minutes from the praça do Comercio.You will enter this sand color church, and one step inside the doors you will see in the highest above some million interlaced huge lace triangles sculpted into the stone, you will feel that you've never seen before such beautiful, serene, attractive gothic pillars. It was a great emotion, I kept on thinking for days about who could have been so artistically gifted to build up such 3D intricate wonders for such huge surface.And all around the church, many notable people's tombs. It was really beautiful.
Wow. The yellow bus will take you there.I spent about an hour contemplating the beauty of this place.It's just wonderful.Loved every minute of it !

Beautiful cloisters and few tourists = very relaxing!. I'm not sure how we got so lucky, but when my husband and I visited Lisbon we encountered very few tourists at any of the sites - which made them all the more enjoyable, and our favorite stop (or t least mine!) was the Monastery of Jeronimos. The cloister is so beautiful, with so much ornate carving to take in, and I spent at least half an hour walking around admiring it all. There were a few interesting exhibits off the cloister that you could enjoy, and the central church area was pretty as well. Also don't miss the elaborate carvings on the exterior of the building near one entrance - a real treat!

Fantastic. Gorgeous building, so full of beauty and history. Wonderful building inside and out. Good views of it from across the gardens and fountains in front of it. A MUST for anybody visiting Lisbon.

Great light in afternoon. A great place for the photographers if you have a blue sky with only some white clouds... and a light yellow or better saying a light brown, very light brown for the stone of the buiding... Great! The Church it is also very special. And of course the Timetable from the Ancient Library where you can see in a huge spiral the Hystory of the World, also the Hystory of the Portugal and the Hystory of the Convent... Very professional idea.Not very far from Down Town / Praca do Comercio / tram (electrico) 15e or bus 714...Enjoy it!

Beautiful cloisters and impressive history. The Jeronimos Monastery should be listed under Lisbon, as Belem is an area in Lisbon, not a separate city. Visited on a Sunday morning. During mass, they let a limited number of people in the back of the church, where you can see some of the famous tombs and the beauty of the church, but not all of the church. The cloisters and exhibit on the history of the monastery are the highlights. We stood in line for 15 minutes to go in the church and equally long for the cloisters. When we left at 11:30 AM, there were VERY long lines, maybe due to free admission on Sundays or limited access due to services. The architecture is quite unique and fun to photograph the gargolyes and interesting shapes. The timelines showing what was happening at the monastery, in Portugal, and around the world was brilliant!

Impressive cloister & tombs of the famous!. The Jeronimos Monastery (Mosteiros dos Jeronimos) is located at the area of Lisbon called Belem & is a huge complex built between 1501 & 1600 to celebrate the voyages of Vasco da Gama. His tomb & that of his patron King Manuel I, other Portuguese royals & some famous poets are all here. It is perhaps the best example of the Manueline architecture of Portugal. The church has a soaring ceiling & is very atmospheric but it is the cloister which is the real star attraction. It is one of the largest & most beautiful that I have seen in all my travels throughout Europe & I've visited a great many. First of all, it is a 2 level one with sculpted pillars & arches at both levels covered in the Manueline style. It is fascinating to see all the different motifs carved into the stone as well as the gargoyles.This is definitely worth a visit.

The Cloisters of the Monastery is worth a visit. The cathedral next to the Monastery of Jeronimos is beautiful but the monastery with its Cloisters is more spectacular, inside and out. The outer structure reminds one of the House of Parliament in Budapest in design, but is not as large. The inner courtyard is immense with columns surrounding the space. A great, peaceful place to spend an hour or two.
Fascinating. The inner court yard and the church are a place to relax and let the world get on without you. The tomb of Vasco de Gama was impressive!
Monastry/Church. It really is a marvelous sight. The workmanship of the structure of the building is quite spectacular. a must visit.
15th Century monument. Words what for? If it has crowds of thousands all along the year, sometimes, in winter time, when it's more quiete, I go inside to pray in silence. Breathtaking, absolutely

stunning building!. this is a really beautiful and breath-taking building and is definitely a must-see in lisbon. tram 15 goes to belem as does 28 from cais do sodre. we went to belem early in the morning before everything was open - but were rewarded by discovering the pasteis de belem which were delicious! there was a queue developing when we returned to the monastery and a rude tour group which just traipsed past us when the doors open. the cloister is beautiful and is worth a linger. there are two storeys and from the top, there is a view down into the church. there is a separate entrance into the church itself which is near the entrance to the cloister on the ground floor. weather was rather bad when we visited, so it was nice to spend sometime in a beautiful building which also acted as shelter for us! absolutely amazing place, MUST VISIT!!!!

Take the 15E tram from Lisbon to Belém to see this monastery. We went on a Sunday morning and the church was occupied at times with service, so we spent our time in the cloister, which is a beautiful building (I think the cloister has an admission fee, but it was free on Sunday).
Another must see place in Lisbon. Well preserved,serene and awe inspiring. Try and visit thru the week, very busy on weekends
love it. the style of this monastery is typical portugese a blend between ghotic and arabic and well executed
It's intricate and big, but overall just ok. Ok inside, not spectacular in any way, the outside is more intricate and beautiful. The courtyard is nice and worth a visit.

Fabulous must see in Belem shame about the front desk. The courtyard and cathedral at this fantastic monument are a real must-see if in Lisbon. Take tram 15 from the Praca de Comercial or Rue de Figueria about a 25 min journey. Free access with the lisboa card. 1-2 hour visit depending on how long you linger. What a shame about the shockingly poor and grumpy guy on the front desk. Whoever is running the place needs to invest in customer service training... Would have scored a 5 if it wasn't for this individual.

Amazing! A must visit in Lisbon.. "Mosteiro dos Jeronimos" was the highlight our our visit to Lisbon. The architecture and the wall carving were truly amazing. Worth spending a good hour or two to just walk around the building looking at the work. The chapel is beautiful as well. The "Monument of Discoveries" across the road is nice and so is the Belem Tower. A must visit location in Lisbon.

Tranquil and Beautiful. This UNESCO World Heritage site is a must see in Belem! Within the walls, the breath-taking Manueline ornate architectural design with wide arches, beautiful staircases and open inspirational spaces encourage a silent, contemplating meditation. Make sure to have time to stroll slowly around this historical site.Beautiful, wide sidewalks, other historical sites and nice park all in the same area. The surrounding area lends itself to a day of sightseeing. Easy train, bus and bus tour transportation.

The perfect symbol of Portugal Manueline style put in practice. You will be impressed by the beauty of this picturesque architectural Lisbon symbol! Not only the outside but the inner garden architecture is what mostly made me make a long and joyful tour through the monastery corridors. It is a good example of the Manueline style, so uncharacteristic for Lisbon, especially found in the part of the city named Belem... The photos are allowed to be taken only in the garden, not in the rooms where there is an exposition of different items related to Portuguese royalties.

Beautiful Monastery. We took the #15 tram to Belem from Praca de Figueria. If you have a Lisboa card your transportation is free. The monastery is free but the cloisters have an admission fee. I think the cloisters is included in the Lisboa card or it is greatly reduced but going to the cloisters is a must see. The church interior is exquisite with Manueline style design. The church was built in the early 1500's to honor Portugal's discoverers. Vasco de Gama is buried here. His tomb is elaborate with designs of ships and rope knots. The cloisters is spectacular with the Manueline arches and from the balcony you have a great view of the church below.

MAGNIFICENT. This is one of the most beautiful buildings I have seen. In my opinion, it is definitely the highlight when you visit Lisbon. It is built in the Manueline-style architecture, and it was classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1983.This monastery was built in the 16th century and it lasted 100 years. The King Manuel I chose the Hieronymite (Jeronimos) order to occupy the monastery since this order’s mission was to pray for the King’s eternal soul and to provide spiritual assistance to sailors and navigators.It costs 7 euros to visit the monastery and the church’s chorus and they are totally worth it. Even with great number of visitors, the interior has a peaceful air, and either its beauty or the spiritual energy invites to meditation and silence. I have been there twice and both times I had the same feelings.

Impressive. You take the 15E tramway if you are lucky you will have an old one. Belem is a pretty wide area from the Jeronimos monastery up to the Belem tower.Choose a dual entrance monastery + Belem tower entrance.Monastery is an example of architecture and if you are here at noon you can have the central garden for you only and enjoy.The Coche museum is located 10 mn east from the monastery but his not so interesting to visit.
A beautiful monument. Located in one of the amazing areas of Lisbon, the details in the architecture of this building its worth it...
Symbol. It's a symbol of Lisbon and an example the Manuelino architecture.
splendid. A very young church compared to the french or english ones from the middle age but beautiful and with a splendid court-yard
Landmark of Portuguese History. Impressive monument. you breath history when your enter here!

Amazing. We loved this place. The price is a bit high (7 euros) for a such small place, but seriously, it's amazing, all the scultural works are impressive (the manuelian style). The outside is as beautiful as the monastry inside. Don't miss it if you like stone carving & romantic places!

A beautiful peaceful place. Go early in the morning so you can enjoy the peace and quiet of the wonderful cloisters that surround a huge courtyard featuring a fountain in the centre. You can almost imagine the monks walking here without any distractions of the outside world. Combine this with a visit to the church next door and see where Vasco de Gama is buried.

Impressive. Impressive as a monument decorated with elaborate stone carvings and an important part of Lisbon's history it seems. Entry is free until 2pm on Sundays and there is also an antiques market until late afternoon on the park outside. Don't forget to stop to taste the Pasteis de Belem in the shop nearby.

Really worth the visit. I went to Belem not knowing exactly what to expect other than it was recommended to go see the monastery.I went on a Sunday where entrance is free (nice!), and the weather was really nice - and wow, Mosteiro dos Jerónimos is a unique place to be when the sun is shining.There are different exhibitions, but to be honest, I was not in the mood to see them, I just enjoyed walking around in the yard and on the first floor, outside of course.The place is well kept and really nice for a Sunday visit.Afterwards, I would recommend that you go on the other side of the street to enjoy the park, and the Tejo river is just nearby - and should you get hungry, then there are in fact small restaurants which make delicious sandwiches, otherwise there are also the pasteis of Belém, a local speciality :-)
Incredible. The Biggest and most incredible monastery in Lisbon, absolutely beautiful.
Well worth a visit. Huge and imposing the Monastery is a must see in Belem. Plan on a 2 hour visit and enjoy yourself.
Must see. You must see this place. It's in fact one of the most important buildings in Portugal. Don't miss the cloisters.

Sublime. We had previously visited the church adjacent to the monastery to view the tomb of Vasco De Gama and came back the next day to tour the monastery. It was well worth the re-visit. A beautiful building, not damaged by the earthquake of 1755, to take your breath away with its majesty and tranquility.

It's wonderful. I visited the Monastery and cloister in the early part of December. The building was magnificently decorated with detailed stone works out side. The church is free to enter. It houses many noble and famous peoples tombs including Vasco de Gama. Inside, the beautiful stone works and stained glass were mystical. There is a room which houses master piece paintings. There was a 1 euro entry fee but when I was there, the collections of arts were admired and studied by many art students. I was not planning to visit cloister but, I am glad that I did (7 euros). Arches all around and each are curved and so detailed. The sculptures on the second floor have some damages to them but, look very carefully, there are different animals and creatures(pig, glass hopper etc). You can access the second floor of the church from the cloister and look straight to alter. You can get the grand view of the church from there. The monastery is very beautiful and wonderfully made. It is also a great architectures which survived the great earthquake.

Visit of the monastery of Jeronimos. Very nice place . The architecture is amazing and it is dated back to the beginning of 16th century. There are also the tombs of Vasco da Gama (Important portuguese navigator) and Luiz Vaz de Camões (the most important portuguese poet) amongst others inside the monastery.

What is most beautiful Manueline architecture in Lisbon. What is most beautiful Manueline architecture in Lisbon. A must visit! The cloister is really beautiful. After the view is well worth experiencing the fantastic Belém's pastel (in a traditional bakery, very close).

Stunning Cloister and great atmosphere!. Wow what a venue, clearly the best thing to do in Belem and a must if you are visiting this area of Lisbon! It cost 7 Euros for each adult to enter the cloister and the museum area. The actual Church is free, but you simply must visit the Cloister! I've seen many cathedrals and cloisters in many different countries, and this has to be the most dramatic and stunning! Being on two levels and being so incredibly ornate just adds to the romantic atmosphere. It was raining when we visited and the animal gargoyles which are dotted all over spat out the rainwater from their ever open mouths!!! The various museums detailing both the history of the monastery and of Lisbon are well worth 30 minutes! Do take your time wondering around the cloister, it is a place you need to simply sit back and marvel at what man is capable of creating! The gallery looking out over the church is a must, just lovely views...

Well preserved if a little crowded. We fortified ourselves in the cafe which sells the original secret recipe custard tarts, then set off for the monastery. It was hard to dodge the coach parties, so I dread to think what it would have been like in high season.However, it was a very interesting visit, and in the church we found the tomb of Vasco da Gama plus the Portuguese poet Camoys. Beautiful light falling on statues (the tradition is to dress them in beautifully embroidered robes rather than just carvings of the clothes). Apparently the stained glass windows were destroyed long ago, but this just means shafts of sunlight on the beautiful artefacts.

Must see area. If you are visiting Lisbon I would say the Belem area, especially the monestary, is an absolutely MUST see area. Its just stunning. The waterfront area is lovely for a walk with cooling sea breeze.

Mind blowing - the highlight of my trip. The architecture and construction of this place are amazing. It's hard to believe how people could have created arches and roofs on that scale hundreds of years ago. Easily reached from town on the bus.We also went to the monument to the Discoverers, which was closing the next day for extended renovations (did they say a year or did I imagine that?), and to the fort. I recommend both highly. Overall this makes a good half day plus trip.

Gorgeous Church. We went to Belem the first afternoon after arriving from the US (so we were a bit tired but it was still great). The Monastery was the highlight of Lisbon in general and definitely the best of Belem. It is so old, yet incredibly ornate. We are Catholic, but it would be a place of interest for anyone. The inside architecture is incredible that is was built so long ago. We just went in the church which was free, it looked like there was another section that was more like a museum that was a couple euros.
Must include in your trip. Excellent gothic architecture inside and much to see spend time both inside and outside and surrounding areas.
Amazing buildings. Amazing buildings and rich historical traditions. Well worth a visit

Awesome!. I visited this attraction during this summer. I expected the place to be very dull & gloomy being a Monastery, but it was the complete opposite! You could actually see that a lot of work had gone into the construction of the building! The Architectural design is one of the best I have ever seen. It is very beautiful & well maintained considering it was built years ago. I also had the opportunity of seeing the Exhibition of Alexandre Herculano, a very popular Portuguese Novelist & Historian, including his Tomb. This is one attraction that you must not miss should you visit Lisbon.
Spectacular place to visit. The hole place is impressive. It's an architectural show, a spiritual and cultural experience. You should definitely visit it when in Lisbon

an absolutely fantastic building. we ignored the queues and walked around the building across the gardens to the huge statue commemorating portugals maritime history what a wonderful place.there is a great view of both the rio statue and the cantilever bridge from here.we bought 3.95 euro tickets which give you 24 hrs.on public transport including the metro lisbons transport is as good as any we have used.we used it on buses trams and metro.got off when we wanted and if we didn,t like it moved on via the next bus/tram/metro to come along
True beauty. Words cannot describe the beauty of this Monastery. You need to see it for yourself. Its unbelievable.

Nice, but not worth the extremely long wait. When we first went to Belém on a sunday, we were horrified by the extremely large queue during the hottest hours of the day and we decided we would come back at a more suitable time.We thought that a wednesday morning would be less busy, but unfortunately, the queue was as big as it was on sundays. Also, there was no shelter from the scorching sun, and we were in this queue for over 90 minutes.The monastery itself is nice, but fairly small, and I don't think I would have waited that long if I had known what it looks like. If you like Manueline architecture you should really visit this building, but if you don't, don't bother.The Monastery is like the Eiffel Tower, the Colloseum, or the Statue of Liberty. It's an attraction that you're "supposed to" visit when you're in Lisbon. I do agree it is a very special building, but I don't think it's worth waiting this long.Maybe the queue is smaller outside of tourist seasons. If that's the case (which I don't know), you should definitely visit this.

History. Lots of history in the area. This is the place where Vasco da Gama left on journeyto india. Museu dos coches, Centr Belen and thr tower are aslo in the surrondings.Don´t forget to eat a pastel de Belen.

Monastery of Jeronimos - A tribute to Portugal's Age of Discovery. The Hieronymites (Jeronimos) Monastery (in Belem, greater Lisbon), for the Order of St. Jerome, is an incredibly beautiful construction (1501 to 1601) at the site of where a previous chapel existed (late 1400s) and where pilgrims, navigators and sailors stopped to rest and receive spiritual guidance on their way of expeditions in search of new worlds. The architecture style, very ornate, was later know as manueline (after Portugal’s king Manuel I, who funded the project). The Monastery served at times as burial site for Portuguese royal members as well as other important historical figures such as Vasco da Gama, navigator and Luis Vaz de Camoes, epic poet. The Monastery is a tribute of the age of discovery and ingenuity of the Portuguese people; a must visit attraction and a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

leisurely Sunday combinação. Belem is an area just a short bus ride from central Lisbon, that is easily walkable to combine the Monastery, Tower, the Discoverer's Monument, and eating pastis. On Sundays, the Monastery is free to all up to 2pm, and you might chance on a wedding party or a community festival in the nearby park (Jardim do Ultramar)

How to skip the long queue for tickets. You may see a long queue for ticket at this venue. Here is a tip we learned from watching what other tourists did when we were in Belem.1. Go to the Tor de Belem as the first thing in Belem. Buy a double ticke for both Tor de Belem and the Monastary.2. When you have finished your visit at Tor de Belem walk back to the monastary. 3. Walk up where the exit it from the Monastary and show your ticket to the guard. He/she will scan the bar code and you are in!You can also do it if you go to the monastary first but the queue for tickets at the Tor de Belem is much less than at the monastary. We saved around 30-45 minutes queue this way.....and we learned it from watching other tourists skip the line at Tor de Belem.Both places are definately worth a visit.

Disappointing. Monastery of St Jerome is a very nice and well-preserved building. When you visit the church you can’t disturb the praying people, so you have to wait for the Mass to be finished. But that’s the only thing I like about this place. You cannot wander inside the church, you have to follow the path with the crowd. I gave up on watching one of the famous gravestones, because it was surrounded by a horde of people. After seeing all others things I wanted to come back to it and I wasn’t allowed (although no-one stood there at that time). When I found myself at the door I was asked to leave, which was ridiculous, as my friends were still inside. Then I went to see the monastery. I liked the carved walls. The whole monastery looks sweet and beautiful, but that’s all. No mystery, no added value, just carvings. Oh, and there was also this exhibition presenting the history of the place, of Portugal and the whole world. Good idea, but the contents – very… ‘controversial’. After this visit I was only angry and disappointed. It’s much better to omit the Monastery of St Jerome and visit a nearby antiques fair instead – you can find there almost everything – old books, jewelry, tiles and many other things.

Nice but not captivating. Inscribed on the World Heritage Site list, Hieronymites Monastery is considered to be one of the highlights of Lisbon, as the perfectly representative example of Manueline style. It's definitely magnificent monastery with many interesting sites like the tombs of Vasco da Gama and Luís de Camoes, but my reception of the monument was disturbed by the tourist crowd what caused a little disappointment. As a result I recommend to visit this place as a sedond/third choice after Alfama, Bairro Alto and other central districts of Lisbon.It's not well-known that in 2007 the Treaty of Lisbon which laid the foundations of reforms in European Union was signed at this place.

Best site in Lisbon. Beautiful, historic bldg in a great area of town with many other attractions. Take Tram 15 to get there (towards Belem). Go to the Navy Museum...Museo de la Marinha..within the Monasterio. Very interesting considering Portugal's contribution to navigation. I'd recommend getting the Lisbon card...by the time you add up the costs...transport, the monastery, and other attractions in the area, it is worth it to get the 24 hour Lisbon Card 17 euros,...or the 48 hour one even, 27 euros. Includes all public transport, very convenient.

Don't miss it!. Mosteiro dos Jerónimos, as it's called in Portuguese, is one incredible building. All the walls are very detailed, both in and outside. Inside, you'll find the tombs of Vasco da Gama (who discovered the maritime route to India), Luís de Camões (Great Portuguese writer) and D.Manuel (king of Portugal at the time). After your visit, don't forget to stop by the Pasteis de Belem, and take some pasteis with you.
Beautiful Cloisters. This was our 1st stop in Lisbon & it was a great way to start out our time in the city. We used our LisbonCard to get in for free & the cloisters make it worth the stop.

Be careful if you need the loo! This.... Be careful if you need the loo!This was a great site and very interesting, however if you need the loo you might want to think again. The queue in the ladies is long and the cubicle doors are almost transparent. You get a pretty good view of the actions of the person ahead of you as they disrobe and do their business. Very bizarre!!

Beautiful. I have been to the most important historical sites in Europe (specifically my coountry Italy + France and Spain) and... this is one of the most beautiful churches and monasteries I've ever seen, both outside and inside !It is very nice also because it's made with "clean" stone, very different from other churches in Portugal that are very nice but along the centuries they took a yellow/orange color which somehow spoils them.

Postcard Perfect. The year was 1999, and this was towards New Year's eve. The initial reason for going to Belem was to eat the most delicious egg tarts ever - Pasteis de Belem, or what we'd call Portugese egg tarts, especially for those who eat in HK or Macau. On the way, we couldn't miss going to Sr. Jerome and the tower at Belem. The architecture of the Church, the dramatic lighting of the monuments, the perfect symmetry of the gardens, the parks, and the monument to Portugese Navigators were all awesome sites to behold. This was at a time when Portugal was not like the tourist mecca that it is now. We are so lucky to have been there.

Beautiful but Beware of Sundays. This was a beautiful place to visit with amazing architecture. We visited on a Sunday and it was waaaaay too crowded! I lost my travelling buddy a few times in the crowd. The main sanctuary is also closed off during mass.

Outside more impressive than the inside.... When we first got to the Monastery, we were amazed at how big and beautiful it looked on the outside. We went into the free cathedral part and it was quite nice too, but then we paid to go into the rest of the monastery and wished we hadn't! We were there in March, and the only thing we saw when we went into the paid part was a large courtyard and a few empty rooms. There was an exhibit in one room about the history of the monastery and it's development, but it was a lot of reading to go through and by the time i was halfway through, I was tired of standing and reading. If you're going to viis the monastery, I would just go around the exterior and spend some time in the free church. Oh, and make sure to grab some Portugese tarts at Pasteis de Belem nearby, those really made the visit to Belem worth it!

Monastery: Lisbon style. St. Jerome is a wonderful example of unique Portuguese architecture. The seafaring history of the Portuguese is evident as soon as you take your first step into the cathedral. The monastery grounds are beautifully maintained, which is no small feat given the site of the site. And Vasco de Gama is there!
Free visit to Church!. Beautiful architecture and church design. A very solemn place.

Very pretty and fascinating. This is free for students and very interesting considering it was made from funds brought my new world explorations. Upstairs there is a room about it's history and the exploreres that I recommend to take some time in. However, since this is a church and museum with only history to see I would not recommend this for small children.
Just beautiful. The monastery is beautiful! Don’t miss it. Just ashamed that the shop/café closes at lunch time!?!? This is at least peculiar…

Absolutely gorgeous. This monastery is a must-see in Lisbon. The architecture is absolutely stunning. Additionally, you'll see the tombs of Vasco de Gama and the poet Camoes, who lionized the explorer in a famous epic. The Monastery is in the vicinity of the coach museum, the maritime museum,an archeological museum, the tower of Belem and the Monument to the Discoveries, so there's lots to see and do.

Superb Jeronimos and super guide Miguel Silva. I visited the Jeronimos Monastery on 31 August 2006, and was delighted to be there as my last visit had been in 1964 as a schoolgirl. The Monastery was as beautiful as I had remembered it, especially the cloisters which are magnificent. I now have MS, and walk with two walking sticks/canes. Imagine my dismay when I went to buy a souvenir of my visit, to find that the shop was on an upper floor, accessed by a staircase which had no handrails. I could not get up there, as there was no lift. Then my "knight in shining armour" appeared. Miguel Silva is working as a guide at the Monastery as part of his degree course. His English is excellent, and he quickly understood my distress. He arranged to have a suitable book brought to me, and I was most impressed by his efficiency, his courtesy, and his sympathetic understanding of how frustrating an illness like MS can be when faced by insurmountable access difficulties. Put simply, his caring action saved the day! I wish Miguel every success for the future in his chosen career. He made my day, and I shall cherish the memory of it.

Stunning architecture. The Cloister and Church were beautiful. Wonderful architecture. But there is no information anywhere as you walk along. Then you come to one room with a large signboard with significant dates on it. You are josteling others for the ability to read it, but even still, it was a fractured history at best. Think about church being in service when you plan your visit. It is a shame that tourists do not understand that "silence" in the church means no talking allowed.
